Title: Minister releases handbook on road safety for teachers
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: As the first step towards integrating road safety lessons in the school curriculum, Kerala Road Safety Authority (KRSA), National Transportation Planning and Research Centre (NATPAC) and State Council of Educational Research and Training (SCERT) have jointly published a handbook on road safety for teachers .

‘Surakshithayatra’, published with an aim to inculcate the habit of following traffic rules among students from primary class, was released by transport minister A K Saseendran recently.

“The integration of road safety rules in school syllabus has been a long-term project and it is being implemented now. The handbook for teachers is just the beginning of this initiative, which is the first ever attempt in the country. Next, mapping will be conducted on how to include the lessons in the school textbooks, as the lessons has to be different for each standard based on their class level.

For example, road safety rules can be included in social science and first aid can be part of biology,” said Rajagopal K , director, communication and public relations, Kerala Road Safety Authority. “There have been enquiries from the Centre about the handbook and we are planning to translate it to English,” he added.

The 110-page book , which begins with a note to teachers, consists of details related to safety of motorists, passengers and pedestrians, traffic rules and first aid. The matter is explained with representative picture and there are questions and answers section and activities for teachers in the book.

Around two lakh copies of the book will be printed and distributed among school teachers across the state. The handbook will be part of vacation training classes for teachers to be held in the next academic year.

“The revision of school curriculum has started as per the directive from the Centre. Regarding the integration of road safety lessons in school textbooks, decision will have to be taken whether to include the lessons in textbooks or as a separate book for children to read,” said J Prasad, director, SCERT.

As part of the activity, road safety clubs will be formed in all government schools after school reopens in the next academic year. “Road safety lessons are likely to be introduced in the curriculum in 2021-22 academic year. Road safety is a matter to be dealt at the grassroot level and integrating it in the school syllabus is the apt way to reduce the number of accidents. There are notes and pamphlets on traffic rules, but it is the first time that a detailed book for school is published. It is proposed to start the training programme for teachers in schools located near national highway and state highway for the safety of students," said an official from SCERT.

Title: How to whine right!
Content: Since our culture sees complaining as a bad habit, we have learned to be silent over the years, even when there is a reason to speak out…That’s about to change. According to a research by Robin Kowalski, professor of psychology, at Clemson University (US), complaining can be a useful tool in bonding. It even helps us process emotions like stress and frustration. The study further states that complaining, in moderation, can be used as an ice-breaker, to convey information about oneself so that others can form a particular impression of you. However, what’s essential here is to pick the right audience. Find someone you feel comfortable confiding in and make sure they support your purpose. Here are four ways of complaining the right way:When we share your story, we are making an intimate bond of friendship. This happens any time we are sharing an emotional truth about ourselves that shows where we are vulnerable. It makes the listener empathetic to our feelings. And that’s a great vehicle for bonding.Journal about the things that are upsetting you or speak to a friend. Be honest. Take time to choose the person with deep care. While complaining, try to understand yourself too. Author Tina Gilbertson writes in her book, How To Beat Bad Feelings By Letting Yourself Have Them: Ask yourself what upsets you? Tell the truth in one sentence.While complaining is, ideally, solution-based, venting is not as focused on solving problems. But that doesn’t mean venting is bad. At times, you should vent because it’s cathartic. The positive benefits of venting are immediate:it allows you to unload and offload emotional weight, thereby, reducing stress and unhappiness. But after that, make sure the complaining gets solution-oriented.Remember that voicing too many expressive complaints gets you into a loop of negative emotion. Modern life gives rise to lots of complaints, but how many of us do a good job of it?When done effectively, it can help you clearly realise what specifically is bothering you. Possibly, because you are hearing yourself speak out loud. Or, the person you are speaking to gives you a perspective you didn’t think of since you were too wrapped up in your own feelings. The research discovered that emotional disclosure is important, but the way in which you disclose it is what determines whether the interaction has a positive or negative impact. Make your complaints short and to the point. Happy people complain to find solutions.There is no passive waiting and dwelling about this kind of complaining. This is solution-based and is done with an actionable goal. People with high self-esteem tend to be instrumental complainers, perhaps, because they are more confident that voicing their complaint can improve things.But while at it, remember not to rant. Effective complaints tend to be concise, fact-based, directed at the right person at the right time and focused on a particular goal. Also, make your complaint directly to the person who has the power to fix it.Journal about the things that are upsetting you or speak to a friend. Be honest. Take time to choose the person with deep care. While complaining, try to understand yourself too.

Title: Pawan Shankar to make his Bollywood debut soon
Content: Actor Pawan Shankar, who recently returned to TV after a break of six years, is all set for his Bollywood debut. His track in the show, 'Guddan Tumse Na Ho Payega', has ended and he will next be seen on the big screen — in the Ajay Devgn and Sanjay Dutt-starrer, 'Bhuj — The Pride Of India'. Talking about his role, Pawan says, “I am playing Omani, the Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) chief, who instigated the Kutch attack during the India-Pakistan war in 1971 and destroyed the runway at the Bhuj airport . It is one of the biggest roles of my career, and I am excited to work with such talented co-stars. Director Abhishek Dudhaiya had seen my work in the TV show 'Siddhanth' (2004) and wanted to cast me in his film.”While Pawan has played the lead role in TV shows, he is playing the antagonist in this film. Does he have any apprehensions about turning negative on screen? He says, “In today’s cinema, the antagonist doesn’t have any particular image. In fact, lead actors are playing both protagonists and antagonists. Saif Ali Khan is among the actors, who have played both kind of roles equally well.”Pawan says that shooting for a film is different from shooting for a TV show. “In films, you finish each shot with precision and accuracy, and the quality of equipment is superlative. On TV, there is so much content to be wrapped up in a day and so, we have to compromise on the performance. Ek baar mein jo de diya, de diya; shot dekhne ka bhi time nahi hota.”

Title: Is Rashmika doing Suriya’s film with Hari?
Content: There have been reports of Malavika Mohanan being roped in to play the lead in Suriya ’s film, which will be directed by Hari . Now, we hear that it might not be the Petta girl, but Rashmika Mandanna who’s in talks for the role.A source says, “A few days ago, there was buzz that Malavika, who’s now shooting Vijay’s Master with Lokesh Kanagaraj, would be pairing up with Suriya in Hari’s film. But the team has been in talks with Rashmika for the film. However, nothing is on paper and it will be a while before the cast is finalised.”Interestingly, Rashmika, who shot to fame with her performances in films like Kirik Party, Geetha Govindam and Dear Comrade, is working with Suriya’s brother Karthi in Sultan, being directed by Bakkiyaraj Kannan.

Title: Column: Tongue in Check
Content: Want the latest buzz on the gossip front? A peep into the lives of the rich and famous? A wind of Chennai’s best-kept secrets? Writer, activist, anchor, and queen bee Apsara Reddy fills you in ...Actor Vishnu Vishal is a happy man these days — his films are doing well and his nuptials with Jwala Gutta are being planned. The cute couple has the blessings of both the families, and are excited about this new phase, say their friends. His killer new look is all thanks to the inspiration from Jwala’s sporty outlook, it seems.Mukund Venkat, the happening and hot celebrity trainer from Chennai, who is now rocking London, is in town and guess what, the ladies can’t get enough of him. Stalkers land up where he is staying all the time, we’re told. But Mukund is too busy bromancing his gym buddies to pay heed. Last heard, this wannabe actress pinged him asking him out to a resort, and the suave gym bunny started the conversation with, ‘sister’...You thought surfing arenas in Chennai are just about the sport? Naah! These surf spots are where some of the most steamy expat love affairs in the city blossom. Some pretty well-known men and women have found love in the arms of namma chennai surfers. Last heard, a businesswoman from Canada, who was famous in the social circles here married a surfer from the fishermen community and flew him to Italy, where he now works as a chef.At a popular workout spot on the ECR, former actress Kadhal Sandhya has won quite a few fans with her fitness moves. She, we hear, has even greater fans for the super bike she rides in on.( Views expressed above are the author’s own)

Title: Gentleman blends comedy and realistic element: Prajwal Devaraj
Content: For the team of Gentleman, the film is rather special — director Guru Deshpande turned producer, actors Prajwal Devaraj and Nishvika Naidu took on roles that challenged each of them, and director Jadesh Kumar attempted to present a unique story about a man with a sleeping disorder, who has to battle an issue. Naturally, each of them is excited about what they bring to the table, which was palpable, when they dropped by our office for a quick chat ahead of the film’s release on February 7. Excerpts from our conversation:Gentleman is a story that revolves around a man with the sleeping beauty syndrome. It follows Bharath , who is plagued by the syndrome and ends up sleeping for 18 hours a day. How he leads his life in the six hours that he is awake and the issues he faces form the theme of the story.The inspiration for the story was a news article we came across back in 2010 about a man who actually suffers from the syndrome. Jadesh worked on this for 10 years to develop a story that I decided to back as producer.To explain Gentleman, one has to begin with the title. In society, everyone wants to be gentleman, and in our film, we have a protagonist who has all of six hours in a day to prove that he is a gentleman. He fights a mafia, falls in love with a girl and has to give time to his family. In that sense, Gentleman is the perfect blend of commercial and realistic elements — a power-packed movie, which will not disappoint anyone.I play Tapaswini, who is very responsible and disciplined. In comparison to my earlier outings, this is a very different character for me. She is also a dietitian, who is very health conscious.When I first heard the story, I was very impressed by the subject, as I had never heard about the syndrome. I have done enough research that is required of me as an actor in presenting this onscreen. Strangely, after the trailer was launched, a former classmate reached out to me to tell me that her husband suffers from the syndrome.In India, there are probably 10 reported cases of the syndrome. In the film, though, we have represented it as the first case to be reported in Karnataka . We worked on the script for a year to ensure that Prajwal would truly embody everything that someone with the syndrome does. But that doesn’t mean that the film is only about his medical condition; it is as much about how he finds it difficult to find time for his love, family and his personal life. Amid all the drama, he even fights against a human trafficking mafia, which gives a thrilling edge to the tale.Honestly, I had no idea that such a syndrome or the mafia angle explored in this film existed in the real world.After we released the teaser, we got a call from someone called Rajeev who has the syndrome and sleeps for 20 hours a day. He also shared videos with us. As it turns out, there is another guy called Ajay from Belagavi who has the syndrome. People are now eagerly waiting to see the movie, as they want to know what solution we have given to the syndrome.It was easy, because the character is rather novel. He needs to do whatever is required of him in six hours. There is also a thriller element in it, which keeps audiences hooked.The movie also highlights relationships. There is a child called Aradhya in the film, whose role will strike a chord with audiences.Prajwal, you were made to shoot in a garbage dump and in a sewer drain....The location that we shot at had such huge mounds of garbage that we needed to bring earth mover equipment to clear some and make space for us to shoot. Imagine moving waste that has been decomposing for long — that raised quite a stench — and then having to shoot there the whole day. One of the sequences required me to sleep on piles of waste, which was quite challenging.

Title: Airport looks are so fake & overhyped: Vahbiz Dorabjee
Content: An extension of your personality. It’s your style and your attitude. It enhances your personality.Black dress, heels, make-up, perfumes, vibrant colours.Short dresses and sneakers.I don’t have any strategies. I go and buy what I love. But I would say that I am definitely a conscious shopper.Wear what suits your body and what you are comfortable in and don’t let anyone shake your confidence.Wear black whenever you want to play safe.When people wear extra-tight clothes on top of T-shirts/shirts.At the current moment it is wearing sneakers. It automatically uplifts my mood.I have not made any big blunders but I have sometimes ended up wearing clothes that don’t suit me.I should start wearing dungarees again. I was hesitant but once I wore it, I got lots of compliments.My mom has flawless skin and thankfully I have her genes. She has always told me not to touch my skin too much or to tamper with it – and I follow it.So overhyped and fake.Regular gym and functional training.Clothes – all the way.VibrantLondonKareena Kapoor Khan hands downMy curves

Title: Not every Punjabi song in a Bollywood film is a hit, says Sukhwinder Singh
Content: Given that musician Sukhwinder Singh has been around in the film industry for over two decades, and has sung songs in just about every Indian language, one would think he would have a huge discography. But, he admits that he is content with singing 10-12 good songs in a year, unlike his contemporaries. During his recent visit to Bengaluru, he explains that the discretion in his selection of the work he takes up is deliberate. Excerpts...I have to be selective; it's my nature. I do not want to have a career that boasts a great number of songs. I'd be happy if it is a selected few that stand out with good lyrics, composers and film teams. This has worked for me since the past two decades. Lyrics have to be very good. That is my only condition to sing.People email and message me whenever my new songs come up. I try to feel the pulse when I am out at an event or a concert. Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior has become a major hit. When my song Maay Bhavani , played on screen, people threw coins to show their appreciation. When I get to know about the success of a song, I go ahead and sign the next one. My musical journey has turned out to be great so far. It is slow and steady, but energetic.The song has to be good. If there is a Punjabi song in every other movie today, it doesn't mean that the song is good. Every Punjabi song is not running successfully. If the song is very good, it will work well, irrespective of the language it has been sung in.AR Rahman is the one who introduced me to world music. He launched me and I have great love and regards for him. I don't know much about his state of mind now or when we will work together again.I don't mind them, nor do I mind singing remixes. But, I've not been approached to sing any remix yet. I think Chaiyya Chaiyya will sound good if remixed. If and when I do get an opportunity to sing a remix, I am sure it will sound great.I am more energetic when I perform in a city that has great weather. And, the weather in Bengaluru is perfect. I love performing in the city as the crowd here is mostly young. They bring in a lot of energy to the concert and that encourages me to give my best. The city is very special for me. It has a musical heritage, which sets it apart from from the rest.

Title: It was Sanam who asked me to keep our engagement confidential: Tharshan
Content: Bigg Boss Tamil Season 3 fame Tharshan Thiyagarajah, who was accused of physical and mental harassment by his former fiancée Sanam Shetty , has now come out asserting that her allegations are untrue. He trashes Sanam’s accusation of him hiding their engagement and avers that it’s she who asked him not to open up about the same for three years. Tharshan also adds that the wedding was called off as he couldn’t handle the pressure from Sanam after coming out of the reality show. He opens up on how they met, the conditions she laid down when they got engaged, what went wrong, and more…First of all, I had no intention of hiding our engagement. But she insisted I do not make it public for three years as she thought it would affect her movie offers. Even otherwise, I don’t believe in talking about personal things in public, so I was okay with it. Her parents, too, requested me to keep it confidential.Both of us had sent our profiles together for the third season of the show but hers was rejected. She even tried to influence them through one of her relatives, who is a politician. The wedding was supposed to take place in June last year, but it didn’t happen because I went to participate in the show. I thought she might get a wild card entry, but that too didn’t happen. Sanam didn’t like my relationship with Sherin in the house though she was only a good friend. Later, when I explained my relationship with Sanam to Sherin, she stayed away from me as she didn’t want her name to be dragged into this. But after I came out of the house, I was taken aback by Sanam’s change in behaviour. I started getting affected mentally because of her pressure to announce our relationship to the public. Moreover, she insisted that I take her with me wherever I went. She used to force me to book business-class tickets whenever I went abroad. She also asked me to refer her for the movie offers that came my way.It’s been more than a couple of months now. When we decided to break up, she again insisted that I talk about it to the media. I was not comfortable with it and told her the same. I said I will talk about this to her parents, but not to the public. Her allegation that my parents threatened her is completely untrue. If I have parents who can threaten others with their influence or power, why would I struggle for a chance in commercials and movies?To be honest, I am clueless about it. Apart from the suicide threats that she came up with, she used to tell me that she’d take revenge on me. That’s why I didn’t make our relationship pubic. There have been instances where she went to production houses and claimed that I cheated her. Once, she even told me that she will do everything to curtail my growth as I hail from a different country.The movie has been temporarily shelved due to financial crisis. She claims she has splurged on me. If she had that much money, she could have used it for the project and finished it. She spent only around `3.5 lakh for my employment visa and I returned the money to her later. She has been saying she helped me with her career, which is another lie. I had enough commercials and movies, some of which had me playing crucial roles. My family also used to send me money.I don’t know who her co-stars are and I never ask her where she goes and who she works with.Whatever said and done, I’m still grateful to her because she did suggest my name for some of the assignments I was part of. I have great respect for her parents, too. I just want to clarify that her allegations aren’t credible.

Title: When in doubt, go for sprouts
Content: When you see sprouts, think “nutrient dense”, that too in one small serving. Sprouts that bud from a seed hold the most nutrients because that seed has the power to grow into an entire plant eventually. It is rich in minerals, vitamins, enzymes, antioxidants, amino acids and several other nutrients making them burst with folate, magnesium, phosphorus, manganese and vitamins C, A, K — however, it may vary based on the type of sprout. Nevertheless, every kind of sprout can be a super healthy addition to your daily meals.The process of “sprouting” or germination is what holds real value here. When seeds are soaked in water, they sprout into very young plants due to the moisture present that softens the outer layers of the seed. This process helps unlock and increase the nutrition value multi-fold – this is what makes sprouts so healthy.- Since sprouting needs a good amount of soaking, it helps get rid of anti nutritional factors like phytic acid thereby unlocking all the nutrients and making it more bio available.- It enhances the nutritional value of the seed. - It is super rich in live enzymes that can aid digestion and break down food more effectively.- Sprouting can make a particular lentil or legume easy to digest. During sprouting, specific complex compounds are broken down into simpler forms and undesirable substances are rendered inactive which makes sprouts easily digestible. This is why sprouts is also called a pre-digested food.- Sprouting makes proteins easy to digest.- Sprouts are rich in folate and can help boost haemoglobin levels.- It is a great way to add fibre to meals.You can practically sprout any seed. Green gram, chana, different types of beans, peas, fenugreek seeds,alfalfa, lentils, nuts and seeds.Having said that, there is one particular sprout from the Brassica family and that’s - broccoli sprouts! These are micro sized, but bursting with nutrients and may need a separate article to name their benefits! But in a nutshell, it has magical benefits on heart, immunity, detoxification, lymphatic system, allergies, asthma, stomach ulcers, inflammation and overall cellular health at a DNA level.Sprouts can be had raw, lightly steamed, used as a stuffing in sandwiches and paranthas when mashed, churned into a batter for dosas, idlis, added to soups, salads, pulavs, khichdi, stir-frys, tikkis.- The seeds could attract fungal/mould growth so it’s necessary to be careful.- Raw sprouts may not always suit you, especially if you have a weak digestive system. In that case, take them in a steamed or boiled form.Semi-boiled sprouted green moong 1/2 cupCoriander leaves: 1.5 tbspMint leaves: 1.5 tbspSattu flour: 1/2 tbspHimalayan pink salt: As requiredAsafoetida: A pinchGreen chilli paste: 1/2 teaspoonSesame seeds roasted: 1 tbspVegetables of choice: (1/2 cup, could be carrots, beans, peas, cabbage stir fried lightly and mash)Cold pressed coconut oil: 1 tbsp; Water: As required.- Mash the semi-boiled sprouts.-Transfer in a bowl and mix it with mint leaves, sattu flour, green chilli paste, salt, sesame seeds (crushed), vegetables and coriander leaves.- Mix thoroughly and make round balls from this mixture in the shape of tikkis.- Take a plate and place some chopped coriander and mint leaves (1/2 tbsp both) in it. Roll the tikkis in this mixture.- Take a non-stick pan, keep it on medium flame and heat coconut oil. Pan fry these tikkis until golden brown in colour on both sides. Remove on an absorbent paper.- Serve hot with your favourite chutney.One can even sprout wheat and millets, which are much more easily digestible as compared to non-sprouted counterparts

Title: Tattoos you can hear
Content: Permanent body art, never sounded better. Literally. Thanks to the growing trend of soundwave tattoos that are making waves. Launched in 2017 by an LA-based company, Skin Motion, it uses an app to convert audio files to soundwaves that you can get etched on to the skin and with the help of the app play it back. It can be your favourite music, voice/s of a loved one/s or anything that you care about.Inventor Nate Siggard revealed that he already has a recording of his child’s infectious laughter on his leg. Another YouTube clip published by the company shows a tattoo artist who got her dog’s bark on her arm. The tattoo even adorns Canadian singer/songwriter sensation Shawn Mendes who got a guitar — his signature instrument — etched on his arm. The very top of the guitar is a soundwave of his parents voices saying ‘I love you’.Celebrity tattoo artist Sunny Bhanushali explains, “Soundwaves are visual representation or a diagram of a voice or sound produced. These diagrams are inked on the skin and when you scan with a device you can hear the message behind the diagram.” He calls it a trending tattoo and people are picking to go for the voice of a loved one, or a line of their favourite song.Even as the tattoos continue to make big noise, many claim that the clips don’t work as well as promised. But that’s not dampening their demand. Bhanushali says that he’s getting queries everyday regarding these audio tattoos. His advice: keep the audio short – maybe 3 to 5 words max, and get it at a safe spot (avoid wrist or neck). “These are very emotional tattoos. You can hear the voice of the person when you scan them. Spots like thighs or forearms are perfect for these tattoos. It’s definitely going to be popular with the millennials,” he predicts. Other tattoos that are doing well right now are armband and minimal tattoos.

Title: Farm to table(t)?
Content: Haven’t the last couple of years been a back-to-the-pediatrician kind of experience with everyone out there reminding us to “eat our vegetables”? While many amongst us have happily warmed up to the idea of seeing more of kale and moringa in our food, picky eaters are still fighting the idea. A trend catering to the latter population is wellness shots, pills and gummies. “Your daily serving of greens” is the claim most of them go around with. Can’t eat your veggies? Just down a shot of greens or chew on a superfood gummy. From delivering Ayurvedic pills customised to your dosha to your personalised batch of adaptogen and herby fizz, wellness comes in mindboggling packages these days.Wellness shots and gummies are actually preserved condensed versions of juices, plant extracts or drinking vinegars that are gaining popularity for being easy to consume, palatable and pleasant to the eye. Since they look more like candy or a mocktail and can be consumed on the go, people are easily buying the idea of considering them as a good alternative to supplements or even the inability to meet their dietary requirements. Almost every medically beneficial herb or food including ashwagandha, asafoetida, carom seeds, apple cider vinegar, ginger, turmeric, wheatgrass, cherry juice, cranberry and a hundred others are available as these shots and gummies.Their beneficial effect as a complete product is debatable. Currently, there are no scientific claims suggesting their actual nutrient content. Studies only highlight the benefits of the main ingredient on which the particular product is based. But a question remains: how jas the processing, along with additional colours and preservatives affected the efficacy of that medicinal food or plant? To sum up, wellness gummies and shots may be used to serve as a quick dose of energy, refreshment or just to feel good but they should not be considered as the desired nutrition your body needs.No supplement/ gummies or wellness shakes can be a substitute for healthy food. Our body is naturally developed to consume, digest and assimilate food to get its dietary requirements. From the bacteria in the gut lining to saliva in the mouth and from the digestive enzymes to the digestive organs such as liver, stomach, pancreas and more, the gastrointestinal tract is aligned to digest and absorb nutrients from food and not really from extracts. You can still consume them between meals or when you are low in energy or feel tired.— With inputs from Manjari Chandra, clinical nutritionistLeafy greens: Spinach, kale, collards, parsleySeaweed: Spirulina, chlorella, dulse, kelpOther vegetables: Broccoli, beets, carrots, tomatoes, green cabbageGrasses: Barley grass, wheatgrass, oat grass, alfalfa grass

Title: All children should be allowed to have pets: Sudha Murty
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

At a recent event in the city, Sudha Murty was in good company — she had her pet labrador Gopi with her. So, she also took the opportunity to speak about the special bond she shares with her pet, whom she had even taken along when she was being featured on actor Ramesh Aravind ’s chat show. “I recite poems to Gopi, which keep him entertained. I also tell him stories and sing lullabies too. I do not know if he enjoys listening to them or if he listens to them at all, but I like doing that. The only thing he does want after it all is something to eat. But spending time with him and talking to him is enjoyable,” says Sudha, adding how Gopi once mistook an egg for a ball when he was given one for the first time in their vegetarian household.

The joy of having a pet, she adds, is something all children should experience, ideally as early as possible. “I request all parents with young children to adopt pets at home, if possible. When one has pets, they need to be responsible, as there are activities that need to be tended to. Children in these homes grow up quickly, as they learn to be more responsible,” she explains.

Title: I never thought I’d complete 25 years in showbiz: Sudeep
Content: A silver jubilee is a career milestone that most people will be proud of. And when you know that getting there was far from a bed of roses, the end result is even sweeter. For Sandalwood star Kichcha Sudeep , 2020 is a milestone year, as it is his 25th in showbiz. The actor recently shared a heartfelt video with fans and well-wishers, where he reflected on his journey so far; how it all began without any fanfare and how he has worked his way up in the industry. “The journey has seen me face both bouquets and brickbats and nothing was easy or came as I willed. I’ve had to work for it and now, when I see fans celebrate and dance in front of the screen for my films, I am filled with gratitude. My only wish has been to do varied roles in different avatars to entertain you,” he said, adding that he’s glad he’s made it here.Sudeep also candidly added, “If I have to consider this journey as a bus, there have been many people who have travelled along with me. While many have remained with me, some have left midway. I miss those who have moved on. As for those who have stayed by my side, I’m happy to say you complete me.”The candid confessions continued as Sudeep said, “I never thought I would be completing 25 years here.” He added, “It would be lies if I say I didn’t run behind box-office collections or the number game. But I will say that today it does not matter any more. I am happy with creative satisfaction that translates into appreciation from fans. By the end of my journey, I don’t want to be the most successful person, but the one who is the most admired.”

Title: In the loop
Content: Think of crochet and it probably reminds you of simpler times – of mom’s hand-knitted sweaters, homemade pickles and the humble sewing machine. Sunday afternoons were spent lazing in the sun with your mother or grandmother crocheting away busily to fashion caps, tablecloths and what not. And with the return of all things handmade, crochet is making a big comeback – if current spring-summer trends are to be believed. The hand-knitted goodness was seen on the ramps for Salvatore Ferragamo, Marni, Kate Spade New York, Fendi, Gabriela Hearst and Jil Sander. As always, fast fashion brands picked up on the trend to launch their versions of crochet chic and upcycling enthusiasts tried their hands at it to craft handbags, coasters, mats and more – all with the humble hook.While, personally, you may not have thought of crochet since you were a kid, high fashion is taking it seriously. The spring-summer is going to see a slew of crochet variants in sexy, feminine dresses with enough holes to make sure you stay (and look) cool in the hot months ahead.HOOK, LINE AND SINKERCrochet is a French term meaning ‘small hook’. Hooks can be made from a variety of materials, such as metal, wood, bamboo, or plastic. The key difference between crochet and knitting, beyond the implements used for their production, is that each stitch in crochet is completed before the next one is begun, while knitting keeps many stitches open at a time. And practitioners claim that it is simpler than knitting.Some variants such as Tunisian crochet or broomstick lace, keep multiple stitches open similar to knitting.The spring fashion update is in the form of ultra-feminine dresses, polished suiting, and even eveningwear that feels modern with a touch of grandma’s handmade crochet. As the fashion industry is searching for ways to be more sustainable, this trend ticks all the right boxes. It’s slow, handmade, uses upcycled material – it screams sustainability. Upcyclers like Swati Soharia and Chindi have crafted bags and baskets out of discarded materials using crochet stitches. Irish designer Colin Burke does exquisite handmade crochet to create signature winterwear that looks luxurious. Crafters are even using it to create toys and hair accessories. Last summer, crochet bikinis were an Instagram favourite. Even crochet in textile jewellery — with big necklaces and earrings — is making waves right now.CROCHET CHICWith the quest for handmade, homespun feel in clothes becoming stronger, it is seeing resurgence of age-old techniques like quilting, knitting, applique, patchwork, kantha and more. The fibre art being picked up by high fashion transports it to haute couture.At Altuzarra and Giambattista Valli, crochet was seen in skin-baring crops and bra tops. Stella McCartney created lace-like crochet dresses with plunging necklines. True to its brand ethos, Kate Spade New York showcased long crochet dresses and skirts in bright colours paired with button-up shirts for a grown-up look. Meanwhile, Marni styled artful pieces with loosely-crocheted yarns over slinky silk to create a juxtaposition of textures.But it’s not a look for the faint-hearted given the fact that it is a bit see-through but nothing a little soft lining can’t cover. A crochet outfit is usually boho with a resort and lounge-y feel – a reason why you can have as much fun with the outfit as you want. Pair with flip-flops, hoop earrings, heels or sneakers – it’s a look you can dress up or down. It’s also Instagram gold with many people showcasing their art of crochet and a gazillion YouTube videos to help you get started. Incidentally celebrities like Meryl Streep, Debra Messing, Jane Seymour and Eva Longoria are hooked to their hook. It’s time you gave it a try.

Title: How can we combat compassion fatigue?
Content:
Feeling burdened by the suffering of others

Blaming others for their suffering

Isolating yourself

Loss of pleasure in life

Difficulty concentrating

Insomnia

Physical and mental fatigue

Bottling up your emotions

Increased nightmares

Feelings of hopelessness or powerlessness

Frequent complaining about your work or your life

Overeating

Excessive use of drugs or alcohol

Poor self-care

Denial

Beginning to receive a lot of complaints about your work or attitude

Is it too early to be talking about surviving 2020? After all, we are just in the second month – with 10 more to go. But if you were to heed political comedian Hasan Minhaj’s advice, we are all suffering from compassion fatigue. What might that be? In his last episode of 2019, Minhaj talked about managing the 24-hour depressing news cycle around us. He said: “We are exposed to all the news, all the time, which makes us feel like we need to care about everything – all the time…”Don’t you feel this? It’s not as if these issues don’t matter. “But we can’t possibly care about all of them – all the time. It’s like we have 50 tabs open in our mental browsers and we are about to crash,” he added. That’s compassion fatigue. And something’s got to change. But what?Trauma therapist Ruchita Chandrashekar has seen this fatigue building up in the younger demographic (that is consuming information at a breakneck speed). “The exhaustion you feel at the exposure to other’s pain is real. It’s accompanied with a feeling of doom – you are pre-occupied with what’s happening, are prone to sudden mood swings, feel helpless and are wracked with guilt for not doing enough,” she says.Midlife coach Vaibhav Datar pinpoints social media as one of the main reasons for the current feeling of doom. “Physiologically, people are more triggered by negative news. The constant availability of news on cell phones, constant bombardment of negative news on social media, the ease of multiple apps, have all helped in propelling negativity, illusion and stress within the mind of every individual – especially millennials,” he says.A feeling of secondary stress in the consumer of news has been proven in many studies. Delhi-based psychiatrist Dr Shobhana Mittal notes, HOW you consume information is a reason why people are feeling more burdened. “A big chunk of information is reaching us through our smartphones, that are often accessed during ‘leisure time’ from a personal space (like one’s bedroom), at a personal time (say at bedtime), when one has his/her guards down. None of us are emotionally prepared to see stressful content at such a time,” she adds.Also, most social media content can be more graphic and visceral than the newspaper, and the comment section is negative and abusive in nature. Chandrashekar says that visceral images, graphic videos tend to have a deeper impact than reading news. Hence, one of the key areas to focus on in combatting compassion fatigue, is our relationship and time with our smartphones.Some signs that you are veering towards this fatigue are: feeling fearful, developing a tendency to wander off and showing escapist traits. A recent research from the University of Michigan and the University of Rochester Medical Center found that empathy among students has declined by more than 40 per cent compared to the late 1970s. Dr Amit Sood, professor of medicine at Mayo Clinic College of Medicine, explains why this has happened to us all over the world. In his book, The Mayo Clinic Guide to Stress-Free Living, he says, “We are inundated with graphic images of unimaginable suffering of millions. We can fathom the suffering of a few, but a million becomes a statistic that numbs us.” The fatigue sets in.Being invested in the news cycle remotely is unpaid, unaccounted labour that takes up your time and mind space. The best way to deal with it all is to switch off. In today’s time we can’t go off our phone, but a good way is to start with 20 minutes. Chandrashekar suggests, use an app to lock your phone away and do some recreational activity that preferably doesn’t involve a screen. She calls it 20-minute active disengagement. Life coach and author Simrun Chopra says, “Stay with something you have read or watched for five minutes to process it better. When you read something, focus, stop, think it over, and once you’ve truly consumed it, move on.”List out your personal strengths, journal, seek therapy to build up your “emotional endurance”. Now, more than ever, you need to regroup with like-minded people. “And every week, make it a point to check-in with them, and yourself, about how you are feeling,” says Chandrashekar.Chopra says that the power is in your hands – your phone. Her survival tips: no notifications, dedicated time for phone use and designated verified sites and select news sources to manage information overload. “What you repost, share and write makes a difference. If you are a person of influence, ask yourself: is what I am putting up making a positive difference? Don’t give in to the social need to keep posting,” she adds.Datar agrees, “There are so many people who are ‘cool’ even though they do not regularly update on their social media accounts. There is no compulsion to be cool, to be the learned and scholarly man on the net. What you do in your real life is more important than what you do in your social media life.” As Minhaj says... it is FOCUS that will save you in 2020.Physiologically, people are more triggered by negative news. The constant availability of news on cell phones, social media, have helped in propelling negativity, stress within the mind of every individual – especially millennials—Vaibhav Datar, midlife coachIn 1980, the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, claimed “knowing of others’ traumas can be traumatising”. The article claimed that proximity to trauma could itself be damaging much like secondhand smoke. Clinically, compassion fatigue is a secondary traumatic stress (STS) characterised by a gradual lessening of compassion over time. At a time where every tragedy is instantly broadcast directly into your home through TVs, laptops, smartphones, the scope of compassion fatigue has increased in mammoth proportions.To see where you fall on the compassion satisfaction/fatigue continuum, take the Professional Quality of Life (www.proqol.org) questionnaire developed by Dr Beth Hundall Stamm, one of the world’s leading experts on compassion fatigue— Psychology Today

Title: Ganesh Acharya files a counter complaint against assistant choreographer
Content: Five days after a 33-year-old assistant choreographer filed a non-cognisable offence against Bollywood choreographer Ganesh Acharya , who is also the general secretary of the Indian Film and Television Choreographers Association (IFTCA), for allegedly expelling her membership, depriving her of work, demanding commission and forcing her to watch adult videos, Acharya has now filed a counter NC against her. The lady also approached the National Commission for Women a few days ago against Ganesh.Talking about the issue, she said, “I started working as a coordinator for dancers in November 2019. However, because of certain issues in the past, Ganesh Acharya, who is the general secretary of IFTCA, used his position to expel me from the association and also directed other members to stop working with me, because I refused to give him commission. I am sitting at home unemployed since two months. That’s when I approached Sarojji (Khan), who assured me that they would look into the matter at the Special General Meeting (SGM), which was held on Sunday. While I was sitting in the corridor waiting to present my side of the story, Ganesh came out and started screaming. He said, ‘Yeh kya kar rahi hai yahaan par? Isko thappad aur laat maar kar baahar nikaalo’. Two women assaulted me on his instructions.”She added, “In my complaint to NCW, I have also stated that Ganesh, who would often be found watching adult videos every time I visited his office, forced me to watch them, too. I reprimanded him and told him that if he ever repeated it or called me, I would file a complaint against him with the association and the police.”BT spoke to Ganesh Acharya, who said, “She was part of a group of dancers I worked with in 2007. Apart from that, I don’t know this girl at all. The accusations of assault in my presence and on my instructions are false, as I had left for a shoot before the altercation between her and the two others took place.”Regarding the accusations of expelling her because she didn’t agree to pay him a commission and forcing her to watch adult videos, he said, “The decision to expel a member is taken after everyone’s consent, and she was expelled owing to her crude and unflattering remarks on dance masters. I am against the practice of commission and don’t work with coordinators, so why will I demand commission from her? Disgruntled by the termination of her membership, she sent letters and notices to IFTCA and its members making false and frivolous allegations of not letting her work and harassing her. However, in these alleged complaints, there was no mention of her latest cooked-up story of porn videos being shown to her. Her accusations are false and baseless.”Ganesh’s lawyer, Ravi Suryawanshi, said, “We have given a written complaint to the Oshiwara Police on January 31 against her for defamation and filed an NC for the same. We have also lodged a complaint at Amboli police station against her for filing a false complaint. Ganesh Acharya will soon be initiating legal proceedings against her and her accomplices.”

Title: Shivin Narang: I won’t be able to give time to a relationship at this point
Content: For Shivin Narang , who is currently seen as Rudra in Beyhadh 2 , playing title roles is not a parameter of success. He says, “That isn’t a benchmark of your talent or success. I have been offered many title roles, but I have never taken them up just for the sake of it. I am secure as an actor.” He is also unperturbed by the fact that the Beyhadh 2 hasn’t managed to rake in the desired ratings. The actor shares, “We were prepared for this, as the show didn’t fetch great ratings on TV even last year. However, the response I get from people is very good. In any case, TV shows don’t enjoy the kind of ratings they used to a decade ago. Also, there is no standard formula to know whether a show will strike a chord with the audience or not. All I can do is give it my 100 per cent and leave the rest to the audience.”Given that his show revolves around love, obsession and revenge, we ask Shivin for his views on matters of the heart. And, he replies, “The definition of love changes with time. You could be possessive, obsessive or sensitive, depending on what you feel about the other person at a particular point.”So, what’s his relationship status? “As of now, I am too focused on work to make space for another person. Even if I were to fall in love with someone, I won’t be able to give time to the relationship at this point. And I am someone who can’t do things half-heartedly,” he says.While he might be happily single, the actor has had his share of link-ups. After being linked up with his Suvreen Guggal co-actor, Smiriti Kalra, for a long time, he is now rumoured to be in a relationship with aspiring actress, Sonali Kukreja . “In my case, most link-ups have been false, the real ones remain a secret (laughs!). It’s common for people to link co-actors and it works wonders for the show. My female friends, who are linked with me, get upset with such stories. Over a period of time, I have realised that there is no point in explaining myself,” he signs off.

White was the colour of the night on Friday as 1,500 plus women, with T-shirts bearing a special message hit the street. They dared to make the night safer by taking part in the Maharashtra Police midnight ‘evethon’. Judging by the turnout of the ‘Tigress moms’ as the participants called themselves, the message certainly was loud and clear: ‘We are fearless’.The 3-km run was from Maharashtra Police Headquarters to NCPA and back. Says runner Suvarna Joshi, “We had been planning this for a month. The idea was to get as many women on board as possible. Among the runners, we actually had three generations of women taking part, which was great. Today, we have 24x7 restaurants in Mumbai, we should have 24x7 fitness also. The police were quite supportive.”Says organiser Sharmila Vasudha Kamat, “The motto was ‘’, which was not just about running , but also that we women are unstoppable and we should not give up on our dreams.”Lauding the efforts, Krishna Prakash , IG Admin, Maharashtra Police, reiterated, “.” He also went on to address women’s safety in Mumbai, adding, “Women are safe in every way in Mumbai and Maharashtra and this new initiative reinforces that belief.Freedom At Midnight.”

I have been coming here for years, so this place is home.” While the guests were leaving, the hosts, along with a few guests, posed on the tractor. Responding to a comment that “Kirron ji has taken the position from where her dimple is visible,” the MP replied, “ Arey nahi! Abhi toh mujhe koi fark nahi padta. Kyunki camera jahan andar laga hai, Lok Sabha mein, main sabse bhayankar wahan par lagi hoon.”: When Kirron Kher saw Baijayant Panda and Supriya Sule on the tractor, she said, “ Yeh kahan Odiya aur Maharashtrians tractor chala rahein hain, yeh toh Punjabiyon ko hi chalane do. Aap kahan tractor chalaoge? Aap toh helicopter chalate ho.” After the banter, while they were deciding their poses, someone suggested, “ Balle-balle kar lo,” to which Kirron replied, “No no, what balle-balle? We are all serious politicians here.”

Title: Lobera To Say Final Goodbye
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: Not every successful story has a happy ending.

In the two full seasons that Sergio Lobera was at the helm of affairs, FC Goa played the most beautiful football and recently clocked 100 goals under him—a first for a coach in the Indian Super League (ISL). Semifinal in the first season, final in the second and a Super Cup trophy too. If that wasn’t enough, the team has now climbed to the top of the ISL ladder and could become the first from India to play in the high-profile AFC Champions League.

If and when that happens, Lobera won’t be around.

FC Goa and the Spanish coach, along with his assistants, Jesus Tato and Manuel Sayabera, mutually parted ways on Saturday. News of the Spanish coach’s exit was doing the rounds since Friday evening, but a confirmation came only more than 24 hours later, at 11pm on Saturday.

“The club would like to thank Sergio and his coaching team for their service over the last two and a half seasons and wish them well for the future. FC Goa won the Super Cup last year under his guidance and finished runners-up in the ISL last season,” the club said in a statement.

Club president Akshay Tandon thanked the coach and his team for their work. “Our objectives when Sergio came in were to instill a style of football and build a platform on which we would move forward as a club and we managed to achieve that consistently,” he said.

Lobera will meet the players and existing support staff for one last time on Sunday and wish them luck for the rest of the season. The Spanish coach is expected to turn up at the GMC Athletic Stadium in Bambolim before training session and say goodbye.

If the league organisers approve, Derrick Pereira will take over as the interim coach. Current assistant coach Clifford Miranda is another option, to tick the box, with Derrick still calling the shots.

Title: ‘Respect the club decision, but we are really unhappy’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: Sergio Lobera and his team has termed FC Goa ’s decision to part ways with them as “unfortunate,” and even though they said they respect the decision, the trio are unhappy.

“We obviously respect the club’s decision in the exact same ways we respected the decision to hire us thereupon. However, we admit to be really unhappy about this decision because we will not be able to enjoy and share with the team the greatest moments we are sure are yet to come,” Lobera and his assistants – Jesus Tato and Manuel Sayabera – said in their official media statement late on Saturday.

“We would like to thank the club for the trust placed in all of us, as well as for giving us the opportunity to work in such an exciting project in which we take great pride. We are also quite proud not only of the work we have performed within this time, but also to be a significant part of the club’s success, as long as we have done our best to place the club at the top of the Indian football, not only by achieving sporting success, but also by setting a well-recognised, respected and admired style of football in the whole county.

“Unfortunately, the club informed us recently that they are willing to separate our ways from now on, since they are confident is the best interests of the club for the present seasons and for the future as well,” the coaches said, wishing the club, team, fans and players deserving success.

Lobera and his assistants will meet the team at the GMC Athletic Stadium in Bambolim before the training session starts on Saturday. They are then expected to leave for Spain.

Title: Income Tax Slabs: Are you richer or poorer?
Content:
Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman (file photo)

The answer to the question above depends on your level of income, whether you use tax-saving investments, and if so, to what extent. The Budget gives all taxpayers the option of migrating to a new scheme. For incomes up to Rs 15 lakh, you do get a lower tax rate, but this means you cannot avail of deductions and exemptions, ranging from HRA and standard deduction to those for investments under section 80C or medical insurance premium under Section 80D. That clearly involves a trade-off.For instance, income between Rs 5 lakh and Rs 7.5 lakh annually will be taxed at 10% in the new regime instead of the 20% you would pay under the current scheme (which continues as an option). If you have an annual income of Rs 7.5 lakh, this translates into a saving of Rs 25,000 in tax. Add the cess of 4% and you get a total saving of Rs 26,000. However, this is possible only if you are not claiming any deductions or exemptions. If you are claiming Rs 1.25 lakh or more as deductions or exemptions, say for standard deduction (flat Rs 50,000 is allowed) plus other deductions under Section 80C — say for PF, LIC premium or home loan interest — then it is best to continue under the current regime because the gain will be more than offset by the addition to taxable income.Let us go forward. If you have an annual income of Rs 10 lakh, this translates into a saving of Rs 39,000 – assuming that you haven’t claimed any deductions or exemptions. But, typically an individual would avail of a standard deduction and have some investments. So, if you are claiming Rs 1.87 lakh or more as deductions/exemptions, again, it is best not to switch.Union Budget 2020: Full text of Nirmala Sitharaman's speechPensioners and new entrants to the job market, who have no investments in tax-saving schemes or HRA and LTA benefits may gain under the new tax regime.However, another key change could have a larger and most often adverse impact. This is in the treatment of dividend income. As a recipient, you paid no tax on dividend income if it was less than Rs 10 lakh per year. Rich shareholders paid tax on their dividend income exceeding Rs 10 lakh at the rate of 10% plus applicable surcharge and cess. That will change.All shareholders will have to bear tax on their dividend income. It will be added to their taxable income and taxed at the applicable slab rate. The more your dividend income and the higher your tax bracket, the larger this impact. At Rs 10 lakh dividend and an annual income of just above Rs 50 lakh, for instance, the extra tax liability would be Rs 3.4 lakh.The Budget also impacts you through higher customs duties on a whole range of imported products, from footwear to electronics, furniture, wall fans, kitchenware, as well as some alcoholic beverages. All of these could get costlier.On the whole, given the variables involved, its best for each taxpayer to work out individually whether the Budget leaves her poorer or richer. It’s complicated.

Title: Republic day: Harvest met art at this event in Pune
Content:
FacebookTwitterPintrest

Last Sunday on Republic Day , the Mahatma Phule Mandai wore an artistic look. Besides the usual bustling weekend activity of people lining up to buy fresh veggies and fruits, there was a set of people who joined in with some artistic products as well.Bringing various mediums of artwork to the forefront, this year’s theme of the Art Mandai event was ‘Harvest’, and artists gave it a spin with their work. From selling water containers to performing a contemporary dance around harvest season, there was no dearth of talent at the mandai. Ruby Jhunjunwala , one of the participants who displayed ceramic artwork at the event, said, “The general perception among people is that artworks are available only at art galleries. The mandai is a common ground where people come to buy daily grocery needs. So, this event gave us a wider platform. Also, the topic of harvest is universal and people connected with it instantly.”On the inspiration behind her dance performance with Sakshi Kapde, Sayli Kulkarni said, “I was travelling to a village named Sonala where I met some tribal kids who told me various things about harvest. I was teaching these kids some of my contemporary moves and in return, they taught me how harvesting is locally done. They told me how the harvesting moves are then incorporated in their harvest dance festival. Things like perni and kaapni are widely used and thus I incorporated the same moves in my dance at the Art Mandai event.”Glimpses from the event:Watch the video here:

Title: Tax charter will spell out what your rights are
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The decision to introduce a taxpayer’s charter as a part of a statute is being viewed as a positive step. A charter defines the rights of a taxpayer and the obligations of the tax department.

Hitesh Gajaria, co-head of tax at KPMG India, said: “While the contours of the charter have not yet been defined, it will lead to greater accountability and send a strong signal that the government intends to be taxpayer-friendly.”

“We wish to enshrine in the statute a taxpayer charter through this Budget. Our government remains committed to taking measures to ensure that our taxpayers are free from tax harassment of any kind,” Sitharaman said in her budget speech.

In a recent report, the International Bureau of Fiscal Documentation had stated that to ensure that the taxpayers’ rights were protected in the real sense, the enactment of such a charter was necessary. As many as 40 countries (of the 42 surveyed) had a charter in place, but only in 33% of these was it legally effective.

Countries like Belgium, Brazil, Chile, Italy, Kenya and Mexico have the charter as a part of their statute, akin to the proposal made by the finance minister. While Australia and Canada do have a charter in place, it doesn’t have the protection of an Act. The Netherlands, on the other hand, has avoided a charter altogether, claiming that taxpayers' rights are sufficiently recorded under various tax laws.

Sitharaman said that any tax system required trust between the taxpayers and the administration, adding that this could be possible only when the rights of the former were clearly enumerated.

Title: Budget 2020: New tax regime will save you hassle, not money
Content:
Nirmala Sitharaman (file photo)

GOVT MATH DOESN’T FULLY ADD UP, SAY EXPERTS

NEW DELHI: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday proposed to introduce new tax slabs with reduced rates for an annual income of up to Rs 15 lakh for those foregoing exemptions and deductions under a “simplified tax regime”. The new system is, however, optional and will co-exist with the old one with three slabs and various exemptions and deductions.Sitharaman said those availing of deductions and exemptions might choose to go for status quo and pay tax as per the old regime. If you are a businessman and opt for the new regime , you can go back to the old system, but only once. However, for the salaried, there is no such restriction.Sitharaman indicated that the government intended to remove all IT exemptions in the long run. She said the government had reviewed over 100 exemptions and deductions and removed around 70. “We will review and rationalise the remaining exemptions and deductions in the coming years with a view to further simplifying the tax system and lowering the tax rate,’’ she said.However, a lowering of the tax rates isn’t a win-win for all taxpayers. Simply put, the “simplified” tax regime is not that simple. For an annual income of up to Rs 6 lakh, the tax liability under the new regime will be higher than that in the old system. This is because a standard deduction of Rs 50,000 allowed earlier is missing under the new regime. Therefore, the tax liability will be the same in both systems only up to an annual income of Rs 6 lakh. For other slabs, even the statutory savings under Employees’ Provident Fund and life-insurance buys make the old system attractive due to the exemptions.For example, if X has a total income of Rs 7.5 lakh per annum (Rs 62,500 per month) with a monthly basic of Rs 40,000, his EPF deduction at the rate of 12% will be Rs 57,600.Now, if X buys an insurance policy with an annual premium of Rs 17,400 -- taking his total savings and investments to Rs 75,000 per annum -- his tax liability after standard deduction of Rs 50,000 in the old system will be the same as that under the new regime. Further, if X claims tax benefits against school fees, mediclaim or a housing loan, he will be better off in the old system due to the deductions allowed.Union Budget 2020: Full text of Nirmala Sitharaman's speechThe finance minister, in her speech, said a person earning Rs 15 lakh in a year and not availing of any deduction would pay only Rs 1,95,000 under the new regime compared with Rs 2,73,000 in the old system. Thus, his tax burden will be reduced by 78,000 under the new regime.Sitharaman argued that the person would still be the gainer under the new regime even if he was taking a deduction of Rs 1.5 lakh under various sections of Chapter-VI-A of the Income-Tax Act in the old system. But if a taxpayer buys a house taking a home loan, or invests in pension funds and mediclaim, his tax liability will be lower in the old system. If he could avail of a deduction of more than Rs 2,50,000, the old system will be beneficial for him.If a taxpayer in the highest tax bracket invests more than Rs 2.5 lakh in the allowed instruments under sections 24 (home loan), 80C (PF, insurance policy) and 80D (mediclaim), he will be better off sticking to the old system.Finance ministry has released calculations that show taxpayers could gain between 10,400 to 78,000 (annual taxable income 5 lakh to 15 lakh) a year if they move to the new no-exemption, no-deduction tax regime. Tax experts say the projected gains are exaggerated because they assume taxable income to remain the same once a taxpayer moves from the old system to the new. That can’t be. Under the new regime, taxable income will go up without any change in total income because all deductions and exemptions will become taxable. This will dilute the gains from lower rate and in some cases increase the tax liability.

Title: DDT spares firms, sprays investors
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The move to abolish dividend distribution tax , which was payable by India Inc , and taxing dividends in the hands of all shareholders, won’t hurt those who enjoy tax-free income up to Rs 5 lakh. However, it will pinch the pocket of rich shareholders. Dividends paid on and after April 1, 2020, will be taxed in the hands of shareholders at their applicable rate.

At present, shareholders earning dividend income of Rs 10 lakh or more have to bear a tax of 10% on such income, plus the applicable surcharge and cess. The dividend, no matter the quantum, is tax-free in the hands of foreign shareholders (but they don’t get a tax credit in their home country on the underlying tax).

Under the Budget proposals, a rich shareholder will find that against a tax rate of 10% on dividend income, the dividend gets added to his taxable income and is taxed at the applicable slab rate.

A person with a taxable income of between Rs 50 lakh and Rs 1 crore is subject to a tax rate of 34.32%.

Let us assume that X earned a taxable income of Rs 75 lakh, of which Rs 15 lakh is dividend income. Under the current provisions, a dividend of only Rs 5 lakh is taxed at a concessional rate of 10% plus applicable surcharge and cess.

Under the Budget proposals, they will end up paying a higher tax as the entire dividend income will be added to the total taxable income and be subject to the regular applicable tax rate. Thus, they will bear a higher tax burden of Rs 4.58 lakh on account of dividend income.

Currently, mutual funds are liable to pay DDT on equity and debt funds, but now investors have to pay tax on the dividend as per their income slabs. The same is true for those who choose the dividend reinvestment option.

Title: Many to miss out on ESOP relief
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

BENGALURU: Two major initiatives for startups in the Union Budget 2020 — relaxation in tax on employee stock options (ESOPs) and tax holiday on profits for startups — have both come under fire. The fine print of the Budget reveals they are only applicable to companies that qualify under Section 80-IAC, which may limit the benefit to only a few hundred startups formed after 2016. ESOPs and tax holiday exemptions only apply to about 200 startups recognised by inter-ministerial board.

“In order to give a boost to the startup ecosystem, I propose to ease the burden of taxation on employees by deferring the tax payment by five years or till they leave the company or when they sell their shares, whichever is earliest,” finance minister Niramala Sitharaman said while presenting the Budget.

ESOPs are currently taxed when they become eligible for allotment, which puts a financial burden on employees as they may not be able to sell them at the same time. Employees are also taxed twice, at the time of exercising and at the time of selling (capital gains tax). Startup lobby groups like IndiaTech, IVCA and LocalCircles had requested the government to simplify this by taxing ESOPs just at the time of liquidity or sale.

Sitharaman also eased norms for the three-year tax holiday on profits for startups, taking the turnover limit to Rs 100 crore from Rs 25 crore and the period during which it can be exercised to 10 years from 7 years. But Budget’s fine print states only 80-IAC startups can benefit from these measures. Over 27,000 startups are registered with the department for promotion of industry and internal trade (DPIIT).

The condition that employees pay taxes when they leave a company and a time limit of five years also restricts the benefit of the move. “If startups want to attract talent, it’s tougher to get it from larger startups (as employees have to pay tax on existing ESOPs if they leave). So in a way, negative impact for younger/smaller startups,” said Vivekananda Hallekare, founder of scooter-sharing startup Bounce. His startup, valued at $500 million recently, does not qualify as it was registered in 2014.

Optional trim

Startups had also asked for parity of long-term capital gains (LTCG) for unlisted shares, given that most companies are private, held by local funds with listed shares. While LTCG on listed shares stands at 10%, on unlisted it is at 20%.

The FM also announced several other new measures for startups, as she said the “Indian spirit of entrepreneurship which weathered several storms over the centuries inspire and motivate us. We recognise the need to support and further energise this spirit.”

These include plans to create digital platforms both for making registration of intellectual property rights (IPR) easy and also an investment clearance cell, which will provide information, support and permissions needed by the business at both the state and central levels. The government also plans to set up a seed fund to back idea-stage companies.

Title: Cheap homes stay cheap, but realty gets no real push
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo

The stagnant property market has little to cheer, except extension of tax sops for affordable homes.

The additional deduction of up to Rs 1.5 lakh for interest paid on loans taken for purchase of affordable homes has now been extended till March 31, 2021.

Currently, while taxing income from capital gains, business profits and other sources in respect of transactions in real estate, if the consideration value is less than the circle rate by more than 5%, the difference is counted as income, both in the hands of the purchaser and seller. This limit is proposed to be increased to 10%.

The tax holiday on profits earned by builders constructing affordable homes is also proposed to be extended by a year.

Satish Magar, president, CREDAI National, expressed his disappointment. “Budget 2020 has not been encouraging for the real estate sector, which needs immediate attention. Unfortunately, none of the issues like a one-time restructuring of loans and enhancement of tax deductions on home loan have been addressed, except the extension of a tax holiday for affordable housing developers and loan sanctioning.”

Niranjan Hiranandani, MD of Hiranandani Group, said: “Affordable housing remains the government’s favourite with previous tax exemptions for both homebuyers and developers being continued for one more year. Commercial real estate segments may also witness a boost, with the focus on warehousing, data centres, schools, hospitals and hospitality.’’

Title: Sending over 7 lakh abroad to face tax trauma
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

In a move that will block a big chunk of funds for those spending abroad, the government has announced a 5% tax collection at source (TCS) for remittances over Rs 7 lakh under the Liberalised Remittance Scheme.

The finance bill states that banks who receive Rs 7 lakh from an individual for remittance out of India under the LRS or from a seller of a tour package shall debit a sum equal to five percent of the remitted amount as income tax. In the 2016 budget, the government had put a similar 1% TCS for purchase of expensive cars. This TCS credit could be adjusted against the buyer’s income tax liability.

Indians have been sending on an average $1.5bn (Rs 10,700 crore) abroad every month under various heads including education, travel, purchase of immovable property, investment in equity/debt, gift/donations, maintenance of close relatives, and medical treatment. The LRS allows every individual to send up to $250000 abroad annually. The 5% TCS will enable the government collect $75 million in advance every month.

“So far there was no deduction of tax at source on remittances under the LRS. Now banks are required to collect tax at source on all remittances under LRS. If the remittance is to the senders own account, then they can claim credit for the tax. However, if it is paid to an overseas tour operator or an gift to a non-resident, the remitter will not get tax credit as the recipient would not be filing returns in India if they do not have any presence in India,” said Riaz Thingna Director, Grant Thornton Advisory

“Until now, tax collection at source provisions, which act as an additional tax on a transaction, are applied by the seller and recovered from the buyer in transactions such as purchase of alcohol, forest produce etc. These provisions are now widened to apply to LRS and the main reason is to create a tax trail for such remittances,” said Gaurav Mehndiratta , Partner - Corporate and International Tax , KPMG in India. He added that this would translate into additional compliance burden for the bankers and also result in working capital issues for the remitter till the time it is able to claim a credit of the same”

Unlike TDS which is deducted by the buyer, TCS is collected by a seller of specified goods from the buyer and the TCS is added to the sale amount and transferred to the government account.

Title: Exemption loss may wipe out your tax gains
Content: The new tax regime which offers concessional tax rates to individuals and HUFs on taxable income up to Rs. 15 lakh provided they forgo a plethora of tax exemptions, deductions and losses is as complicated as a millennial’s relationship status.Just look at the list of exemptions and deductions that go out if you opt for the new regime:· Standard Deduction· Leave Travel Concession· House Rent Allowance· Deduction under Section 80C i.e. equity linked savings scheme (ELSS), provident fund (PF), insurance premium, school fees, and principal repayment on housing loan.· Deductions under 80D for medical insurance and 80G for donations· Interest on Housing Loan· Food vouchers Rs 50 per meal· However, deductions such as per diems (daily allowance on travel) and employer’s contribution to National Pension System are still availableThe Finance Minister, in her speech mentioned that a person earning Rs 15 lakh in year and not availing any deduction will pay only Rs 1.95 lakh of tax, as compared to Rs 2.73 lakh. This is a saving of Rs 78,000.However, typically a salaried employee will be availing of a flat standard deduction of Rs 50,000. Plus, he or she will also have an HRA component, on which tax exemption can be availed if rent is paid. If the taxpayer is not on rent and has availed of a housing loan on self-occupied property, he or she can avail of principal as deduction from gross total income as well as tax benefits on interest paid. Even on rented property, interest can be set off against rental incomeand loss if any can be adjusted against any other head of income.

Title: In the dumps, FMCG hopes for a boost
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Income tax deductions for a section of salaried employees is expected to put more money in the hands of consumers, particularly the middle class. This could boost growth of fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) industry, which is confronted with sluggish growth.

Marico MD & CEO Saugata Gupta said the budget will lead to a gradual reversal in the prevailing slowdown. "It is expected to aid consumption at the mass end, however, this will depend on how many taxpayers will opt for the new regime," he said.

"I foresee that these measures will amplify growth within the sector and encourage its revival,” said Parle Products senior category head Mayank Shah.

Allocation of funds to rural development, too, would boost rural growth in the long term, said Godrej Consumer Products MD & CEO Vivek Gambhir .

Title: Sitharaman levies ‘make-in-India’ duty on made-in-China products
Content: NEW DELHI: The government has clearly signaled that it’s willing to walk the talk about ‘Make in India’. Boosting localisation in consumer categories is a priority from a policy perspective as protecting the domestic industry from low-cost imports , much of it from China, is seen as a positive for local players. It would also help boost employment, an imperative in poor job environment.“Measures have been taken for providing a level-playing field to our domestic manufacturers, particularly the MSME sector … The provisions for checking dumping of goods and imports of subsidized goods are also being strengthened for ensuring a level-playing field for domestic industry,” the FM said in her Budget speech.In the near term this means the price of imported daily-use items such as shelled walnuts, peanut butter , shavers, hair dryers, table and kitchenware, footwear, kids toys and even electric cars and two-wheelers will rise as the customs duty on these and many more have been increased (see table) quite substantially. The hikes could range from a few hundred rupees in case of certain items to well over thousands for items like an electric cars and bigger green buses.“Labour intensive sectors in MSME are critical for employment generation. Cheap and low-quality imports are an impediment to their growth,” the FM said.The localisation drive was also strengthened on the high-volume mobile phones category where components such as printed circuit boards, fingerprint scanners, display panels, and ringers also saw the import duty go up. However, industry players said that prices would not see much of an impact as investments are already underway for making them here. “This is in line with the phased manufacturing plan (PMP) and we don’t expect any major impact on retail prices,” said Pankaj Mohindroo , president of India Cellular and Electronics Association (ICEA).Panasonic India MD Manish Sharma said products such as hair dryers, shavers, and trimmers could now be made in India as companies take steps to cut costs.On the electric vehicles category, companies are not happy with the customs hike as they feel that it has come in too early as local suppliers are yet to firm up. “We feel that the customs duty hike on electrics assembled in India is a bit harsh, as this may impact the nascent category which was beginning to expand off late," Rajeev Chaba , MD of MG Motors India (which launched ZS electric), said.

Title: Nirmala’s changes not mutually beneficial
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Mutual fund managers want to see implementation of the Budget proposals for the economy to be back on growth track while they feel that the FM’s proposal to do away with exemptions in favour of lower income tax rates may hamper household savings.

Nilesh Shah, MD & CEO, Kotak Mahindra MF said that the budget was good on intent. “However, the key is efficient execution in a time-bound manner. There are many positives to simplify things and encourage entrepreneurs but again, key will be execution in a time-bound manner. Intent needs to be converted into implementation,” Shah said.

Fund houses are guarded on their reaction to FM’s proposal on cut in number of tax exemptions. At present investments of up to Rs 1.5 lakh per year in ELSS by fund houses qualify for tax exemptions under section 80cc under the tax laws. “The personal tax reductions was well intentioned but the flip side is that removal of exemptions could have negative implications for savings” said Navneet Munot , ED & CIO, SBI MF.

As of December 2019, going by assets under management (AUM), ELSS was the third largest among equity fund categories, contributing nearly Rs 1 lakh crore to total segment AUM of Rs 15.5 lakh crore.

Title: Tallah closure Day 1: Traffic chokes north Kolkata roads, kids take over bridge
Content:
Demolition work on Tallah Bridge on Saturday.

TimesView Hopefully, these are teething problems and will be sorted out by the first weekday. Neither the traffic department nor the transport department is responsible for this but both will have to work together to mitigate commuters’ problems.

KOLKATA: On the first day of the Tallah Bridge shutdown vast parts of north Kolkata were choked with traffic snarls. As earth-moving machines were put to work on the Shyambazar-bound flank of Tallah Bridge, the cars in the area barely managed to inch forward — with the snarls stretching almost a kilometre at times.
