The travel time doubled or tripled even for short distances.The bitter experience on Saturday morning has sent cops to the drawing board — from Monday, truck movement on BT Road-Khagen Chatterjee Road-Cossipore Road-Dum Dum Road will be stopped throughout the day. The biggest challenge, said cops, was to educate motorists on the alternative routes.Around 11am, it took 40 minutes for a TOI team to travel from Sinthi crossing to Chiria More on a bus. Similarly, the journey from Neelgunj Depot to RG Kar Hospital through Raja Manindra Road and Belgachhia Road took another 35 minutes. During non-peak hours, around 12.30pm, the tail of the snarl at Lock Gate Flyover reached Fariapukur-Madanmohantala and the tail of the jam at Belgachhia bridge went up to Milk Colony bus stand at 2pm. Traffic movement remained slow around Ultadanga, Hatibagan, Shyambazar, Khanna crossing and pockets of Dum Dum and Lake Town.“It usually takes me around 10 minutes to take my daughter to Bagbazar Multipurpose School on my two-wheeler. On Saturday, it took me 40 minutes,” said Ravik Banerjee, a banker. “It took me two-and-a-half hours to complete a bus trip from Nowapara to Dharmatala,” said Arup Chowdhury, owner of a bus on route 34C.Auto drivers made the most of the situation. They offered shuttle services between Chiria More and Bagbazar via Cossipore Road and between Chiria More and Shyambazar via RG Kar. Passengers were asked to shell out anything between Rs 30-Rs 50 with the journey time ranging between 70 minutes in the morning and 30 minutes in the evening.On the closed bridge, local kids played football and cricket while a few pedestrians walked over the structure. Cops said they will stop pedestrian movement on the bridge after midnight when specialized machines will be operated.Over 100 cops were deployed to manage Saturday’s traffic. They said too many vehicles at both Chiria More and Belgachhia Road led to the gridlock. In a bid to avoid snarls on Raja Manindra Road, many buses took Indra Biswas Road with cars, choking both avenues. “This is going to be a major challenge in the coming days,” said a cop.

Title: Bharuch nagarpalika tanker hits a 10-year old boy to death
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Surat: A 10-year-old boy was killed and other seriously injured when a speeding water tanker of the Bharuch Nagarpalika rammed into the bicycle the duo was riding on Saturday morning.

Jairajsinh Chauhan, 10, a resident of Narayan nagar in Bharuch town went on a bicycle ride with his friend Jian Jadhav, after returning home from school. While Jairajsinh was riding the bicycle, Jian was riding pillion when the speeding tanker hit the duo near the traffic intersection at Sambhu Dairy in Bharuch town.

Police sources said that the children were immediately rushed to the New Civil Hospital where Jairajsinh was declared dead on admission. Jian is still fighting for his life.

Bharuch town police have registered a case of accident and arrested the driver, Gopal Narayan Solanki.

Talking to TOI, chief officer of Bharuch Nagarpalika, Sanjay Soni said, “The area where the accident took place remains congested throughout the day. Thus, there is no question of over-speeding by the vehicle. We gathered information from the accident spot and found out that the boys lost balance and fell down from their bicycle and got injured in the rear wheels of the tanker.”

Soni added, “Once the police investigation is over, we will order inquiry into the entire incident. Our deep sympathy is with the bereaved family. We will also urge the state R&B department to construct a speed breaker near the intersection to avert such accidents as the road where the accident took place falls under the department.”

Title: Directionless with no action plan: Congress
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: The Union budget is directionless and a total disappointment for Goa, which is facing distress due to the closure of mining, Congress said on Saturday.

State Congress president Girish Chodankar said that the Budget was “all talk” with “no plan for concrete action” that could revive the country’s sluggish economy.

“This lacklustre budget gives full confidence that the government has given up its efforts to revive the economy. Budget is anti-common man, considering reduced food subsidy and fertiliser subsidy and slashing budget on mid-day meals and MGNREGA scheme,” he said.

The Congress described the Budget as “utterly directionless and depressing” as it failed to address the woes of the mining and tourism dependant families.

“The mining industry continues to be in total distress and there is no indication of any package for mining dependants, nor to the state. Our declining tourism sector continues to be directionless in the absence of any meaningful support from the Budget,” party spokesperson Tulio De Souza said.

Congress said that the Centre also failed to provide impetus for the housing industry, employment, and honest taxpayers. “Honest tax payers have lost all hopes of either higher deductions and lowering of tax burden. The Budget has punished them,” Chodankar said.

“Goa’s BJP CM has also failed to get any new projects sanctioned for Goa,” Chodankar said.

Title: Limbayat rioters were carrying stones as planned
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Surat: Police investigation the incident of rioting and stone pelting on cops in Limbayat area has revealed that the attack on cops was planned by the accused well in advance.

The rioters were carrying stones with them, in their pockets and hand, with an aim to help spread violence. The accused started pelting stones when the police tried to stop the protestors from entering the area where shops were open on Wednesday during Bharat Bandh call was given in protest of CAA and NRC.

Initially police booked the accused for rioting but detailed investigation revealed that it was a pre-planned conspiracy. Police have so far arrested 18 people, including the key conspirator Ansar Ehmad Ramjan Ali Qureshi, 25, a labourer. A native of Khagrelu in Fatehpur district of Uttar Pradesh, Qureshi works in a metal fabrication unit.

“It was Ansar who called everyone to gather in a lane near Madina Mosque and provoked the protesters to carry out a march to the neighbouring areas dominated by other communities and where shops were open as usual. They wanted to force these shops to down shutters,” said a police officer supervising the investigation.

Before the group could make a move, a police patrolling team reached the spot and dispersed the crowd. “After a while Ansar provoked the group again to move forward. Police tried to stop them but they continued shouting slogans and pushed the cops. Taking advantage of the situation some persons also pelted stones on the cops,” the officer informed.

So far police found that Ansar called the accused personally to spot. Police are also checking mobile phones of the accused to find out if they shared any provocative messages to encourage youth to join in the protest. “There were no stones lying in the street where the crowd was stopped by police. They must be carrying stones in pocket or hand,” police informed.

An assistant sub inspector suffered injury on the head in the incident while police booked a group of around 200 for rioting.

It should be noted that for the past three decades Limbayat has remained a communally sensitive area and police station was attacked in the past too. Even the murder of Kamlesh Tiwari, leader of Hindu Samaj Party, in Lucknow in October 2019 was planned in Limbayat.

Title: Cooperative sector not enthused by tax reduction
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Surat: Cooperative banks in south Gujarat play a crucial role in the rural economy of the region as they provide finance at low rate to small businessmen. Thus, the proposal of Union Budget 2020-21 to reduce tax on cooperative societies to 22 per cent from 30 per cent will help banks in cooperative sector a great deal.

Surat District Cooperative Bank (SDCB) with annual business of about Rs8,300 crore earns a profit of approximately Rs85 crore. In 2019-20 it paid tax at the rate of 30 per cent which amounts to Rs21 crore. In the new financial year, with the same profit it needs to pay only Rs20 crore as tax.

SDCB director Dilip Bhakta said, “Yes, there will be some benefit because of tax reduction, but it remains to be seen how much? Exempting cooperative societies from alternative minimum tax (AMT) is a good step, but the amount of benefit is not enough. Will these help create a level playing field for cooperative banks vis-à-vis the private sector financial institutions? It is highly doubtful.”

SDCB chairman Naresh Patel said, “We welcome reduction in tax, but increase in depositor insured amount from Rs1 lakh to Rs5 lakh will make us pay higher premium to Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation. This will eat away whatever we will save from reduction in tax.”

If a bank saves Rs2 crore tax but has to pay Rs2.5 crore in premium for depositors assured money, it is like giving from one hand and taking away from another, a cooperative bank officer said.

SV Chaudhary, managing director of SUMUL Dairy, said, “Things are not clear but will be once notification comes. At present, full rebate is given to business of a cooperative society with another. Full tax rebate was given under AMT. For such transactions, there is no benefit now. Why should cooperatives opt for 22 per cent tax regime when they don’t pay anything under 30 per cent structure with all deductions and rebates?”

Title: Gujarat: Rape-murder convict to challenge death penalty in apex court
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo of convict Anil Yadav who raped, killed a three-year-old girl.

Title: Bihar: Kanhaiya Kumar’s convoy attacked in Saran
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kanhaiya Kumar

PATNA: The convoy of former JNU Students’ Union president Kanhaiya Kumar was attacked in Saran district on Saturday. Two of the vehicles in his convoy were damaged when a group of unidentified people pelted stones near Kopa Chatti village under Kopa police station around 12.30pm. Windscreens of the vehicles were also smashed in the incident.

Kanhaiya, who is spearheading an anti-CAA-NRC yatra from Bhitiharwa Ashram in West Champaran in the state, was on way to Chhapra to address a public meeting. There were altogether 12 vehicles in the CPI leader’s convoy. The yatra is to conclude at Patna’s Gandhi Maidan on February 29.

Chhapra Sadar SDPO Ajay Kumar said a man travelling in the convoy received minor injuries in his hands. The police team, which was assigned to escort Kanhaiya, intervened and chased the attackers, who were shouting pro-CAA slogans. The SDPO said Kanhaiya escaped unhurt in the incident. A complaint was lodged in connection with the incident, he added.

Earlier, Ajay Singh, husband of JD(U) MP from Siwan, Kavita Singh, was detained at Dahiawa Tola as a precautionary measure. Singh, who had unsuccessfully contested assembly byelection from Daraundha in Siwan district last year, is considered to be a potential threat for Kanhaiya on his political turf.

Later, Kanhaiya addressed the public gathering at Hawai Adda Maidan in Chhapra where he assailed the Narendra Modi government for making certain amendments to the citizenship Act. Kanhaiya also urged Bihar CM Nitish Kumar to pass a resolution in the state assembly against the CAA and NRC to uphold the secular outlook and fabric of the county.

Earlier, Kanhaiya was greeted with ‘Go back, Kanhaiya’ slogans in Gopalganj where he had gone to address a public meeting as part of his ‘Save the Constitution Yatra’ launched from Champaran. On Friday, he was in Siwan from where he had left for Chhapra. On Saturday, he later went to Muzaffarpur to address another meeting against CAA-NRC.

Title: Gujarat: Minor boy steals revolver, cartridges from parked car
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: An 11-year-old boy was detained on Saturday for stealing a revolver and cartridges from a businessman’s parked car on Vasna Road. Two more men have been declared wanted in this connection.

The prevention of crime branch (PCB) detained the boy near Gotri water tank looking at his suspicious behaviour. On checking his handbag, sleuths were surprised to find Rs 10,220 in cash, two mobile phones, three wrist watches and gold and silver ornaments. “We had a rough sketch of a boy made from the CCTV camera footage after the revolver was stolen. Since the boy’s behaviour seemed very suspicious and his face too matched the sketch, we checked his bag and brought him to the police station,” said inspector M V Bhagora of PCB.

The boy later admitted of being involved in breaking the window of the parked car and stealing the weapon along with the cartridges from the car. The boy said he used a catapult to break the widow glass and unlock the car. He told cops that two others – Pawan Jawad and Ajay Naade – planned such thefts and used to take him along.

“To avoid suspicion the duo used the boy as a cover for their nefarious activities. The boy would take out valuables from the cars and pass it on to Jawad and Naade and the trio would leave the area in separate autorickshaws,” said Bhagora. He added that after reaching the target site, the trio would not talk to each other verbally, but signal through eye contact.

Although the minor boy has been detained, the search for the two kingpin is on as the stolen revolver has not yet been recovered. Besides breaking the car’s window on Vasna Road, the trio had also attempted theft from another car near Golden Chowkdi. Police said that the minor boy was detained earlier in Ahmedabad twice for similar offences.

The revolver and cartridges belonged to a businessman identified as Ajitsinh Solanki and was stolen from the parking lot of Pancham Icon Complex last weekend.

Title: Denied Rs 25,000, man kills wife in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

BEGUSARAI/PATNA: A 24-year-old man killed his wife in Begusarai district late Friday night after she refused to give him Rs 25,000 to buy a cellphone. Police said that Vikrant Paswan assaulted his 20-year-old wife Kajal Kumari at Paswan Tola under Khodabandhpur police station around midnight.

The couple had heated argument over the issue in the evening. But Vikrant woke up around midnight and strangled Kajal. He hanged the body from the ceiling fan to make it appear to be a case of suicide. Vikrant, a daily wager, escaped. Kajal, who belonged to Sakh Mohan village in neighbouring Samastipur district, had got married to Vikrant in 2018.

Khodabandhpur SHO Dinesh Kumar said a complaint was lodged against Vikrant and his mother Neelam Devi had been arrested. Kajal’s mother Sheela Devi has accused her son-in-law of harassing her daughter for dowry.

In another incident, one Monu Kumar was shot dead by unidentified criminals near Batika Chowk under Phulwaria police outpost late Friday night. Police said Monu, a student of an engineering college in Purnia, was attacked when he had gone to attend a feast at his friend’s house on the occasion of Saraswati Puja.

SHO Jyoti Kumar said Monu’s father Ramdev Mandal is a native of Bhagalpur district and employed with railways. He lives with his family in Garhara Railway Colony in Begusarai.

On Friday evening, one Hema Maurya was gunned down when she had gone to attend the idol immersion in the Gandak canal. A case was lodged with the Naokothi police station in connection with the incident.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Youth held for derogatory post on religion
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: People of Muslim community blocked the road and staged a massive demonstration in Saiyyedraja market under the same police station in Chandauli district on Saturday demanding the arrest of a local youth Vikky Keshari for allegedly posting derogatory remarks on their religion.

The stir was called off after Saiyyedraja police lodged a case against Keshari under sections of IT Act and arrested him. SO Saiyyedraja Santosh Kumar Rai said that Keshari has been arrested and matter is being investigated.

Noticing some objectionble post on Kehari’s social media account, people of Muslim community reached Saiyyedraja police station and demanded action against him.

The police assured them and promised to initiate appropriate action. However, alleging delay in initiating action, they staged a massive demonstration.

Title: Luxury bus rams into 2 motorcycles; 2 dead, 4 injured
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The bus was trying to overtake another bus at Anaval–Mahua Highway

Surat: Two motorcyclists died on the spot when a private luxury bus hit their bikes head on at Anaval–Mahua state highway in Surat district some 50 km off Surat city. In the accident that took place on Saturday morning, four more persons including a woman were seriously injured after the driver of the bus, trying to overtake another bus , collided with the bikes .

The dead were identified as Satyen Hasmukh Patel, 27, of Vehval village in Surat district and Kishor Gaman Patel, 25, of Gangadia village in Surat district. The injured include Hasmukh and Partima Patel parents of Satyen who were riding pillion with Satyen. The trio works as mason and were going for work. The other injured people are Lalji Chima Patel and Jignesh K Patel who were riding pillion with Kishor Patel. While three injured are being treated in a private hospital in Navsari, the fourth one had to be shifted to a hospital in Surat.

According to Mahua police, the driver and a conductor of Patel travels Bardoli was taking the empty bus to collect passengers on Saturday morning in the outskirts of Tarkani village near Anaval. Here, the driver tried to overtake another bus from the wrong side it collided head on with the two bikes coming in the opposite direction.

Local people who gathered on the spot shifted the victims to the hospital and an angry mob started to pelt stones on the luxury bus breaking its window panes and front glass. However, police reached the spot and controlled the situation.

“The driver and the conductor of the bus fled the spot after the accident. But we will nab them soon,” said the police and added, “The accident was apparently caused by speed and overtaking from the wrong side. We will bring the guilty to books.”

Title: Eatery owner, stabbed by four miscreants, dies in Limbayat
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Surat: A roadside eatery owner , who was stabbed by four persons on the night of January 26, died during treatment in a hospital in the early hours of Saturday. The attackers had refused to pay money for the food they consumed at the eatery following which a fight started between them.

Bhargav Chaudhary, 32, a resident of Khodiyar Nagar, was stabbed with a sharp-edged weapon by one of them. This led to heavy bleeding and an internal injury to him, police informed.

Friends and family members of Chaudhary on Saturday held a protest on road outside his house alleging that police didn’t book the accused on attempt to murder charge initially. They had registered the offence under IPC sections 324 (voluntarily causing hurt by dangerous weapon), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 506(2) (criminal intimidation) among others.

“Police had already submitted a report in court after registering the offence. The accused were booked for attempt to murder. We arrested three accused on the day of crime and one on Saturday,” said a police officer at Limbayat police station.

Those arrested earlier were Sumit Gupta, 23, Dipak Mishra, 23 and Vishal Upadhyay, 20. They do petty jobs to earn their livelihood. Dipak Pande, 18, was arrested on Saturday. “Pande had stabbed the victim with a knife,” said police.

In his complaint registered at Limbayat police station soon after he was attacked, Chaudhary alleged that the accused refused to pay after eating Chinese food at his eatery in Shreeji Arcade at around 11.30pm on January 26.

The accused attacked eatery employees and Chaudhary as well when asked to pay for the food. They also ransacked the food cart and damaged the furniture as well.

Title: RTI activist, who protested against illegal sand mining, found dead in Kendrapada
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kendrapada: A 40-year-old RTI activist was found dead in Kendrapada early on Saturday. Police suspect that Ranjan Kumar Das, convener of the district unit of Odisha Suchana Adhikar Abhijan, was killed by some miscreants on Friday night. His body was found on a road in Berua village under Marsaghai police station in the district. It bore several injury marks.

“A case has been registered under Section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code. We have formed a special team to investigate the case. We had also pressed a sniffer dog into service during investigation,” Rajiv Lochan Panda, the subdivisional police officer (SDPO), Kendrapada, said.

Many social workers and RTI activists too suspect that he might have been killed as he had raised his voice against illegal sand quarrying, brick kiln owners and some allegedly venal NGOs and officials in the district and its nearby areas.

An RTI inquiry filed by him two years ago had exposed the illegal construction of a tourist resort by government-run Odisha Tourism Development Corporation (OTDC) in Kendrapada’s Bhitarkanika National Park. Das had brought to the fore the brazen violation of law by OTDC in building a tourist resort in the park’s core area where no such construction is allowed.

“Last year, Das had blown the lid off the embezzlement of about Rs 25 lakh of the integrated coastal zone management (ICZM) funds by an NGO in the district in a clear nexus with the forest officials of the Bhitarkanika National Park by not planting mangrove trees in the forest,” Amarabara Biswal of Kendrapada, said.

Police have seized Das’s body and sent it to the SCB Medical College and Hospital in Cuttack for autopsy.

Pradeep Pradan, the state convener of Odisha Suchana Adhikar Abhijan; Chitta Ranjan Behera an RTI activist and adviser to the Odisha Suchana Adhikar Abhijan; senior advocate Sudhir Mohanty and other RTI activists rushed to Kendrapada to offer their condolences to the Das’s parents, his wife and other relatives at Talasanga village.

“On December 10 last year, RTI activist Abhimanyu Panda (54), who was spearheading an anti-liquor movement was shot dead in broad daylight at Baliguda in Kandhamal district. In 2015, two RTI activists Krupasinghu Sahoo and another one from Niali block in Cuttack district were also killed. In 2014, RTI activist Ganesh Panda was killed,” Pradeep Pradhan the state convener of Odisha Suchana Adhikar Abhijan, said.

Title: Disappointing budget, says Cong
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: The state Congress slammed the Union Budget claiming that it is disappointing and will fail to solve the unemployment problem. Finance minister Tarun Bhanot said, “The budget is very disappointing and the announcements made by Nirmala Sitaraman will make the unemployment situation more critical. Modi government has reduced state’s share of central taxes and more than Rs 14,000 crore has been reduced. The Centre’s improper imposition of GST is causing distress to the states”.

Law minister PC Sharma said that the Union government is just copying the schemes of the Kamal Nath government. “Despite their tall claims inflation and poverty has not decreased. Till the time prices of petrol and diesel do not reduce, I will never accept that inflation is under control”, he said. Revenue minister Govind Singh Rajput said that the budget has failed to address the problems of poverty and inflation. “Smart City work is terribly slow. Farmers are our food growers and so far, the Centre has only indulged in politics over the agrarian community. Many schemes have been announced for farmers but they haven’t yeilded any result. Manmohan Singh government gave Rs 7,000 crore to Madhya Pradesh as Bundelkhand development package which was misappropriated. The Modi government only diverts attention from real issues. They promised 2 crore job creation per year but in the past six years no employment has been generated”, he said.

Slamming the budget, higher education minister Jeetu Patwari said, “Inflation and unemployment are increasing. Prices of petrol and cooking gas have increased and food prices have gone up. So how has inflation come down? In the name of budget, the Modi government is cheating the people. The government is more engaged in dividing the nation and selling the country’s assets to private players”. State Congress media cell chairperson Shobha Oza said, “It is an extremely disappointing budget . The longest budget speech had no announcements regarding how to arrest the sinking economy, farmer distress and increasing unemployment. The budget should have explained how and why Air India, Indian Railways, LIC, Bharat Petroleum and IDBI have come to a stage when they have to be sold.” State Congress spokesman Durgesh Sharma said, “People of this country were expecting that the annual budget will try to address the falling economy. But it is still the old Modi story – sell LIC, sell IDBI, decrease subsidies on fertilisers for farmers and no control over shooting prices of fuel. Such a long budget speech. It is true that empty vessels make the most noise. Today’s budget proved the idiom right”.

Title: Bihar: Angry villagers torch shop, vehicles over land dispute
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A group of villagers torched a shop selling construction materials and set four vehicles parked in front of it on fire at Neori village under the Bihta police station area in western Patna on Saturday. The villagers alleged that one Mahesh Yadav was running the shop from government land.

According to locals, Mahesh had opened the shop at the disputed site after entering into an agreement with an ex-serviceman, who had identified himself as the owner of the land. The villagers had asked Mahesh several times to vacate the land, but to no avail.

Senior police officers rushed to the spot after the incident to bring situation under control. Neora police outpost incharge Santosh Kumar said a tractor, an SUV, an autorickshaw and a bike were torched by the villagers.

“At least five people have been detained in connection with the violence,” Kumar said, adding raids were on to arrest those involved in the incident.

Bihta circle officer S K Verma said Mahesh had submitted documents to prove his claim that the then ADM (law and order) had made settlement of the land in favour the ex-serviceman in 1966. “He had attempted to fill up a portion of land after which an encroachment case was registered against him,” he said.

Verma said he had written to deputy collector (land reforms) recently to raise the issue with the present ADM (law and order). “We will now write to the local police to enforce prohibitory orders on the disputed plot,” he added.

Title: Start plastic waste-to-fuel plant by May 15, high court of Bombay at Goa warns contractor
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The contractor has already been paid Rs 8.3 crore by the government to set up the plant, the high court noted

PANAJI: Observing that the contractor, M K Aromatics Ltd, has not been able to set up a plastic waste-to-fuel plant at Pernem within the stipulated timeframe, the high court of Bombay at Goa directed the state to encash the contractor’s Rs 1 crore bank guarantee. It also directed the contractor to get the plant operational by May 15.

The high court also directed the contractor to deposit a fresh bank guarantee of Rs 2 crore within 15 days.

M K Aromatics will deposit Rs 2 crore as guarantee in a nationalised bank within 15 days in favour of Goa State Urban Development Agency (GSUDA), the agency overseeing the implementation of the project, its counsel A D Bhobe told the court.

“This statement is accepted as an undertaking to this court,” the division bench of justices M S Sonak and M S Jawalkar observed, adding, “if the guarantee is not furnished within 15 days, we will be left with no option but to consider taking action for the breach of undertaking solemnly given to this court.”

The court noted that “if the plant is not made operational by May 15, GSUDA will have absolute unqualified and irrevocable rights to invoke the bank guarantee without any necessity of issuing notice to the contractor.”

The court directed the state government and GSUDA to mention this matter in case of any difficulties in encashing the bank guarantee.

The contract for setting up the said plant was awarded to M K Aromatics Ltd, on November 11, 2014 and the work was to be completed on August 10, 2015.

The bench noted that the government extended a loan of over Rs 6.3 crore to the contractor, when it was in need of such a plant. “The loan was made repayable in instalment only upon the plant being made operational, which we regard as quite easy terms,” the court observed.

“Further Rs 2 crore was paid to this contractor. This means the contractor, as of date, has received an amount of Rs 8.3 crore,” court noted.

In terms of the original work order, the plant was to be made operational on August 10, 2015. However, the contractor stated that the Pernem Municipal Council and the locals at the site didn’t allow the works to proceed at the desired pace.

An MoU was signed between the government and the Pernem Municipal Council to resolve the issues. Based on the same, there was a revision in the schedule and the contractor had to complete the works by March 31, 2017. Even this was not complied with by the contractor, the court observed.

Title: Four new parks on Tapi riverbank
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Eight spots along the Tapi Riverfront have been identified to turn water hyacinth waste into manure

Surat: Four new river parks will be set up on the banks of river Tapi in Surat city and district in the next six months. More than one lakh trees will also be planted to increase the green cover in city. The work to be done under Tapi River rejuvenation Project will carried out with grants from National River Conservation Project (NRCP).

Apart from this, heavy plantation drive will be carried out on the riverbank at six places and eight vermicompost plants will also be set up. These parks will come up near Shiv Mandir at Bhairav at the cost of Rs 67 lakh, at Bhimnath temple in Dungra at the cost of Rs 82 lakh, at Galteswar bank at the cost of Rs 1.38 crore and at Waghecha at the cost of Rs 92 lakh.

These six spots are used by people largely for picknicking purposes while incidents of drowning in the river are also very high on these particular spots. “The idea is to develop these spots with green cover and provide people a safe venue for a one-day outing.” said an official from SMC.

SMC will also carry out a big plantation drive on the banks of Tapi River at Katargam and Sarthana water works in city besides Valak, Kamrej, Kholwad and Kathor in Surat district. More than 50,000 trees will be planted at these spots.

Under Tapi Shuddhikaran project, eight vermicompost plants will be set up in coming six months, of which six will be in SMC and two in Surat Urban Development Authority (SUDA) areas.

“The plan is to gather water hyacinth from the river and take these to the plant sites where the weed waste will be turned into vermicompost manure,” said an executive engineer from SMC.

Municipal Commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani said, “The creation of green space in and around city will create a healthier living environment for people and wherever we have the opportunity and space we will develop more such parks and green areas for people’s benefit.”

Title: Balasore boy gets tea party invite from Prez
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Balasore: A Class VII student from Madhupara in Basta block of Balasore district has been invited by President Ram Nath Kovind to attend a tea party in New Delhi, scheduled to be held in March or April.

Biplab Kumar Ghosh (12), son of Sushanta Kumar Ghosh from Madhupara, received the invitation from the President’s office for his innovation in the field of agriculture.

He studies in Upendra Nath Nodal Upper Primary School.

Biplab, with the help of his teachers and some of his classmates, invented a solar-run farming equipment that will make farming less labour-intensive and help save time.

Biplab said, “I used to see my father working in the fields all through the day under the scorching heat of the sun. It was then that I had made up my mind to create a machine that will help my father in farming.” He added, “I later decided to make a machine that will save time, reduce labour and cut down other expenses as well.”

Biplab took the help of his teachers and some classmates to come up with the innovative multi-tasking machine by spending Rs 10,000.

Called Seeds and Fertilizer, the machine can do six different works simultaneously. They include preparation of land before sowing seeds, ploughing, sprinkling water and pesticides, sowing seeds and applying manure, he said

Biplab had showcased his invention at the district-level, state-level and national-level science exhibition and won medals for the same. He was recently felicitated with the INSPIRE Award MANAK (Million Minds Augmenting National Aspirations and Knowledge).

Chinmay Kumar Nanda, headmaster-in-charge of the Upendra Nath Nodal school, said, “The machine designed by Biplab was among the seven projects to be selected for INSPIRE Awards MANAK. It will run on solar energy and help save time and expenses.”

Notably, the Innovation in Science Pursuit for Inspired Research (INSPIRE) scheme is one of the flagship programmes of the department of science & technology (DST). The scheme aims to motivate students in the age group of 10 to 15 years and studying in Classes VI to X.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Afghan man held with fake documents from passport office
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Fake voter ID of Abid

VARANASI: An Afghan national Ibadatullah alias Abid was held from passport office in Mahmoorganj area under the limits of Bhelupur police station with fake Aadhar and voter identity cards. He was nabbed by the police while trying to procure Indian passport with fake documents , arranged by one Alam of Phoolpur area in Azamgarh district.

Alam was taken under custody on Saturday, said SP city Dinesh Kumar Singh adding that police are now probing as to how he managed to arrange fake documents.

According to the police, Abid, along with a youth, reached shops providing services of filling on-line application for the passpor, near passport office on Friday afternoon. As he could not speak English or Hindi properly, the shop keepers guided him to passport office. As he reached the passport office, the employees found his activities doubtful and alerted the police.

The police reached there and arranged a translator after Abid’s name and nationality became clear. The officials of anti-terror squad and other agencies also joined the police in interrogation. During initial interrogation Abid divulged that he had become friend of Alam through Facebook and later reached India on January 11 to meet him as he was interested in seeing urban and rural lifestyle of India.

He also divulged that his Aadhar and voter ID card was arranged by Alam. On Saturday, the police raided Alam’s place in Phoolpur area and took him under custody for further investigation. Police initially recovered the passport-visa of Abid in Azamgarh, said Singh. On being interrogated, Alam divulged that Abid was interested in getting an Indian passport for which minimum two documents, of nationality and other details of individuals is a must.

He revealed that on finding out that one Mohd Javed of his village had never applied for passport, Alam got voter ID card in the name of Javed along with his personal details using Abid’s photograph, said Singh adding, that on the basis of the same voter ID card he got Aadhar card for Abid.

The role of the staff and officials concerned is also being investigated, said Singh. After initial investigation, an FIR would be lodged against Abid, Alam and those, involved in enbling them to procure voter ID and Aadhar cards, he said.

Title: As fee hike protest rages on, AU alumni allege receiving crumpled certificates
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: As protest over fee hike rages on at Andhra University , a new problem has come to fore. Several alumni , who have joined the protest, have related the ordeal they faced to obtain their certificates and many of them said they received creased certificates.

A case in point would be Poonam (name changed), who has joined the students’ sit in and held up her crumpled certificates. Poonam told TOI that she paid Rs 1,200 for the original degree certificate and Rs 800 for her consolidated mark sheet. But when she received them, they were completely creased. “My Class X, XII and degree certificates are much better and I didn’t even pay anything for them.”

Ujwal Surampalli, another AU alumnus, who graduated in 2014, said, “I received my original degree and other certificates in an A4 envelope, which was all crumpled and damaged,” said Ujwal, who has a startup now.

Another student who completed her postgraduation in 2016, Apeksha, said “I was told to get a no-due certificate from the department library, central library and hostel (although I was not a hosteller). As per norms, I had to submit a DD of Rs 100 to the principal’s office. After the payment, when I went to get the no-due certificate, I was forced to pay Rs 100 to the hostel warden and another Rs 100 to the library staff. Upon questioning, I was told that if I wanted to get my work done, I needed to pay.”

Speaking to TOI, K Kumar Raja, lifetime academic senate member of AU, said, “It must be ensured that degree certificates are properly sent with the required protection. Most of the universities and institutions usually use hard board or thermocol sheets sto support important documents so that they are not damaged while being posted.”

“If the certificates are crumpled and if they are presented for job interviews, they would reflect on the candidate’s attitude. This issue will be discussed in our next meeting,” said Kumar Raja, who is also the founder-member and joint secretary of Andhra University Alumni Association. On contacting V Krishna Mohan, the registrar, he said, “Usually, the certificates are packed properly and are despatched by registered post. However, we regret the inconvenience caused. The students will be contacted by our controller.”

Title: Bondvoll lake gets 3 ‘wetland mitras’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: As Bondvoll lake is in the final stages of becoming first officially notified wetland in Goa, the Goa State Biodiversity Board (GSBB) on Saturday appointed the first three ‘wetland mitra’ under a central programme to look after the protection and management of lake.

Under the programme, citizens are appointed to work as wetland mitra on a voluntary basis. GSBB member secretary Pradip Sarmokadam said that work has already begun to get 35 other areas notified as wetland.

Naresh D’Souza, Elsa Fernandes and Lucio Rego from Santa Cruz will now work as ‘wetland mitra’ for preservation and management of Bondvoll lake for an initial period of two years. They were officially handed over their badges on Saturday.

“The National Institute of Oceanography (NIO) is carrying out the work of identifying wetlands in the state. But we have already identified as many as 35 wetlands on the ground. But there is a lengthy process to be completed for their notification. A document has to be created on the wetland and its biodiversity, but is requires detailed data,” Sarmokadam said during an event organised by GSBB and Goa state wetland authority to observe World Wetland Day.

He said that GSBB is also going about the process of notification very carefully keeping in mind the fears of locals.

Pramod Salaskar made a presentation to members of the biodiversity management committees (BMC) in the state on how he helped save the Powai lake from deterioration. BMCs help create people’s biodiversity register (PBR), which is a detailed record of the biodiversity in each village.

NIO’s acting director Sanil Kumar said that they have expedited the work to identify wetlands in Goa for the GSBB.

Title: Women in Tandalja protest against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Tent erected in the area for the protesters

Vadodara: Women from the minority community in the Tandalja area of the city have started a protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). The protest began on Friday night and is likely to continue in the days to come.

Tandalja area observed a near total bandh along with the other minority pockets of the city on Wednesday. Sources said that it was after this that women from the community here decided to hold protests in the area.

Sources said that the women have sought help from community leaders and youths with the arrangements for the protest. A pandal for the protests has been erected in Saudagar Park in Tandalja.

Sources said that the women have said that they will not stop protesting till CAA and NRC are not withdrawn. The group sitting on protest includes women from all age groups. Most of them arrive at the spot in the evening and sit through the night as part of the protest.

Title: Coronavirus: UP tourism issues alert on arrival of two Chinese nationals in Agra
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Agra: UP tourism department issued an alert to travel fraternity in Agra and Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), Agra circle, to immediately inform the health department about visits of any Chinese tourists anywhere in the city. The move comes days after the first positive coronavirus case was reported in Kerala.

According to the alert advisory, as per information provided by Mukesh Kumar Vats, the chief medical officer (CMO), Agra, “one or two Chinese nationals were likely to visit Agra from Patna on Saturday”. However, no one could be traced till evening, said officials.

The officials added that their passport details have been sent to travel agents and hotel association members across Agra for identification. ASI officials have also been directed to alert their staff and to inform the district authorities immediately, if some Chinese nationals visit Taj Mahal or any of the tourist places under ASI purview.

The CMO told TOI on Saturday that his department had received information about the arrival of two Chinese nationals from their office in Lucknow on Friday and he had immediately alerted people in the tourism sector. He, however, said they have not been traced so far.

He added two Chinese nationals, who had visited Agra last month, were found medically fit after being thoroughly screened by doctors. He also said that there is no need to panic as doctors and health officials are all on alert.

Superintending archaeologist (Agra circle) Vasant Swarankar, said, “I have directed my team to check identity of foreign tourists. If they spot any Chinese national they will immediately inform the district authorities along with the health department.” He added that Agra needs to be on alert as it is a major tourist destination and lots of Chinese nationals visit the Taj and other monuments.

Vice-president of Tourist Guild Association, Rajiv Saxena, said that everyone should be on alert. He, however, said that many Chinese tour groups had already cancelled their trips to India for the month of February. “This dangerous virus would badly impact our tourism sector in Agra,” he claimed.

Title: AMU VC grants Rs 1.5 lakh each to injured students
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Agra: More than 45 days after two students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) were injured in the anti-CAA violence on December 15 , vice-chancellor of the varsity professor Tariq Mansoor on Saturday announced a compensation of Rs 1.5 lakh each to both of them.

Compensation for two undergraduate students was announced on the recommendation of a committee constituted to decide the same. According to the administration, the committee spoke to the students and took cognizance of the evidence related to the incidents.

Title: MNGL to lay cooking gas pipeline in Pahchavati and Sharanpur
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nashik: After laying the piped natural gas (PNG) pipeline on the 1.1-km stretch of the maiden smart road between Ashok Stambh and Trimbak Naka, the Maharashtra Natural Gas Limited ( MNGL ) has now decided to lay similar supply pipelines in Pahchavati and Sharanpur areas of the city where roads are to be developed under the smart city.

Around 36-km of road is to be developed under the smart city and the project is being carried out by the NMSCDCL. A civic official said they will give layouts of the roads to be developed under the smart city to the MNGL so that the latter can plan the laying of pipelines.

“We had meeting with MNGL officials over cooking gas lines in the city. We are constructing roads under the smart city and it has been decided that the MNGL will lay the pipeline simultaneously when the road is being developed under the smart city,” Uddhav Nimse, civic standing committee chairman, said.

Smart city area development has been planned in core areas of the city like Panchavati and Sharanpur. The 36-km length comprises 23-km major and 13-km minor roads.

The MNGL has laid underground pipes for supplying compressed natural gas to fuel stations and piped natural gas to the households and industrial units. In the next eight years, it has to lay underground pipes with a length of over 500-km across the city for supplying both the green fuels.

Apart from piped natural gas, MNGL has also proposed six CNG stations to provide green fuel to city buses and other vehicles. These six CNG stations are expected to be operational by March-end this year.

Title: Goa: Plans to harvest rainwater for man-made ponds
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The forest department plans to harvest rainwater to create small and medium sized man-made water bodies in forest areas across the state.

Principal chief conservator of forests Subhash Chandra on Saturday said this initiative will help the state contribute to the Central government’s water conservation campaign, Jal Shakti Abhiyan. These water bodies will also ensure that wild animals do not wander into nearby villages in search of water, he said.

Speaking at the Goa state biodiversity board’s event on the occasion of World Wetland Day, Chandra said Goa’s hinterland has immense eco-tourism potential and that the forest department wants to aid the state government in promoting areas like wetlands, forests and green landscapes in the hinterland as eco-tourism attractions.

Chandra said the recently organised bird festival, hosted by the forest department, was an example of how the department can help the state attract tourists to the hinterlands. “The local cuisine in the hinterlands is also part of the diversity, and this can become another USP,” Chandra said.

Title: Bid to extract money from operators: Congress
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The BJP government headed by former chief minister Manohar Parrikar accepted Rs 100 crore from the casino industry in order to delay the appointment of the Goa gaming commissioner, Congress alleged on Saturday.

State party president Girish Chodankar said the recent appointment of the gaming commissioner was an attempt by chief minister Pramod Sawant to extract additional funds from off-shore and on-shore casinos .

“With rules not in place, the appointment of the gaming commissioner is just a means to extract more money from casino owners as the government knows that if you put a little pressure on the casinos, the operators will come running with bags,” Chodankar said.

“Soon someone will file a petition in the courts and get a stay on the ban on Goans , and this will give the state government an excuse not to frame the rules for the gaming commissioner,” he said.

Title: Lokesh extends support to protesters
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The ongoing protest at Andhra University took a political turn on Saturday when former minister and TDP MLC Nara Lokesh extended his support to the students on social media. In a Tweet, Lokesh found fault with the authorities concerned for increasing the fee. “A majority of the students of Andhra University belong to the rural parts and weaker sections. I demand the authorities to roll back the fee hike ,” demanded Lokesh on Twitter.

On the other hand, the students intensified their stir on Saturday – the fourth day of their protest. A huge police force was deployed on the campus to prevent untoward incidents.

Speaking to TOI, K Ashok, a PDSO leader said vice-chancellor Prof PVGD Prasad Reddy has reached out to the students in the evening and tried to explain the developmental initiatives taken up after he assumed the charge as the in-charge vice-chancellor in July, 2019. “But he did not promise to decrease the fee,” he said.

However, varsity officials suspect interference of political forces in the protest. “The fee structure was revised during the tenure of the former vice-chancellor in April 2019 and it is not a new decision. Leave aside the full allocation of block grants, the former state government had diverted a large amount of internal funds of the varsity to Pusupu-Kunkuma scheme before the elections. The varsity is currently facing a financial crisis due to all these factors,” said a university official.

Title: Not Enough Done To Jumpstart Slow Economy: Industry
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman ’s Budget for 2020-21 may have won praise for initiatives that could benefit the country in the long-run, but has left many industry players rueing that more could have been done to revive the sluggish economy.

Captains of Goa’s corporate sector were eyeing some big announcements in the Budget which could jumpstart the nation’s economy. Many, however, were left disappointed.

“We were expecting decisions that would have brought money into the market and into hands of individuals who would have spent it, thus boosting the economy. Unfortunately, the proposals seem to be all long-term planning which might not result in immediate revival of the economy,” said Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry president Manoj Caculo.

Caculo did laud the Centre’s move to recognise the contribution made by large corporate houses to the Indian economy. “I have to admit that a lot of things the government has proposed will definitely help the economy and country, but all this will be work-in-progress, it will be in the long-run,” Caculo said.

Goa State Industries Association president Damodar Kochkar felt the government could have done more to relax the stress on enforcement. “In this budget we were expecting a bit of leeway in the enforcement part to give people confidence to invest. If you want the private sector to invest, you need some clarity about ease of doing business and your liability. This, however, has not been clarified,” Kochkar said.

Industry leaders welcomed the announcement that Rs 100 lakh crore will be invested on infrastructure over the next five years. But they stressed that this money needs to be spent in such a way that its benefits trickle-down to the economy, thus reviving the economic cycle.

“The government needs to spend money on infrastructure to get the wheels of the economy moving. Unless they do that, I don’t think they will come anywhere close to 10% nominal growth that Sitharaman announced,” said Verna Industries Association president Blaise Costabir.

“Focusing on Goa, infra spending on cold storage facilities, logistics and other areas would help the state’s fisheries sector. Encouraging farmer producer organisations for the fisheries sector is also a welcome step for the state,” said CII Goa State Council chairman Lalit Saraswat.

Title: Collector orders joint survey of identifying parking spots
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kolhapur: District collector Daulat Desai ordered various departments to carry out a joint survey within 15 days to identify the parking spots and shift the government offices with an aim to streamline traffic and reduce congestion across the city.

A meeting was held with the activists and officials of various departments at the district collector’s office on Saturday.

The activists demanded that the government offices, especially a police station, in old Rajwada near Mahalaxmi temple be shifted. Desai said that it was necessary to have the police station near the temple for security purposes. Activist Ramesh More said that a small chowki could be developed with a few police staff to look after the security of the temple and the police station could be shifted to a ground, which they claimed was being used for illegal activities. Desai said that the permission from the district police was a must before shifting the police station.

Activist Ashok Powar said the offices in Paga building, which also houses a library, be relocated to the central administrative building at Kasba Bawda. Desai said that the offices could be shifted to other locations, but the library should remain there. “We can propose a modern study room for the students. Let Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) manage it,” he said.

Some officials said that the building was owned by a trust run by the royal family. The activists requested Desai to have word with a Shahu Chhatrapati Maharaj, who is the chief patron of the trust.

Activists further demanded that the traffic congestion along the busy Bhausingji road, which houses the offices of the tehsildar, land survey and land records, be reduced. Activists claimed that a few buildings along the roads were heritage structures, which were facing damage due to the smoke from the vehicles.

KMC’s chief city engineer Netradip Sarnobat said that they were considering introducing one-way traffic along the route, besides odd-even parking. Desai said that the KMC should take the help of the traffic police to undertake a trial of the one-way route and odd-even parking and ensure the visitors were asked to park their vehicles nearby Dasara Chowk.

Title: VDA team asks to vacate 38 shops outside apartment in Lanka
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Traders outside shops, being vacated by for demolition

Varanasi: Tension gripped in Lanka market on Saturday when a team of Varanasi Development Authorities raided the area for vacating 38 shops outside Kamdhenu apartment for demolition in compliance with a High Court order.

Apart from shop owners other traders from nearby areas also gathered there. VDA vice chairman Rahul Pandey said that against the construction of a double-floor lane of shops containing 38 outlets with the boundary of Kamdhenu apartment the residents association of apartment had taken shelter of the court. He said that the High Court had issued order for the demolition of same shops on February 9, 2018.

The builder took shelter of the Supreme Court against the HC order but failed to get any relief, said Pandey. Notices were issued to all shop owners to vacate their outlets by February 1 three months ago, he said.

The VDA will carry out demolition drive in a day or two as it has to submit compliance report before HC in a week.

Title: 600 more booked for violating prohibitory orders, blocking road
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Slug: Anti-CAA protest

Agra: Over 600 people, including three identified students of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) were booked by Aligarh police late on Friday for allegedly violating prohibitory order and blocking a road near Shahjamal area, where women have been sitting on protest for the past few days.

Police said that a group of people led by AMU students’ union vice-president Sajjad Subhan Rather reached Eidgah in Shahjamal area and started shouting slogans against CAA and NRC. When the group was asked to end the protest, as they did not have any permission, they started shouting slogans loudly. Rather allegedly incited the protesting women to do so, police said.

While, police claimed that Rather wore a burqa and mixed with the crowd to evade arrest, the latter refuted the allegations. Rather said, “I went to the dharna site to help the protesting women, who were sitting in the open area and demanding quilts and tent.” He said that he also wrote a letter to the SP (crime) and SP (city) demanding the same.

Meanwhile, former AMUSU vice-president said that he was surprised to know about the FIR against him as he did not vitiate the peaceful protest at Shahjamal area in any manner.

The FIR, against Rather, two students from Law faculty and 600 unidentified people was registered under sections 147 (riots), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 283 (danger or obstruction in public way) and 341 (wrongful restraint) of IPC with the Delhi gate police station.

Title: More loans to trap us in debts: Farmers
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Agra: Farmers in Agra region were largely disappointed by the Union Budget, pointing out that by increasing agriculture lending target to Rs 15 lakh crore for 2020-21, the government wanted to perpetually keep them chained by debts. More loan will only worsen the financial situation, they said.

Many wondered how the government proposed to double their income or prevent stray animals from destroying their crops. Besides, Budget was quiet on hiking minimum support price.

Farmer leader Shyam Singh Chahar said, “Farmers were expecting at least a 50% increase in the Rs 6,000 annually handout under the PM-Kisan scheme.”

Farmer organizations found nothing new about the proposed Krishi Udaan by civil aviation ministry and Krishi Rail to transport agri-products to both within and outside the country. Bharatiya Kisan Union’s Somveer Yadav said, “These schemes are not going to benefit farmers. Traders who deal in agriculture products will reap benefits.”

Aamir Bhai, general secretary of Potato Producers Association, said the Budget did not even mention problems of farmers of the region. “There are just 270 cold storage facilities in the district with a capacity of over 25 lakh metric tonnes whereas potato is cultivated in around 72,000 hectares. Farmers are not even able to retain their investments.” He added that government was yet to fulfill the promise made by PM Modi before 2014 Lok Sabha elections to set up a potato processing unit in Agra.

The only thing, farmer organisations appreciated were the proposals on addressing problems of 100 water-stressed districts and offer on use of solar power.

Title: Budget 2020 has given Maharashtra step-motherly treatment: CM Uddhav Thackeray
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

CM Uddhav Thackeray

MUMBAI: Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray said on Saturday Budget 2020 presented by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman is removed from reality and has given a “step-motherly” treatment to Maharashtra and Mumbai. “It is deeply disappointing for Maharashtra. This Budget does injustice to Maharashtra and Mumbai, which are the country’s growth engine,” said Thackeray who was a BJP ally till a few months ago.

Thackeray said the Budget does not address key problems such as unemployment, and the allocation for Skill India is inadequate.

He said it does not support development of public amenities and ongoing infrastructure projects in Mumbai, such as the Metro.

“The Budget gives no momentum to the development of a railway network in the state, except for the mention of projects announced earlier, such as the Mumbai-Ahmedabad bullet train.”

He said the scheme Sitharaman announced to develop heritage sites as “iconic sites” did not mention any from the culturally rich state. “The step-motherly treatment given to Maharashtra has become evident in the Budget. The International Financial Services Centre in Gujarat has been strengthened while Mumbai, which makes the highest contribution to the country’s growth, has been deliberately ignored,” he said.

The decision to divest stake in LIC and possible privatisation of the railways reveal the precarious state of the economy, he said. The GDP growth rate for the current financial year is 5% while the economic survey estimated 6-6.5% in 2020-21, he added. “This growth does not have the potential to achieve Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s dream of making India a $5 trillion economy,” said Thackeray. He dismissed the claim GST gave relief to small and medium enterprises. “Small and medium enterprises have been troubled by GST. People’s purchasing power has shrunk, impacting small-scale industries. This has landed workers in trouble.”

Title: Cops confiscate liquor from abandoned van on Kalaghoda Circle
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vadodara: The traffic police seized a stock of liquor from a van on the busy road near Kalaghoda Circle on Saturday. The van driver, however, fled the spot seeing cops checking vehicles on the road. The case has been handed over to the prevention of crime branch (PCB).

According to the PCB sleuths, the police were conducting routine checking of vehicles on the road near Kalaghoda Circle. After cops checked the abandoned vehicle, they found 240 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) and 95 cans of beer worth Rs 1 lakh. The liquor stock was seized along with the van.

“We are now scanning CCTV footage to ascertain identity of the accused who fled the spot. We will also track the vehicle’s owner from the license plate,” said Mukesh Bhagora, police inspector, PCB.

Title: 6 of a family killed, 2 injured in accident
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Six of a family, including two children and three women, were killed and two others injured in a road accident after the car they were travelling in collided with a cement-laden tanker near Velapur on Pune-Pandharpur road on Saturday morning.

Police said that the tanker was travelling in the opposite direction, adding that, the victims are residents of Vairag village in Barshi taluka of Solapur district and were on a pilgrimage tour. The driver of the tanker fled from the spot soon after the accident, said police.

The deceased have been identified as Shivraj Nagesh Falfale (38), Dinanath alias Babaso Nagesh Falfale (34), Vanita Shivraj Falfale (30), Utkarsh Shivraj Falfale (9), Sahyadri Babaso Falfale (6) and Parvati Mahadev Falfale (80).

The injured —Puja Dinanath alias Babaso Falfale (28) and Utkarsha Shivraj Falfale (11) — have been admitted to the nearby Velapur primary health centre.

According to police, the car was travelling from Pune to Vairag and the tanker was heading towards Pune. At around 8 am, both the vehicles collided with each other near Velapur, killing six people.

Police said that the impact of the collison was such that both the vehicles were thrown apart due to the force.

“Immediately after the accident took place, some alert passers-by informed us and we rushed to the spot. The people gathered at the spot helped us in removing the deceased and the injured people from the vehicle. All were immediately rushed to the hospital. The driver of the tanker fled from the spot. We have launched a search operation for him and are gathering his whereabouts. We are also searching for the owner of the tanker to get more details about the driver," a police officer investigating the case said.

With inputs from Suryakant Asabe

Title: Woman killed, daughter injured in attack in Ballia
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: A woman was killed and her daughter was seriously injured after some miscreants attacked them while they were sleeping inside their house in Shrinagar village of Revati police station area of Ballia district on Friday night.

Old enmity with neighbours and other reasons are suspected to be behind the attack, said SO Rajesh Singh on Saturday.

According to reports, Bindu Devi (45) and her daughter Anshu Verma (18) were sleeping inside their residence. After midnight some unidentified miscreants broke into their house and attacked the duo with some sharp-edged weapons. on hearing their cries, the villagers rushed to their house but before they could reach there the miscreants managed to escape.

The mother and daughter were immediately rushed to district hospital where doctors declared Bindu Devi as brought dead while Anshu was referred to Trauma Centre of BHU in Varanasi following a sharp deterioration in her health condition.

Additional SP, CO and other officials reached the incident site. SO Revati said that initial investigation revealed that Bindu’s family had an old enmity with their neighbours following which a clash between them also took place in 2017. Apart from this some other reasons are also being suspected behind the attack, said Singh claiming that the case would be worked out very soon.

Title: Kolhapur citizens to face water cuts on Monday and Tuesday
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The work of repairing pipelines will be carried out on Monday and will be completed on the same day, said auth... Read More

KOLHAPUR: Water supply to the entire city will be affected for two days from Monday owing to the repair work of the main pipeline that has been damaged.

In addition, officials will also carry our repair work of the electric installations in the pumping stations.

Authorities said that A, B, C and D wards will face water cuts owing to the repair work of the main pipeline. The water supply department of the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has reported major leakages to two pipelines carrying water to high rise tanks in the Aptenagar area.

The work of repairing these pipelines will be carried out on Monday and will be completed on the same day, said authorities. Owing to the repair work, the water supply to the A and B wards will be cut off, the added.

Areas such as Lakshtirth Vasahat, Saneguruji Vasahat, Kanerkar Nagar, Devkar Panand and rural and fringe areas will be affected. Officials claim that the water supply to these areas will resume by Monday mid-night if both the leakages are repaired. They said that even if one pipeline is repaired, the water supply to the A and B wards can be resumed, but, in that case, the areas will receive water at the low pressure.

The Balinga pumping station which supplies water to C and D wards is not functioning properly, said authorities. “At times, the pumps stop functioning, and, this time, the glitches have been reported in the electric installations of the pumping station,” they said.

A senior water supply official said, “We are going to replace the pumps soon. The pumping capacity will also be upgraded. Accordingly, we are going to carry out installation of the electric set up. The existing installations are not effective and get tripped several times. Such on and off behaviour of the electricity installations may damage the pumps. We are working with the engineers of the electricity department to get the electric installations replaced which will take at least two days.”

Owing to the works to be carried out at Balinga pumping station, the areas under C and D ward along with some sections of E ward will be affected. Areas such as Dudhali, Gangavesh, Uttareshwar Peth, Shukrawar Peth, Bindu Chowk, Mahalaxmi temple, Mirajkar Tickti in C and D wards will not receive water. Also, areas falling under E ward such as Shahupuri lane 5 and 6, Parvati Talkies, Kumbhar Galli and Udyamnagar too will not receive water.

Title: Gujarat: Eunuchs to perform yagna, pray for coronavirus victims
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

VADODARA: The eunuch community will perform havan on Sunday and also pray for the victims of coronavirus. The havan will be performed in Baranpura area — a hub for eunuchs – in the walled city. They will also offer prayers to end the outbreak of the virus that has killed many residents of China and infected many others across the globe.

“We read about the outbreak and how the deadly virus has been affecting people across the globe including India. We, therefore, decided to perform a ‘Navchandi Yagna’ to appease our goddess to end the meance of the virus,” said a member of the community, Anju Maasi. Thousands of eunuchs will participate in the ‘havan’.

“For the first time, a national meeting of eunuch community is happening in the city wherein members from across the country will attend the yagna on Sunday and garba on Monday. We wanted to show solidarity with the victims of the virus and also send a message to the society that we are with them,” Anju Maasi added.

Eunuchs, led by Anju Maasi, meet regularly in the city and work for welfare of their community. “We will also offer prayers for the lakhs of animals that died in forests of Australia,” she said.

Title: State already engaging engg grads as interns
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state has set a few precedents with regard to internship for fresh engineering graduates in urban local bodies as announced in the Union Budget for 2020-21. Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman said in the budget speech that the government proposes to start a programme whereby urban local bodies across the country would provide internship opportunities to fresh engineers for a period up to one year.

Thiruvananthapuram corporation and Thiruvananthapuram district administration had successfully implemented internship models in various projects. Former district collector K Vasuki had launched DCIP (district collectors internship project) during her tenure. “Engaging young graduates and students as interns in projects has yielded great results. There is so much of energy among the youth and internship is a great way to tap that energy. During the collection camps organised during floods in 2018, it was the interns who organised the volunteers and there was a high level of professionalism in that collection drive and in the way it was conducted. It happened mainly because of the active work of professionals who volunteered to be a part of that mission,” said K Vasuki who is now the director of department of agriculture.

Thiruvananthapuram corporation formed a collective under then mayor V K Prasanth which was titled as Green army comprising young graduates and students who spearheaded awareness on climate change, anti-plastic campaign and no burn movement.

The local self government department and department of education have teamed up to offer internship opportunities for BTech graduates. Engineering graduates and post-graduates can now do internship in local self government institutions (LSGI) as well as project management units and related institutions under LSGD at a monthly stipend starting from Rs 10,000. The project is being implemented as part of making use of engineering students’ skills in resolving technical issues related to LSGD and to create job opportunities.

Those who complete their courses in government, aided, self-financing engineering colleges can apply for internship in local bodies and in related institutions like KILA, Suchitwa mission, MGNREGA, Clean Kerala company, Amrut mission management unit etc. The internship will be for a period of one year. The graduates and post-graduates will get monthly stipend of Rs 10,000 and Rs 15,000 respectively.

Title: Parking fee row: Traders go bare chested in protest against Agra Municipal Corporation
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The dispute over parking fee between traders of Sanjay Place and Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) is sub judic... Read More

AGRA: Traders of Sanjay Place went bare chested at the Dharna spot in the parking area on Saturday as a mark of protest against the Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) administration over the issue of parking fee. Traders who’ve been on an indefinite strike since past 19 days claimed that AMC is making it difficult for them to do business.

Leaders of the Congress and Samajwadi Party are participating in the strike on a daily basis. The dispute over parking fee between traders of Sanjay Place and Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) is sub judice. The traders want AMC to cancel the parking contracts till the court delivers its final orders in the matter.

Vice president of the Sanjay Place market association Brajendra Baghel said, “AMC has flouted norms as traders of the market have already paid a fee for parking space at the time of purchasing property. We have sought details under the RTI Act. It will reveal all the malpractices done by the AMC administration to exploit the traders and common people. We will continue our fight against the parking mafia.”

Title: No restrictions on tourists in casinos till rules are out: Goa CM Pramod Sawant
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Saturday said entry of tourists into casinos would not be restricted until rules and regulations for the functioning of the gaming commission are in place.

Sawant told reporters that the gaming commissioner has been appointed but it will take some time before the rules are notified. He said the ban on Goans has become effective from February 1.

A state government official said that right from designating staff to issuing the tourist permits and from specifying documentation to fees and fines, the rules will define everything.

“The gaming commissioner will have to designate people to issue tourists permits across the state,” he said.

“For this, the government has to first define what documents the gaming commissioner should insist on. Further, modalities for challans and penal liabilities, if any, have to be specified in the rules,” he added.

Title: Halcon upbeat about Krishi Udaan scheme
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

(done)

Nashik: It would be a win-win situation for farmers and exporters in the region if Nashik is brought under the ambit of the Krishi Udaan scheme.

Union finance minister Nirmala Sithraman on Saturday announced that the civil aviation ministry would launch the scheme for both national and international routes to help farmers transport their produce.

“The scheme would be a big boon for farmers from the entire region as well as for exporters,” said sources in the Nashik-based Halcon — a joint venture between Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd (HAL) and Container Corporation of India (Concor).

Halcon CEO Sudhakar Sen welcomed the government’s move. “We will surely request the civil aviation ministry to bring Nashik under the scheme,” he said.

“We already have all infrastructure like packaging house, cold storage and customs clearance. Air cargo complex of Halcon is adjacent to the Ozar airport. Hence, there is huge potential for Kirishi Udan flights from here,” added Sen.

Halcon is involved in export of various agricultural and horticulture products from Nashik and other districts in the state.

It exports around 4,500 tonne of fresh vegetables and fruits annually to London, Dubai and other international markets from the Mumbai airport.

Vegetables like okra, drumstick, luffa, flat beans and chilli are being exported by air directly from Nashik airport to Dubai. However, fresh fruits like pomegranate, guava and chiku are exported through the Mumbai airport.

Halcon sources said the bulk of produce is sent from Nashik to Mumbai by road and then despatched either by air or by ships from Jawaharlal Nehru Port. If cargo flights start operating from Nashik airport under the scheme, it would be cost effective to exporters.

Road transport of about four tonne of produce costs the importers around Rs 10,000.

Title: Kolhapur: Man gets 10-year rigorous imprisonment for sexually assaulting minor girl
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

Title: Doing films for party and family, says Pawan
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Referring to former IPS officer V V Lakshminarayana, who recently resigned from the party, Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan on Saturday said he will not stop because of someone leaving the party. He said only those who believe in the ideology of Jana Sena will only remain in the party.

Speaking to party workers from Vijayawada east constituency, Kalyan while referring to lone party MLA Rapaka Vara Prasad but without naming him said that he does not know whether he is with the party.

Responding to allegations levelled against him by those who left the party, Kalya said “They are only criticising me after leaving the party when they had the freedom to raise the issues with him in the party. If I had thousands of crores of properties and income of one crore every month I would not have agreed to do films again. I have decided to do movies for my family and for the party. Are those making allegations ready to give thousand rupees for society” he asked.

Meanwhile, a joint team of Jana Sena and BJP is going to visit the capital region and meet the farmers on Sunday. Functionaries from both the parties will first meet at Hailand before heading to the capital region. The team will visit Mandadam, Velagapudi and Thulluru villages.

Title: Gujarat: Loco engines get branded at local shed
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

‘Fortune’ engine gets flagged off on Saturday.

VADODARA: ‘ Fortune ’ — a locomotive engine branded at the electric loco shed, Vadodara, was flagged off in presence of senior officials of Vadodara railway division of Western Railways and Adani Wilmar on Saturday.

A senior technician of the loco shed, Mukesh Mishra, who will retire this month flagged off the locomotive in presence of Devendra Kumar, divisional railway manager of Vadodara division among others.

This branding of 10 locos will generate an additional non-fare revenue earning to the tune of Rs 1.05 crore for the period of five years, the railway officials said, adding that it will also result in saving expenditure of Rs 8.1 lakh that is incurred in painting of the locos.

The branding has been done as per the approved specification and the painting is done by a professional agency, officials said.

Title: Onion, grape farmers at odds in Nashik
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Grape cultivators say they deserve to be included in the scheme because of tough competition in the internatio... Read More

NASHIK: The ‘one-product, one-district’ scheme envisaged in the Union Budget on Saturday triggered a slugfest among farmers in Nashik district, which is a hub of onions and grapes .

While onion farmers are arguing that their produce should be brought under the scheme because of price volatility and losses, grape growers say they deserve it because of tough competition in the international market.

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman made the announcement in the budget about the Centre’s support to states to boost marketing and exports of crops in the horticulture sector. “States have to resort to a cluster basis programme under one-product, one-district scheme,” she said.
