Sources in the Union agriculture ministry told TOI that either onions or grapes grown in Nashik district is likely to be included in the scheme. “Nashik is known in the country as hub of onion and grape production. Hence, there will be a tussle between farmers on inclusion of their crop in the scheme,” said an official.

Onion farmer Nivrutti Nyaharkar said, “The production cost of onions increases due to fluctuation in the climate most of the time. The farmers don’t get profit even if the rates are high. Hence, the government needs to bring onions under the scheme.”

The onion farmers reminded that there are over 10 lakh of them are engaged in cultivation of the crop across Nashik district.

The onion crop cultivation is done in 10 of the 15 talukas in the district and the annual production is estimated at over 30 lakh tonne a year.

Grape plantation is spread over two lakh acres in Niphad, Dindori and Chandwad taluka of the district and its annual production is around 18 lakh tonne. There are around 1.5 lakh grape farmers in the district.

Manik Patil, senior member of Maharashtra Rajya Draksha Bagayatdar Sangh, “The district has monopoly in onion crop and that the government only needs to decide on the export policy. There is, however, no need for the government to intervene in marketing and production as Nashik’s onions have a huge market in India as well as abroad.”

“There is a need to take grapes under the one-produce one-district scheme. There is huge competition for grape exporters in the international market. The government should focus on marketing and production of grapes,” added Patil.

Title: Police arrest suspect in extortion case
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Gokul Shirgaon police arrested Prakash Bandiwadekar from Indore, Madhya Pradesh for his alleged involvement in an extortion case . He was produced before the local court on Saturday and remanded to three-day police custody.

Sushant Chavan, assistant inspector in-charge of Gokul Shirgaon police station, said they had received a complainant that a woman stone crusher in Nerli village was threatened by one person demanding Rs 50,000 to allow her to start the crusher.

The complaint was lodged on January 10 stating that the stone crusher received a call from the suspect, who demanded money for letting her operate the crusher in the village.

“A case was registered against an unidentified person under section 387 (Putting person in fear of death or of grievous hurt, in order to commit extortion), 506 (Punishment for criminal intimidation) and 507 (Criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication) of IPC,” he said.

Chavan said that investigation revealed that Bandiwadekar is involved in the case and launched a search operation. “We got information from sources about his whereabouts in Indore and nabbed him there,” he said.

Title: Chennai-B’luru Expresswayto take shape, tenders soon
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Team TOI

The Chennai-Bengaluru Expressway is about to take shape with Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announcing in the Budget that the work will start soon. The project, expected to cut short travelling time between the two metros and promote an infrastructure corridor along the alignment, will be a growth engine and will be taken up under the hybrid-annuity model (HAM).

The eight-lane access-controlled expressway will pass through Karnataka (77km), Andhra Pradesh (91km), and Tamil Nadu (94km). While land acquisition is nearing completion in the other two states, Tamil Nadu has appointed an authority to acquire 972.81 hectares in Vellore, Kancheepuram and Tiruvallur. "The NHAI regional office, Chennai takes care of the third phase of the programme covering 106km, including a stretch of 12km in Andhra Pradesh. Tenders will be floated in a few weeks for four packages. The state pollution control board is all set to conduct a public hearing as the environment impact assessment/ environment management plan report has been submitted," said a senior NHAI official.

The agency proposes to take up the project under the Bharatmala Pariyojana scheme to provide a corridor parallel to the existing NH-4 (Mumbai-Kolar-Bengaluru-Chennai), which is one of the most congested highways in the country. The new expressway will ease traffic, as per feasibility study report submitted by a consultant.

The environment appraisal committee of the Union ministry of environment and forests, in May 2018, approved the terms of reference for environmental clearance of the project, subject to the condition that cumulative impact assessment study and traffic density study be carried out. "The NHAI has assessed that the estimated Passenger Car Units (a measure to assess traffic flow) could be 49,126 per day in the next fiscal, the year of award of tender. The growth rate could be 5.6% per annum and the projected traffic could be 1.46 lakh PCUs in 20 years," another official said. There is no case pending in the court as of now against the execution of the project.

Private land measuring 757.41 hectares has to be acquired for the project, and public notification has been issued in this regard. The Central agency has taken possession of 328.69 hectares so far. The NHAI is also preparing a detailed project report for constructing a six-lane elevated corridor from Sriperumbudur to Maduravoyal, for about 23.2km, as part of Chennai-Bengaluru Expressway.

Title: Naveen welcomes Budget, with caveats
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Union Budget drew a mixed response from the state government, with chief minister Naveen Patnaik welcoming proposals to increase agriculture spending and FDI in education, but expressing concern over stagnant allocation under centrally sponsored schemes and shrinking of divisible pool. He said Odisha would lose around Rs 3,000 crore in the current fiscal as the divisible pool of central taxes has shrunk by almost Rs 59,000 crore.

“We welcome initiatives such as Krishi Rail and Krishi Udan for a seamless national cold supply chain. The PM-KUSUM to provide 20 lakh farmers with solar pump is also good,” he said, adding that he appreciated the announcement of a new education policy and FDI in the education sector.

The chief minister also lauded finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s proposal to abolish dividend distribution tax (DDT). He also gave a thumbs up to the introduction of concessional component tax.

“Odisha had requested extension of concessional tax rates to cooperatives in line with corporate tax cuts. We welcome the announcement of concessional tax rates for cooperatives and increase of deposit insurance coverage from Rs 1 lakh to Rs 5 lakh,” said Naveen.

The BJD chief also sounded a warning note to the Centre, citing the slump witnessed by the Sensex on Saturday. He said this showed that there was huge scope for rectification as the Sensex was an indicator of investor confidence. “Investor confidence is important for attracting investment and spurring growth,” he added.

The Budget was welcomed by the industry bodies of the state. Chairperson of FICCI Odisha State Council, Monica Nayyar Patnaik, said, “The measures announced by the government will strengthen India, individuals and industry.” J B Pany, co-chairman, ICC Odisha State Council, said the decision to set up an investment clearance cell to facilitate investors investment advisory, land bank and facilitate clearances was to be appreciated.

Title: Nashik Tribal Department starts ‘Mission Udaan’ at Ashramshalas
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

NASHIK: The Nashik Tribal Department (NTD) has initiated a new campaign called ‘ Mission Udaan ’ for the upliftment of tribal students in all its 39 schools of government ashramshalas.

Under the campaign, the students of class VI to VIII will undergo a monthly test of 100 marks and help them prepare for competitive examinations after passing out from the schools.

Kumar Ashirvad, project officer, NTD, said “These students are very talented but they require exposure for the competitive examinations. With the help of the monthly tests, the students will be prepared for such competitive examinations after school.”

The NTD wishes to carry on the campaign for at least two years and the first test of the campaign was conducted on the last two days of the January month.

“We are positive that the test will yield good results. We will bring necessary changes to the pattern of the test as and when required. Our only aim is to let the students get some exposure and practice for the pattern of various competitive examinations,” Ashirvad told TOI.

The students get multiple choices for the test and have to attempt it on the OMR (optical mark recognition) sheet. This sheet is now used in all the competitive examinations to select the correct option. Also, many colleges require the students to fill up their details like roll numbers and subject codes on OMR sheets these days.

The questions asked in the test are from Mathematics, Science, Social Science, English and General Aptitude. Over 5,800 students with approximately 150 students per school will appear for the test.

The tribal department is also training its teachers to conduct the tests. The teachers should be able to train the students for the test during their school hours and conduct a three-hour test in the same time frame, added Ashirvad.

The ashramshalas are residential schools where the students stay and study at the same premises.

Title: Minor girl raped by 18-year-old youth
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

An eight-year-old girl was allegedly raped by an 18-year-old youth in a village under Dwaraka Tirumala mandal in West Godavari district on Friday. The incident, however, came to light on Saturday after the parents of the girl lodged a complaint with the police.

Dwaraka Tirumala police sub-inspector Surya Bhagwan said the accused is a distant relative of the victim, who studies in a local school. Her parents, who are daily labourers, left her at the school and went for work on Friday. The girl was playing during lunch hour when the accused took her aside and sexually assaulted her. Police said he gave the girl his cell phone and told her to hold it. After some time, he asked her to come to a cashew plantation nearby. The girl refused, but the accused forcibly took her into the cashew orchard where he alleged committed the crime.

The family members, who were searching for the girl, found her with the accused. On seeing her family members, he fled from the spot. The girl later narrated her ordeal. She also said that the accused had assaulted her once before and warned her not to disclose it to her parents. The girl’s parents lodged a complaint with Dwaraka Tirumala police, who sent the victim for medical examination. A case of rape has been registered against the accused under the Pocso Act. Police are searching for the accused, who is at large.

Title: It’s a war cry against Kerala: Thomas Isaac
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: “The Union Budget is a war cry against Kerala. Never before in the history of Independent India did the state meet with such a raw deal. The budget comes as a huge disappointment to Kerala,” finance minister T M Thomas Isaac said here on Saturday.

Isaac said finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has proved to have learned no lessons from her previous budget. “The Union finance minister failed to feel the vibes of an economic recession around the corner when she presented her budget for 2019-20. Here she committed the same mistakes again and overlooked the economic slowdown staring at the country. The budgetary provision to Kerala has been whittled down from the existing 2.5% to 1.9%. This is something unexpected and unacceptable. While the allocation to the state was Rs 17,872 crore in the last budget, it has been reduced to Rs 15,236 crore this time,” Isaac said.

The Union Budget would have its impact on the state budget that Isaac is set to present in the assembly on February 7. “A shortage of around Rs 5,000 crore in the allocation, compared to our expectations is bound to have its impact. We will have to explore out of the box solutions to fund the programmes and schemes being readied as part of our next budget,” Isaac said.

He said the Union government was obsessed with the “monetarist economic outlook”, which prompts it to see the economic slowdown as a result of the problems in the supply end. “The government is not yet willing to come into terms with the plain fact that it's the deterioration of buying capacity of people that debilitate the economy. But, the Union government tries to save the economy by doling out more and more freebies to the corporates,” Isaac said. There was substantial decrease in the allocation to key sectors, but the Union finance minister tried to create a mirage by not recalling the allocation those sectors had received in the last budget, he said.

Meanwhile, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the budget proposal to impose 22 % tax and surcharge on primary cooperative societies would further weaken the cooperative sector at a time when the sector was in need of governmental support than ever before. “The attempts to eliminate cooperative sector would evoke strong repercussions. How big the impact of steep cut in tax share would be known only after some time. The budget once again proved to be anti-people and corporate friendly. Attempts to violate the spirit of federal principles are galore. The decision to go ahead with disinvestment and sell out LIC are unacceptable,” he said.

According to Vijayan, the demand of state for more funds for major projects like semi-high speed rail and Angamali-Sabari rail line was totally ignored in the budget.

Title: SCB officials turn up at shrines to promote ban on single-use plastic
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: To make Secunderabad Cantonment free from the bane of single-use plastic , officials are now strategically identifying vulnerable locations such as religious shrines, weekly vegetable markets and parks that witness maximum footfall in the area. In a fresh bid, a team of senior SCB officials led by the deputy chief executive office of SCB, Vijay Kumar Balan Nair, visited major shrines in SCB limits and promoted the use of paper and cloth bags.Officials visited the Tadbund Hanuman temple at Sikh Village and seized all plastic material being used by vendors to pack puja material. Officials also distributed cloth bags for free. They interacted with temple authorities and people to explain Ministry of Defence’s (Mod) ban on the uses od single-use plastic.“People from across the city visit Hanuman temple to perform special pujas when they buy a new vehicle or a new home. So we knew we could interact with considerable number of people and spread the message on ban on single-use plastic,” Parusuram, an SCB official told TOI, explaining the decision to kick-start the anti-plastic drive with the Hanuman temple.“On Saturday, we also visited Surya Narayana temple at Trimulgherry. We seized plastic bags from vendors and explained the ban on plastic. We distributed cloth bags to use as an alternative,” he added.The Hanuman temple at Trimulgherry was also visited by officials. Meanwhile, many women groups working under Mission for Elimination of Poverty in Municipal Areas (MEPMA) are receiving bulk orders for cloth bags from commercial properties.Over 8,000 cloth bags have been distributed to establishments in SCB, the official said.“We have given a month’s time to all shopkeepers to stop using single-use plastic. Raids will be conducted from next week onwards to impose penalties against violators,” a senior official said.

Title: Ahmedabad: ‘Rich suitor’ cheats woman of Rs 17 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 39-year-old woman, a resident of Naranpura and an assistant manager with a pharma company, lodged a complaint with the cyber cell on Friday, alleging that a man who identified himself as Dr Himesh Parikh from the UK and said he was working with the United Nations (UN) had cheated her of Rs 17,28,000 after promising to marry her.

According to the FIR, the woman had put her biodata and a photo on a matrimonial site. On July 2, 2019, she got a message from a man who identified himself as Dr Himesh Parikh from UK.

“He told her that he is from Rajkot and works at a UN military base in Kenya as a doctor. They kept chatting and talking on the phone till July 27, 2019, and Parikh then stopped messaging her,” said a cyber cell official.

The FIR states that on September 2019, he messaged her from another number and told her that their camp had moved to Saudi Arabia and had come under attack and he could thus not contact her. He then told her that he would marry her when comes to Ahmedabad.

“In November, he called her and said that those ‘killed in the attack’ had been compensated and others had not and they were thus protesting against the UN,” an investigator said. At the end of December, he told her that they had won and he had been compensated $24,000,000 and had named her as his beneficiary, as she was now his fiancée.

The accused then told her that he was sending her a parcel with a cashier’s cheque for $240,000 and a watch. On January 3, 2020, she got a call from a man called James Grey from one ‘Global Security Courier’ who told her that her parcel had reached Delhi and she would have pay Rs 98,000 to get it, which she sent through her bank account by NEFT.

“The man then demanded Rs 2,10,000 for an ‘anti-terrorist certificate’. She called the accused and asked if she should pay the sum or not. The accused told her to pay, saying it would be easy to convert the money into Indian currency later. She paid the sum.

She was similarly made to pay Rs 6,80,000 lakh for ‘RBI assistance’ and Rs 4,40,000 to ‘generate a code to release the parcel’.

The perpetrators also demanded Rs 17,00,000 for a ‘tax certificate’. She then Rs 3,00,000 but got suspicious and on inquiring with the RBI learned that no such charges are levied.

“By this time she had already paid Rs 17,28,000 to the cheats. She approached us with an application. We registered an FIR on Friday. We are tracing the mobile numbers from which she received messages and calls,” said DCP, cyber crime, Rajdeepsinh Jhala.

Title: After lean season, another disappointment for tourism
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: Tourism stakeholders on Saturday said they were disappointed with the Budget as, for the second consecutive year, it had nothing to offer a sector that is going through a lean phase owing to less footfalls.

“A bit disappointing, we were expecting something better. We welcome the target of 100 airports by 2025, specialised grants to states that will boost tourism, and the setting up of museums,” president of the Travel and Tourism Association of Goa, Savio Messias, said.

Atish Fernandes, director at First Class Holidays, said there was nothing positive for tourism. “There is piecemeal heritage upgrade and minimal budget allocation. However, expectations were quite low in the first place,” he said.

A South Goa hotelier said the Centre has neglected the tourism sector and that there was nothing great to help elevate an industry that is facing tough times.

“When you don’t offer anything specific to the industry that has a potential to grow, one ought to feel neglected. It’s as if we don’t count,” the hotelier said even as he added that his hopes were buoyed after chief minister Pramod Sawant’s statements. “There is hardly any thing concrete to talk about,” he said.

Title: 20 special trains for Medaram Jatara rush
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Secunderabad: To clear devotees’ rush heading for Medaram Jatara , South Central Railway ( SCR ) will operate 20 special trains . Trains will operate between Secunderabad-Warangal, Hyderabad and Sirpur Kagazhnagar and Warangal.

“Ten train services will run between Secunderabad, Warangal, and Hyderabad between February 4 and February 8. Train No: 07014 will depart Secunderabad at 12:00 noon and reach Warangal at 3.40pm the same day,” SCR said in an official statement.

“Train 07015 will depart Warangal at 5:45pm and arrive at Hyderabad at 9:40pm ,” it added.

Another 10 services would run between Sirpur Kagazhnagar and Warangal between February 4 and February 8. TNN

Title: New tax regime splits aam aadmi down the middle
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Rourkela Chamber of Commerce and Industry members watch the budget proceedings

BHUBANESWAR: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s announcement of a new tax regime for the salaried class, and the reduction of tax rates for those who choose to enter the new regime after giving up existing exemptions, has evoked mixed reactions among the ‘aam aadmi’ here.

While some have welcomed the announcement, others said the coexistence of two different tax regimes for people with income up to Rs 15 lakh per annum would lead to confusion, and send people hunting for the nearest tax consultant.

According to the finance minister’s proposal, persons earning between Rs 5 lakh and Rs 7.5 lakh per annum will have to pay tax at 10 per cent, instead of the existing 20 per cent. Those with annual income between Rs 7.5 lakh and Rs 10 lakh will have to pay tax at 15 per cent as against last year’s 20 per cent.

People earning between Rs 10 lakh and Rs 12.5 lakh can pay tax at 20 per cent instead of 30 per cent, while those earning between Rs 12.5 lakh and Rs 15 lakh per annum will need to pay tax at 25 per cent. The tax rate remains unchanged at 30 per cent for those earning Rs 15 lakh and more.

Chartered accountant A K Sabat said taxpayers would now have to calculate to see which tax regime would serve them better. “I personally feel the older tax slabs were better,” he said.

Sabat was echoed by Manas Behera, a salaried man, who said two tax structures would confuse people. “The government should have reduced indirect taxes to tackle price rise,” he added. Another salaried person, Hemaprabha Das, however, said the tax announcement would help middle-class employees. “The reduction in tax rate will help us save money,” she said.

Some, like entrepreneur Tanaya Patnaik, said they were trying to understand the nuances of the announcement. “To be honest, I’m still going through the various segments of the Budget . It is a lot to process. I’m not sure how successful it will be in improving our economy,” she said.

Housewife Bandita Kar was more optimistic. She said the revision in personal income tax slab would help people save money, but added that the amount saved would not be enough to cover rising cost of essential commodities. “The budget does not have anything for senior citizens and women,” she pointed out.

Title: ‘Love for Tamil should not develop hatred against other languages’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

(From left) Justice Sundaresh, Justice Ramasubramanian and Justice Kirubakaran at the Bar Council of Tamil Nad... Read More

CHENNAI: Love for one’s mother tongue should not develop hatred against other languages. To prosper in legal profession, proficiency in English is a must, Justice V Ramasubramanian, judge, Supreme Court, said while addressing a gathering of over 400 newly enrolled advocates.

“Love for Tamil and proficiency in English would take you places,” he said, while delivering a special address in the enrolment function organised by the Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry here on Saturday. This apart, every lawyer must possess three qualities – hunger for knowledge, hard work and professional integrity. These three qualities would definitely give you all a successful career, Justice Ramasubramanian said.

Felicitating the advocates, Justice N Kirubakaran cautioned them of a section of lawyers who involve in kangaroo courts and other criminal activities. “There are two groups of advocates. One practices before courts and the other before police stations. The second category is the sin to the profession,” he said.

Pressing the need to be well-versed in English, Justice Kirubakaran said, “English is the passport to the entire world.”

On professional ethics, he said, “In your attempt to gather wealth you must not exploit your clients. You are entitled fee for the service you have rendered but not a share in the benefits ordered to your clients.”

Justice M M Sundaresh and Justice V Bharathidasan suggested the young advocates to work under a senior for at least for three years to learn the trade.

Earlier, delivering his presidential address, chairman of the council P S Amalraj informed the gathering that the council is taking steps to provide stipend to young lawyers in their initial years to help them stay in the profession. Senior advocate and member representing Tamil Nadu in Bar Council of India S Prabakaran said lawyers should be students life-long and never cease to learn.

Title: No respite for farmers: AIKMS
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Allahabad: Slamming the Union Budget 2020, All Indian Kissan Majdoor Sangh ( AIKMS ) on Saturday said the budget had nothing to offer farmers reeling under high procurement prices and mounting debt.

AIKMS general secretary Ashish Mittal said, “The Union Budget 2020 proposes increased penetration of MNCs and corporate giants in the agricultural sector. It offers no relief to peasants suffering from problems like high input costs, low crop prices, distress sale, crop losses. Their exploitation by companies will increase through leasing of agricultural land and increasing their debt burden.”

“There is no concrete proposal on Mnrega, on rural wages, pension, irrigation and subsidies for diesel, electricity, seeds and fertilizers or on any worries of the landless peasants, agriculture workers and share croppers,” he added.

Title: Kutch family faces music for land compensation fraud
Content:
Representative image

अमित शाह जी, ये आपने क्या हाल बना रखा है हमारी दिल्ली का। दिनदहाड़े गोलियां चल रहीं है। कानून व्यवस्था की खुलेआम ध… https://t.co/FC1LMQ4dyN — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) 1580560295000

NEW DELHI: AAP Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Singh on Saturday urged Shaheen Bagh protesters to “rethink” about their sit-in against CAA to “avoid anyone from taking political advantage of them”.Singh said the protesters should not let anyone harm them physically. “They should rethink about their protest. They should not allow anyone to take advantage of their protest or harm them. Polling date is drawing near.”Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, meanwhile, on Saturday slammed Union home minister Amit Shah after a man opened fire near the Shaheen Bagh protest site and urged him to focus on the law and order situation in the capital.“Amit Shah ji, what has Delhi turned into! A shooting takes place in broad daylight. Law and order has turned into a joke. Elections will come and go, politics will also continue, but for the sake of the people of Delhi, please focus on improving law and order,” Kejriwal tweeted.Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra also responded saying the incident reflected the helplessness of BJP just before the elections. “BJP has lost all hope. It is trying to polarise the electorate due to which law and order has been thrown to the wind. It is doing all this for political benefits,” he added.Meanwhile, AAP wrote to the Election Commission to inform that it had learned that certain anti-social elements, in connivance with certain parties, were planning to create unrest and violence on Sunday. The party stated that a group has put out hoardings in some areas asking people to assemble near Sarita Vihar. It claimed that it feared that this might be a well-planned conspiracy to sabotage the Delhi polls. It requested the EC to direct the police commissioner and other agencies to take appropriate preemptive action.BJP leader Vijay Goel also condemned the incident. “People at Shaheen Bagh should consider that due to their protest, inconvenience is being caused to thousands of people, including children, office goers and traders. The kind of slogans being raised there is also instigating people,” he added.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Retired cop throws chemical on face of pregnant daughter
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A retired police head constable on Friday threw a chemical on the face of his pregnant daughter and attacked her in-laws when they tried to rescue her in Tiruvallur. The woman and her in-laws who intervened suffered burn injuries in the attack.

Police said B Deepika married her boyfriend B Saikumar last year against the wishes of her father. Saikumar, a resident of Veppampattu, works as an AC mechanic. He fell in love with Deepika a few years ago when they were neighbours.

But her father Balakumar was opposed to the match and moved his family from Veppampattu to Tiruttani. He began to look for a groom to marry off Deepika. But the woman left her family and married Saikumar. The couple moved to Bengaluru after that.

After Deepika conceived, Saikumar brought her to his parent’s house in Veppampattu. When Balakumar got the news, he went to Saikumar’s house and told his daughter that her mother was unwell. He asked Deepika to accompany him to Tiruttani.

After Deepika refused, Balakumar left the house but returned with three men and smeared her face with the chemical.

Hearing Deepika screaming for help, her mother-in-law Bhagyalakshmi and her sister-in-law Divya came to her rescue. The men threw the chemcal on the other two women.

Balakumar and his accomplices threatened Deepika’s neighbours and forced her into a vehicle. Saikumar’s father Balaji alerted the Sevvapet police station about the incident.

With police on his tail, Balakumar pushed Deepika on the road near the Veppampattu bus terminus and fled. Police and neighbours rescued Deepika, who, along with the other two women, had suffered burns. The three were admitted at a government hospital in Tiruvallur.

Police have registered a case and have launched a hunt for Balakumar and his accomplices. Police have sent samples of the chemical, that was used in powder form, for analysis.

Title: ‘Pick & choose’ tax slab method may discourage savings, feel experts
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: The Budget proposal to give up all the deductions and pay tax at a lower rate has led to apprehensions that it will discourage investments into savings schemes and insurance products that qualify for a rebate.

Tax-payers can now choose between the old and new methods. The salaried class invests into small savings schemes like NSC, KVP, PPF, insurance to save tax. Even home loans are seen as tax saving mode.

Experts say paying at a lower tax rate without deductions will leave higher disposable income at the hand of an individual. The savings schemes may not look as attractive in light of the new pattern. There was also a view that it may not make any impact because people may still invest in the such product purely for the purpose investments, if not tax planning.

Chartered accountant Naresh Jhakotia says, if a person has a salary income of Rs10 lakh, the tax liability can be minimized to Rs13,500 after taking into account the standard deduction of Rs40,000. “It can be done by investing in schemes listed under section 80c, NPS, medi-claim and home loan. However, to bring down the tax to that level one has to park at least Rs4.30 lakh in various schemes,” he says.

Earlier, if an individual had made no investments, the tax on Rs10 lakh came to Rs1,12,500. Now by opting for the new system, a person earning Rs10 lakh has to pay Rs80,000 tax with no need to invest anywhere.

“There is also a concern that it may lead to a drop in demand for certain investment schemes. However, I don’t see any such scenario,” says Jhakotia.

Ranjit Dani, an investment adviser, says if taxpayers get a better deal without any investment, not many would be interested to park their funds in products that were generally seen as tax-saving plans. “An impact may be seen on home loans’ demand too,” he said.

“The new method, which also proposes to do away with deductions, will now also include all the compensatory allowances like those for conveyance and leave travel in taxable income. This will ultimately increase the liability,” says Kailash Jogani, a chartered accountant. He said investment into savings plan will be hit due to the no-deduction norm.

Insurance agent Bharat Parekh says people will now will be able to exercise their choice for investment and may go for higher paying products. “I do not see any impact on the demand for other products in which investment was normally done for tax saving. There is a class of investors which will continue with the old system,” he adds.

Sanjay Jaodia, a chartered accountant, says that the entire habit of savings by the middle class may be affected

Neeraj Wagh, a certified financial planner, says the mutual funds (MF) industry is unlikely to see a drop in inflow. “The no-exemption clause won’t affect mutual fund business as people have understood that investing here is the only way to beat inflation. Falling fixed deposit rates have fuelled the rush for MFs and today’s decision to abolish dividend distribution tax will help further. But the new tax regime is likely to see a fall in insurance policy subscriptions,” says Wagh.

Tax lawyer Manish Gopalani said this will increase the work for chartered accountants. “It is but natural that clients would demand to see both computations, which means double work for CAs. Also, there is a shift towards one time investments like tax saver FDs rather than getting stuck up in annual subscriptions, which is likely to affect investments,” says Gopalani.

Title: As council sits on Bill, GO issued to shift vigilance commissionerate
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: Even as the Bill on three-capitals is yet to overcome the legislative council hurdle and a batch of petitions is pending with the high court challenging the Bill, the state government has made its first move towards decentralising the capital .

The government issued an order late on Friday night decreeing the shift of vigilance commissioner and commissionerate of inquiries offices to Kurnool, which is set to be the judicial capital.

The GO 13 issued by chief secretary Nilam Sawhney stated that the state government on administrative grounds and after careful examination of the issue has decided that the office of vigilance commissioner and chairman of commissionerate of inquiries and member commissioners of inquiries shall function from Kurnool.

The GO further directed the engineer-in-chief of roads and buildings department and the collector of Kurnool to take necessary steps to identify buildings to relocate the offices immediately. Both the offices are now functioning from an interim government complex at Velagapudi in Amaravati.

Defending the GO, finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy told reporters on Saturday that the state government has the right and power to shift the offices whereever it wants to. Besides, the state government is committed to honour the Sribagh Pact (1937) and will establish the judicial capital at Kurnool to balance regional aspirations, he said.

Rajendranath added that the high court and all other judicial and associated offices will be established in Kurnool.

The decision to decentralise the capital was taken keeping in view the future, he said, adding that historically the Telugu speaking region has witnessed turbulence every 20 years over regional imbalances. “To avoid such situations we have decided to develop all regions equally by decenteralising the seat of power,” he said.

Title: Chennai: Anna University tells colleges to verify PhDs of faculty
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Anna University

CHENNAI: Following complaints that some faculty members are working with fake PhD certificates in engineering colleges, Anna University has asked all affiliated engineering colleges to get genuineness certificates for PhDs of their staff from concerned universities.

In a circular to principals and chairmen of engineering colleges, the university raised doubts that some faculty members might have bogus PhD degree certificates.

“PhD degree holders are having doctorates obtained from different universities and (are) lending their names to more number of colleges. It is also suspected that some faculty members are having bogus PhD degree certificates and working in affiliated colleges,” the circular said.

“Hence, the chairman/principals of all affiliated colleges are requested to apply for genuineness certificate of PhD degrees of their employees from concerned university and produce it to the inspection committee. Attested copy of genuineness certificate and PhD degree certificate should be submitted to the university on or before March 16,” the circular added.

Around 7,000 professors with PhDs are currently working in around 500 engineering colleges in Tamil Nadu .

Recently, there were complaints from faculty members to university that some faculty members were working by producing fake certificates.

“Any department should have professors, associate professors and assistant professors in the ratio of 1:2:6. Due to fake certificate menace, many faculty members not able to get employment in private colleges. These faculty members were also working for very low salary,” professor from an engineering college said.

Anna University officials said it is difficult to verify the genuineness of certificate during inspection. “If faculty members produce PhD certificates obtained from outside the state or from private universities, it is difficult to find out their genuineness,” an official said.

Title: Drought relief: Why Tamil Nadu has to cry harder
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: No sooner had Union finance minister Nirmal Sitharaman promised “comprehensive measures” for 100 water-starved districts than Tamil Nadu chief minister Edappadi Palaniswami raised his hand. “All water-starved districts in the state should be chosen for the Centre’s special programme and big funds have to be allocated,” said the chief minister.

EPS was being ambitious, but not without a reason. Drought-like conditions have been spreading across Tamil Nadu at an alarming pace, partly because of its inherent nature of its vast parts being in the rain-shadow region and partly because of climate change. Monsoon failure has left the state’s groundwater table overexploited. An assessment by the state public works department shows more than 60% of the state is short of water , the worst districts being Tiruvannamalai, Salem, Vellore, Thanjavur and Tirupur. Many of the districts including Chennai and Coimbatore overdraw groundwater.

Having been excluded from the Centre’s Atal Jal mission launched in seven states to strengthen groundwater resources, Tamil Nadu is keen to get a bigger pie from the proposed scheme. In December, the chief minister wrote to Prime Minister Narendra Modi , pointing out that 541 of the 1,166 firkas (revenue sub-divisions) in Tamil Nadu fall under the ‘critical’ and ‘over-exploited’ categories and they should be included in the Atal Jal programme. The Centre did not respond.

In Vellore, 33 of the district’s 52 firkas and 37 of the 52 in Tiruvannamalai have been found to be overexploited. Lack of flow from neighbouring states have compounded the problem. A Ashokan, a member of a non-profit called Reversal of Ecology Committee, Vellore, said construction of check dams and increasing the height of dams across the Palar by the Andhra Pradesh government have led to further drying up of Tamil Nadu’s northern districts. “Even those living along the banks of rivers struggle for drinking water. Governments of the past and the present looked at water only as an election issue,” Ashokan said.

Title: Gandhinagar: Woman officer complains of being cyberstalked
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A class-1 officer who works at the state secretariat in Gandhinagar has filed a police complaint of stalking and outraging her modesty against a Facebook friend, states an FIR filed with Sector-7 police. The complainant is going to retire within a year due to superannuation.

In her FIR with Sector-7 police of Gandhinagar, the woman, 57, resident of Sector-7 in Gandhinagar, states that she works at the post of deputy secretary at the state secretariat and an unknown man Upendra Raval, the accused in this case, was her Facebook friend.

“I was just his Facebook friend but I did not know that man in real life. The man had in September 2018 begun sending me lewd messages which cannot even be described,” states the FIR.

As he kept sending obscene messages, the woman warned him not to send such messages.

“But even then he kept sending such messages which are against dignity of a woman. On inquiring about this man, I found that he had four different accounts on Facebook,” she states in the FIR.

She also said that she had first filed an application to register a complaint before Gandhinagar SP.

The accused had on October 2, 2018 sent an obscene video to the woman and also dropped his contact number. Using this contact details, the cops came to know that the man was a resident of the Isanpur area of city.

Sector-7 police on Friday registered a complaint of stalking under IPC along with charges under Information Technology Act.

Title: Asaduddin Owaisi slams arrest of school headmistress
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: AIMIM president Asaduddin Owaisi took umbrage at sedition charges filed against a school headmistress in Karnataka’s Bidar for staging a play against CAA in her school. He expressed hope that the charges against the headmistress, Farida Begum , would be dropped soon. He met Bidar district SP T Sreedhara on Saturday in connection with the arrest of the headmistress of Shaheen Urdu Medium Primary School.

“Met with SP Bidar. We strongly objected to arrest & sedition charge for a school play. He said it’s under investigation & sedition maybe removed I said this should’ve been done before arresting these women as they are local residents. How can a school play be a crime? (sic)” he tweeted.

Farida and Najamunnisa, mother of a student, were arrested after social activist Neelesh Rakshal filed a complaint. An FIR under sedition charges was filed against them.

After meeting the headmistress and Navida in Bidar Prison, Owaisi tweeted: “In a condemnable incident, they were arrested by Bidar police for sedition in connection with a school play.”

Six children, who acted in the play, were below 10 and examined by cops in presence of their parents. Staffers of the school were also questioned.

Owaisi also opposed KTR’s idea of adopting Mumbai’s traffic model. “This is a primitive way of punishing entire traffic at a traffic signal because of few cars honking...,” he tweeted.

Title: State eyes dividends from Centre’s airports plan
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhubaneswar/Berhampur: The Budget proposal to develop 100 airports under the Centre’s Udan scheme has come as a boost to the prospects of Rourkela, Utkela and Jeypore to find a spots on the domestic flight map. The three smaller airstrips in Sundargarh, Kalahandi and Koraput districts, respectively, have been included under the Centre’s regional connectivity scheme.

In a recent meeting, civil aviation secretary P S Kharola and state government officials said the Rourkela airport would require an additional 41 acres for development of virtual flight rules (VFR) and 143 acres for instrument flight rules (IFR) to enable landing of ATR-72 flights under Udan.

The Rourkela, Utkela and Jeypore airstrips will be made operational under Udan IV, for which the Centre will start bidding this year.

The Birasal airstrip in Dhenkanal, which is now being used by the Government Aviation Training Institute (GATI) to provide flight training for aspiring pilots, may be included under Udan, as the state government has decided to make the airstrip fully operational soon. The Birsal airstrip had got approval from Director General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) in November last year and started flying trainee aircrafts in December on a temporary basis.

Ganjam district’s pre-independent airstrip at Rangeilunda may also be one of the new airstrips to be included under Udan. Berhampur, the biggest commercial hub in southern Odisha, is yet to be connected with air travel. “We hope the Rangeilunda airstrip will be developed under the proposed scheme,” said former union minister and Berhampur MP Chandra Sekhar Sahu. Last year he had given a proposal to the Centre for development of an airport near Berhampur.

EoM

Title: ‘Pvt medical college plan in sync with FM’s announcement’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Health minister Vishwajit Rane said that he is happy that the Union Budget lays thrust on private participation in tertiary health care. “There are many positives in the Budget. I will need time to study it entirely. As for as setting up a private medical college in Goa, we will go by the Centre’s roadmap,” he said.

Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman , in her Budget speech, spoke about a proposal to attach an existing district hospital to a medical college via the public private partnership (PPP) mode.

Rane had earlier announced plans to allow a private college in South Goa which would be linked to South Goa District Hospital. Goa currently has only medical college, the GMC.

Title: Marathon speech ended in utter despair: AAP
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Panaji: A Budget speech of nearly two hours and 45 minutes the longest ever had very high expectations but ended in utter despair, AAP said on Saturday.

Party functionary Rahul Mahambrey said the Budget failed to lay out a path to give employment to the youth, announce measures to boost the housing and manufacturing sectors, or give impetus to the sluggish economy by increasing citizens’ spending power.

Mahambrey said the government had not thought about the present socio-political situation prevailing across the country, which involves the youth who are out on the streets. He said that it’s a steep climb for the government to achieve a 6.5% growth in the backdrop of six consecutive quarters of decline in growth figures.

While agreeing that an allocation of Rs 99,300 crore for education, up by 4.7%, was a good measure, the AAP functionary said a higher allocation was desirable .

“An allocation of only Rs 3,000 crore for skill development is awful. For a country that has a third of its population in the 15-24 years age group, a higher allocation to education and skill development was required as it would build a foundation for a stronger and resurgent India,” he said.

On the personal taxation front, Mahambrey said an option not to claim any deductions to avail lower tax slab rates would hit personal household savings. “This will affect young families who will be spending impulsive rather than building on their savings and wealth for later years,” he said.

Title: Special bridge courses may benefit state’s healthcare providers
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kochi: With job opportunities opening for healthcare providers in Germany and Japan, the proposal in the Union budget to introduce special bridge courses will benefit several nurses and para-medical staff in the state.

The courses, to be designed by the ministries of health and skill development along with professional bodies, will aim at ensuring that a candidate’s skill set matches the employer’s requirements and also meet the language requirements of various countries.

“In several countries, it is important to know the local language. While healthcare providers from Kerala are high in demand, often language is a barrier. Therefore, such an initiative will certainly benefit Malayalis,” said N Sasidharan Nair, chairman, Overseas Development & Employment Promotion Consultant Ltd, that functions under the state ministry of labour.

In 2019, majority of health care providers from the state were recruited in Saudi Arabia and United Kingdom. Incidentally, job opportunities for healthcare providers from the state is on a decline in Saudi Arabia, making it important for them to explore new avenues.

Teachers from Kerala are mostly in demand in Indian schools in the Middle East, UAE and Qatar.

“This discussion is not new. It has been going on for long. But nothing has happened on the ground yet,” said Aboobacker MK, director, Careers World Travels & Tradelinks, Kozhikode.

Title: Karur Vysya Bank reports Q3 net profit down by 29%
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: Karur Vysya Bank reports net profit declined by 29% at Rs 15 crore for the quarter ended December 2019, as against profit of Rs 21 crore in the same period last year. Sequentially the bank reported a profit of Rs 63 crore.

Net Interest Margin for the quarter remained strong at 3.33%, while net interest income and other income continue to be stable. In the third quarter, deposit grew by 6% (Rs 3,638 crore) to Rs 62,262 crore, and the CASA share improved to 31% (Rs 19,063 crore).

The private bank’s bad loans (gross NPA) has gone up to 8.92% in December, 2019 from 8.49% in December, 2018, as against 8.89% in September, 2019.

Provision Coverage Ratio has increased over the last four quarters to a high of 65.43% - up by 857 bps. Year-on-year, advances growth was moderate at 4% (Rs 1,847 crore) from Rs 47,766 crore to Rs 49,613 crore, despite shrinking corporate portfolio due to the overall market conditions.

Retail credit growth continues to be strong at 21%. Gold loans have grown by 10% (Y-o-Y), aided by migration of the underwriting process to a digital platform and resulted in portfolio climbing up by Rs 450 crore during the quarter, as compared to Rs 250 crore during the last quarter.

Capital Adequacy remained robust at 15.87%, with CET-1 ratio at 14.14% much higher than the regulatory minima of 7.375%. Shares of the bank ended at Rs 45.9 apiece, down 4% on BSE.

Title: Mumbai: No action plan for joblessness, auto sector, says Sharad Pawar
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

NCP president Sharad Pawar

MUMBAI: Reacting sharply to Budget 2020, NCP president Sharad Pawar said on Saturday it was the longest speech by a finance minister but was not far-sighted and lacked vision.

“The finance minister was expected to draft an action plan to revive the automobile sector and tackle the issue of unemployment. But she ignored both the crucial issues. There was lack of vision and no specific action plan was drafted to double the income of farmers,” he said.

State NCP president and water resources minister Jayant Patil called it a directionless budget and disappointing for the agriculture sector. “We expected a major action plan to tackle the agrarian crisis. But no steps have been taken for the welfare of farmers,” he said.

Patil further said at a time when Prime Minister Narendra Modi was expected to take key decisions to revive the economy, no measures have been taken to restore people’s confidence. “No steps have been taken to halt recession in all sectors,” he said.

Patil said when GST was introduced, Modi had said it will help strengthen the economy of the states. But now, two years later, the economy of most states has collapsed and funds have not been released for them, he said. “The government’s decision to sell Air India reflects the state of affairs in the country,” said Patil. More shocking, he said, was the fact that Maharashtra and Mumbai have been ignored. “Since maximum taxes are recovered from Mumbai, we were expecting a better deal. Modi is concentrating on Ahmedabad.’’

Revenue minister and state Congress president Balasaheb Thorat described the Budget as meaningless and directionless. “Modi has ignored Maharashtra.”

Title: Bengaluru: Charged Rs 20 more for water at multiplex, man wins Rs 7,000
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A moviegoer who sued a city multiplex for selling him a 500ml water bottle for Rs 40 — double the Maximum Retail Price (MRP) printed on it — has won the legal battle. A Bengaluru consumer court has pulled up the multiplex authorities for illegal trade practice, ordering them to pay him a refund of Rs 20, compensation of Rs 5,000 and Rs 2,000 towards court expenses.

The proceedings began at 3rd Additional Bangalore Urban District Consumer Disputes Redressal Forum in September 2017 when Dasarahalli resident Om Hedge Uratota lodged a complaint against Cinépolis Royal Meenakshi Mall in Hulimavu, Bannerghatta Main Road .

Uratota had visited Cinépolis on June 7, 2017, and purchased a half-litre Kinley bottle. Much to his chagrin, the seller demanded Rs 40 even though the MRP was Rs 20, and told him a one-litre bottle would cost Rs 50. Following a brief argument, Uratota paid the money but he wasn’t planning to let the issue of illegal pricing go. He sent a legal notice to the mall authorities but didn’t get a response.

Uratota then approached the consumer forum against the multiplex on September 7, 2017, citing deficiency in service and illegal trade practice. The multiplex authorities, represented by an attorney, said the complaint was vexatious, false and frivolous. The lawyer said the multiplex offered top-notch amenities to customers and had obtained the required approvals from the government. The lawyer added users could drink free water from dispensers in the multiplex or buy bottled water sold on the premises through ‘select channels’ for Rs 40 for 500ml and Rs 50 for 1 litre.

The judges noted that colour photocopies of the Kinley bottle in question didn’t have an MRP printed on it or it had been possibly removed. They said the lawyer representing the multiplex mentioned about the facilities provided to customers but failed to provide justification for collecting Rs 40 for a half-litre bottle which is sold outside at an MRP of Rs 20.

The judges came down heavily on Cinepolis representatives for the illegal trade practice of charging more than the MRP and cheating customers. On the other hand, they lauded Uratota for his single-minded pursuit to fight such illegalities and not remain a mute spectator when his hard-earned money was being unlawfully pocketed.

In the verdict pronounced on January 16, 2020, the forum ruled that Royal Meenakshi Mall authorities, within 30 days, must refund Rs 20 with 12% annual interest to Uratota, who had been charged in excess of the MRP, and also pay Rs 5,000 as compensation for causing him mental agony. An additional Rs 2,000 should be paid to Uratota towards court expenses, the judges ordered.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Betting racket busted, 29 arrested
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: Crime branch of the district police have busted a cricket betting racket and arrested 29 persons from a building in Rani Mandi area under Attarsuiya police station, on late Friday night.

The arrseted persons were allegedly betting on India-New Zealand cricket match underway in Wellington, New Zealand. Police have also recovered cash worth over Rs 2.15 lakh.

ASP Anil Yadav said that on a tip-off, a team led by CO Civil Lines Brijnarayan Singh and SWAT in-charge/SHO-Ghoorpur Vrindavan Rai raided the building and nabbed 29 people betting on the cricket match. The police recovered cash worth Rs 2.15 lakh and 10 live bullets of 32 bore, he added.

An FIR in this connetion has been registered at Attarsuiya police station under relevant sections and the accused have been sent to jail, police said.

Title: Adichanallur to have an on-site museum
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bones and other remains inside an urn found buried in Adichanallur in Tuticorin district

CHENNAI: Adichanallur in Tuticorin district is among the five archaeological sites that would be developed with on-site museums, said Nirmala Sitharaman, minister of finance, in her Budget 2020-21 speech. Rakhigarhi (Haryana), Hastinapur (Uttar Pradesh), Shivsagar (Assam) and Dholavira (Gujarat) are the others.

Adichanallur, a remote village, is home to a three-tier cemetery spread over more than 200 acres, one of the largest and oldest early Iron Age cemeteries in South Asia. While past excavations at Adichanallur brought to light many salient features of a composite culture that could bridge the gaps in the cultural assemblages of South East Asia, one conducted by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) in 2004-06, found 85 human skeletons in a squatting position in giant, dual-coloured clay urns. The report, however, took a long time to be filed.

In 2019, ASI submitted before the Madras high court’s Madurai bench carbon dating results of samples taken from Adichanallur and sent to a lab in Miami, Florida, and Kalina Campus, University of Mumbai. The report said one of the urns is aged between 696BC-540 BC (2,645-2,489 years) and 791BC-701 BC (2,740-2,650 years), while the other is from 905-806 BC (2,854-2,755 years). The division bench noted that the results proved Adichanallur was the earliest ancient site in Tamil Nadu.

Raghavan Pathmanathan, who studied the material excavated from Adichanallur, found its population included more than one ethnic group ans all lived together in peace. “The skeletal remains also prove their sea-faring trade activities. The cultural material unearthed reflect various stratum of the population that lived there.”

An on-site museum at Adichannalur, under ASI Chennai circle, is a great idea, say heritage experts. T Sathyamurth, former superintending archaeologist of ASI who headed the excavation in 2004-06it would help the site get the importance it deserves.

Sathyamurthy pointed out how Arikamedu in Puducherry, one of the earliest Roman sites in the Tamilakam lost its significance after being excavated in 1945-50 due to the lack of an on-site museum.

Title: Ahmedabad: Extortion complaint filed against real estate broker
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 46-year-old businessman from Vastral, Vatsal Patel, on Friday registered a complaint against a real estate broker, Bhupendra Patel, a resident of Santosha Nimlane in Adalaj, for attempting to extort Rs 1 crore from him. Odhav police have registered an offence under Sections 384 and 294(b) of the IPC against Bhupendra.

According to the FIR, Vatsal had bought a 4,401 square metre plot in Singarva from a farmer named Narsinh Patel in 2016. Vatsal stated that between June 2016 and July 2017, he had paid Rs 92,45,000 to Narsinh and only Rs 2,450 was outstanding.

According to the FIR, Narsinh had signed an agreement to sell the plot to Vatsal, and had promised to register the sale deed soon. However, he did not register the sale deed with Vatsal and instead sold the land to one Paresh Patel in 2019, along with a non-agricultural (NA) certificate.

Vatsal Patel and his partners learned about the sale to someone else on December 28, 2019, and lodged a complaint against Narsinh at Odhav police station.

Vatsal Patel stated in his FIR that before he bought the plot from Narsinh Patel, they had a series of meetings at which Bhupendra Patel was present, as the deal broker.

“Vatsal and his partners then went to Bhupendra Patel and told him that Narsinh had sold the plot to someone else and was refusing to register a sale deed with them despite them paying him in full,” a police source said.

The FIR states that after a series of meetings, Bhupendra told them that he would need Rs 1 crore to convince Narsinh to register the sale deed with them. Vatsal and his partners did not agree to this because they had already paid the full sum to Narsinh.

Bhupendra Patel finally bluntly told them that they should pay him Rs 1 crore or he would block the sale deed with Narsinh Patel.

Title: Seers search for salvation along banks of Ganga with ‘dhuni tap’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Seers performing ‘Dhooni Tap’ at Khak Chowk area on Magh Mela campus

Allahabad: The sight of seers surrounded by dense smoke and meditating are drawing the attention of many a visitors at the Magh Mela ground in Allahabad these days.

Joining the rush to attain salvation during the Magh Mela, seers choose the strict ritual of ‘dhuni tap’ as a form of atonement during the 10-day period between the snans on Basant Panchami and Magh Purnima.

Performed along the banks of Ganga, the ‘sadhak’ (the person who performs the ritual) fasts for the day, meditates and prays in a fixed asan. The seer is surrounded by the thick smoke billowing from fires lit up using cow dung.

Also known as ‘panch agni tap’, this harsh form of self-denial is being practised by saints since decades. “This is among the oldest forms of penance and it also finds a mention in ancient Hindu scriptures like the Padma Puran and Shiv Puran. The scriptures mention Naga seers surrounded by fire and meditating for hours together,” said city-based astrologer Ram Naresh Tripathi.

The ritual starts with seers sitting around four fires, using cow dung, while the sun acts as the fifth source of fire.

As the ritual progresses, the numbers of fires lit up also increases. “The ‘sadhak’ then carries a fire pot on his head. The final stage of the ritual is called kapal dhuni, wherein the fire (dhuni) is lit up in a bowl (kapal),” he added.

During the ‘dhuni tap’, seers also offer food to the burning cow dung cakes, while reciting mantras. Having made the offering, the seers blow a conch shell to invoke the deity. This marks the end of preliminary rituals and the seer then proceeds to meditate.

Most saints perform the ritual between the sandy banks of the two bridges over Ganga connecting Allahabad to Jhunsi during the Magh Mela.

Magh Purnima will be observed on February 9.

Title: Octopus base likely to be shifted
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The Organisation for Counter-Terrorist Operations (Octopus) base is likely to be shifted to Visakhapatnam from Mangalagiri. Its over 25 km long coastline and the presence of other defence establishments in and around in the city make the region condusive for setting up the Octopus base.

However, a senior IPS officer said, “There’s no news of the base of Octopus being shifted out of the CRDA region. If at all it is shifted, the anti-terrorist wing would need around 100 acres of land to set up the quarters and training arena.”

Sources said, the base would be accommodated close to the Greyhounds. Earlier, there was a plan to set up a regional center of Octopus in Visakhapatnam with a unit of commandos. But with the government gearing to set up three capital, with Visakhapatnam as the executive capital, the plan is likely to be revised, said sources.

The question whether the base of Octopus would be moved out of Mangalagiri gains in importance because Octopus commandos replaced Greyhound commandos in the security cover of chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy last year.

Title: Electronics policy may help state get back on its feet
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: The new electronics manufacturing policy announced in the Union Budget , which seeks to encourage manufacturing of electronics and semiconductors in India, will bring Tamil Nadu back on its feet as a manufacturing hub after it lost out to Uttar Pradesh following the exit of Nokia in 2014.

India offers tremendous cost advantage in electronics manufacturing, and the sector has a high job-creation potential. Domestic manufacturing will also bring with it large investments, the finance minister said in her Budget speech.

Though industrial houses in the state, which is home to about 10 large electronic manufacturers and more than 300 small and medium manufacturers, are waiting for finer details, they are gung-ho over the policy.

The announcement couldn’t have come at a more opportune time for the state, especially with Foxconn, Flex and Salcomp announcing plans to expand or already expanding their

operations.

"In the next 12 months when we expect more clarity on the policy and definite action, we foresee a doubling of output from the state’s electronic manufacturing sector. If we focus on improving the ease of doing business, the state’s share would improve. Four of the largest EMS companies have their presence in TN and they will increase their investments," said George Paul, CEO, Manufacturers Association for

Information Technology (MAIT).

Salcomp, which has agreed to acquire Nokia plant in Sriperumbudur, is seeing heightened action. The company’s India MD, Sasikumar Gendham, said the new policy could accelerate its current plan to invest `2,000 crore and employ 10,000 people (direct employment) over the next five years.

Typically, at least five new indirect jobs are created for every direct employment.

Foxconn has resumed operations in TN with the highlight being assembling iPhones. Country head and India MD Josh Foulger, in an earlier interview, said the state has a $100 billion opportunity in the electronics manufacturing space.

Besides Foxconn, Flex is scouting for land in Tamil Nadu to increase its

manufacturing presence in the state by setting up a new plant. The company now has four facilities.

Title: Goa: State left out, leaders have no sway at Centre, says Vijai Sardesai
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijai Sardesai

PANAJI: Goa Forward Party (GFP) president Vijai Sardesai said on Saturday that while the state government is taking suggestions for the Goa budget from the public, it forgot to give its suggestions to the Central government for the Union Budget.

He said that despite both, Central and state governments being BJP governments, there is nothing in the Budget for Goa. With this, he said, one can conclude that the state leaders promises have no weightage at the Centre.

Sardesai said that GFP, along with like-minded parties including Congress and MGP, will bring up this and other issues such as Mhadei and CAA/NCR/NPR for discussion at the upcoming state assembly session.

“The Budget was 2.5 hours long, but the stock markets are unhappy. The Goa Chamber of Commerce and Industry has said it is below expectations where Goa is concerned. I don’t understand how farmers will benefit. This Budget is nothing but an exercise in grandstanding. The speech was so long that even the finance minister became uncomfortable. This is only being done because the Delhi assembly polls are coming up,” Sardesai said.

Sardesai also said that chief minister Pramod Sawant had announced at the start of the year that 5,000 jobs are being created, but that in reply to a question for the upcoming assembly session, the government said that state is ‘unable to quantify the number’.

Title: Goa: GFP to bring up Deepak Pauskar extortion case in assembly
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijai Sardesai

PANAJI: GFP chief Vijai Sardesai on Saturday said that his party will bring up for discussion in the upcoming state assembly session the case of extortion from the PWD minister Deepak Pauskar .

He said that it is a matter of concern that a member of legislative assembly was threatened and some persons tried to extort money from him, yet the accused were barely kept one night in custody and released prematurely.

“It is a very serious issue. Every MLA can be a soft target. Mysteriously the people who were arrested were not kept in police custody. They were kept in judicial custody and within one night they were given bail. It is not even investigated by the police,” Sardesai said on Saturday.

He said that there are various types of speculations with regards to this case and everyone in the state has a right to know what the case was about.

Title: Locals should be allowed to visit casinos: Ports minister Michael Lobo
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Michael Lobo

CALANGUTE: Even as the state BJP government enforced The Goa Public Gambling (Amendment) Act, 2012, which debars Goans from entering casinos , party MLA and ports minister Michael Lobo on Saturday said Goans should be allowed to continue visiting them. He said there was a difference between entry and gaming and that Goans could not be stopped from entering casinos.

“There are other things in casinos besides gaming. There is music, entertainment, food, etc. Somebody will challenge this in court,” he told reporters at Parra. “Nepal and Sri Lanka have banned their citizens from gambling in casinos. Goans are Indian nationals, so you should not allow all Indians entry while not allowing Goans. This needs to be debated at the highest levels.”

Lobo said former CM Manohar Parrikar had amended the law to ban Goans from casinos following complaints that gambling had ruined people financially. He said there have been cases of people taking bank loans to gamble, hoping they would become rich instantly, only to lose their money. “Because of this, Parrikar had amended the law. This government is implementing the new law,” he said.

Title: Renovated Valankulam, Periyakulam lakes to open for public from March
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Coimbatore: The city corporation is planning to open parts of Valankulam and Periyakulam lakes, which are being beautified under the smart city mission, for public from March.

The civic body had proposed to beautify the bunds of the lakes under the ‘quick-win’ projects category. Restoration works are being carried out along the Perur Bypass side of Periyakulam lake at a cost of Rs 39.74 crore. Beautification of walkers’ plaza along Valankulam lake is done at a cost of24.31 crore and works are undergoing beneath the Valankulam flyover at a cost of Rs 23.83 crore. The works were flagged off in July 2018.

After floating decks were installed on the lakes and the bunds were decorated, people have been thronging the places. Commuters stop vehicles near the lakes to click pictures even though they are not allowed to access the premises as work is still going on.

A senior corporation official said that each project has about 450 components including floating decks, gardens, birdwatching towers, fountains, shade structures, bicycle tracks, benches, lamps and container restaurants. “As it is the first time beautification works are being carried out along lake bunds, it took the contractors more time to complete the work. They have planted 40 types of native plants along the lakes,” he told TOI.

Municipal administration minister SP Velumani had conducted a review meeting a few days ago, the official said. “The minister directed the contractors to speed up the work to complete it before March. Over 70% of the construction work, especially installation of important components, have been completed.”

Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami is expected to throw the spaces open for recreation and relaxation to thousands of residents in March, the official added.

Title: Over 700 banks shut as strike enters second day
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Coimbatore: More than 700 branches of public and private sector banks remained closed on Saturday as the strike by bank employees demanding the central government to fulfil their demands entered into second day. More than 5,000 employees from 20 public sector banks and 22 private banks participated in the strike.

R Maheswaran, district general secretary, Bank Employees’ Federation of India, said, “Unlike other central government departments, we work six days every alternative week. Each day, we work for 11 to 12 hours. We have been undergoing tremendous pressure due to unregulated working hours and it is affecting our performance.”

He wondered whether it was too much to ask for regulated working hours and 5 working days a week that were already implemented in other central government departments.

The employees, he said, had long been also demanding the central government to scrape the new pension scheme, update the pension and family pension and allocate the staff welfare fund based on operating profit instead of net profit, but in vain.

Pointing out that public sector banks were offering the companies that create employment opportunities low interest rates, no service charge and no processing charge, Maheswaran said that would have an impact on the net profit of banks. “That’s why we have been demanding the government to allocate the staff welfare fund based on operating profit of the banks.”

The employees also want the government to revise their wages. While their demand is 20% hike, the government has expressed willingness to increase the wages up to 13.5%. During the recent talk that was held with the employees, officials had promised to recommend their demands to update family pension to the government, he said.

Bank Employees’ Federation of India has decided to stage a three-day bank strike from March 11, to press their demands.

Title: Allahabad University teacher lodges FIR against four professors for ‘manhandling’ him
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

Allahabad: An Allahabad University ( AU ) faculty member on Saturday lodged an FIR against four senior professors — including the varsity’s former proctor Ram Sevak Dubey — for allegedly abusing him and manhandling him during a meeting on campus.

According to reports, the complainant DC Lal is a faculty member of AU’s physical education department. The four professors named in the FIR are Ram Sevak Dubey, Harsh Kumar, Pankaj Kumar and Rajesh Singh. The FIR was lodged at Colonelganj police station.

The FIR has been lodged under section 323 (punishment for voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (punishment to for intentionally insults) and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code.

In his complaint, Lal alleged that the incident occurred during a meeting of AU Teachers’ Association convened at the medieval and modern history department on Friday.

“When I raised the issue of conducting elections for appointing members of teachers’ union and the returning officer for the said polls, the four faculty members started abusing me. They made remarks against me and also manhandled me. They then pushed me out of the room by pulling at my collar,” Lal told the police in his complaint.

Of the four accused professors, Harsh Kumar is the former dean of student welfare, Pankaj Kumar is a former member of the UP Public Service Commission. Rajesh Singh is presently the superintendent of Tara Chand Hostel.

Inspector of Colonelganj police station Arun Kumar Tyagi said, “Lal has registered a complaint and on the basis of the same we have registered an FIR. We are probing the case.” The inspector confirmed that the four faculty members have been named in the FIR.

One of the faculty members accused in the FIR, Harsh Kumar said, “The AUTA meeting had begun with opening comments from Dubey. After him, Deepshikha Sonkar stood up to speak, but Lal interrupted her and raised the issue of conducting elections for appointing AUTA members. Pankaj Kumar had then alleged that Lal had been posting objectionable comments on a WhatsApp group of AU teachers. A number of teachers present at the meeting also objected to the posts.”

Officials said that in the WhatsApp group, Lal had alleged that teachers were being appointed in AU on the basis of commission.

Lal left the meeting and and lodged an FIR on Saturday.

“An incident, which was witnessed by so many teachers, has been misrepresented. There is no truth in the allegations,” said Harsh Kumar.

Lal also alleged that the accused used ‘jaati soochak’ (casteist) remarks against him.

Title: Postal dept gets 15k entries for letter writing competition
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Coimbatore: The postal department in the district received 15 ,764 entries for the annual letter writing competition, Dhai Akhar , as the last date for entry submission ended on Friday. While this is almost 10,000 entries less than last year’s 25,000 entries, officials are confident that this year too Coimbatore would top the number of entries from Tamil Nadu and Kerala. The competition was introduced by the postal department to inculcate the habit of letter writing among the current generation that is more technology driven.

Speaking to the media on Saturday, Sudhir Gopal Jakhere, senior superintendent of post offices, Coimbatore, said they had received 15,764 entries from students across 50 schools in the district as of Friday. The competition was announced in August with November 30 as the last date to submit entries. The deadline for submission of entries was, however, extended twice and fixed on January 31, due to shortage of stationary in post offices.

This year’s topic for letter writing competition is “Dear Bapu, you are immortal”. “The letter had to be written only on our inland letters or submitted in our postal envelopes,” Jakhere said.

According to another official, the competition also aims to create awareness on postal stationary, besides inculcating letter writing habit among the young generation.

While the competition is open to any member of the public, it will be judged in two categories - below 18 years and above 18 years of age.

This year is special for the district, as in a first it has got two visually challenged students from CSI boys’ high school to write their letters in Braille. “Though they wrote the letters from 5pm to 6.15pm, we have ensured that their letters have entered the competition,” Jakhere said.

Title: Two businessmen killed in SUV accident on ORR
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Two businessmen were killed at Rallaguda in Shamshabad when their SUV hit a moving lorry from behind on the Outer Ring Road (ORR). Police, who are ascertaining if the SUV driver was under the influence of alcohol, said the two businessmen along with a friend were on their way to Farooq Nagar when the accident occurred in the early hours of Saturday.

Bal Reddy, 35, was at the wheel. From Kukatpally, he drove till Gachibowli and got on to ORR to reach Farooq Nagar via Shamshabad. When the SUV reached Rallaguda, Bal Reddy dashed into the lorry at a high speed. The lorry was just ahead of the SUV. “It looks like it was a mistake on the part of Bal Reddy and the lorry driver was not at fault,” RGIA police SI Venkateshwarlu said.

While Bal Reddy died on the spot, the two others — businessman M Narasimha and M Shankar, both 35, — suffered serious injuries. Narasimha died while undergoing treatment. Both the deceased sat in the front seats of the ill-fated vehicle at the time of the crash, police said.

The accident occurred at 1.30 am. A case was registered under section 304-A (negligence causing death) of the IPC. Police said they are waiting for post-mortem report to ascertain whether it was a case of drunken driving.

The deceased hailed from Farooq Nagar.

Title: Goa: Celebrating our soil & its abolim
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vishwanath Shetkar’s live pottery counter at the festival

PANAJI: This year, the theme of the annual Abolianchem fest, a cultural festival dedicated to the flower Crossandra infundibuliformis (firecracker flower) locally known as ‘ abolim ’, was ‘Goenchi Mati’ ( Goan soil ).

The day-long event on Saturday started with a traditional brass band led a procession of people in ethnic wear.
