Trainee teachers of the Nirmala Institute of Education (NIE), which organised the event, performed a prayer dance. A song dedicated to the Goan soil and a poem depicting the richness of Goan soil was also put up.

The institute’s officiating principal, Delia Antao, urged visitors to celebrate and appreciate ‘Goenchi mati,’ by understanding the Goan culture and in turn growing in responsibility to save the land.

Institute director Rita Paes told guests to adopt kitchen gardening.

The festival had an interactive pottery counter by Vishwanath Shetkar . Among the various stalls, there was a photo-booth that showcased traditional mud houses with ‘choouls’.

The trainee teachers clad in elegant traditional attires danced to the beat of ‘cotti fugdi’ and ‘kalshi fugdi’. A harvest dance was also performed. Traditional games such as ‘fatrani’ and ‘mitani’ were demonstrated to the public while ‘tiktem’, ‘vrani’, ‘tablam’ and other games were organised for visitors.

A one-act play ‘Matiechi Girestkai’ highlighted various facets of Goan soil. A street play ‘Amchi Jin Matiyechem Rinn’ was staged by the trainee teachers.

Title: Woman attempts suicide due to dowry harassment by in-laws
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: A woman attempted suicide by consuming pesticide on Friday night allegedly due to harassment by her in-laws for dowry . The victim, P Lawanya, married Yasaram Jagadish, a resident of Parvathapur village in Ghatkesar, a few months ago and her parents gave Rs 1.5 lakh cash and 10 tolas of gold as dowry. However, her in-laws allegedly started harassing for more dowry.

On Friday night, the victim was rushed to Yashoda Hospital after she consumed pesticide. She is currently undergoing treatment. Lawanya’s parents filed a dowry harassment case against the victim’s in-laws at Medipally police station. Police are yet to arrest the accused. tnn

Title: Capital farmers in Delhi to meet PM
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: A group of farmers went to New Delhi on Saturday to take up the issue of the three- capital proposal with the Union government. They are planning to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Union home minister Amit Shah and other Union ministers.

The farmers met TDP MP Kesineni Srinivas on Saturday who is coordinating the appointments. They will be in Delhi for two days. tnn

Title: Budget: Focus on taxpayers, farmers earns public praise
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Many organisations arranged big screens to watch the budget speech

Allahabad: The Union Budget 2020 evoked a mixed response from Allahabad citizens, most of whom welcomed the provisions for the middle-class and farmers of the country announced by finance minster Nirmala Sitharaman.

Chartered accountant Sunil Singh said, “The message the government tried to send across with this budget was welcoming. It focussed on middle-class taxpayers. All in all, it was a non-political budget which will boost the economy.”

On the other hand, city-based lawyer Manoj Kumar Singh ‘Lokesh’ said the allocations announced this year were disappointing.

“The cost of auto parts and medical devices equipment will go up. There is nothing for lawyers or to ease the struggles of the common man in getting justice. There is hardly anything to talk about in this year’s budget,” he added.

Meanwhile, housewife Pratibha rues the rise in prices of various commodities. “The finance minister announced several measures for farmers and the poor, but what about housewives who are struggling to run households with limited budgets? We have seen prices rises for almost every commodity including fuel. The government also did not say anything about how they plan to bring down the rising prices.”

Businessman Pawan Agarwal, who owns a construction company, said he was happy with the Budget as it sought to increase the spending ability of the common man. “However, I wish there were some provisions for construction and real estate sector, which is often stifled by strict laws,” he added.

Smita, a PhD scholar from Allahabad University, said that the lack of any announcements related to setting up of IITs or central universities left much to be desired from this year’s Union Budget.

“This is budget was mostly for the farming community, but even the salaried class would be happy with the new slabs of income tax,” she added.

Meanwhile, North Central Railway’s chief public relation officer Ajeet Kumar Singh lauded the announcement of new trains, especially the ones on the lines of Tejas.

“There are several announcements made by the Union finance minister in this year’s Budget. However, we would get to know the exact details about how they would affect the NCR only after the release of the pink book,” he added.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Special train to Palani to clear Thaipoosam rush
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The Southern Railway has introduced an additional train between Coimbatore and Palani for 11 days to manage the rush during the Thaipoosam festival . The train will leave the city at 9.45am and reach Palani at 12.45pm. It will then leave Palani at 1.45pm and reach the city at 4.45pm. A day train to Palani has been a long-pending demand of rail activists and devotees, as the existing one leaves the city in the afternoon and reaches Palani in the evening, forcing devotees to either catch a bus for return trip or stay back there overnight and take the morning train to the city.

The railway on Saturday said it would run the special train service from February 2 to 12, to clear extra rush of devotees to the Arulmigu Dhandayuthapani Temple for the Thaipoosam festival.

Devotees, who manage to finish their darshan in an hour, could take the return train that would start from Palani at 1.45pm. Or else, they could take the train that leaves Palani at 5.30pm and reaches the city at 9.50pm. There is also a morning train that leaves Palani at 10.45am and reaches the city at 2.10pm.

Deputy speaker Pollachi V Jayaraman and MP P R Natarajan welcomed the announcement and said the special train was introduced based on their requests. Natarajan said he had demanded the train during the divisional rail users’ committee meeting on January 7, while Pollachi Jayaraman said he had officially written to the Southern Railway asking for the train in December and as recently as January 23.

The special train will have 10 coaches. Thaipoosam, which is celebrated in commemoration of Goddess Parvati giving Lord Muruga a “vel” or spear to vanquish evil demon Soorapadman, draws huge crowd to the Murugan temple in Palani. “More than the timings, we wanted to introduce just another train to clear the rush of devotees, who are otherwise forced to take buses as the existing trains become too crowded,” said a railway official.

Title: Chennai: 50 squatters set to be evicted from Pallikaranai marshland
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

At least 1,085 squatters occupy the marsh at five different locations

CHENNAI: At least 50 houses encroaching on Pallikaranai marshland are set to be removed, and occupants relocated to slum clearance board tenements in Perumbakkam . The eviction is part of the forest department’s plan to restore the marshland as ordered by the Madras high court. At least 1,085 squatters have been occupying the marshland at five different locations.

V Karuna Priya, Chennai circle chief conservator of forests, said the department had been taking a series of measures to restore the marshland, evicting squatters by providing them alternative housing accommodation.

A total of 1,085 squatters are occupying marshland in five different locations. There are 70 in Mahalakshmi Nagar, Mettukkuppam; 100 in Dr Ambedkar Nagar, Veppampatti; 550 in Kamakshi Nagar; 115 in Quaid-E-Milleth Nagar and 250 in K P Kandan Nagar.

The department conducted biometric survey in August last year in Mahalakshmi Nagar and Ambedkar Nagar.

In Mahalakshmi Nagar alone, of the 74 encroachers, only 50 were identified as eligible ones, as others did not have correct address proof. In Ambedkar Nagar 102 encroachers were identified. All of them in the area were found to be eligible for getting tenements. For the remaining areas the biometric survey would be taken up soon.

To get the allotment in the Perumbakkam tenements, the department deposited Rs 34.78 lakh with the Slum Clearance Board in November last year.

District forest officer V Subbiah said this is the first time that encroachers of a marshland were being removed and given alternative accommodation.

Chennai-based biodiversity research organisation Care Earth Trust’s co-founder Jayashree Vencatesan said in 2002 when the first assessment of the marshland was undertaken there was already a loss of 90% of its original habitat.

Another challenge to the authorities is encroachers on the fringes of the wetland, as they are intensifying their efforts to convert the ecosystem into a habitable zone by dumping solid waste and compacting it with construction debris, she said.

Title: No major railway announcements for Kerala in Sitharaman’s speech
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: With huge promises to improve railway infrastructure in the country, passenger associations are hopeful about the allocations for the state. Though no specific announcement were made for the state, electrification, utilising renewable energy and operation of trains in PPP modal were some of the proposals in the Union Budget.

P Krishnakumar, member, Zonal Railway Users’ Consultative Committee said that the investments for electrification of entire broad gauge network by 2023-24 is a good proposal.

“The proposal to complete electrification by 2023-24 will benefit railways financially. Also, the budget mentioned about operation of 150 passenger trains through PPP mode. There were proposals from state for tourist pilgrimage sector from Vasco da Gama railway station to Kanyakumari , trains to Tirupati and Madurai, etc. After railway budget was merged with the Union Budget, the details related to new trains and projects are published later,” said Krishnakumar.

Electrification is pending in Palakkad-Pollachi, Shoranur-Nilambur, Kollam-Punalur and Ernakulam Harbour route in the state. And Kochuveli-Guwahati triweekly train was among the trains proposed to be introduced by private entities.

“Considering the railway network in the state, the infrastructure needs more focus to benefit from the projects. And before introduction of new trains we need fund allocations for development of facilities to handle more trains here,” added Krishnakumar.

A railway official from Thiruvananthapuram railway division said that the budget is hopeful for development of railway network and Pink Book with details of fund allocations and projects will be published within two days.

Title: Two leopards, two bears electrocuted in Maharashtra’s Ordnance Factory area
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The animals were electrocuted in the forest patch under OF Chanda jurisdiction

CHANDRAPUR: Two leopards and two sloth bears were electrocuted by poachers in the forest patch under the jurisdiction of Ordnance Factory (OF), Chanda, in Bhadrawati town . The decaying carcasses of all four wild animals were recovered just 100 meters in the jungle, adjacent to the OF residential colony on Saturday morning.

The incident has also exposed the lapses in security in the high security OF under the jurisdiction of defence ministry. Forest department has launched an investigation into the poaching of four wild animals at once and suspect the involvement of local poachers hunting for bushmeat (wild herbivores).

Official sources claimed the electrified wire was 200 to 500 meter long. Initial investigations suggest the four animals were not killed at once, but at different times over the last four days. The electrocuted leopards and bears were male and female pairs.

The residents of OF residential colony came to know about the carcasses after they started emitting a foul stench. “After searching for the source of foul smell, people discovered the carcasses and reported the matter to the forest department. We have recovered some part of the wire used for electrocution,” said DFO, Chandrapur forest division, Ashok Sonksure.

He claimed that the poachers used the 11 KV electric power supply line to electrify the wire laid along the ground. Post mortem carried out on the spot confirmed death due to electrocution.

Sources claimed the animals came into contact with the electrified wire at different times. The dead bodies of the bears appear to have decomposed more than the leopards. It is also a mystery why MSEDCL did not share tripping data of this particular power supply, despite repeated power failure in short span of two-three days. The forest department has sought tripping data from MSEDCL to confirm the time of electrocution of the animals.

Officials suspect the poachers could be from village Piparbodi, located a few kilometres from OF Chanda. Source said two leopards had been seen roaming through the residential area of OF Chanda in the last few days. Videos of their prowling between the houses at night have gone viral on social media.

Several kilometres of dense forest lies adjacent to buffer zone of Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve under the jurisdiction of OF, Chanda, and is the habitat for many wild animals. Sighting of leopards, tigers and bears in OF locality is quite common. In fact, more than a dozen leopards have been captured from the OF area during the last few years. This poaching incident has, however, revealed that the poachers were using the forest stretch of OF, Chanda, and the security of defence facility was unaware of their repeated intrusions into the high security area.

Local Congress MLA Pratibha Dhanorkar has asked for an inquiry into the matter in a letter written to the state’s forest minister.

Title: Five student teams from Coimbatore district to present survey findings at state-level meet
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

COIMBATORE: Five teams of students from as many government schools in the district would present their survey findings at a state-level event on February 6, in Namakkal. They had conducted the surveys as part of the improving participation (Impart) scheme conducted by Samagra Shiksha.

Officials said under the scheme, five teams were formed in each school to do a survey on a particular topic from one subject each. The teams would do a survey or a research on a topic from one of the five subjects: English, Tamil, Maths, Science and Social Science.

“Students had chosen topics such as problems faced by children of migrant labourers in their education, body mass index and nutrition, old age people who are not supported by families and the trend of liquor consumption. They had interviewed a sample-size of 50 people each and have produced a survey report,” said the official.

From the initial 500 teams across 100 schools in all 15 blocks, 75 teams — five from each block — were shortlisted. From among these, on Friday, one team, each for one subject, were selected. These teams would represent the district at the state-level Impart event, said the official.

The Impart scheme mainly aims to reduce dropout rates. “We encourage students who are vulnerable of dropping out of school to take part in the scheme. We provide a fund of Rs500 for each project,” said the official.

The schools selected for the state-level event are: Government Higher Secondary School, Mettupalayam in Tamil, Government Higher Secondary School, Velliangadu, in English, CCMA Girls Higher Secondary School, Raja Street, in Maths, Government High School, Arasampalayam, in Science and Government Girls Higher Secondary School, Chinnathadagam in Social Science.

Title: Trichy routes get four more low-floor buses
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC), Trichy region on Saturday launched four low-floor red buses on city routes and nine new mofussil buses to connect the city with various districts.

TNSTC officials said the state government on January 29 inducted 240 new city and mofussil buses for all the TNSTC divisions. Of these, Kumbakonam division received 35 buses and 13 were allotted to the Trichy region. Two of the 13 new buses were already launched from Chennai a few days back connecting Trichy with Madurai, Salem and Thanjavur districts. The remaining 11 new buses covering Trichy, Ariyalur and Perambalur districts were launched here at the Central bus stand.

Of the four city buses, two will be operated between Central bus stand with Chathiram bus stand via Thillai Nagar, while the other two will be run from Central bus stand to Viralimalai in Pudukottai district.

“Good to see TNSTC Trichy gradually inducting low-floor buses for city operations. Perhaps, air-conditioned city buses introduced in Chennai can also be run here connecting Srirangam, Thiruvanaikoil and Samayapuram temples,” K Janakiraman, a resident of No. 1 tollgate said. Locals also reiterated their demand to introduce low-floor buses from Chathiram bus stand to Thuvakudi connecting NIT Trichy.

The mofussil buses will connect Trichy with Madurai, Mannargudi, Jayankondam, Vridachalam and Kumbakonam.

Title: Union Budget has nothing much to offer Nagpur directly
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Members watching the Union Budget presentation at Vidarbha Industrial Association (VIA) on Saturday

Nagpur: Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced no new projects for the city in her Budget speech on Saturday.

The only benefit the city could get is engineering graduate students can do internship at Nagpur Municipal Corporation for up to one year. This will help keep third party check on all infrastructure development works being carried out in the state’s second capital.

Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced in her Budget speech that students in the general stream (vis-à-vis services or technology stream) need to improve employability. About 150 higher educational institutions will start apprenticeship embedded degree/diploma courses by March 2021.

“NMC doesn’t benefit directly in the Central government Budget,” said a senior official from the civic body. NMC only gets the allocation under various Central government funded projects. Currently, NMC is implementing two major projects; AMRUT Yojana and Smart City. Whatever funds are allocated or increased for urban bodies, eventually NMC will also get benefits,” the official explained.

Under the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan, NMC has so far received Rs69.98 crore and is expecting another Rs266 crore for three projects including compost unit, MRF centre and BIO-CNG plant. Detailed project reports for these three projects have already been sent to the government for its nod.

Though no fresh funds have been allocated for existing Smart Cities, including Nagpur, it will not hamper ongoing work in area-based development in east Nagpur. An official from Nagpur Smart and Sustainable Development Corporation Limited said it has already received Rs196 crore from the central government, Rs148 crore from state and Rs100 crore from urban local body, and work for developing smart city project is underway.

Welcoming the Budget, mayor Sandip Joshi said the announcements like drinking water at every house, converting district hospitals into medical college will definitely improve amenities, including health services etc. According to him, all sectors have been covered.

BJP city president and former mayor Pravin Datke welcomed the Union Budget and said it has covered all sectors, like 16-point programme for farmers, and Rs90,000 crore for education sector, which is an all-time high. With other cities, Nagpur may also get benefit from Rs1 lakh crore allocation for infrastructural projects, he said.

Senior Congress corporator Praful Gudadhe termed the budget as misleading. Being a Union minister from Nagpur, Nitin Gadkari hasn’t been able to get the FM to budget for any new projects or industry for Vidarbha, he said. Educated unemployed youths would continue to move out of the city to other metro cities like Pune, Mumbai, Bengaluru etc, said Gudadhe.

City coordinator of Shiv Sena Nitin Tiwari expressed displeasure over the budget. Despite city MP Nitin Gadkari holding the charge of small scale industries, no funds have been allocated under this. The sector could have been provided lakhs of employment opportunities, he said.

Title: Padma awards still elude doyens of Tamil cinema
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: Another Republic Day has come and gone and again the list ofpeople named for the Padma awards lacks several luminaries of Tamil cinema , giving credence to the belief that political affiliations, not just talent or achievements, matter when it comes to such honours.

It is disheartening that despite their clearly evident contributions to cinema and the arts, greats such as M S Viswanathan , Nagesh , R S Manohar, M N Nambiar and P S Veerappa have not received any of the coveted Padma awards. Such awards lose their sheen when not given to the right people at the right time. Though the awards are not usually conferred posthumously, the government could consider honouring deserving artists, just like it did to BJP leaders Sushma Swaraj and Arun Jaitley and socialist stalwart George Fernandes.

TOI+: Read the full story here

Title: Bike-borne men snatch two gold chains from woman, 60
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: In yet another chain-snatching incident, bike-borne men snatched two gold chains weighing eight sovereigns from a 60-year-old woman near Palpannai in Trichy . Though the incident took place on Thursday, the woman, M Santhakumari from Vishwas Nagar 2nd street, lodged a complaint only on Friday.

Police said that Santhakumari reached Palpannai bus stop from Kumbakonam after attending a funeral at around 2pm on Thursday. She was walking on the road opposite Nalli apartment near Palpannai. A masked man in the age group of 30 years approached her. He asked the woman for an address to a hospital. The woman said she had no idea and tried to leave, but he snatched her two gold chains each weighing four sovereigns.

As the woman raised alarm, the man ran and hopped on to a bike that was waiting for him. Both of them escaped from the spot in few seconds.

Santhakumar lodged a complaint with the the Gandhi market police.

It was the second such incident to take place the same day. A couple of bike-borne men snatched the chain of M Maria Michael, 45 of Lalgudi when she was walking near Aristo roundabout at 1.30pm.

Title: Allahabad: Four arrested for supplying rectified spirit for hooch
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: Special Task Force (STF) on Saturday arrested four persons in Allahabad for allegedly supplying rectified spirit to illicit liquor manufacturers in the state.

The team also recovered 2,200 litre of rectified spirit, estimated to be worth Rs 11 lakh. The accused were identified as Ambuj Awasthi, Sopnu Shukla, Alok Patel and Yogendra Yadav. Awasthi, Shukla and Patel are residents of of Allahabad and Yadav is native to Kannauj.

Circle officer (STF) Navendu Kumar said, “STF had received tip-offs about the use of rectified spirit in manufacturing illicit liquor in various districts of eastern UP.”

On Friday, STF received a tip-off about a truck ferrying drums of rectified spirit having arrived in the city from Delhi. The truck was reported to be parked in Transport Nagar. “The informer had claimed that the drums were being loaded into a mini-truck and were to be supplied to Ambedkar Nagar and nearby districts in Bihar,” the CO said.

Based on the information, police raided the spot and recovered 2,200 litre of rectified drums from two mini-trucks. “Two persons were arrested from each of the two vehicles,” said CO STF.

During interrogation, the accused said they used to procure rectified spirit at a cost of Rs 25,000 per drum and sold them to smugglers at Rs 40,000 per drum. They also said that they were on their way to supply seven of the seized drums to one KK Pandey in Karchana and four drums to a house in Transport Nagar.

The CO said that efforts were on to arrest KK Pandey and others involved in this racket.

An FIR in connection with the case has been registered at Dhoomanganj police station.

Title: Former SC judge: Religion-based CAA unconstitutional
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

BENGALURU: Terming the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ) unconstitutional, a section of legal experts on Saturday claimed the National Population Register ( NPR ) is a prelude to the controversial National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and that both would have serious repercussions on citizens.

In his keynote address, former Supreme Court judge V Gopala Gowda said CAA, which seeks to confer citizenship upon people belonging to six minority religions in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh, is a blatant violation of the Constitution. "It is inexplicable as to why similarly placed people as well as non-religious groups in other countries have been left out, including about 88 lakh Tamils in Sri Lanka and Rohingya Muslims of Myanmar,” he said.

Regarding NPR, Justice Gowda said since the rules give more power to lower-rung officials, there may chances of crores of people losing out citizenship and being sent to concentration camps on the lines of what has been done in Assam after NCR, owing to whimsical action of officials.

Senior advocate Prashant Bhushan opined that institutions formed under the Constitution, right from Election Commission, CAG and even the judiciary, are either being attacked or taken over. According to him, under NPR, an individual is put at the mercy of local officials and based on the remarks which say “doubtful citizen”, he or she can even lose citizenship.

Former advocate general Prof Ravivarma Kumar said commencing of the NPR exercise before census-2021 virtually takes away the sanctity of census operations, wherein a person need not disclose his identity. Senior advocate AS Ponnanna termed CAA, NPR and NRC as traps laid out by the ruling dispensation, which seeks to turn the country into a “Hindu Rashtra”.

Title: Manager, 3 others arrested for cheating pvt bank of Rs 33 crore
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Coimbatore: The crime branch police on Saturday arrested four people, including the former deputy general manager of a private bank in the city, for cheating the bank of Rs 33crore.

The arrested people were identified as Sivasubramaniam, former deputy general manager of Tamilnad Mercantile Bank’s main branch on Trichy Road, who was placed under suspension, N Mahesh, an Ondipudur-based broker, Pandian, an engineer and Gomathi, an industrialist, who had availed loan from the bank.

Audit conducted by a team from the bank’s Chennai office last year had found out that Sivasubramaniam had misused his authority and sanctioned loans to the tune of Rs 33 crore, causing loss to the bank. He conspired with Mahesh, Pandian and 29 others in 2018 to make documents and photographs of a non-existing poultry farm and inflated land value using fake documents to give Rs 33crore loan to Gomathi, who had been running a mill at Selakarichal. The loan was not repaid.

Title: GHMC to build 500 toilets in next two months
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A day after the Ink Wash Summit was held in the city with sanitation as one of the primary agenda, municipal administration and urban development (MAUD) minister KT Rama Rao on Saturday directed the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) to build 500 toilets in the next two months. However, only a few smart washrooms and eco loos will be constructed.

Civic officials are in the process of identifying locations to install these washrooms. “The location of these public toilets will be made available on a mobile app,” said a GHMC official.

These one-of-its-kind washrooms will be built on the lines of those set up by Loo Café which do not require water or septic tanks. The eco loos will use Swedish technology, which converts waste into liquid fertiliser and manure, which are primarily located in Jordan Mountains, heritage sites and places where there is water scarcity and no place to install a septic tank .

The washrooms will have integrated live toilet management system to monitor smell, footfall and hygiene from a command control centre. “This technology has been recognised as a path-breaking innovation by the United Nations ,” said Abhishek Nath , founder of Loo Café.

Title: Farmers ‘sabotaged’ pipeline to city to get water for farms
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: Three of the seven major leaks on the water pipeline supplying raw drinking water from Pench reservoirs to the city have turned out to be sabotage. Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) did not lodge a police complaint since ‘farmers caused the leaks to get water for farms’, said sources.

NMC now plans to shut down the pipeline for 45 days to repair the leaks, and also install seven electromagnetic flow meters at regular intervals to detect any future leaks. During this time, water will be brought to the city via canals. This may affect water supply, as any breach in canal will stop supply completely.

NMC had laid a giant pipeline of 2,300mm diameter in 2014 with funds under central government’s JNNURM scheme to bring raw drinking water from Kamptee Khairi reservoir, downstream of Pench reservoirs, to Mahadula Pumping Station. The water is supplied to treatment plants from pumping station. Around 550 million litres per day (MLD) water is supplied from the pipeline, which caters to over 70% of the city.

The 31km pipeline passes through farms and forests. Some leakages in the pipeline were causing loss of around 30 MLD water, enough for over 2 lakh people. Though detected one-and-a-half years ago, the civic body could not repair the leaks for various reasons, leading to huge water loss. Now, NMC proposed to undertake the repairs, and during inspection the cause of the leaks was discovered.

NMC superintending engineer Shweta Banerjee told TOI, “Leaks at three locations are man made. There might have been a minor leak in pipeline and miscreants expanded it. Or miscreants breached the pipeline. These are major leaks, from where huge quantum of water was going waste,” she said.

Banerjee did not comment on who caused the leaks. “We managed to bring down losses to 15 MLD through temporary works,” she said.

NMC water works department said farmers might be behind the leaks. “Systematic canals has been made to direct the leaking water. The canal ends in some farms. But NMC did not file police complaint as already farmers are facing various problems,” sources said.

There is low threat of contamination of raw water, as it is treated at water treatment plants and then sent to tanks before being supplied to households.

NMC first planned repairs during last monsoon, but had to postpone the plans first for low rains and then due to heavy rains. The plan was delayed after monsoon due to assembly elections in October and November last year.

Banerjee said shut down will be taken for 45 days to repair the leaks and also install seven giant full-bore electromagnetic flow meter at regular intervals on the pipeline. “NMC will bring raw water from canal of Kamptee Khairi to pumping station. There would be no water crisis,” she said.

Water supply will be affected in case of any breach in canals, considering past experience.

NMC will be able to narrow down location of any future leak by checking quantum of water flowing through the flow meters, which cost Rs2.80 crore.

IAN

* NMC laid giant 2,300mm pipeline from Kamptee Khairi reservoir to Mahadula Pumping Station to supply raw water in 2014

* Leaks developed at seven places over 1.5 years ago

* 30 MLD water, enough for over 2 lakh people, was going waste

* On inspection, NMC concluded three of seven leaks were man-made

* NMC sources said farmers caused leaks to get water for farms

* NMC plans to repair leaks and also install flow meters during shut down of 45 days

* Water will be drawn through canal

* Flow meters will give location and quantum of leaks in future

Title: A few misses & a few hits: Kovai Inc
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Coimbatore: The Union Budget evoked mixed response from industrialists, who were predominantly disappointed.

While a section of those running micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) welcomed the announcements such as exempting firms with Rs 5 crore turnover from tax auditing, extension of debt restructuring till March 31, 2021, and simplified GST returns from April 2020, others said the Budget has no other major announcements for MSMEs, automobile sector and electric vehicles.

V Lakshminarayanasamy, president of Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ICCI), Coimbatore chapter, said the Budget fulfilled 55% of expectations. “As the fiscal deficit target has been fixed at 3.8%, we can expect more expenditure to spruce up the economy,” he said and welcomed the announcements on agriculture and water harvesting “This Budget is better than the last one. But we have to see how much it would increase spending.”

R Ramamurthy, president of Coimbatore District Small Industries (Codissia), said the decision to announce national logistics policy would help MSMEs compete at the international level. Allocation of Rs 27,300 crore for industrial development is also encouraging, he said.

Meanwhile, J James, president of Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Micro Enterprises (TACT), said the Budget was an overall disappointment, as it did not have any major announcements on GST and defence production. “We expected GST exemption for job-order, which was not announced. We had also demanded reduction of loan interest rates to 5%. There is also nothing on defence production in Coimbatore, which is disappointing.”

C Sivakumar, president of Coimbatore Tirupur District Micro and Cottage Entrepreneurs Association (Cotma), welcomed the announcement on GST simplification and tax-audit exemption up to 5crore. “But our demands of reduced interest rates and giving 40% of turnover as working capital loans have not been met. This Budget is neither promising nor disappointing.”

K Maniraj, president of Kovai Power Driven Pumps and Spares Manufacturers Association (Kopma), said though 20 lakh farmers will be given financial aid to buy solar pumpsets, they would work only for five to six hours on sunny days and would be a waste of investment. “If electric motors are given GST exemption, farmers and manufacturers would benefit,” he said.

Regarding the announcements for textile sector, representatives of Indian Texpreneurs Federation said the announcement on abolishing anti-dumping duty on purified terephthalic acid (PTA) will be a big boost to the textile sector’s export competitiveness. The formulation of National Technical Textiles Mission will help tap the huge potential of the sector.

The industrialists also expressed disappointed over no announcement on new train services and infrastructure development in Coimbatore.

Title: CII-Yi Trichy chapter gets new chairperson
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Trichy: The Young Indians (Yi) Trichy chapter of Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) celebrated their annual day here on Saturday. New chair and co-chair for the year 2020 -2021 for the chapter were nominated during the event.

Ketan J Vora, managing partner of the national art diamond works was nominated as the chair of Yi, Trichy chapter. He is a recipient of Karmaveer Chakra medal for the proactive voluntary action instituted by Rex Karmaveer global fellowship for creating awareness on child sexual abuse through project Komal, an initiative by Young Indians Trichy chapter.

Kaveri Annamalai, director, ARA wealth management services was nominated as the co-chair of Yi, Trichy chapter. She has been a project director of green temples initiative from ITC and EXNORA in working towards sustainable waste management practice in temples by recycling and managing the waste generated in the religious institutes.

Addressing the entrepreneurs Shankar Venugopal, vice president, Mahindra & Mahindra, Mahindra Research Valley, Chennai spoke about the advancements made in innovation and technology such as artificial intelligence, 3D printing and self-propelled vehicles that can contribute towards exponential growth.

Title: KTR bats for right to walk, asks officials to build footpaths
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao on Saturday emphasised on right to walk and directed GHMC officials to ensure dedicated footpaths in each GHMC zone.

He wanted officials to replicate Miyawaki method for taking up plantation in each zone and set up bicycle tracks in parks and playgrounds. The Miyawaki technique has a proven record worldwide, under which plants are grown irrespective of soil and climatic conditions. More than 3,000 forests have been successfully created worldwide using this methodology.

KTR was addressing a review meeting at the enforcement vigilance and disaster management office.

GHMC has decided to install grills on pavements in school zones to prevent accidents. Zonal commissioners have been asked to submit a detailed report on status of parks, facilities, CC cameras for security, lighting and security guards at major parks. tnn

Title: Four held for Paranur toll plaza theft
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: Police on Saturday said they had cracked the January 26 theft of Rs 18 lakh at the Paranur toll plaza near Chengalpet with the arrest of four daily wage workers of a car manufacturing company. A hunt is on for a few more people. Investigators earlier thought a few passengers of an SETC bus, whose crew fought with the toll plaza staff, and a few others were behind the theft.

An officer said the images of the jerseys of the four, sporting the company logo, and their boots all caught on camera at the plaza were the key. Police, however, retrieved only Rs 1.19 lakh of the stolen money.

P Bhoopathi Raja, 26, of Salem, his face masked, was ‘caught’ walking away with the money. A team led by Chengalpet inspector D Stalin picked up Bhoopathi Raja before nabbing S Marimuthu, 26, of Mamandur, R Suresh Kumar, 29, of Chengalpet and D Jaya Vijayan, 29, of Gingee. Chengalpet deputy superintendent of police Kandan said police teams armed with images of the suspects fanned out in the neighbourhood. The four suspects will be remanded in judicial custody on Sunday.

On January 26, just after Chennai-Trichy SETC bus rolled to a stop at the Paranur toll plaza at 1 am, the staff there asked the driver to pay charges, though government buses are usually exempt from them. An argument broke out and the booth staff allegedly attacked the driver and conductor. While the bus passengers backed their crew, other bus drivers joined the fracas and the plaza was vandalised.

The next day police arrested Kuldeep Singh, 24, of Rajasthan and Vikas Gupta, 27, of UP, both staff members at the Panarur plaza, SETC driver Narayanan, 46, conductor Pasumpon, 38, both of Tirunelveli and Muthu, 37, of Chengalpet. What was then not known was that the four arrested on Saturday, along with a few others, cashed in on the opportunity provided by the attack on the plaza.

Title: Trichy MSMEs unhappy with Union Budget
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Trichy: Micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) sector have expressed disappointment at the Union budget 2020 tabled in Parliament on Saturday. Entrepreneurs rued the lack of concrete announcements in simplifying the goods and services tax (GST) for MSMEs in filing tax returns.

Stating that the budget lacked focus on efforts to improve the business environment for MSMEs by paving way for more work orders, they claimed that extending the restructuring of non-performing assets (NPA) for one more year will not play a catalyst role in their business. “We expected more relief through a tax cut. While corporate tax ceiling stands at 25%, those who earn an income above Rs 15 lakh per year will fall under 30% tax slab,” R Ilango, president, Tiruchirapalli District TIDITSSIA said. tnn

Title: Cop suspended for siphoning off stolen property
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Coimbatore: A 35-year-old female constable attached to Singanallur police station was suspended on Friday for misappropriating recovered stolen items. According to an inside source, constable Sapna Suja had stolen gold ornaments worth around Rs 50 lakh from the recovered items over a period of three years.

Suja, the source said, was the “court contact”, whose responsibility was to keep track of the station’s cases and produce recovered stolen properties before court.

“It was also her duty to coordinate with other police stations and collect recovered stolen properties in the cases that we were dealing with. She never used to hand them over to court or another station fully. In some cases, she hadn’t handed them over at all. Whenever she was questioned by sub-inspectors or inspectors, she used to say she had informed assistant commissioner or other senior officers and handed them over to some other police station,” the source said.

However, the newly-appointed inspector, Sivakumar, recently ordered a report on cases that were solved, recovered stolen properties and recovered properties that were handed over to victims or court. “It was then we realized that we were neither in possession of recovered properties in 11 cases, nor were they handed over to the victims. The same was also not recorded in the court’s recovery list,” the source said.

Following this, the inspector summoned Suja, seeking an explanation. She, however, went on long leave the next day after she was summoned.

Other sources in the station said Suja had been misappropriating recovered stolen properties ever since she joined the station four years ago.

On Friday, Suja was suspended for not submitting recovered stolen properties to the court, and not appearing before the court or police station when she was summoned to provide an explanation.

Title: Tamil Nadu: IS suspect wanted in SSI Wilson murder case nabbed in Ramanathapuram fishing hamlet
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

A Shaik Dawood

CHENNAI: A man linked to the killers of special sub inspector Y Wilson was arrested by state police from a hideout in a fishing hamlet in Ramanathapuram district on Saturday.

Believed to be having IS links, A Shaik Dawood , 32, was hiding in an abandoned hut, and was found amid a jumble of gym equipment, police said. Wilson was shot dead on January 8 at Kaliyakavilai close to Kanyakumari-Thiruvananthapuram national highway.

R V Varunkumar, superintendent of police, Ramanathapuram district, said: “Dawood had transferred funds to one of Wilson’s killers, Abdul Shamim’unt in his father’s name.” Dawood has close links with the IS suspect Khaja Moideen, who ran ‘Al-Hind Trust’ and radicalised youngsters to wage war in the name of Islam, the SP said.

During questioning, Dawood told investigating officers that he was heading the group and the members shared the common ideology of eliminating those who spoke or acted against Islam and freeing their leaders lodged in different prisons in the State by force. They had been mobilising funds through foreign handlers for purchasing weapons, said the officer.

Saturday’s arrest was executed by a special police team led by the deputy superintendent of police Velladurai, S Dhebakar, R Yesudoss and G Senthil Kumar.

The National Investigation Agency (NIA) had arrested Dawood in 2018 on charges of radicalising youngsters from poor backgrounds. After coming out on bail, he went underground and was involved in funding radical elements, police said.

A police team had earlier arrested Dawood’s associates Mohammad Ameer alias Arunkumar, 31, of Villupuram, Mohammad Ali alias Manikandan 28, of Cuddalore, and Pitchai Kani alias Pura Kani, 45 of Keezhakarai in Ramanathapuram on January 22. Dawood had a narrow escaped on that occasion.

Dawood moved from one place to another to escape the arrest. As he didn’t use any mobile phone, police team found it hard to track him. However, they kept all their informants in high alert. The Tamil Nadu police have now informed the NIA and Kanyakumari police about the arrest of Dawood, as they would apprehend him in the cases pending against him.

Title: Tamil Nadu puts interstate borders on vigil as precaution against coronavirus
Content:
Health department officials pay a visit to a student (second from right) from China

CHENNAI: Hotels and eateries have been asked to serve properly cooked meat and ensure chefs follow hygiene protocols while handling meat and other animal products in the kitchen as part of the state’s precautions against the coronavirus , director of public health Dr K Kolandaisamy said.The state food safety department directed hotel managements to ensure hygeinic handling of meat products. The World Health Organisation and Centre for Disease Control have said there are chances of the virus spreading from uncooked meat. “With many people coming into the city we have to ensure there is no cross infection. Passengers are being quarantined at home to ensure minimal chances of transmission,” Dr Kolandaisamy said.More than 700 passengers from China, including four from Wuhan, were put on the mandatory 28-day home quarantine by the state health department till Saturday evening. Earlier, health secretary Beela Rajesh said 579 passengers, including 68 Chinese citizens, were on quarantine By Saturday evening 150 more passengers landed at various airports. While samples – nasal swab and blood – were taken from flyers from Wuhan, all other passengers from China and other affected areas were screened and put on mandatory home quarantine.Health minister C Vijaya Baskar told reporters in Pudukottai that no one has shown symptoms — cough, cold, fever and running nose — of the novel virus. “Besides air and sea ports, inter-state borders are under vigil. It is a challenging task for us. Passengers with travel history to China entering TN from other states are also being screened,” he said.The condition of two patients, who came to government hospitals in Chennai and Tiruvannamalai fearing infection, was stable he said. “They are being monitored because they said they had a travel history and complained of discomfort. They have not shown any symptoms of the viral disease,” said the minister.On Friday, joint director (Epidemic), directorate of public health and preventive medicine Dr P Sampath inspected the preventive measures in place and the special novel coronavirus isolation ward at the Government Rajaji Hospital.One of the students M Chandrasekaran of Hosur told reporters there’s no panic in China as reported in the media. “I was instructed to return to college on February 21,” said the 21-year-old pursuing fourth year medicine in China.The state has set up round-the-clock control rooms that can be reached at 044-29510400/044-29510500 or 94443 40496/87544 48477. People can also dial the state helpline 104 for queries.Chennai airport is also screening passengers from China, said a senior AAI official. Thermal screening machines have been deployed along with hand-held infrared thermometres.

Title: School students recreate Sangam era literary works in Tamili script
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Trichy: Students of a private school in Karur district came together to recreate the original literary works of the Sangam era, written in the more than 2000-year-old ‘Tamili’ script, which is regarded as the first Tamil script. The effort is an attempt to further popularise Tamili script.

Sangam literature was originally written in Tamili and these works were changed to the present form of Tamil language by successive scholars.

About 4,500 students from Bharani Park institutions in Karur district sat together to recreate the 36 literary works in Tamili. All the works running into thousands of pages were recreated in Tamili in 24 minutes as hand-written manuscripts, thereby making it to the record book.

Dragon A Jetlee, founder, Jetlee Book of Records and chief adjudicator acknowledged and certified their work. Jetlee said there has not been any similar attempt so far.

C Ramasubramanian, senior principal, Bharani Park institutions said that Pathitrupathu - one of the early works of the Sangam era was recreated in three minutes and 41 seconds by the students. Sangam literature was written by various saints across 1,000 years and is said to be the oldest form of literature found in Tamil language, he added.

Lauding the students for doing service to Tamil language, V Ramaraja Pandian, chairperson, school of Tamil studies, Madurai Kamaraj University termed it as one-of-its-kind attempt at such a young age.

“Not many, especially the younger generation may be aware of the Tamili script and Sangam literature. Such attempts will popularise Tamili among youngsters,” he said.

The school has not just stopped with teaching Tamil language to the students but also encouraged them to learn Tamili script. The idea is to preserve the heritage and tradition of the language and pass it on to the next generation.

Title: One arrested for poaching spotted deer, hunt on for 5
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Erode: Forest department officials have arrested a 43-year-old person for poaching spotted deer in Sikkinandhi village near Kermalam forest range and recovered from him deer meat.

A forester attached to Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve (STR) identified the arrested as M Thiruman, of Sikkinandhi village.

According to him, they received a tip that a six-member gang had entered STR on Friday evening with sickles. “We immediately rushed to the spot and surrounded them. However, they had already hunted down a spotted deer. While five of them managed to escape, we succeeded in catching Thiruman.”

Preliminary inquiry revealed the gang came across the spotted the deer while it was being chased by stray dogs near the forest boundary. Thiruman was produced before the judicial magistrate of Sathyamangalam sub-court and lodged in Gobichettipalayam sub-jail under judicial custody on Saturday. “We have launched a manhunt for the remaining five and will arrest them soon,” the official said.

Title: 2 die in road accidents in city
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: An auto driver died after his vehicle was hit reportedly by a speeding taxi in Bowenpally on Saturday.

Around 7.30am, M Raj Gopal,50, was travelling in his auto from Bapuji Nagar to Bowenpally Market, police said. A taxi, which came in the opposite direction, rammed into the auto. In the mishap, Gopal suffered grievous injuries and died on the spot. A case was registered against the taxi driver.

Meanwhile, in a similar case at LB Nagar, a 29-year-old private employee, riding a two-wheeler, died after an unidentified vehicle hit him at Bairamalguda. Police said the victim Ravi Teja died on the spot. A case was registered. tnn

Title: Bail pleas of two Babupurwa riot accused rejected
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: Additional district and sessions judge, Vinay Kumar Singh , on Saturday rejected the bail applications of Adil and Mustaqeem, the accused in the recent Babupurwa riot case. Police had charged them under sections 147/148/149/332/353/336/307/188/427/34/109 of the IPC and also under section 3/4 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984, the Arms Act and the Criminal Law Amendment Act.

Moving Adil’s bail application, his mother Shaheen claimed that his son had falsely been implicated in the case. She stated in her affidavit that on December 19-20, 2019, as there was a marriage of one of her relations, the relatives and family members were staying at Bagahi Eidgah ground to guard marriage articles. While Adil and other relatives were removing the articles, a stampede took place in the area and her family members and some young boys stayed there at the Eidgah.

After some time, the police entered the Eidgah and caught Adil and framed him in riot and other charges, she stated in her affidavit. In support of her claim, she submitted a marriage card and claimed that the police had neither any proof nor any video clip which could show that Adil had indulged in the violence. Moreover, there was no recovery of any arm or ammunition from Adil and that he has no criminal record.

Mustaqeem’s mother Afroz, who moved his bail application too took the plea of marriage in her house held at Eidgah ground. She also pleaded that following a stampede taking place at the Eidgah, the police reached there and arrested Mustqeem.

Opposing the bail applications, ADGC Shiv Bhagwan told the court that on December 20, 2019, after the namaz was over, the accused along with other co-accused started hurling petrol bombs, acid bombs and the bottles containing acids at the police party due to which the body protectors, cane shields, helmets and vehicles were damaged and then the police had used force on the order of the magistrate.

The prosecution stated that around a dozen cops had suffered injuries. Moreover, the accused and the co-accused had burnt the motorcycles of the police. The field unit collected empty shells of 12 bore and 315 bore cartridges and bottles used in petrol and acid bombs, and the accused and the co-accused were arrested from the spot, the prosecution alleged.

The court went through the evidence on record and the police report in which they had claimed that charges under section 302 of the IPC had also been added against the accused.

The court said that under those circumstances and after considering the evidence oral and documentary, there was no ground to grant bail to the accused and hence the bail applications of the two accused were being rejected. The bail applications of two other co-accused Shahzad and Parvez Alam had already been rejected earlier.

Title: No TNPCB consent, Putlur sewage plant under NGT scanner
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: An unlicensed common sewage treatment plant being operated by Tiruvallur municipality has come under the scanner of National Green Tribunal as activists moved the latter saying untreated effluents were being let into the Putlur lake.

The southern bench of NGT comprising Justice K Ramakrishnan and Saibal Dasgupta has given three months for a joint committee, monitored by Tiruvallur collector, to submit inspection and action-taken reports, in case any violation was noted.

The matter came to light after R Gokulraj of Tiruvallur filed a petition in NGT seeking action against officials responsible for unsafe disposal of treated sewage. It is being operated without obtaining consent from Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB), the petitioner said.

Established in 2014 by the municipality, the treatment plant handles waste from houses in all 27 wards by collecting them through underground sewer lines. Treated water from the CSTP is then let into the take. In October 2019, the TNPCB inspected the plant and issued a show-cause notice to rectify certain defects failing which the plant will be closed, said counsel appearing on behalf of the board in response to the case.

The municipality claimed that lake was dry during most of the year and discharging treated water into it would neither pollute it nor affect ground water quality.

Seconding them, the PWD said at present there was no irrigation based on lake and permission was granted only after ensuring that there was no inflow of water from nearby catchment area. However, TNPCB inspection found out that Total Suspended Solids (TSS) and Biological Oxygen Demand (BOD) levels exceeded the permissible limits.

Title: Delta farmers not quite happy over unfulfilled demands
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Trichy: Though the Budget allocations to the agricultural sector have sought to reassure delta farmers to an extent, no word on writing off agricultural loans has upset them. Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced that the agriculture credit for 2020-21 has been set at Rs 15 lakh crore.

State president of Tamil Maanila Congress (TMC) farmers’ wing Puliyur Nagarajan listed out the unfulfilled expectations such as waiver of crop loans, fund allocation for river-linking projects like Vaigai-Gundar and Nadanthai Vazhi Cauvery scheme. “Farmers are unhappy that the budget made no mention of fund allocation for crucial projects that can be a stimulus to the agriculture sector in Tamil Nadu,” said Puliyur Nagarajan.

Stating that sustainable cropping pattern and involvement of more technology can be achieved in cooperation with the states, the finance minister unveiled a 16-point action plan for boosting agriculture development. Tamil Nadu Tank and River Irrigation Farmers’ Association saw the Budget as unimpressive for the farmers despite providing some sops. “Allocation of Rs 2.83 lakh crore, 16-point action plan and crop loans are appreciable. Yet, there was no announcement on reduction of premium on crop insurance,” said association state president P Viswanathan . State spokesperson of Bharatiya Kisan Sangh N Veerasekaran said, “We thank the government for considering our demand to have facilities to help market organic agriculture produces,” he said.

Title: Water released from Kodiveri check dam for second-term crop
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

ERODE: Close to 32 cubic feet per second (cusecs) water gushed out from Kodiveri check dam near Gobichettipalayam here on Saturday as Public Works Department (PWD) officials opened the sluice gates to irrigate the second-term crop as directed by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami.

PWD officials and farmers participated in the sluice gate opening ceremony. “The quantity of water released will be increased in the coming days based on the requirement in ayacut areas,” a PWD official said. Water is likely to be released from Kodiveri dam as well to help farmers take up the second-term crop cultivation.

The official said water would be released from the check dam for a period of 120 days. The move would benefit 39,000 acres. “About 24,504 acres of fertile land in Thadapalli, Arakkankottai and surrounding villages, and another 15,000 acres across Kalingarayan canal will benefit from the water release, which would be stopped on the evening of May 31, 2020,” the official said.

Title: GST staff among 2 held for hoarding foreign liquor
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Two persons, including a havildar of central GST department, were nabbed and 31 liquor bottles were seized from their possession on Saturday.

Excise officials have arrested Ranga Sandeep Kumar, 29 from Kotwalguda, who has been working at a duty-free shop at RGI Airport, Shamshabad, and Kuthadi Mallesh , 55, from Secunderabad, a havildar with central GST department office, Basheerbagh .

On Saturday, excise department sleuths intercepted a two-wheeler near Taj Mahal Hotel at Abids and nabbed Sandeep with 12 bottles of foreign liquor .

After interrogation, he revealed about his associate following which the officials raided the house of Mallesh and seized 15 more bottles of foreign liquor and four bottles of liquor bought from defence canteen from his possession.

According to officials, the duo had procured the foreign liquor from the duty-free shop at the airport and selling them to customers at a higher price.

In all, 31 liquor bottles, including 27 foreign ones, a Honda Activa and two mobile phones were seized from their possession. The excise team handed over the contraband and accused persons to the prohibition and excise inspector, Narayanguda excise station, for further action.

Title: Two rank holders in 2017 TNPSC Group II-A scam arrested
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: CB-CID sleuths probing the TNPSC Group II-A examinations scam conducted in 2017 arrested two rank holders in the exam.

The arrested are K Velmurugan, 30, a native of Sivaganga, who managed to get the eighth rank and K Jayarani, 30, a native of Srivilliputhur, who secured the 21st rank.

While Velmurugan had been posted at Karaikudi district registrar’s office as an assistant Jayarani was posted at the district registrar’s office in Tirunelveli. Both wrote the exam at a centre in Rameswaram.

Forty-two more candidates are suspected to have cleared the exam in a fraudulent manner through mediators apprehended in TNPSC Group-IV examination, an official release said.

While Velmurugan’s brother Chithaandi, a policeman, who is said to have been the main accused behind the scam, is still absconded, Jayarani’s husband Muthu is also a policeman, said a CB-CID police officer.

S Jayakumar, a resident of Mogappair and a key suspect in the Group IV exam scam, is also absconding and CB-CID police seized sixty varieties of pens, a laptop and a pen drive, apart from a few documents from his house in Mogappair during a surprise check.

Title: 259 child labourers rescued in January
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Rachakonda police rescued 259 child labourers under operation Smile in January. Of them, 159 were from other states. According to police, 18 cases were registered against 37 persons under Child Labour Act, 1968, and Juvenile Justice Act for employing child labourers. Forty-four girls were rescued from shops, while 15 children were rescued from brick kilns. As many as 38 kids were from Assam, while 24 were from Bihar and 21 from UP. A missing boy was traced through Darpan App in Dammaiguda. tnn

Title: ‘Town’s facelift will draw tourists to sanctuary’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Meerut: The choice of Hastinapur for ‘iconic’ development of an archaeological site by FM Nirmala Sitharaman has brightened the prospects of the 2,073 sq km wildlife sanctuary of the same name near the town.

Though less than 100 km from Delhi, the sanctuary is the least explored in terms of tourist footfall. Despite being a pilgrimage site and so close to the sanctuary, tourists shy away from exploring Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary because of the lack of adequate lodgings and other facilities.

Divisional forest officer, Meerut, Aditi Sharma said, “The Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary is the biggest in the region spread across five districts of western UP along with Ganga corridor. It has everything from migratory birds, wetlands, gharials and swamp deer. Now, with Hastinapur (town) figuring in the Union government’s development plan, the sanctuary will certainly benefit in terms of tourism. Besides, the ongoing joint endeavour of UP forest division and WWF India in the conservation of threatened species like gharials, dolphins and turtles will also get a boost.”

Additional chief conservator of forest, biodiversity department, UP government, Mukesh Kumar said, “We are already in the process of developing the sanctuary as a tourism site and this announcement will give further impetus. Instead of permanent structures, we will have makeshift tents as lodgings close to the river.”

Joseph Zaidi, a bird enthusiast, said, “Hastinapur Wildlife Sanctuary is a perfect getaway for Delhi weekenders but lack of basic facilities like safety, lodgings and food is a big deterrent. If Hastinapur is developed, it will certainly attract wildlife tourism as well.”

Title: Now, apply for net meters online for rooftop solar plant
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: Residents installing rooftop solar plants will now be able to apply for net meters online on Tangedco’s website. The facility was launched early this week and the link is up on the state-run discom’s website, an official confirmed the development.

This is likely to resolve a major headache of residents and commercial establishments which install rooftop solar plants. Currently the process of getting a net meter is tedious. Wait for a meter may be close to six months for many city residents with no clarity on when it would be received. Only if a net meter is received, can the resident start enjoying the benefits of the rooftop solar plant as the device would calculate the number of solar units generated. The bill generated would be based on the net consumption after the net solar units are exported to the grid.

The online system ensures residents can track their application and raise queries about delays.

Tangedco sources say net meter installations will now be completed in 15-30 days and applications for all LT connection is likely to be made online from February.

According to the 2019 solar policy of the state government , commissioning of a solar rooftop unit should be completed within 3 weeks. "However this process is riddled with delays, red tape and bribes demanded by lower level officials,” said R Ramalingam, of South Chennai.

Title: Guv advises doctors to look after own health
Content: Hyderabad: Referring to the rise in suspected coronavirus cases, governor Tamilisai Soundararajan on Friday advised doctors to look after their own health besides treating patients.Speaking at the first international conference and live workshop on advanced interventional pulmonology at Yashoda Hospital, the governor said, “Interventional pulmonology is a sub-specialty of pulmonary medicine, which deals with diseases of the airways and lungs, using minimally invasive endoscopic procedures. The technical advancements in this field over the last two decades have been phenomenal and play an important role in improving quality of life in patients with lung cancer, severe asthma, COPD, ILD and tuberculosis.”Meanwhile, around 300 pulmonologists from across the country and the world like China, Malaysia, Italy, Japan, US, Hong Kong, UK, Singapore and Thailand, deliberated on technical advancements at the conference.

Title: Three new suspected coronavirus cases in Hyderabad, 7 results awaited from NIV
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Three new suspected cases of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) were reported in the city on Saturday and the patients have been kept in the isolation wards of Government Fever Hospital and Gandhi Hospital . With this, the total number of suspected cases in the state have gone up to 18.While 11 patients have already tested negative for the virus, reports of seven samples are yet to be sent by the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune. The testing facility at the ICMR lab of Gandhi Medical College is likely to open on Monday as testing kits arrived a day back.“The three new patients have a record of travelling to China. They have been kept in the isolation ward and samples have been collected for testing. We are hoping to get the reports in a day,” said Vijay Kumar, nodal officer for coronavirus.Meanwhile, a massive exercise of training doctors, nurses, medical students and Class IV staff has begun at Gandhi Hospital and Gandhi Medical College to raise awareness on infection control. On Saturday, 40 doctors, house surgeons and nurses who work in the isolation facilities were given a refresher training, while 80 staffers including drivers and security personnel were trained on personal safety on Friday.Though doctors already have necessary training, the exercise is being conducted in anticipation of an outbreak of 2019-nCoV. “The intention is to familiarise and train all frontline staff including security personnel, nurses and doctors on personal safety measures in case of infection outbreak,” said Dr Arjun Raj, who along with Dr Nikhat Shirin and Dr Nagamani, head of the microbiology department, conducted the programme.

Title: Maharashtra: Farmer groups decry just Rs 15,000 crore rise in allocation
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Farmer groups in the state are unhappy with the allocation made for agriculture and allied activities in Budget 2020 .

According to the Budget analysis by the All India Kisan Sabha , in 2019-2020, the Union government had budgeted a total of Rs 2.7 lakh crore for agriculture and allied activities, rural development and irrigation, all put together. This year, only an increase of Rs 15,000 crore has been made, taking the total allocation to Rs 2.8 lakh crore.

“The Budget did not focus on agricultural processing or waste reduction. There has been talk of zero budget and traditional farming but the use of technology in farming is being neglected,” said Ajit Navale of the AIKS.

Navale said key issues such as setting up of godowns and warehouses and ways to ensure farmers get better rates were not addressed.

He said last year under the PM Kisan Samman Nidhi Yojana, small and marginal farmers across the country were to get Rs 6,000 annually. Of the Rs 75,000 crore budgeted for the scheme, merely Rs 43,000 has been spent, which has benefited only eight crore farmers in the country.

Congress’s Balasaheb Thorat said the government scheme to double farmer income by 2022 is unrealistic. “This would need a growth rate of at least 11%, which is currently at 2% due to faulty policies of the government.”

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Students back from China under health department’s lens
Content:
Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: Doctors are closely monitoring the nine students, who returned to their hometowns in the district from China on Friday evening, for any symptoms of coronavirus infection Dr Govindan, deputy director of district health services, said health department officials had collected their blood samples as soon as they landed in Chennai airport on Thursday and that they were tested negative for the virus.A team of doctors from the district, meanwhile, visited the students at their houses on Friday and Saturday and conducted a thorough check-up. “We will monitor them daily until they return to China,” Govindan said.While the students do not have any symptoms of coronavirus, they have been instructed not to go outside and mingle with others. “They should not move with others, especially with people suffering from fever and cold. They should also remain isolated at their houses,” the deputy director of district health services said.One of the students, M Chandrasekaran, 21, of Hosur, however, told reporters that there wasn’t any such panic in China as described in the media. “I was instructed to return to my college on February 21,” he said. He is pursuing fourth year medicine in China.The health department officials, meanwhile, appealed the public not to panic. “People should approach doctors at the earliest if they have cough and cold accompanied by high temperature,” an official said.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man kills friend who shot wife’s bathing video
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A 35-year-old construction worker who recorded the video of his friend’s wife bathing and demanded ransom from him to delete it was murdered by the husband and two of his friends. Tuticorin district police have picked up the man and are on the lookout for his accomplices.

The murder which happened on January 25 came to light only on January 31 when foul smell from the decomposed body of the man emanated from a private farm land near Thirumangalakurichi near Kayathar. Initially, the police faced difficulty in identifying the man as the body was decomposed. It was sent to Tirunelveli government medical college hospital for autopsy, which confirmed cut injuries and stabs on the body. During inquiry the police led by deputy superintendent of police M Jebaraj identified the deceased as D Miltonraj, a construction worker from Kammapatti near Kayathar.

The man is married and has a three-year-old son but is separated from his wife. While tracking the call details of the victim they narrowed down on a fellow construction worker A Vijayan of the same village. Vijayan lives with his wife and three children. The two men used to work at the same construction site and also consume liquor.

According to the police, preliminary inquiry revealed that recently the duo was consuming liquor when Miltonraj showed Vijayan a video and pictures he shot on his mobile phone. Vijayan was shocked to see that it was his wife bathing which was recorded without her knowledge. An argument ensued between them and Miltonraj demanded ransom to delete it. Vijayan sought some time to arrange the money. He called Miltonraj on January 25 and promised to give him the money that the latter had demanded. Vijayan took him on his bike to Othaveedu, where two others also joined in murdering him with knives and screwdrivers and abandon the body. On Saturday, the police secured Vijayan for questioning. The police said that Vijayan tried to mislead them during investigations to protect his accomplices and further investigations were under way.

Title: Himalayan states should stop dreaming of Green Bonus: Environmentalists
Content: Dehradun: The lack of mention of any ‘ Green Bonus ’ for Himalayan states in Nirmala Sitharaman’s Budget speech has disappointed many environmentalists.Ravi Chopra, noted environmentalist and head of the All-weather Char Dham Road Committee appointed by the Supreme Court, told TOI, “The budget allocation for environmental conservation is less than the amount allocated to some big NGOs. Only Rs 4,400 crore has been kept for checking air pollution and that, too, will be used in cities with a population of one million or above. Also, the budget does not provide for restoration of rivers or forests.”He also cautioned against the massive infrastructural projects proposed in the ecologically-sensitive Himalayan state. “Our state is prone to natural calamities and we must not fall prey to fancy ideas that may ultimately prove detrimental.”However, environmentalist Anil Joshi who has recently been awarded the Padma Bhushan, told TOI that the Centre didn’t allocate ‘Green Bonus’ as the state had no concrete plan to spend the amount. “The demand is genuine but those who are demanding it are not sure as to how they will use it? We failed to present our case scientifically before the Centre. Also, if Himalayan states are given Green Bonus, the coastal states may also demand a Black or White Bonus. That would not be feasible for the government. We must prepare a proper strategy for the Green Bonus.”

Title: ‘Duty hike on components to hurt Kanpur leather industry’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

ddsfdfsfdsf

Kanpur: The city’s leather industry is a little disappointed with the budget presented by the Union finance minister in Parliament on Saturday.

Commenting that leather industry also needs an uplift, former chairman of Council for Leather Export (CLE) Mukhtarul Amin said that increase in import duty would benefit the domestic industry, but on the other hand, the enhanced duty on components in the leather industry would hurt the industry which was already crawling due to some decisions taken by the state government.

He said though this was just a proposal and would be discussed in the house, but a delegation of the leather industry would meet the Union finance minister and request her to reduce the duty on components so that the industry can be run properly.

General secretary, Leather Industries Welfare Association, Asad Iraqi, said that the industry was expecting some relief, especially due to its present condition. “The budget is a great disappointment for the leather industry”, he said.

The budget experts, however, evoked mixed reactions. Bhagwan Jagwani, director, Allen House Colleges said the budget has given an indication of growth and vision in India because the finance minister tried to cover the maximum fields in her budget.

Govind Maheshwari and Rajesh Bajpai, both chartered accountants, stated that they were hoping an increase in the home loan sector limit but that was missing. “The budget has withdrawn the mandatory provision of an audit by a chartered accountant for companies having a turnover of Rs 5 crore or more. It is good for businessmen but against the chartered accountants”, they said. They have however praised the initiative of minimum governance and extension of disposal scheme of income tax matters of Rs 4 crore or more.

Anuradha Varshney, chairperson, Flow, Kanpur Chapter while welcoming the budget stated that it was in the interest of women associated with the Agri sector, middle-income group employment, and industry.

President, Kanpur Income Tax Bar Association, Deep Kumar Mishra, said that planned investment in Agri, rail, milk production and fishery, 100 new airports, data centre park etc would push the country towards development. Baby Rani Agarwal, principal of Mahila Degree College said though the budget was good there was a need for more tax reforms. The taxpayers should have been given some more facilities, she said.

In a debate on budget held at the Allen House, the banking experts welcomed the enhanced guarantee of the finance minister on investors’ deposits from Rs 1 to 5 lakh and said it was a right measure to secure the deposits of the people.

Announcement regarding reduction in income tax rates would bring a smile on faces of middle-income groups, said a tax expert

Title: One nation, one ration card kicks off in Tuticorin, T’lveli
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Madurai: The Union government’s ‘one nation, one ration card’ scheme was kick-started in Tuticorin and Tirunelveli districts on Saturday as a pilot project in the state.

“The software used in the public distribution system (PDS) shops has been updated in the two districts. We will closely monitor stock in the shops and study if there is any defect in the stock movement or handling,” Tuticorin collector Sandeep Nanduri told TOI.

Stating that they have allotted 5% more stock in each PDS shop – compared to their usual quota, Nanduri said that successful implementation of the project in these two districts will be studied for a month before the state government implements it in the other districts. He added that 41 ration cardholders from Tirunelveli and other parts of Tuticorin district made their purchase under the scheme on day one.

Elaborating on how the scheme functions, Nanduri said that there are 4,93,842 PDS cardholders in 957 PDS shops in Tuticorin district. Similarly, there are around 4.5 lakh cardholders in nearly 500 shops in Tirunelveli district. Cardholders of this region temporarily relocate themselves for a considerable part of the year within the district or neighbouring districts or states in search of jobs.

The scheme is aimed at helping such people so that they can get their monthly quota of provisions in a hassle-free manner at the place where they are working, instead of missing their quota or travelling all the way to the shop where they are registered for the monthly PDS purchase. Kerosene is exempted from the scheme as it can be purchased only in PDS shops where the card has been registered.

Since it is a pilot project in two districts, the scheme is implemented only for cardholders of Tuticorin and Tirunelveli. The only limitation is that the cardholders cannot buy in another shop located in the same ward or revenue village where the card is registered.
