On the software front, the PDS card details of all the cardholders in the two districts has been fed into the point of sale machines of every PDS shop to make the transaction possible.

“On full-fledged implementation it will help the migrant workers from Bihar, Odisha and Andhra Pradesh working here to buy their provisions,” an official said.

Title: Goon demands Rs2 lakh per month from employee of AG Enviro
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: Gittikhadan police on Saturday arrested dreaded goon Akhilesh alias Pappu Mishra for allegedly threatening and demanding Rs 2 lakh per month from an employee of AG Enviro, which is one of the two garbage collection agencies of NMC for allowing them to work in Gittikhadan area.

Senior PI of Gittikhadan police station, Sunil Gangurde, said, “The accused had demanded Rs 2 lakh per month from the complainant for letting him carry out work in the area. The complainant had initially gone to Sadar police station, but the incident took place under our jurisdiction and so, we registered the case and arrested him.”

Gittikhadan police officials have booked Mishra for extortion, assault and criminal intimidation.

According to police, Sachin Chavhan, a vigilance executive at AG Enviro, was approached by Mishra who claimed to be the president of Akhil Yuva Sangram Kamgar Union. Mishra demanded Rs1 lakh for his organization and an additional Rs1 lakh for himself for allowing Chavhan to carry out garbage collection in the area.

He threatened to destroy and set on fire garbage collection vehicles if Chavhan did not comply with his demand. He also told Chavhan to employee 200 of his men.

“When I refused to agree to his demands, Mishra threatened me at different locations. He also came to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) with around 40 people and ordered them to attack me,” said Chavhan.

Sources said that Mishra used to collect protection money commonly known as ‘hafta’ from employees of the previous garbage collecting agency. As the old agency was replaced by two new ones, he was threatening them and demanding money.

It is learnt that Mishra has around 25 offences registered against him, including rioting and robbery. In 2015, he was externed from the city limits for criminal activities.

Title: Leadership conclave held to motivate young entrepreneurs
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Madurai: Over 550 delegates from across Tamil Nadu were treated to discourses by eminent personalities at the ‘Evolve – A Leadership Conclave’ event, organized by Young Indians – Madurai Chapter, the youth wing of the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), Madurai.

The event held in Madurai on Saturday saw over 20 eminent personalities from different industrial sectors deliver speeches on various topics related to developing businesses and creating opportunities for entrepreneurship. The speakers were top officials at various successful brands like Toni and Guy, Hot Breads, Naturals Salon and Spa, Venus Home Appliances and Chai Kings. During the event, Nagaraj K, CII Madurai Zone chairman and Managing Director of Aparajitha Corporate Services, delivered the inaugural address while Dr Sathish Devadoss, CII Madurai Zone vice chairman and medical director of Devadoss Hospital, delivered the special address. Actor and film director Karu Palaniappan was a special guest at the event. A couple of panel discussions were also held at the event.

In one of the sessions, TEDx speaker and the man behind the auto model with a range of services on offer, Auto Annadurai, interacted with the delegates, sharing experiences about his journey from being a normal auto driver to going on to become an entrepreneur by developing an innovative auto model replete with Wifi and latest gadgets.

“The most important part of any brand’s success is the customer. We should look at what the customer’s expectations and needs are and try to fulfil them. Every single customer is important and building customer loyalty is the only way for brands to thrive,” Annadurai said.

Title: Hastinapur finds mention in Budget, historians, experts happy
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Meerut: Hastinapur figuring in the Budget speech of Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman among the five archaeological sites that Union government proposes to transform into iconic sites across India with on-site museums, has brought a wide grin on the faces of historians and archaeologists alike. The town that finds mention in the Mahabharata as the capital of Kauravas, is situated 18 km from Meerut in western Uttar Pradesh.

During her Budget speech on Friday, Sitharaman said, “Five archaeological sites will be developed as iconic sites with on-site museums. These sites are Rakhigarhi in Haryana, Hastinapur in UP, Shivsagar in Assam, Dholavira in Gujarat and Adichanallur in Tamil Nadu.”

Experts said the FM’s announcement brings hope for an extensive archeological excavation in the historic town.

The only time an exhaustive excavation was conducted here was in 1950 by prominent archaeologist BB Lal, which revealed a large amount of artefacts, including iron nails, axes, knives, spearheads, painted greyware pottery etc.

“Since Hastinpur has been mentioned in the epic as the seat of Kaurava-Pandava conflict, sustained survey of the region could have resulted in possible evidence of Mahabharata. Now after 70 years, it is certainly a golden opportunity. I am sure there is a huge amount of history embedded beneath earth. A sustained excavation is the need of the hour,” said Prof KK Sharma, HoD, department of History, Multani Mal College in Modinagar.

Sharma was instrumental in the excavation of Sinauli, another archaeological site, in Baghpat that revealed biggest burial site of the region in 2007. In 2018, in a first-of-its-kind find, remains of chariots were excavated from the same site.

“Hastinapur is a key Mahabharata site. There is little on the ground in terms of ruins as such, but we have rich and detailed literature to back the importance of this site. ASI has artefacts which can be shifted to the proposed museum and facilities like light and sound shows can draw tourists. In fact, I suggest the nearby sites like Barnawa in Baghpat and Kurukshetra in Haryana can also be interconnected into a circuit,” said Kamal Sharma, former superintending archaeologist, ASI.

At present, Hastinapur is a spiritual pilgrimage centre for Jains that draws a great number of devotees to Jambudweep and other sites here. Besides, it is an important site for Sikhism as well.

According to Prof KK Sharma, “One of the Panj Pyaras chosen by Guru Gobind Singh in 1699 – Bhai Dharam Singh – belonged to Saifpur village in Hastinapur, which has a famous Gurdwara here. So, it is a multicultural and multi-religious site that can be developed into tourist and spiritual attraction.”

Uttar Pradesh tourism minister Neelkanth Tiwari told TOI, “As far as tourism is concerned, we had been gradually developing the town from our end; but for historical and cultural development, we had been seeking Union government’s intervention both in terms of resources and funds. In fact, we had an elaborate meeting in this regard in September last year with various Union ministries. Now, the inclusion of Hastinapur in the list of five archaeological sites to be developed is the result of that continuous endeavour. Besides, Draupadi’s Ashram and Pandeshwar Mahadev Mandir will also get a facelift.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Cops seize illicit liquor, arrest six
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: The police seized 693 pouches of illicit liquor worth Rs 30 lakh and fake stickers of a popular brand and arrested nine persons in Kanpur Dehat district on late Friday night.

“Nine persons were arrested for preparing illegal liquor,” said ASP Anoop Kumar. The arrested persons were identified as Ratnesh, Vineet, Sunil, Mukesh, Neeraj, Alok, Vijay, Banwari and Ajit.

They had been involved in preparing hooch since long, he said. “They had prepared hooch estimated to be worth around Rs 30 lakh to be supplied in nearby villages and pockets. Acting on a tip-off regarding the same, the police arrested the six miscreants, ASP added.

Kanpur Dehat police had intensified drive against groups involved in making country-made liquor targeting low-income groups in the remote areas.

Title: Gujarat: International bullion bourses to come up at GIFT City
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday announced setting up of international bullion exchanges ... Read More

Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday announced setting up of international bullion exchanges at International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) in GIFT City near Gandhinagar.

This was one of the measures announced in the Union budget to bring GIFT City at par with global financial hubs in Hong Kong, Dubai and Singapore.

“IFSC, GIFT City has the potential to become a centre of international finance as well as a centre for high end data processing,” Sitharaman said in her budget speech.

The bullion exchanges will enable India to enhance its position worldwide, create jobs in India and will lead to better price discovery of gold.

“This announcement is in line with Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s vision that GIFT City would become a price setter in some of the world's largest traded instruments in the next 10 years," said Tapan Ray, MD and group CEO, GIFT City.

The IFSC already houses 19 insurance entities and 40 banking entities. It has also provided for setting up of precious metals testing laboratories and refining facilities.

“In recent years there has been a surge in trading volumes of Indian rupee in the offshore financial centres. The government and RBI has taken various measures to permit rupee derivatives to be traded in the IFSC at GIFT City," the minister said in her speech.

The finance minister also proposed to reduce the withholding tax rate to 4% from 5% on interest payment on bonds listed at IFSC exchange. The move is expected to attract more international investors at the IFSC exchange.

V Balasubramaniam, MD and CEO of BSE’s India International Exchange (India INX) at GIFT IFSC said that the exchange is fully geared up and ready to launch rupee dollar futures and options contracts trading as soon as approvals are received from regulators.

“We are keen to set up an international bullion exchange at GIFT IFSC,” he said.

India INX has already listed medium-term note programs worth USD 47 billion dollars with drawdown of USD 18.5 billion dollars till date.

Title: Now, cyber conmen pretend to be police to dupe people
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: Cyber crooks have come up with yet another modus operandi to steal money—by posing as cybercrime cops from Delhi, or as an executive from Vodafone. Two such instances were reported at Machavaram and within Krishna Lanka police limits. Krishna Lanka cops, who did not wish to reveal the identity of the complainant, said a person lost Rs 7.7 lakh.

Similarly, in Machavaram cybercrooks stole Rs 1.07 lakh from a complainant.

Explaining the modus operandi, cybercrime police said that the miscreants contact the victim pretending to be Delhi cybercrime sleuths. They first intimidate the person by accusing them of committing various cybercrimes. Then they pretend to be a Vodafone executive and claim they have received a complaint against them for committing a cyber fraud.

The miscreants then explain that the victim’s SIM card might have been cloned and seek their assistance to declone it. This is when they request the victims to download a screensharing application like Team Viewer, after which the crooks collect bank details and the One Time Password (OTP), which will allow the cyber crooks to steal the victims’ money from their accounts. “Do not download any links or applications, or provide OTP numbers to a stranger,” the city police advisory reads.

While the modus operandi has been proven, Vijayawada also witnessed a case where Gurugram police slapped a Rs 3 lakh cyber fraud charge against a local on January 26. Sarath (name changed), the local resident, then approached the city cybercrime police who investigated the incident and found that he did share his Aadhaar card, PAN card and bank account details with an unidentified person through WhatsApp. Sarath lost Rs 1,750 but had not lodged a police complaint.

Title: Minister appeals to Madurai residents to take part in Ease of Living survey
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Madurai: Residents of Madurai should come forward to participate and vote in the Ease of Living Index Assessment survey being conducted by the ministry of housing and urban affairs, said minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju.

Speaking to reporters at Alwarpuram in Madurai during the mass cleaning campaign held as part of the Namma Madurai programme of Madurai Corporation on Saturday, Raju said the citizens perception survey will help understand the quality of life in the city from the citizens’ perspective. The details obtained would be compared with the global as well as national data.

It is being conducted in 114 cities across the country including Madurai. The survey covers various topics including hygiene, safety, greening development, education, roads, electricity facility among others. Citizens can log onto Eol2019.org or scan the QR code for the survey and participate in it. They would have to answer 24 questions, the minister said.

Later, the minister inaugurated the cleaning campaign in which 150 volunteers, 400 students and about 600 workers of the corporation participated and cleaned the banks of river Vaigai. They removed the plastic wastes and other garbage dumped on the riverbed between Alwarpuram and Kuruvikkaransalai. Corporation commissioner S Visakan, city engineer S Arasu among others participated.

In the morning, the minister flagged off a marathon in which more than 400 children participated stressing the importance of a clean Madurai. The ‘kidathon’ was flagged off from the Gandhi Museum. He said that it was important to ensure that people did not throw their garbage on roads and maintained hygiene.

Title: HR headache of 2 tax systems
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Managing payrolls could become an administrative nightmare for large employers as the new tax regime kicks in. Experts said organisations will need to put in efforts to counsel employees on the new tax regime before April 1 this year.

Employees whose salaries fall in the respective tax brackets where the tax reduction benefit is being offered — earning between Rs 5 lakh and Rs 15 lakh per annum — will have to decide on the path they want to pick. If they choose to continue with the existing tax regime (let’s call it plan `A’), and decide to claim deductions from their investments in tax saving schemes as they do every year, then the organisation would not make any changes to the manner in which their taxation is computed.

However, if they opt for the new tax regime (say Plan B), they will have to declare this intent to their employers before March 31, this year. Once employees opt for the new tax regime they will not be able to go back to the old one. For employees opting for Plan B, it will be more straight forward as tax will be deducted upfront from the employees’ salary.

Aditya Birla Group director HR Santrupt Misra , said, “Compensation of employees will continue in the same manner. We will have to, however, counsel employees on the two taxation paths, explaining the implications and possibly creating a helpline which can assist employees with any kind of queries. Once employees voluntarily declare which tax path they would like to opt for, the organisation will format and compute it accordingly.”

PwC partner (personal tax) Ishita Sengupta , said moving to the new optional tax regime could be a huge administrative exercise for the HR and payroll departments of organisations who will have to figure out how they are going to run alternative payroll if they wish to offer this option to the employees at the withholding stage.

“Employer organisations may have to explain the changes in the tax regime and related impact which can vary from case to case. Suddenly, for employees who opt for the new regime, it would mean giving up on a whole bunch of exemptions they earlier sought, such as LTA, HRA. Depending on what they were claiming earlier and are now foregoing, some may even end up paying more. Perhaps, a familiarisation process can be undertaken for the employees, with the help of tax experts,” said Sengupta.

Freshers and young employees, with incomes below Rs 15 lakh, might be the target for Plan B while a majority of the employees in the middle and upper bracket might stick with the earlier tax regime. What is absolutely clear is that it will add to the paperwork of most companies with the finance departments racing to provide thousands of employees with options on how the two schemes work.

Title: To pay or not to pay: I-T changes leave Gulf NRIs confused
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: The proposed amendment to Income Tax Act to tax non-resident Indians (NRIs), who are not paying taxes in any country, has created confusion among the migrant workforce particularly in Gulf countries. Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has proposed in the Union Budget 2020 that NRIs not paying taxes in any foreign country will be deemed as resident Indians for purpose of income tax. Any income they earn from April 1 will be taxable in India if the NRIs do not pay tax in the foreign country.

While NRIs working in the US and Europe pay taxes there, those in the Gulf countries are not taxed. They are also not taxed in India due to their NRI status. The confusion arose as the Indian government has proposed to tax people, who simply globetrot for a specified number of days to claim NRI status, only to avoid paying taxes in India. Many employees in the Gulf are confused whether the provision is only for businessmen, who travel abroad for NRI status, or genuine workers are also covered by it.

Reports from the UAE and other Gulf countries point out that many NRI employees are confused over the new provision. While some tax experts say they will be taxed, others say no. Advocate and tax expert HP Ranina clarifies that Indians holding resident visa (permit) in the UAE need not pay tax in India as India and UAE have entered into Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement. However, Indians, who are not resident of any country but stay out for more than 240 days (183 days under existing rules, 240 days from April 1, 2020) only for the sake of NRI status should pay tax in India.

Tax consultant A Mehta feels that the new proposal in the Budget has dented the confidence of NRIs and it would hit NRI investment in India.

Senior auditor and tax consultant, Naveen Sharma, said under the new legislation an Indian should stay out of the country for 240 days to claim NRI status. If an Indian businessman settled in Gulf returns to India and stays there for less than 120 days, he will lose NRI status and thus he is liable to pay tax in India on his global income.

Title: People get pension at their doorsteps
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: The government’ s door-to-door pension distribution began across Andhra Pradesh on Saturday. Village and ward volunteers, and senior officials in the state government also took part in this initiative and made their way to the doors of beneficiaries to distribute the pension.

Volunteers reached out to the pensioners across the state with biometric equipment and data to carry out the procedure and ensure the pension is credited to the beneficiaries’ bank accounts. Krishna district collector Mohammed Imtiaz visited the house of a mentally disabled girl and gave her the pension.

Speaking to the media, Gopala Krishna Dwivedi, principal secretary PR & RD, who participated in the pension disbursement in Jupudi village Krishna district, said, “Through village and ward volunteers we are distributing the pension right at the doorstep of the beneficiary. Almost 4 lakhs volunteers are on this initiative today and with in 5-6 hours, as many as 54.6 lakh beneficiaries are to get their pensions. For this, Rs 1320.14 crores has been released by the state government”

He added: “This is the first time that any state in the country has taken up such initiative, where lakhs are people are going to receive their pensions without any hassles.”

Title: Travel agents offer S’pore, Indonesia as options
Content: Hyderabad: After Coronavirus outbreak in China, the travel agencies are offering alternate destinations like Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia or an option to defer the trip to customers who had booked their China trip in advance. Many airlines are even waiving off cancellation and rescheduling charges for those who had booked their travel to China, until February 29, 2020.“We are closely monitoring the situation in coordination with the government and health authorities and also our on-ground partners/suppliers to assess the situation on a day-to-day basis and keep our customers updated. We are in touch with airline partners and most of them have waived off cancellation and rescheduling fees for our customers who were booked to travel to China till February 29, 2020,” said Rajeev Kale, president & country head of holidays, MICE, Visa, Thomas Cook (India) Ltd.He said that in the interest of customers, who prefer cancelling their China tour, three other options are being offered. “They can choose alternative destinations like Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam or they can defer their trip or avail a future travel voucher, as per their convenience,” he added.The travel firms said that since the outbreak of Coronavirus, there has been a massive dip in the number of bookings to China, however, tours to Japan and South Korea remain unaffected. “The second week of January registered 31 per cent dip in bookings to China as compared to the week before that,” said Balu Ramachandran, Senior Vice President, Cleartrip.Many people reluctant to travel to Singapore and Thailand in the current scenario asked for cancellation fee waiver. “Indigo is refusing cancellation fee waiver due to the coronavirus in Singapore. Singapore is on alert, why do you want me to travel to Singapore? Please help #indigoairlines,” read a tweet from @saurav123india.Another user Ravi Agrawal tweeted, “@goairlinesindia why would you charge a full cancellation fee on coronavirus threat for travel to Phuket.”

Title: A mixed bag for Madurai docs in Neet PG exam
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Madurai: Two days after the results of the National Eligibility cum Entrance Test Post Graduate (Neet PG) exams were declared, major medical entrance coaching centres in the city said that though the performance of candidates from Tamil Nadu was satisfactory with quite a few securing top ranks in the All India Rankings, the results were not good as last year’s results.

“We are yet to sort out the complete results and confirm our toppers. Tamil Nadu has got the maximum pass percentage at 55 per cent. However, when it comes to top ranks, the number of top ranks from Tamil Nadu in the top 1000, which is usually around 200 is sadly less than 100 this time around,” said Dr Arun Kumar, co-ordinator of a Neet PG coaching centre. A few students from Madurai Medical College have secured top 1000 ranks this year.

The co-ordinator of another Neet PG coaching centre, Tamil Selvam, said that many students from Madurai and Tamil Nadu have scored between 600-900 marks. “A score above 650 is likely to guarantee that students get admission in colleges within Tamil Nadu itself,” he said. The cut-off scores for this year for General Category, SC/ST/OBC, and UR-PWD are 366, 319 and 342 respectively. The individual score card of the candidates who appeared for Neet PG exam 2020 can be downloaded from the website https://nbe.edu.in by Monday.

Title: Harappan sites get budget boost
Content:
A water reservoir at Dholavira. (File photo)

Two of the most prominent Harappan sites in India – Dholavira and Lothal – featured prominently in Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s Budget speech on Saturday.Dholavira in Kutch district is going to be developed as one of the five ‘iconic sites’ identified by the Union ministry of culture. The ongoing project of national maritime museum at Lothal in Ahmedabad district was also mentioned. The total budgetary allocation for the Union ministry of culture for 2020-21 is Rs 3,150 crore.Sitharaman said that the five archaeological sites including Rakhigarhi (Haryana), Hastinapur (Uttar Pradesh), Shivsagar ( Assam ), Dholavira (Gujarat) and Adichanallur (Tamil Nadu) will be developed as iconic sites with on-site museums.Dr Y S Rawat, former director of the state archaeology department and an archaeologist who worked on the Dholavira excavation, termed the move as a major impetus for development of the historic site.“The site witnesses major footfalls of international tourists today – especially in winter months. The proposed museum will add value to that experience. Hopefully, the status will not only be motivated by tourism, but also towards encouraging more research and interpretation of the site,” he said.The site, having the oldest excavated artefacts dating back to 5,491 years Before Present (BP) or 3,471 years before common era (BCE), consists of a fully-developed Harappan-era metropolis complete with castle, bailey, middle and lower towns and reservoirs. A recent paper by multi-disciplinary researchers claimed that Dholavira was an example of how climate change affected the human habitation in the past.Lothal, on the other hand, is significant for the find of the dockyard, considered to be one of the oldest in the world. It dates back to 5,720 years before present (BP) or 3,700 years before common era (BCE). Prime Minister Narendra Modi had performed the ground-breaking ceremony for the national maritime museum, being set up jointly by the Union ministry of culture and ministry of shipping and Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), in March 2019.Sources close to the development said that the thematic museum aims at highlighting India’s links with other parts of the known world in ancient times, the country’s trade links and how it shaped today’s India, the maritime milestones and regional achievements.“While deliberations are still going on under leadership of the Sagarmala project of the central government, Prof Vasant Shinde, vice-chancellor of the Deccan College, Post Graduate and Research Institute has been roped in to oversee the development,” said an official close to the development. “A space has been procured at GIFT City to give final shape to the drafts, artefacts and designs.”

Title: Union Budget 2020: AMT exemption to boost investment in dairy sector
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

Proposed reduction of tax on cooperative societies to 22% plus surcharge and cess as well as exemption from Alternative Minimum Tax ( AMT ) will help increase investments in dairy sector. The relief to cooperatives has come at a time when milk processing capacity is being doubled in the country.

The cooperative sector proposals will also lead to more creation of jobs and remunerative prices to farmers.

Gujarat Cooperative Milk Marketing Federation , India’s largest cooperative that markets Amul brand, along with its 18 district level milk unions will be able to save Rs 15 crore on account of the reduction in tax and AMT exemption.

Cooperatives had demanded level playing field by seeking lower tax on the lines of reduced corporate tax offered to companies. “This discrepancy has been eliminated. Farmers will now try to earn more profits from animal husbandry,” said R S Sodhi, managing director, GCMMF.

Gujarat’s dairy cooperatives have 36 lakh farmers as their members and they are currently paying nearly Rs 150 crore as taxes. Both GCMMF and the National Dairy Development Board ( NDDB ) had demanded reduction in tax ahead of the budget.

The target to double milk processing capacity from 53.5 million tonnes (MT) to 108 MT by 2025 will create 96 lakh new jobs in rural and urban India, said industry players.

“With addition of each one lakh litre milk processing capacity in the organised sector, 6,000 new jobs including 5,000 in rural India and 1,000 in urban India get created,” he said.

The dairy economy suffers a loss of around Rs 20,000 crore per year due to foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) alone directly affecting livelihood of farmers.

“Eradicating FMD and brucellosis in the country by 2025 would require effective implementation for the benefit of millions of small and marginal dairy farmers. The effective implementation includes manufacturing and sourcing of quality vaccines, robust testing methods and facilities, introduction of robust systems and processes and training of personal at all levels,” said NDDB’s chairman Dilip Rath.

“Eradication of FMD and brucellosis will help us overcome the technical barrier of trade agreements for export of milk and milk products and also follow the codex guidelines on quality and safety,” he said.

Title: 6 yrs on, all 10 accused appear in court in a Ist, charges yet not framed
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Slug: M’nagar riots

Muzaffarnagar: For the first time ever since 2013 Muzaffarnagar riots, all 10 accused in a case pertaining to incitement of masses reached the court for a hearing. But more than six years and dozens of hearings later, the charges could not be framed as the judge was on leave.

According to lawyers, it is imperative for all accused to be present in the court at the time of the framing of charges. The 10 accused include two former MPs and as many MLAs. The incident pertains to August 30, 2013, in which these leaders delivered provocative speeches in Muslim-dominated Khalapar locality of Muzaffarnagar. The leaders included former MP from BSP Kadir Rana, the then MLAs Noor Saleem Rana, Maulana Jameel, among others.

Notably, another case has met a similar fate in which 13 accused have not appeared before the court, and hence, no charges have been framed. The accused in this particular case include the likes of Union minister and MP from Muzaffarnagar Sanjeev Balyan, UP sugarcane minister Suresh Rana among others.

It should be noted that on January 16, the court had ordered all 10 accused to appear before the court on January 27, but some of them could not reach there on the date. The court again fixed January 31 as the next date for their appearance.

However, as the judge was not present, they were instructed to appear in the court on February 25, said sources.

Defence lawyer Nakli Tyagi said, “Due to the judge being on leave, the court has fixed February 25 as the next date to frame charges.”

Notably, the Allahabad high court had directed shifting back the trial of the cases of political personalities, including cases related to Muzaffarnagar riots, to sessions court five months ago.

This came after, a special court had been formed in Allahabad in November 2018 to take over around three dozen cases against politicians in Muzaffarnagar for their speedy disposal. Leaders from various political parties, like UP minister Suresh Rana, BJP MLA Umesh Malik, BJP MLA Kapil Dev Aggarwal, Union minister Sanjeev Balyan, BJP MP Kunwar Bhartendra, former BSP MP Kadir Rana, former BSP MLA Noor Saleem Rana, were booked for making inflammatory speeches in 2013, which led to the 2013 riots, which resulted in deaths of 60 and displacement of over 50,000.

Title: Murdered woman’s valuables untouched
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: The mystery behind the murder of 55-year-old woman in Bhavanipuram deepens, with the police finding that the cash and jewellery at the murdered woman’s house was left untouched, on Saturday. Not just that, the victim Yedupati Padmavathi’s earrings too were found untouched at the crime scene.

Police sources said that while they have gathered the necessary clues regarding the case, the motive remains a mystery as physical evidence in the crime scene does not suggest that it is a clear-cut case of murder for gain. “We are looking into every angle, including that the culprits could have been known to the victim’s family,” a Bhavanipuram police official said.

The gold ornaments that were robbed are said to be worth Rs 5 lakh, overall, while other untouched valuables were worth more. Preliminary post-mortem report indicates that the murder might have happened between 2pm to 4pm, while the incident came to light only at 7pm when the victim’s husband Venkateswara Rao found her in a pool of blood in her bedroom.

The police also found a glove on the spot and suspect that chilli powder was used. These clues lead them to believe that the perpetrator could be a ‘professional’.

Though Rao informed the cops—who reached the spot with clues team—but enough time had passed for the culprits to have fled the city.

Cops also suspect that the accused could be from a different state.

The entire incident happened at the victim’s residence in Crombwe Road area, under Bhavanipuram police station limits in the city.

Title: SCR pins hopes on Hyd-Mum corridor
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: While South Central Railway ( SCR ) officials are optimistic about the proposed Mumbai-Pune-Hyderabad high-speed corridor, workers unions are worried that privatisation of rail networks will lead to increased fares.

With the Union Budget 2020 proposing high-speed train projects across the country, SCR officials said that Mumbai-Pune-Hyderabad high-speed route — one of the six sections for high-speed corridors identified by Indian Railways — will reduce running time by almost 50%. “The 747km distance between Mumbai-Hyderabad is currently covered by Hussainsagar Express in 17 hours and 10 minutes. The bullet rail corridor project can help optimise the high-speed rail connectivity between the two major citie,” said officials.

The IR is also mulling handing over operations of more trains to private players.

Railway union members in SCR zone are, however, unhappy with the expected privatisation. “Privatisation of trains will lead to increased fares for common people. Rather than improving train facilities, authorities should focus on running trains on-time,” said senior member, South Central Railway Mazdoor Union. “If trains will now be owned by private organisations, how will passengers who take these daily be able to afford them?”

Title: Ports gear up to deal with novel coronavirus threat
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ahmedabad: Gujarat, which handles about a third of the country’s sea cargo, has begun taking precautions to combat the deadly novel coronavirus (CoV) outbreak in China that has spread to a few other countries.

The Gujarat Maritime Board, the state’s maritime regulator, has put in placing screening, detection and quarantine systems at all minor ports for disembarking seafarers or passengers and regular reporting using thermal scanner screening, said sources.

“As Kandla and the state’s minor ports receive many ships, crews and passengers from China, Hong Kong and Singapore, the health ministry has asked that all points of entry, including ports and airports, be on alert to prevent the virus contagion in India,” sources added. The secretary of the shipping ministry met senior officers of all state governments and state maritime boards on Thursday, to review measures taken by ports.

GMB chief nautical officer Capt A B Solanki told TOI over the phone that the Kandla Port Health Organization (PHO) has issued an advisory to all stakeholders, including pilots, customs and immigration officials and ship masters, demanding strict compliance. No vessel will be allowed without clearance from the PHO, he added.

The advisory deals with pre-arrival screening, grant of ‘pratique’, and suspected crew management, among others. “All GMB port offices have been instructed to procure 200 N-95 masks and thermal portable scanners for screening of coronavirus,” Solanki said.

Title: Telangana's cup empty, KCR terms Union Budget 2020 unfair
Content:
Centre had cut Rs 3,731 crore funds from the share it had announced in Parliament in 2019-20 financial year

HYDERABAD: Telangana chief minister K Chandrashekhar Rao has called the Union Budget 2020 ‘totally disappointing’. He said that Telangana would be adversely affected by major cuts in budgetary allocations and charged the central government of discrimination.“It is sheer incompetence of the Centre to decrease the ratio of the state in Central funds. Normally, funds are given to the states according to the Budget proposals. Reducing the funds by 18.9% in 2019-20 clearly demonstrated the Centre’s faulty fiscal management. This has adversely impacted Telangana,” he said.“It is atrocious that the Centre has reduced the ratio of the state in the central taxes. There is a danger of having a fund scarcity for several welfare schemes and development programmes being implemented in the state,” he said. The CM held a four-hour long discussion with officials at Pragati Bhavan on the Budget proposals and its impact on the state.He was also upset over the Budget not providing funds for the state’s projects like Mission Bhagiratha and Mission Kakatiya. Niti Ayog had recommended Rs 24,000 crore for them.“The Centre is committing a fraud and cheating on the GST front. The Centre has not given any clarity on these (compensation) funds in the Budget,” he said. Among his main grouses was the Centre accepting the 15th Finance Commission ’s proposal, reducing the state’s share of funds from 42% to 41%. Earlier, Telangana was given 2.437% of share and this financial year it was reduced to 2.133%. “With this, there will be direct decrease of Rs 2,381 crore of funds from the Centre.”He said the Centre, which had cut Rs 3,731 crore funds from the share it had announced in Parliament in 2019-20 financial year, is now proposing Rs 16,726 crore in 2020-21. “There is no link between what the Centre is promising to the states and what it actually is releasing.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Prison department warns of action against corrupt officials
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Corrupt practices of prison department personnel, which range from forcing relatives of inmates to buy groceries for families of the personnel to colluding with gangsters for monetary benefits, have been taken into account by the prison department headquarters that sent out a circular cautioning erring officials of stern action.

Deputy inspector general of prisons (headquarters) K Kanagaraj on January 31 sent a circular to all the heads of the central prisons for men and women, district jails and borstal schools listing out the “widespread and deep-rooted corrupt” practices involving everyone from superintendents to jail wardens.

Though the circular did not name anyone, it hints at a second-grade warden who had illicit relationships with wives of several inmates. The circular that highlighted 15 points stated that a few jailors, superintendents and wardens have been taking bribe and extending facilities to inmates against the prison manual. The four-page circular also revealed that some officials were also colluding with rowdy elements and gangsters and acting against the law” for personal gain. “The circular has been sent after the department received reports from police department from various districts,” said a senior official in the headquarters. He, however, said no department enquiry has been ordered yet.

Additional director general of police (prisons) Abhash Kumar told TOI that departmental action had been taken against seven personnel for indulging in corrupt practices four months ago. “The circular is to warn others and dissuade them from indulging in such practices,” he said.

Though the inmates are eligible for ordinary or emergency leave as per the prison manuals, some officials are granting it only after taking bribes. Casteism is also being practised by a few wardens. TOI had earlier reported the ill practices, highlighting caste discrimination within the central prisons in Palayamkottai and the practice of taking bribes from convicts to grant eligible leave.

Demanding bribe to release inmates despite court orders, allowing inmates to use mobile phones and facilitating a comfortable stay for gangsters for money were some of the other issues highlighted in the circular. It also pointed out that a doctor working in the prison hospital had been smuggling out medicine to his private clinic.

Title: ‘Gujarat Model’ to be replicated?
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday proposed the formation of a ‘National Police University’ and a ‘National Forensic Science University’ in her budget speech.

While the fine print is yet to be made public, experts say the proposed universities may be formed on the existing models of Raksha Shakti University (RSU) and Gujarat Forensic Sciences University (GFSU) in Gandhinagar.

“Both universities — RSU, founded in 2009, and GFSU, in 2011 — were established by the then CM Narendra Modi to provide security forces a formal educational platform, to improve their investigation and security management skills,” said a Gandhinagar-based educationist. “After a decade, these universities are still developing to realize their full potential. While GFSU is now training officials of 20-odd countries in Asia and Africa, RSU is primarily attracting those aspiring to Gujarat Police jobs.”

The two universities may provide a template in terms of course designs and industry requirements, with the FM outlining forensic science, policing science and cyber forensics as domain areas for the proposed universities. “There was talk of giving GFSU national status and making it a nodal centre. Thus, at the moment it’s not clear whether there will be a new university or if GFSU would be upgraded,” said an official close to the development.

Likewise, the public private partnership (PPP) model of attaching a medical college to existing district hospitals — the basis of several Gujarat Medical Education and Research Society (GMERS) medical colleges — has also found mention in the budget. The FM said that to meet requirements for qualified doctors, hospitals and medical college facilities would be provided land at concessional rates and they would also receive viability gap funding.

Title: Case against parents for ‘kidnapping’ daughter
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: A man lodged a complaint against his wife’s parents and relatives for allegedly kidnapping his wife for marrying him against their wishes, at Nellore Chinna Bazaar police limits on Friday.

Within hours, cops solved the case and the woman was back with her husband. According to the police, Venkataramana—a resident of AS Peta—lodged a complaint against his wife Pavani’s parents claiming that they attacked him and kidnapped his wife.

The police said that Venkataramana and his wife Pavani fell in love and eloped against their parents wishes and got married five months ago.

On Thursday, Venkataramana and his wife visited their college to collect their certificates when Pavani’s parents ambushed them and allegedly assaulted them before taking her away.

Upon getting the information, police formed a team and cracked the case within an hour and got Pavani back.

The police said that Pavani’s parents had held her captive at her relatives house. The parents were placed under arrest. A kidnapping case was registered against them at Chinna Bazaar police station.

Title: Notorious burglar caught
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: City cops busted a notorious burglar and recovered Rs 30 lakh worth of gold, cash and other property from his possession, within Patamata police station limits on Saturday. The accused was identified as Dasari Hari Teja (27) from Kovvur village in West Godavari district.

Addressing a press conference, deputy commissioner of police (DCP-Crimes) D Koteswara Rao explained that Hari Teja came to Vijayawada and worked as a car driver. Soon, he was addicted to bad vices like gambling and alcohol, which left him debt-ridden. Teja left the job and began burgling locked houses at night.

On January 20, Teja broke into a house belonging to Korrapolu Srinivas Rao in Madhavapeddivari street and decamped with several valuables in the house.

Based on the victim’s complaint, police filed a case and looked into the activities of previous offenders, which included Teja. When the Central Crime Station (CCS) received credible information from sources that the accused tried to sell the stolen property, cops intercepted and caught him red-handed.

The police recovered 703 grams of gold ornaments, 464 grams of silver valuables and Rs 2.2 lakh cash from him. Cops also said he confessed to all his crimes. tnn

Title: Man in possession of cannabis worth 8L held
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nashik: Police arrested a 28-year-old person from the Mumbai Naka area on Wednesday for allegedly possessing cannabis worth Rs 8.79 lakh.

The suspect, Mosin Anis Shaikh (28), a resident of Bhadrakali area, was slapped with relevant sections of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1985. He was produced before a city court on Thursday, which remanded him in police custody for five days.

Senior officers from the central unit of the crime branch were issued directions to check the sale, distribution and consumption of narcotic substances. On Wednesday, sub-inspector Mahesh Shinde of the central crime branch received a tip-off that narcotic susbtances were kept in a flat in the Renuka Nagar area of Wadala Naka and that a certain person would be arriving there to transport the drug stock.

After the information was passed on to senior police inspector Seetaram Kolhe of the crime branch, a team was prepared under sub-inspector Sachin Sawant, which laid a trap near the residential building. After the suspect arrived at the scene and entered the flat, police immediately intercepted him. On searching the flat, police found cannabis worth Rs 8.79 lakh.

Police said that they would try to find out from where did the suspect procure the narcotic substances, where was he going to supply it, how long he was into this business and other factors during the course of the investigation.

Title: Students suspended for taking part in protests
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: Four students from Acharya Nagarjuna University were suspended from the university hostel on Saturday for participating in ‘Save Amaravati’ protests organised by the Amaravati Parirakshana Samiti Joint Action Committee (JAC). The university termed the participation as ‘anti-government’ activity and used it as grounds for initiating action against the students.

Asirvadam and Naveen from department of journalism and mass communications, Raju and Edukondalu from department of English were suspended from the university hostel.

The chief warden of the university Dr D Ramachandran, in his orders, stated that “as per the orders of the vice-chancellor the students have been suspended from the university hostel with immediate effect for their participation in anti-government activities. They have participated in the anti-government activities of AP JAC for Amaravati”.

The orders further stated that the issue was referred to the university disciplinary committee to seek explanation from the students and to decide the period of punishment.

Title: DMK Trichy unit divided into three
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

K Anbazhagan

CHENNAI: The DMK has divided its Trichy district unit into three parts and appointed Tiruvembur DMK MLA Mahesh Anbil Poyyamozhi as the south Trichy district secretary. Poyyamozhi is in place of K N Nehru, who was recently promoted as party’s principal secretary.

In a statement DMK general secretary K Anbazhagan on Saturday said the present Trichy north and south districts will be divided into north, south and west. ‘“Musiri, Thuraiyur and Manachanallur assembly constituencies will be part of Trichy north party district and Kattuveddi Thiagarajan will be district secretary,” said Anbazhagan.

In Trichy west party district, Trichy west, Srirangam and Ilangudi assembly constituencies will part of the district and Vairamani will be the district secretary. DMK’s Trichy south division, which will include Tiruverumbur, Manapparai and Trichy south assembly constituencies, will be under the charge Poyyamozhi. He is at present the joint general secretary of the party's youth wing and is likely to replaced by T R B Raja, who is the party’s MLA from Mannargudi.

Title: Over 2.5 lakh devotees take part in Radhasapthami fest in Tirumala
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Lord Balaji during the Radhasaptami festivies in Tirumala on Saturday

TIRUPATI: A sea of devotees thronged the abode of Lord Venkateswara as the 175 galleries around the four mada streets encircling the hill temple were jam-packed all through the day at Tirumala on Radhasapthami on Saturday.

Lord Balaji blessed the devout who assembled for seven different processions in a day. The series of processions began with the Surya Prabha Vahanam, as Lord Malayappa Swamy stepped out of the Vahana Mandapam at 5.30 am on Saturday. Then it was the turn of Lord Garuda—the celestial carrier of Lord Sri Maha Vishnu—to carry Lord Venkateswara, in a colourful procession around the main temple complex. In the afternoon, Lord Venkateswara bestowed his grace in the guise of Lord Rama during the Hanumantha Vahanam procession held at 1 pm. The ‘Chakrasnanam’ fete was held in the sacred waters of the Srivari temple tank as the temple priests dipped ‘Chakrathalwar’ in the waters at 2 pm.

In the evening, Lord Malayappa Swamy took a pleasure ride on the ‘Kalpavruksha’ vahanam (Tree of boons). Sending a message that he is the supreme force in the whole universe, Lord Balaji was taken out in a procession on the ‘Sarvabhoopala Vahanam’ at 6 pm. The processions held in connection with the Radhasapthami festival culminated with the ‘Chandra Prabha’ vahanam at 8 pm.

TTD sources said that nearly 2.5 lakh devotees took part in the Radhasapthami festivities on Saturday.

Title: Doctor killed in accident, close shave for family
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: A doctor working for a well-known private hospital died on the spot, while his wife and daughter had a narrow escape, when their car lost control and crashed into the canal at Karakatta road, near Thotlavaleru area, in Krishna district on Saturday evening. The deceased was identified as Kosuri Srinivas (38), a gastroentologist.

According to the police, the incident happened in the evening when there was low visibility. The lack of a retaining wall on the road is said to have been a major contributing factor for the mishap. Cops said that the doctor and his family were heading towards Avanigadda from Vijayawada. Luckily, locals were quick to respond and managed to rescue Srinivas’s daughter and his wife from the sinking car.

However, by the time they fished Srinivas out of the car, he was dead. Cops reached the spot and shifted Srinivas’ body to a local government hospital.

Title: TTD to get land for temples at Ulundurpet and OMR
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams is set to receive 5.5 acres on the Trichy-Salem highway at Ulundurpet to construct a new temple. Chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami after a darshan at Tirumala told reporters on Saturday that a new temple will come up along the highway.

Sources in TTD told TOI the land in Ulundurpet belongs to private individuals, including AIADMK MLA R Kumaraguru. “Four people, including the MLA, who is also a member of TTD board, have donated the land and in the coming days it will be registered in the name of TTD. Once the land is registered, TTD board that is meeting at the end of this month will decide about the type of temple. After that we will know the total cost of construction,” said TTD local advisory committee chief Sekar Reddy.

Meanwhile, Palaniswami is said to have promised to provide five acres in OMR for construction of a new TTD temple. “Along with Ulundurpet, a new temple will also come up at Old Mahabalipuram Road. Here too we have been promised five acres,” said Reddy. The plot on OMR near Sholinganallur is a government land. “The OMR land transfer will be between Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu governments. This too will be discussed in the TTD board meeting and a decision taken,” said Reddy. TTD board chief Y V Subba Reddy visited the plot on OMR.

Earlier there were proposals to use a HR&CE temple land at Tiruvadandai on East Coast Road. “But as the land is far from Chennai city, the AP government had requested a land closer to the city so that it would be easily accessible to devotees,” said a TTD LAC member.

Title: Pune: ‘Ind-SAT welcome but internet a challenge’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Ind-SAT for Asian and African students to award scholarships to study in India will bring in quality students, said heads of educational institutions in Pune.

The challenge will be its large-scale implementation, though, especially in countries where internet connectivity is poor. Currently, there is no standard examination for foreign students arriving in India to study.

Vidya Yeravdekar, principal director of Symbiosis Society that runs the Symbiosis International University, told TOI they had 75 scholarship students in India programme last year and 45 this year. “If it is an online test, bandwidth will be a problem in many African countries. But the test will help students take India seriously. It will also create a level playing field for students from different countries. At present, we rely on marks obtained by them in their country,” said Yeravdekar. There are about 3,000 students studying in various courses in the university.

Meanwhile, with the central government allowing top 100 institutions in the country to offer online degree programmes, educationists said the move is likely to improve the enrolment ratio.

Another positive move, they said, is allowing urban bodies to provide one-year internship to engineers. The move will help engineering students, as AICTE had made internships compulsory two years ago.

Title: Budget positive, but lacks big bang reforms: Telangana Inc
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

HYDERABAD: The thrust on agriculture, education and healthcare, had Telangana Inc terming the Budget as positive, aspirational and balanced. The industry captains also lauded various initiatives of the FM to put more money in the hands of common people by lowering taxation rates to boost consumption in the economy. However, those hoping for bold moves to kick-start the economic engine were left high and dry.

FICCI president Sangita Reddy said: “Given the constraints, this has been a comprehensive statement. By invoking the deviation clause in FRBM Act and relaxing the fiscal deficit to 3.8% in the current year and targeting 3.5% in the next year, the government has underscored its resolve to support the economy at a time when it needs a fiscal boost.” She said this was FICCI’s key suggestion to the government and through this it expects more money in the hands of the people that will spur consumption and industrial growth. “Much of this money will go towards capital expenditure in infrastructure and agriculture sector — two areas that can have the maximum growth enhancing impact,” she added.

Terming the Budget as balanced, Federation of Telangana Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FTCCI) president, Karunendra S Jasti, said increasing turnover limit from Rs 1 crore to Rs 5 crore for compulsory audit, abolition of Dividend Distribution Tax (DDT) for companies, bringing smaller NBFCs under SARFAESI Act, and reducing the loan size from Rs 1 crore to Rs 50 lakh for applicability of SARFAESI Act, extension of debt restructuring facility for MSMEs till March 2021 and extension of tax holiday for developers of affordable housing by one year, are steps in right direction.

However, Dr Reddy’s Laboratories chairman, Satish Reddy, felt the high expectations of the industry were dashed as the Budget was devoid of any bold reforms given the state of the economy. “I would have liked to see a significant financial incentive to boost exports and improve the competitiveness of the pharma sector. I hope this will take shape with a new export incentive scheme,” he said.

Reddy praised the expansion of Ayushman Bharat programme by setting up additional hospitals in Tier 2 and 3 cities.

Title: New tax demand flips e-seller kart
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo

BENGALURU: Sellers on e-marketplaces may face liquidity squeeze as the government has introduced a new withholding tax on e-commerce transactions. Essentially, companies like Amazon India and Flipkart will withhold an additional 1% tax-deduction-at-source (TDS) while making payments to merchants who sell goods on their platforms . This would be in addition to the GST tax deduction that e-tailers charge online sellers.

While this would not impact consumers in terms of final pricing of products on e-commerce platforms immediately, the new 1% TDS would make sellers work around their working capital arrangements—to buy or source goods to sell online. “The tax at 1% is required to be deducted on the gross amount of such sales or service or both,” says the finance bill. It is not clear if these norms are expected to impact restaurants on online food delivery platforms like Zomato and Swiggy and service professionals on platforms like Urban Company (till recently UrbanClap).

This will not be applicable to those with an annual gross sale of less than Rs 5 lakh, provide their furnish their PAN or Aadhaar to the e-commerce operator. For those over gross sales of over Rs 5 lakh, this TDS would be deducted at 5% if they do not furnish their PAN or Aadhaar number.

“Working capital will be affected due to this. We had supported 1% tax collection under GST despite marketplace opposition and we had recommended application of 1% TDS under the Income Tax Act as inserted today as section 194-O. However, we had also sought relaxation from the technical application of section 194H due to which we have to deduct TDS on marketplace services and claim back from marketplaces. The new provision would be welcome only with the relaxation of existing provisions,” said a spokesperson of All India Online Vendors Association , which represents a group of small online sellers.

While an Amazon India spokesperson said that they are studying the matter, Flipkart declined to comment at the time of going to press.

Title: FM gives mini doses of joy to biotech players
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: The biotech sector had reason to cheer as the Budget had direct and indirect boosters. Be it the thrust on animal vaccines or mapping country’s genetic landscape to encourage discovery of next-generation medicines or even IPR protection and cold chain supply infrastructure, FM injected the right doses.

Biocon CMD Kiran Mazumdar Shaw said, “The announcements related to building a genetic database for drug innovation and investing in quantum computing for advancing our analytical capabilities are critical components for leveraging technology to gain a competitive edge. The measures can give returns in the medium to long-term but we need to ensure they are implemented fast.”

Bharat Biotech CMD Krishna Ella said the big push comes from the thrust on five vaccines – including Foot and Mouth Disease, brucellosis and PPR (goat plague) eradication. The focus on cold chain infrastructure development, which plays a crucial role in ensuring efficacy of vaccines, will also have a positive impact, he said.

Lauding the announcement of two national-level science schemes to create a comprehensive database, Mapmygenome CEO Anu Acharya said that this will lead to availability of quality data for healthcare players and open doors for collaborations and innovation.

Indian Immunologicals Limited deputy MD Prasanna Deshpande said that the proposal to expand the coverage of artificial insemination to 70% from 30% will also assist in increasing livestock productivity and benefit farmers.

However, Ram Kaundinya, director general, Federation of Seed Industry of India (FSII), rued the lack of structural reforms in agri-biotech sector. “While the FM said that they wanted to make the Indian farmer competitive, she did not talk about using modern science and technology in seeds...”

Kaundinya also expressed scepticism about the government’s emphasis on Zero Budget Natural Farming (ZBNF) stating that it cannot take our farmers towards global competitiveness and financial security.

Title: Directives for home isolation issued
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The government has issued directives for home isolation for those who have returned to the state from coronavirus affected places and are under observation.Health minister K K Shailaja said that there are high chances of such people being affected by the virus and those people should stay confined to their houses for a minimum of 28 days. By staying inside their houses, they can rule out any possibilities of infection being spread to others. Such people should ensure that they use a separate room and toilet for their purposes and while interacting with other members of the house, they should maintain a distance of at least one metre, the instructions said. They have also been asked to ensure that no functions are organized in the house and also desist from participating in any other public function.Those confined to the houses should avoid visitors. While sneezing or coughing, they should use handkerchiefs or masks. Periodically, hands should be washed by using soap or sanitizers and should consume lots of water. They also have been asked to inform the control room about their presence in the house. In case of fever, cough, throat infection or breathing difficulties, they should seek medical help after contacting the control rooms.Under no circumstances should they visit the hospital on their own, but should contact the control room and use the vehicle provided from the control room. Any doubts can be allayed by contacting Disha, on the number 0471 2552056. In addition to the control room, a round-the-clock call centre has also been set up in the health directorate. The call centre numbers are 0471 2309250, 2309251 and 2309252. The health minister said that active measures to contain the infection have been launched in all the districts and that there is no room for any kind of scare. The minister urged all to strictly follow the instructions in the larger interest of the society.

Title: Delhi: Artistes come together to ‘protect Constitution’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Artistes and various organisations from across the country took part in the protest at Jantar Mantar.

NEW DELHI: It was an all-out “art attack” on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC) at Jantar Mantar on Saturday. With songs, poems and street plays , artistes raised their voice against CAA and NRC as part of the protest titled “We the people to protect the Constitution.” One of the plays was based on the idea of secular India.

“Artistes have the power to change views and we are here to protect the Constitution,” said one of the protesters. Theatre groups, poets and several other artistes and organisations from across the country took part in the protest. They included Kerala-based Janasmriti, Jana Natya Manch, All Indian Lawyers Union, Delhi Science Forum and Dastak from Delhi University.

Poet and lyricist Hussain Haidry, who recited his poem “Hindustani Musalman,” said that it was necessary for the artistes to speak up. “Art involves image and sound, which can strike a chord with the public,” added Haidry, who is known for his protest poems.

On the importance of protests, the poet said: “Artistes have the capacity to create a counter-narrative against the wrong ideas. They have the power to use sound and visuals to bring about a change. Artists are always the first to be attacked because they have the power to counter.”

Srinivas, member of Janasmriti, said that his group decided to join the protest “as the new laws were against the Constitutional values.” Members of the group sang in chorus about “the need to protect the life for the next generation.”

Title: Centre releases funds for MGNREGA wages
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: After chief minister Ashok Gehlot 's letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi , the Centre on Saturday released Rs 682 crore for the payment of wages to MGNREGA workers.

Earlier, in the last week of January, the Centre had released Rs 195 crore for payment of wages to MGNREGA workers up to November 5.

However, the Centre has not released funds amounting to Rs 1,026 crore for material component yet. The payment of wages to the workers was due since October 2, 2019.

Gehlot had written to the PM requesting him to release funds under NREGA for the payment of wages and material component. The chief minister had pointed out that the due wages of workers have gone up to Rs 848 crore and Rs 1,026 crore was due on account of material component.

“We have received Rs 195 crore on January 22 for payment of wages to workers up to November 5. The remaining due amount, around Rs 700 crore, will also be released in a couple of days,” said state's MGNREGA commissioner P C Kishan.

Title: More gloom than cheer for AP in Budget
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: The Union Budget presented by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in Parliament on Saturday has triggered a political war in the state between the ruling YSR Congress ( YSRC ) and the opposition Telugu Desam Party ( TDP ). While both parties accused the Centre of meting out a raw deal to the state, both parties also accused the other of allowing this to happen.

Former state finance minister and TDP MLC Yanamala Ramakrishnudu blamed the YSRC for the non-allocation of grants to Andhra Pradesh in the Budget. The state government, Yanamala said, has failed on all fronts to ensure budgetary allocations from the central government, and said the state’s policies were to blame for the Centre’s inaction.

Holding chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy responsible for the failure to secure grants, Yanamala said, “In his first meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, Jaganmohan Reddy said that we do not need funds for the capital city. When the state government has asked the Centre to not give funds, why would the Union government allocate funds to the state?”

Yanamala also took note of the YSRC-led government’s decision to cancel Power Purchase Agreements (PPAs), stating that it affected investor sentiment in the state. The chief minister went ahead with the decision even after the Union government warned against the cancellation of PPAs, the embassies of five nations expressed concern and the high court issued a stay order, Yanamala said, adding that the move dented the image of the state.

Investments worth nearly Rs 1 lakh crore have been withdrawn from the state in the last eight months said Yanamala, a result of the state government’s decision to cancel PPAs, stop work on the Polavaram project and the proposal to set up three capital cities. The chief minister should also give an explanation to the people of Andhra Pradesh for claiming to bring in funds and special category status to the state, and then for failing to achieve this, the former minister said.

The demand for special category status has been long-pending in the state and was promised by the former UPA government at the Centre at the time of bifurcation of the state.

Hitting back at Yanamala, finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy said that corruption and mismanagement by the former TDP-led government had placed the state in poor condition, with pending debts amounting to Rs 60,000 crore. Responding to the charge that the YSRC was responsible for the non-allocation of grants to AP in the Union Budget, Rajendranath blamed the TDP for failing to bring pressure on the Union in 2014 in the matter of special category status.

Stating that the TDP compromised the interests of the state for personal and political benefit while in power, Rajendranath said, “They do not have any moral authority to blame the YSRC government, which has only been in power for eight months. Had the TDP acted in the last five years and brought pressure on the Union government for implementation of the promises made during the time of bifurcation of the state, we would not have to start over again.” The TDP, Rajendranath said, compromised on the issue of special category status and accepted a special package instead.

Rajendranath also justified the review of Power Purchase Agreements taken up after the YSRC-led government came to power last year. The government reviewed 41 PPAs in wind power that were entered into without exploring cheaper alternatives and negotiating prices.

Title: Funds cut to affect devpt works: SCB V-P
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Cantonment boards across the country now have an uphill task on the financial front following an allocation of around Rs 382 crore in the 2020-21 Budget for Defence Estates Organisation, a sharp drop from the revised outlay of Rs 497.15 crore in the previous fiscal. The decision attracted sharp criticism from officials of Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) who said the reduction in funds will adversely impact many ongoing projects.

“The budget has been very disappointing. For the past few years, the government has been consistently reducing its allocation for cantonments. This has halted multiple development works in the SCB,” said J Rama Krishna, vice-president of the board. He said: “Earlier, the SCB was a self-sustaining entity. But, now we have to depend heavily on direct government.”

Repairing of roads and the underground drainage system might get stopped, they said. “The water board is willing to increase the supply, but we do not have the infrastructure to receive it. We have been meaning to address this, but the future of that project now hangs in balance,” said another senior board member, P Venkat Rao.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Chinese woman quarantined at Jaipur's SMS Hospital
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Four persons including a 39-year-old Chinese woman, who had reportedly travelled in the same flight with a person who tested positive for novel coronavirus (nCoV) in Kerala, were quarantined at Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital here on Saturday.

The Chinese woman’s friend, who hails from Bharatpur, is among those who have been quarantined in the hospital. Both of them were brought to the city by the health department from Udaipur on Saturday. The Chinese woman, who hails from Nanjing, came to India on January 23 with her friend. Her travel history showed she did not visit Wuhan, the epicentre of the virus outbreak.

“We have taken samples of them and sent them to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, for nCoV test,” Dr DS Meena, SMS Hospital superintendent, said.

A health department official said the Chinese woman’s friend, a 30-year-old man from Bharatpur, had gone to the neighbouring country to learn Mandarin on September 6, 2019 and returned to India on January 23. The Chinese woman accompanied him to India.

The other two admitted to SMS Hospital are a 27-year-old man from Jaipur who recently returned to India from China and was found suffering from symptoms of fever, cough and body ache. The fourth person, also from here, was found suffering from fever, cough, sore throat and breathlessness after he visited Guangzhou and nearby places from January 14 to 22.

Two persons, who were admitted to the hospital earlier with fever, cough and body ache, were discharged after NIV Pune’s report showed that they tested negative for the disease.

Three persons quarantined in Bikaner’s government medical college have also tested negative. The doctors discharged them from the hospital.

Currently, 30 people in the state are under the watch of the health department officials for suspected Corona virus infection. All of them returned from China recently and the health department is monitoring them as a precautionary measure.

The screening of patients at Jaipur airport for nCoV continued on Saturday. “The passengers travelling by international flights have been screened for the disease. So far 2,842 passengers of 19 flights have been screened for nCoV,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health), health department.

Title: Industry unhappy as AP overlooked, again
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: Industry bodies in the state have expressed unhappiness over the Budget for ignoring AP’s interests. They, however, feel the tax cuts proposed by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman may help in reviving the economy to some extent.

“It’s a balanced Budget, which clearly gives impetus to MSMEs and start-ups. Though the fine print is yet to be scrutinised, the reduced income tax rates may stimulate consumption,” Vijay Naidu Galla, chairman of CII-AP, said. Galla also welcomed the proposal to scrap dividend distribution tax, and Sitharaman’s focus on the need to honour contracts signed by the government. “The plan to set up a clearance cell to fast-track investment proposals is a positive step. The Centre’s plan to set up five new smart cities is also a welcome move. The Budget is good on many counts, but it is disappointing that there is nothing in it for the state,” he added.

D Rama Krishna, vice-chairman of CII-AP, said the Centre’s thrust on skills development and the plan to offer internship opportunities to engineers to work on municipal construction projects would help them get an idea of how the government works.

JSRK Prasad, a former chairman of CII-AP, praised the Budget’s focus to double farm income by 2022. According to P Ravi Kiran, chairman of CII’s Vijayawada zone, the removal of dividend distribution tax would encourage big companies to invest in the country.

“We were expecting some major reforms given that the economy has slowed down markedly, inflation has risen and jobs have disappeared instead of being created. The Budget is a disappointment because it has prescribed some cosmetic changes here and there without addressing the structural changes required to revive economic growth engines like real estate, manufacturing and mining,” said Potluri Bhaskara Rao, general secretary of AP Chambers of Commerce & Industry Federation.

“The finance minister has tweaked the income tax rates, and increased the slabs to six from the earlier three. I think the new slabs will only confuse taxpayers more. More importantly, however, it is disappointing that the finance minister did not announce any new spending for AP, which needs industrial investment following its bifurcation in June 2014,” Bhaskara Rao added.

Title: ‘Allocation poor, but Indo-SAT a good move’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Upset with the Centre over poor allocation for education, academics from the city said the money earmarked for the sector is too little given the move to introduce the New Education Policy (NEP). The Rs 99,300 crore,they said, will barely be enough to implement central government schemes like Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan, mid-day meals, information & communication technology at schools among others.

“Last year, the budget for education was increased by Rs 10,000 crore when compared with 2018-19. This year, it has been increased by just Rs 4,446 crore. Leave alone allocating 10% of the budget to education, as suggested by the Kothari Commission in the 1960s, the Centre has given education even less than what it offered last year,” said Chava Ravi, a teacher. Without funds, experts said, implementing NEP would not yield any results in school education.

Academics at prestigious institutes in the state, however, said allowing foreign investments would improve the quality of education. “The private universities can generate money by increasing the intake of foreign students. Now that the Centre has decided to introduce Indo-SAT examination, entrance test for foreign students, especially from Asia and Africa, planning to study in India, only meritorious students will be allowed into the country, which in turn will improve the rating of our institutes,” National Institute of Technology, Warangal, director N V Ramana Rao said.

On internships for engineering students, the academics said it might not have any significant impact on overall employability. “Any company can offer only 5% of workforce as internships. So, offering internships will not have any significant impact,” said Ramesh Loganathan, professor, IIIT-H.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Masks sell like hot cakes in Bengaluru
Content:
The price of clinical masks has doubled due to shortage, say chemists in Bengaluru

BENGALURU: With the coronavirus scare gripping the city, panicky Bengalureans are knocking on the doors of pharmacists seeking to buy masks to prevent being infected. Though no positive cases of coronavirus infection have been seen in the city, chemists confirmed the spike in sale of masks.It may be recalled that the guidelines issued by the Centre, as a preventive measure, mention the usage of handkerchiefs or masks to maintain cough hygiene. In Singapore, which has reported three confirmed cases of coronavirus, the government has decided to issue four masks to every family.Mahesh G, proprietor of Yasho Pharmacy near Residency Road, said the sale of masks in his shop has gone up due to the panic surrounding coronavirus. “Not everyone who buys a mask may be using it the right way. People are just buying masks and keeping them. This is panic buying, which was seen earlier during outbreak of respiratory infections like H1N1,” he said.He added that a month ago he was selling not more than 20-22 masks a day, and over the past three or four days, the number has crossed 200.Masks are available from Rs 5 to Rs 300 a piece. N-95 masks are available at Rs 40 each and are the most sought-after. However, the well-known 3M N-95 masks are unavailable in most shops.Confirming the rampant sale of masks, president of All India Druggists Association’s Bengaluru chapter, MK Mayanna, said the price has doubled for clinical masks. “What was sold at Rs 5 now costs for Rs 10 owing to shortage,” he said.According to Dr Anoop Amarnath, chief of clinical services, Manipal Hospitals, wearing a mask is only one of the precautions to prevent infections. “Importance should also be given to other preventive aspects like washing hands, staying away from an infected person and maintaining cough hygiene,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Chinese woman quarantined at Jaipur's SMS Hospital
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image
