JAIPUR: Four persons including a 39-year-old Chinese woman, who had reportedly travelled in the same flight with a person who tested positive for novel coronavirus (nCoV) in Kerala, were quarantined at Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital here on Saturday.

The Chinese woman’s friend, who hails from Bharatpur, is among those who have been quarantined in the hospital. Both of them were brought to the city by the health department from Udaipur on Saturday. The Chinese woman, who hails from Nanjing, came to India on January 23 with her friend. Her travel history showed she did not visit Wuhan, the epicentre of the virus outbreak.

“We have taken samples of them and sent them to the National Institute of Virology, Pune, for nCoV test,” Dr DS Meena, SMS Hospital superintendent, said.

A health department official said the Chinese woman’s friend, a 30-year-old man from Bharatpur, had gone to the neighbouring country to learn Mandarin on September 6, 2019 and returned to India on January 23. The Chinese woman accompanied him to India.

The other two admitted to SMS Hospital are a 27-year-old man from Jaipur who recently returned to India from China and was found suffering from symptoms of fever, cough and body ache. The fourth person, also from here, was found suffering from fever, cough, sore throat and breathlessness after he visited Guangzhou and nearby places from January 14 to 22.

Two persons, who were admitted to the hospital earlier with fever, cough and body ache, were discharged after NIV Pune’s report showed that they tested negative for the disease.

Three persons quarantined in Bikaner’s government medical college have also tested negative. The doctors discharged them from the hospital.

Currently, 30 people in the state are under the watch of the health department officials for suspected Corona virus infection. All of them returned from China recently and the health department is monitoring them as a precautionary measure.

The screening of patients at Jaipur airport for nCoV continued on Saturday. “The passengers travelling by international flights have been screened for the disease. So far 2,842 passengers of 19 flights have been screened for nCoV,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health), health department.

Title: Birds cold-shoulder Osman Sagar, find haven in Adilabad
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

HYDERABAD: Greater flamingos, the much-awaited avian visitors that migrate to the city during winter, have given Osman Sagar a miss this year. This is the second consecutive year that the birds have given the lake a miss, which is a prime breeding site, leaving birdwatchers and photographers wondering about their migration pattern.

While the formal count will take some time, birdwatchers say that from about 500 birds that used to flock the lake a couple of years ago, the numbers have come down to less than 15 this year.

“There are hardly any flamingos. Usually, greater flamingos land up at the water bodies in this region around November and stay for nearly 4-5 months before flying back to Gujarat, where they come from. This year was disappointing,” said Hari Krishna Adepu of Hyderabad Birding Pals.

While birdwatchers and photographers have been visiting the lake every week since the beginning of the season in the hope to spot some birds, ornithologists have attributed the decline in number to factors such as increase in water levels, lack of food, pollution, climate change and habitat loss.

“There is no specific reason for the decline in the number of migratory birds in natural history. Reasons could vary from local poaching to quality of habitat and climate change. This year, the number of birds is less everywhere. The main reason for a decline in the number of flamingos is increase in water level and scarcity of food,” said Ananda Banerjee, an ornithologist.

When asked if climate change could have an impact on the decline, Banerjee said, “There is some disturbance due to climate change, but we are not in a position to pinpoint just one reason. From a scientific point of view, one must look at several factors including past data. There is never just one factor that can causes a decline.”

Title: Affordable housing sector set to get fresh lease of life
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

JAIPUR: Houses upto Rs 45 lakh including affordable housing will receive a boost in the state after the government’s proposal to extend the tax for new such projects by one more year.

A member of CREDAI, which is the apex body of Private Real Estate Developers ’ Associations said, the union Budget 2020-21 will boost the affordable housing sector by extending the permitted additional deduction of up to Rs 1.5 lakh for interest paid on loans borrowed for the purchase of an affordable house valued up to Rs 45 lakh by one year, i.e. up to March 31, 2021. A CREDAI member said, “There are many ongoing affordable housing projects in Rajasthan . The total tax deduction available on such interest paid stays at Rs 3.5 lakh for one more year, which is expected to positively impact demand in the affordable housing segment.” Many believe this will also give a push to the middle class segment in the state capital as people can buy houses under this range and many new developing areas of the city.

Title: No fresh cases, student stable
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Thrissur: No fresh novel coronavirus (nCoV) infection cases have been reported from the state till Saturday.

Meanwhile, the condition of the student, the first infection case confirmed in the country on Thursday, was also improving and she is under surveillance at the Thrissur Medical College Hospital.

Briefing reporters, health minister K K Shailaja said the test results of two more samples sent earlier have turned out to be negative. Altogether 39 samples were sent for the tests and 24 of them have been received so far. Only one among them has been confirmed positive, the minister said.

The minister said altogether 1,793 people are under observation in the state, 71 of them in isolation wards in different hospitals. They include people who have come in close contact with those who have returned from the coronavirus-infected areas in China. The health officials have so far tracked 69 people who have come in contact with the student who has been tested positive and 39 of them are direct contacts.

The minister said that three persons from Thrissur –– Puzhankaraillath Shafi (35) of Moonupeedika, Ampalath Sirajudeen (37) of Perinjanam and Vadakethara Kunnath Sabari (28) of Pazhayannor –– have been arrested for spreading false news on coronavirus infection and treatment. A case has also been registered against Punaloor resident Aneesh George for spreading fake news through social media.

In all 322 people, who have returned from China, have been put under observation on Saturday.

Experts from the National Institute of Virology, Pune, will soon reach the virology institute at Alappuzha to build up facilities for nCoV test there, she said. The highest number of 268 people under surveillance is in Kozhikode district, while lowest of 24 is in Idukki.

Three discharged from Kozhikode hospitalKozhikode: Out of the five people admitted in isolation wards of the Kozhikode Government Medical College hospital and Beach hospital suspecting coronavirus infection, three of them were discharged today as test results for the three turned negative. The result of the other two is yet to come from Pune based National Institute of Virology (NIV).

Title: Startups get help to take quantum leap
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Jaipur: As an emerging hub for startups, Rajasthan’s entrepreneurs, early stage investors and the ecosystem players said the announcements in the Budget will lend a fillip to innovation and development of new-age technologies.

During her Budget speech, finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman said an eligible startup having turnover up to Rs 25 crore is currently allowed deduction of 100% of its profits for three consecutive assessment years out of seven years. “In order to extend this benefit to larger startups, I propose to increase the turnover limit from existing Rs 25 crore to Rs 100 crore,” she said.

She further said that considering the fact that in the initial years, a startup may not have adequate profit to avail this deduction, I propose to extend the period of eligibility for claim of deduction from the existing seven years to 10 years.

Similarly, she said ESOPs given by startups are taxable as perquisites at the time of exercise. “This leads to cash-flow problem for the employees who do not sell the shares immediately and continue to hold the same for the long-term. In order to give a boost to the startup ecosystem, I propose to ease the burden of taxation on the employees by deferring the tax payment by five years or till they leave the company or when they sell their shares, whichever is earliest.”

Mahavir Sharma, chairman of TiE Global, said that the announcements are expected to deepen the startup ecosystem. “ESOPs will help startups attract talent. At an early stage, these ventures need good talent to do research and development for finding breakthrough technologies. ESOP is a significant component of compensation for these employees and they should not come with strings attached. The Budget proposals have come in right time.”

Quantum technology is opening up new frontiers in computing, communications, cyber security with wide-spread applications. It is expected that lots of commercial applications would emerge from theoretical constructs which are developing in this area.

To harness the potential, the finance minister proposed to provide an outlay of Rs 8,000 crore over a period five years for the National Mission on Quantum Technologies and Applications.

Sharma said, “Technology is the future and will drive global economy. To remain ahead of the curve, we need to develop new technologies. In that sense, the outlay of Rs 8,000 crore is very apt.”

Title: Solar pumps to light up farmers’ fortunes in Rajasthan
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Solar pumps have emerged as a key tool for the government to achieve its ambition of doubling farmers’ income ... Read More

JAIPUR: Solar pumps have emerged as a key tool for the government to achieve its ambition of doubling farmers ’ income by 2022. Rajasthan is one of the few states to have taken a lead in popularizing solar pumps at a mass scale in rural areas and the Budget announcement is likely to add further impetus.

In the Budget speech, the finance minister said the PM-Kusum scheme removed farmers’ dependence on diesel and kerosene and linked pump sets to solar energy.

“Now, I propose to expand the scheme to provide 20 lakh farmers for setting up stand-alone solar pumps; further we shall also help another 15 lakh farmers solarise their grid-connected pump sets,” she said in her speech.

In addition, the government also proposed a scheme to enable farmers to set up solar power generation capacity on their fallow or barren lands and to sell it to the grid, would be operationalized.

The Kusum scheme is implanted by the energy department in Rajasthan and has set a tariff of Rs 3.14 per unit at which the department will buy power from farmers or investors.

But the solar industry in the state said that the tariff is lucrative and the government needs to increase the rates to attract farmers or investors to the scheme.

Sunil Bansal, general secretary of Rajasthan Solar Association said, “To make the scheme a success, the rates need to be improved. Drawing parallel with tariffs for large projects with Kusum schemes is not logical. The maintenance cost for small projects is much higher than large projects. We expect the government to factor in the differences and set a rate accordingly. Because at Rs 3.14, the return on investment is not even 10%.”

The Ministry of New and Renewable Energy , which is implementing the scheme nationally, also provides 40 paise as subsidy which means the cost of power to discoms comes to Rs 2.66 per unit.

Title: Journo's death: Crime branch charges Kerala IAS officer with drunk driving
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The accident pertaining to the case took place on the early hours of August 3.

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Two days after the government extended his suspension period, IAS officer Sriram Venkitaraman received another setback on Saturday with the crime branch submitting a chargesheet against him in the case pertaining to the death of journalist K M Basheer . The crime branch have charged Sriram with culpable homicide not amounting to murder, driving under the influence of alcohol, destruction of public property and destruction of evidence.

The crime branch has also arraigned Sriram’s friend Wafa Firoze as the second accused in the case, charging her with the offence of abetment of crime. Sriram was driving Wafa’s car with her on the passenger seat when he rammed Basheer’s motorcycle in front of Public Works office here, killing him instantly.

The chargesheet was filed by crime branch Superintendent A Shanavas before judicial first class magistrate - III here. The investigation officer has listed around 100 witnesses, 70 material objects and 80 documents as evidence.

The accident pertaining to the case took place on the early hours of August 3. The case is that Sriram, while returning from a party in an inebriated state, forcefully took the wheel from Wafa and drove the car at a high speed, eventually causing the accident. The accident occurred barely 200 meters away from Museum police station.

Sources in the investigation team said that Sriram was charged with the offence of drunk driving based on witness accounts, including people who stopped at the accident spot and the government doctor who noted the smell of alcohol when Sriram was taken to General Hospital soon after the accident. He got himself admitted to a private hospital in the city and refused to give blood sample for blood test, causing half-a-day’s delay in finally carrying out the procedure and the test result turned out negative.

The sections pertaining to destruction of evidence was invoked as the investigation team found out that there was a clear attempt from the part of Sriram to evade legal action, especially when Wafa turned up before the local police claiming that it was she who was driving the car. The sections under Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act was invoked as Sriram allegedly damaged the periphery wall of the Public Works office as well as a heritage lamp on the pavement of the road by crashing the car.

Recently, Sriram, who is under suspension due to pending inquiry, had requested the government to revoke his suspension citing the delay in completion of the investigation. However, the government rejected it and extended the suspension to three more months.

Title: Alwar villagers stage protestagainst proposed isolation ward
Content:
Villagers protest against the proposed isolation-cum-observation centre in Alwar on Saturday

ALWAR/AJMER: Villagers have started protesting against the Centre’s decision of setting up a 250-bed isolation-cum-observation centre in Alwar for Indians who are scheduled to be airlifted from coronavirus-hit Wuhan city.Even labour minister Tikaram Juli has expressed anger on the Centre’s decision of setting up an isolation centre at the Employees State Insurance Corporation (ESIC) Medical College Hospital . He said it was not a ‘fodder land’ where infected people will be brought for treatment.He said though more than Rs 1,000 crore had been spent on the ESIC medical college, it was still not functional. He added the Centre was planning to bring infected people here which would enhance the chances of spread of infection. He said the Centre should first make the medical college functional and only after that it can bring patients for treatment.The villagers are expressing their resentment said the hospital has been lying almost defunct for the past six years. They pointed out that on what basis the Centre was planning to conduct monitoring of patients here.However, a 25-year-old Coronavirus suspect from Kishangarh was admitted to JLN Hospital here on Saturday afternoon. Doctors said the suspect was living in China from last one-and-a-half years and now returned to his hometown. He was suffering from cold and fever and as a precautionary measure he was admitted to JLN Hospital in Ajmer. Doctors collected his blood samples to for nCoV test.As the news spread, there was panic in the locality but doctors said it was the routine check-up and they were following the directions. The suspect patient was then kept in an isolation ward of of JLN Hospital where doctors said sample of blood has been sent for verification.Chief Medical and health officer KK Soni said the suspect was having normal symptoms of cold and fever but since he came from China, they were following the advisory.

Title: ‘Prepaid smart meters too ambitious’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

JAIPUR: As finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman , while presenting the Union Budget on Saturday, urged all the states and union territories to replace conventional energy meters with prepaid smart meters in the next three years, a senior government official termed it as an ambitious plan.

“The state has already started installing smart meters, but it appears to be an ambitious plan considering the shortage of manufacturing capacity in the country. It requires behavioural change among consumers to install prepaid meters,” said Peeyush Samariya , managing director, Rajasthan Urja Vikas Nigam Limited, Jaipur. Stating that installing smart meters in all households in the next three years is difficult, Samariya said, “Let us see...only if manufacturing and supply is available and if the Centre is ready to support us financially. But it is not possible to implement the project if the burden is solely on Discoms.” While presenting Budget, the FM said, taking electricity to every household has been a major achievement. However, the distribution sector is under financial stress.

Title: No Rajasthan ‘iconic’ site in fab five
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Union Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman arrives at Parliament to present the Union Budget 2020-21 in the Lok... Read More

JAIPUR: Despite having about a dozen world-renowned archaeological sites, none of them figured in the list of five announced by finance minister Nirmala Sithraman to develop iconic sites in the country.

During her Budget speech, Sitharaman named Rakhigarhi (Haryana), Hastinapur (Uttar Pradesh), Shivsagar (Assam), Dholavira (Gujarat) and Adichanallur (Tamil Nadu) which would be turned around as iconic sites with on-site museums.

Disappointed that none of the sites from Rajasthan like Kalibangan, a major provincial capital of the Indus Valley civilization, found the favour, people engaged in the tourism industry said that politics plays part in such decisions.

“When you don’t have your party running the government at the Centre, it is obvious that your state’s interests may not get the same weight,” said a tour operator.

The finance minister said that she expects the state governments to develop a roadmap for certain identified destinations and formulate financial plans during 2021 against which specified grants will be made available to the states in 2020-21.

But there are three proposals for developing three tourist circuits which have been submitted to the Union tourism ministry but till now, none of the projects have been sanctioned.

“Three plans for ecotourism, desert tourism and tribal tourism have been submitted to the Centre around two-and-a-half-year ago. Each proposal has estimated a budget of Rs 100 crore. But none has been sanctioned so far,” said an official at the state tourism department.

The finance minister said that for purpose of tourism promotion, she has proposed to allocate Rs 2,500 crore for 2020-21.

Title: More funds for education as 3 varsities allocated Rs 119cr
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Newly-founded state varsities, Central University of Andhra Pradesh and Central Tribal University of Andhra Pradesh, received a budgetary support of Rs 60 crore and Rs 27 crore respectively in the Union Budget 2020-21.

The Indian Institute of Petroleum and Energy ( IIPE ), Visakhapatnam, established under the ministry of petroleum and natural gas, has been allocated Rs 32 crore.

Speaking to STOI, director of IIPE, Prof VSRK Prasad, said the allocation is low compared to the institute’s expectations. “However, we are hopeful of getting more funds in the revised budget proposals. We have so far got budgetary support of about Rs 95 crore. We are also trying to be a part of the ministry of human resource and development’s (MHRD) Higher Education Financing Agency ( HEFA ),” Prof Prasad said.

Other premier educational institutes in the state, such as Indian Institute of Technology-Tirupati, Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam, National Institute of Technology-Tadepalligudem, Indian Institute of Science, Education and Research-Tirupati and Indian Institute of Information Technology-Sri City, drew a blank. These institutes are part of the MHRD’s HEFA, for which allocations in Saturday’s Budget were merged under the heads ‘support to Indian Institutes of Technology’ and ‘support to Indian Institutes of Management’.

Under HEFA, the institution can draw any amount from funds sanctioned to it upon submitting utilisation certificates. The agency is a joint venture between MHRD and Canara Bank and finances the creation of capital assets in premier educational institutions. It leverages funds from the market to finance infrastructure and supplements it with donations and CSR funds.

The Budget has also proposed introducing full-fledged online degree programmes to be offered only by institutions ranked below 100 in the National Institutional Ranking Framework (NIRF).

In her Budget speech, Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman said initially only a few institutions will offer online degree programmes. Andhra University, Vizag and Sri Venkateswara University, Tirupati will be eligible to offer online courses with NIRF ranks of 29 and 72, respectively, in 2019.

Title: NMC action against 40 illegal vegetable markets
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: Following directives of mayor Sandip Joshi and municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) probably for the first time initiated action against 40 unauthorized vegetable markets. Around 2,500 vegetable and fruits vendors selling products outside designated market places were removed.

However, NMC teams returned without taking action from Chor Bazaar in front of Empress Mall and the weekly vegetable market at Mominpura.

NMC will continue the drive from Sunday morning as many unauthorized vegetable markets come up on the roads on Sundays.

Following the policy framed by Joshi for stringent action against encroachments on roads and footpaths, Mundhe on Friday directed NMC’s enforcement, market, health departments and zone offices to ensure no unauthorized vegetable markets and vendors remain on the roads. Accordingly, the drive was launched in all ten zones from 7am on Saturday.

NMC teams did not allow vegetable markets to be set up at many locations, including Gokulpeth, Kelibag Road, Pardi, Rameshwari, Gandhisagar Lake, Uday Nagar, Manewada etc.

Action was taken against vegetable and fruit vendors at Pratap Nagar Square, Mate Square, Trimurti Nagar, Jaitala, Gopal Nagar, Ashirwad Chowk, Manewada, Cotton Market, Ramna Maroti, Mhalgi Nagar, Kamal Chowk, Kabir Nagar, Taj Nagar, Char Khamba Square, Gittikhadan, Gorewada, Itarsi Puliya, Mahal Budhwaar Bazaar, Ayachit Mandir, Hiwri Nagar, Nikalas Mandir, Amardeep Talkies, Bagdiya Chowk, Teen Nal Chowk, Marwadi Chowk, Zade Chowk, HB Town, Jaripatka, Chhaoni, Katol Road, Mankapur, Bharat Chowk etc.

Joshi and Mundhe have taken the decision as unauthorized vegetable markets and vendors create congestion on roads and also cause unhygienic condition by dumping waste. Apart from encroachment on roads, vehicles coming to these markets and vendors also block a major chunk of roads.

Unfortunately, vendors at Chor Bazaar and weekly market at Mominpura Bakri Mandi protested the drive and managed to force NMC teams to return without taking any action.

NMC teams from enforcement department and Dhantoli zone sought police personnel for the drive at Chor Bazaar. Similarly, NMC enforcement department and Gandhibagh zone asked for police protection for action at Mominpura Bakri Mandi vegetable market. NMC officials said police personnel were not provided, forcing the teams to return. “NMC teams conducted the drive at other locations without police personnel. Police should cooperate with the drive as it is meant to ease traffic congestion and welfare of the city,” officials said.

NMC’s Nuisance Detection Squad also recovered penalty from vendors for creating unhygienic conditions.

Title: Big thrust on MSMEs to keep economy rolling
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Jaipur: Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises ( MSMEs ), the mainstay of Rajasthan’s industry, won the attention of finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, who made a slew of announcements for the sector in the Union Budget, saying they are vital to keep the wheels of economy moving.

Sitharaman said amendments to the Factor Regulation Act 2011 will be made to enable NBFCs to extend invoice financing to the MSMEs through TReDS, thereby enhancing their economic and financial sustainability.

Reacting to the announcement, former chairman of CII-Rajasthan Dillip Baid said, “Given the current tight liquidity condition, the move will provide new windows to the MSMEs to secure working capital. NBFCs will be another option before them besides the banks.”

Similarly, the finance minister also proposed to introduce a scheme to provide subordinate debt for entrepreneurs of MSMEs. “This subordinate debt to be provided by banks would count as quasi-equity and would be fully guaranteed through the Credit Guarantee Trust for Medium and Small Entrepreneurs (CGTMSE). The corpus of the CGTMSE would accordingly be augmented by the government,” said Sitharaman in her Budget speech. Extension of debt restructuring scheme was another demand of the MSMEs. The FM obliged them by proposing to more than five lakh MSMEs have benefitted from restructuring of debt permitted by RBI in the last year extending this window till March 31, 2021.

Suresh Agarwal, president of FORTI, who had urged the government for the extension of the window by a year in his recommendations prior to the budget, said, “This will save many MSMEs from being classified as NPAs.”

Sitharaman’s proposal to raise the turnover threshold for audit from the existing Rs 1 crore to Rs 5 crore though got thumbs up, the rider that companies who carry out less than 5% of their business through cash transactions would be eligible dampened the enthusiasm.

Proposals like launching of an app-based invoice financing loans product to cut delays, and raising customs duty on items like footwear and furniture. But Baid said that the decisions to adopt a taxpayers’ charter will remove a lot of mistrust that exists between the businesses and the tax authorities. The government will notify details of the contents of the charter soon.

Title: Will Budget boost air connect to smaller cities?
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Union government’s proposal to start 100 new airports under its UDAN regional connectivity scheme could prove to be a boon for small airports like Visakhapatnam, Rajahmundry and Vijayawada.

Aviation experts feel the main focus now will be on developing the smaller airports, which will lead to increase in number of flights from non-metro cities across the country. “A hundred new airports in smaller cities across the country mean at least 500 to 600 new flights. A better part of these flights would actually connect only the non-metro cities,” said an aviation expert in the city, who works with a private airline.

As of now, AP has four operational airports — Vijayawada, Visakhapatnam, Tirupati and Rajahmundry — all of which suffer from withdrawal of flights by different airlines. In the last two years, Visakhapatnam airport saw the withdrawal as many as 10-12 flights, including three international ones.

“There would be two advantages if the government seriously focuses on the smaller airports. First, the number of flights will go up. Second, competition would increase quality of on-board services even in non-metro sectors and would also make airfare competitive,” opined Joydeep Mukherjee, an international travel expert who has drafted the tourism policy for a few countries.

However, he warned that the government should be careful about selecting the cities and towns for the new airports, otherwise it might not prove to be lucrative for flight operators. “Selections should be made as per demand and infrastructure, and the airports should spread across all states and union territories,” added Mukherjee.

Title: New regime leaves income taxpayers puzzled in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: The new optional tax regime with additional tax slabs and reduced taxes has left taxpayers confused at large in Jaipur.

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced the new slabs and reduced tax in each slab along with an option to choose the existing tax regime left the taxpayers either calling their CA’s or making calculations on their own. The new regime doesn’t support any deductions and exemptions while the old does. Many have started making calculations to see which one saves them extra money.

City-based Shailendra Agarwal told STOI that every taxpayer has to make several calculations and pre-empt their financial decisions to come close to finalise either of the regime. “Those who don’t have any major deductions and exemptions like house rent allowance, mediclaim, LIC and other deductions, can opt for the new regime. While those who have several deductions can go with the old regime,” Agarwal said.

He added that it is premature to say which one one is good or bad for individuals. “Until you make the calculations, nobody will come to the conclusion which can save you more money,” he added.

The tax proposal says that those earning between Rs 5 lakh and Rs 7.5 lakh will have to pay 10% tax and no deductions and exemptions while in the earlier tax regime it is 20% with deductions and exemptions. The taxpayers can choose either of them.

Samir Babel, an owner of an event management company, said most of the companies facilitate their employees in filing their tax returns and it is likely that they will pass the additional burden on them. “I have already asked my accountant to follow up with our employees as to which regime will help make more savings. So far, what I have understood that by and large majority of the taxpayers will go with the existing tax regime which is very convenient and easy,” Babel said.

Title: Rajasthan: 16-year-old killed as drunkard randomly fires in Karauli district
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

JAIPUR: A 16-year-old boy was killed after being accidentally fired at by a drunk man in Karauli. According to police, the accused has a criminal record and would randomly fire in air but this time the bullet hit the teenager, who was standing on the roadside after leaving his animals in the forest area for grazing. The accused is yet to be arrested.

The deceased was identified as Teja Ram, who hailed from Langra in Karauli.

Dinesh Chand, SHO, Langra police station said, “The accused, Ramveer Gujjar, is a known criminal and in the past also, he had fired in air multiple times. On Saturday morning, he was drunk and carrying his weapon. Teja Ram came there after leaving his animals in the forest when Gujjar fired from his weapon and the bullet hit the boy, who died on the spot.”

The accused is absconding and cops are trying to find him. The SHO added, “We are trying to find the accused and check his old hideouts. We are getting in touch with his known accomplices to see if they know about his location. Our team is looking at various locations. We also have witnesses who saw the accused firing and will question them further in the case. They can tell where Gujjar went.”

According to cops, Gujjar has a long criminal history including dacoity and the villagers told police that Teja Ram died after the accused fired senselessly with a country-made firearm. “The villagers told us that the accused kept brandishing his weapon for a while before firing in a haphazard manner. He probably did not even realise that the teenager was standing in the line of fire,” added the official.

The victim’s post-mortem was done on Saturday and the body was handed over to the family and a case registered under relevant IPC sections.

Title: Expert: Get rid of fad diets, concentrate on taking healthy food
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: Healthy food habits, nutritious and balanced diet alone can help people lose weight and not the fads many of them indulge in, said Dr Varsha, found chair of Indian Institute of Nutritional Sciences on Saturday..

She was speaking on ‘Weight reduction- nutrient myths’ at XVII annual scientific conclave, organized by the Nagpur chapter of Nutrition Society of India at the department of pharmaceutical sciences of Nagpur University.

People often believe that diets like Keto, Atkins, vegan and Paleo will help lose weight. Even the brand of diet control Dr Dixit and Divekar promote will not work in the long run, claimed Dr Varsha, a dietitian.

“Losing weight is not the linear process. It’s a long-term process full of fluctuations. Body composition keeps changing and weight management is all about coping with these changes,” she said.

Fad diets are unhealthy ways of losing weight. Indians should concentrate on traditional food rather than the ones based pm calories, Dr Varsha said. “What is the point of eating corn flex in breakfast when we already have better option like rice flex (poha) in our kitchens since generations? Indians have their own body types, metabolism and we should not apply western parameters for the purpose,” she said.

Earlier, pro vice-chancellor of Maharashtra University of Health Sciences (MUHS) Dr Mohan Khamgaonkar inaugurated the event. Dr A Laxmaiah, scientist ‘G’ and head, public health, NIN-ICMR, delivered a keynote address. Talks on nutrition related subjects, poster and oral paper presentations also marked the daylong event.

Title: Coronavirus scare: China-returned MBBS student prefers prayers, officials raise point of law
Content:
Representative image

THRISSUR: Health department officials here had to remind a China-returned MBBS student a legal provision to make her shift to a hospital from home.The 23-year-old woman, who returned from China where she has been studying, was found running mild temperature, but preferred prayers to medical treatment—based on her religious belief—to cure her condition.The young woman preferred staying home even after another student from the district had tested positive for novel coronavirus. She refused to follow the medical protocol, and did not report to health officials.Officials tracking those who had returned from China, found the woman missing. When contacted over the phone, she refused to follow the protocol, but expressed confidence in prayers to keep her safe.The officials rushed to her home in the city corporation limits. Meanwhile, a new-generation bank where her mother has been working, sent the older woman home on knowing of her daughter’s condition.Officials said the student and her family relented after about three hours of counselling and persuasion on Friday. During the counselling, officials reminded her of the legal provision that could lead to her arrest if she still rejected the protocol.“Anyone refusing treatment can be arrested under the provisions of the disaster management mitigation,” district collector S Shanavas said on Saturday. Section 269 of the Indian Penal Code also envisages imprisonment to those who “unlawfully or negligently does any act which is, and which he knows or has reason to believe to be, likely to spread the infection of any disease dangerous to life, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine, or with both.”Agriculture minister V S Sunilkumar confirmed the incident: “The student's blood sample was sent for examination on Friday itself after the girl was shifted to the isolation ward of the Thrissur Medical College Hospital.”Her family members have been kept under home quarantine.Dr K P Aravindan of the Kerala Sastra Sahitya Parishad recommended stringent action against those refusing to cooperate.

Title: Rajasthan: Students cheer internship move at urban local bodies
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The Budget proposal of providing internship to fresh engineers in urban local bodies has been rejoiced by the ... Read More

JAIPUR: The Budget proposal of providing internship to fresh engineers in urban local bodies has been rejoiced by the technical education sector in the state. The proposal is like extending a silver leaf to the struggling technical education institutes in the state which are closing one after another. The proposal says that internship period will be for a year came at a time when campus placements are at an all-time low.

“I am delighted with the Budget proposal. First of all, internships are not available and secondly, if they are available, only for a month or two. This one-year internship programme will certainly give us the required training and confidence to take up bigger opportunities,” said Chandan Singh, a final-year engineering student.

Puneet Sharma, a technical education expert, feels that this is the most awaited decision taken by the government. “It will be a golden opportunity for the institutes and the students to make the most by taking up internship roles in their local government. It will help them in gaining much required experience which will make them more employable,” said Sharma.

State had once 198 engineering colleges which have reduced to little over 100 at present. Most of these colleges closed down in want of students. The poor quality of education along with poor placements has left very few students to take up engineering in the state.

Rahul Singhi, director of a private university in Jaipur feels that students can innovate and experiment and improve the governance of the local bodies. “The internship programme has to be linked with jobs also. A proper training module has to be made so that students can be trained and prepared for the challenges ahead. I am waiting to read more about the announcement,” said Singhi.

Title: Dividend tax leaves investors in a fix
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Jaipur: Investors dependent on the share market and mutual funds are unhappy with the Budget proposal of making dividend income from shares and mutual funds in the hand of recipient taxable. Many involved in the day-to-day trading of shares and investing in mutual funds in Jaipur said that this move may benefit the companies but will certainly become a deterrent for investments. However, those involved in long-term trading and bigger investments in the stocks believe that it will finally benefit the buyers.

“The dividend earned whatsoever would be added as income and is going to be taxable. Suppose my annual income from salary is Rs 4.75 lakh and if I get a dividend of Rs 35,000 in a financial year by some company, I would come under the taxable slab of Rs 5 lakh to Rs 7.5 lakh,” Mahesh Pareek, a Jaipur-based investor in stock market said.

According to the experts dealing the stock market, the provisions relating to the abolition of DDT will be effective from April 1. However, dividends declared between April 1, 2003, and March 31, 2020, will be subject to DDT under the old regime, while those declared after April 1, 2020, will be excluded.

“I would say it is a good move which is going to benefit both the companies and the shareholder. Abolishing the DDT which was earlier to be paid by the companies will enhance the quantum of dividend to be paid to the shareholder,” said Kapil Nagar, a chartered accountant based in Jaipur.

Others dealing with sale and purchase of shares added this will benefit investors in low tax brackets while those in higher brackets would be affected.

Title: Specific concerns of AP do not find mention in Union Budget
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: Apart from the generic all-India railway initiatives, Andhra Pradesh did not find any specific mention for any infrastructure project in the 2020-21 Union Budget . With the decentralisation of the capital process already underway, a clear message of either deferring or cancelling all the proposed infrastructure development in Amaravati was noticed.

The Union finance minister too avoided mention of anything specific for Andhra Pradesh. Despite several proposals being handed over by Lok Sabha MPs from the state in the past, not a single one seem to have found mention in the budget.

Some of these proposals include improving passenger amenities across different stations, including Waltair division in the upcoming South Coastal Railway (SCoR) zone and train connecting Machilipatnam to Mumbai.

However, some of the measures that will have an impact on the state include solar power on vacant railway land under the National Solar Mission, overall capital expenditure of Rs 1.56 lakh crore for new railway lines, rolling stock, locomotives and electrification projects.

A portion of the Nirbhaya Fund of Rs 267 crore will also be allocated to AP for CCTV coverage and other security measures.

Title: ‘Scribes should express views without fear’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The event was organized on Friday

Nagpur: Babasaheb Ambedkar’s writing bound this country in unity and came to the aid of abolishing discrimination against minorities, said former minister for social justice Rajkumar Badole on Friday. Representation of people from the Bahujan community is important in the present times, he added.

Badole was speaking at the 100th anniversary of ‘Mooknayak’, Ambedkar’s first newspaper, being published. The programme was jointly organized by Yugandhar Creations, Vandana Sangh Deekshabhoomi and Lord Buddha Maitree Sangh to felicitate nearly 50 journalists, from across the country, who follow the principles of Ambedkar that challenge the dominant social problems.

Badole congratulated the awardees and inspired the journalists to be more vocal by quoting the first few lines of Javed Akhtar’s ghazal, “Jo baat kehte darte hai sab, tu woh baat likh. Itni andheri thi na kabhi pehle raat, likh.”

Criticizing the current scenario of journalism, senior journalist SN Vinod said, “100 years ago, Ambedkar wrote about how despair and injustice can be observed when we look in all four directions. We are witnessing the same situation at present. Even though politicians are responsible for it, media is one of the biggest complicities. We, as journalists, have become unreliable and it is shameful for me to admit in the society that I am a journalist.”

He said, “We saw absurd reporting in the recent occurrence in Delhi where a man took out a pistol and shot at people in which a student was injured as the police stood like bystanders. The editor-in-chief of a news channel said he had seen the video closely and that he believed blaming the police was wrong. Another anchor of the same channel said inaction of the police must be investigated. Yet another anchor revealed that the man was a minor. If journalists kneel before the power, we will be untrustworthy.”

Addressing the aspiring journalists, he said, “You will face several obstacles and this line of work will demand several sacrifices. But journalism is a field that requires sanctity.”

In his introductory speech, Bhaiyyaji Khairkar said, “Taking inspiration from Ambedkar’s journalistic values, there are countless newspapers who have been running for many years in the country. The current situation of counter-revolution in the country calls for today’s ‘Mooknayak’. We stand in need of people to speak out and write fearlessly and take the revolution of newspapers forward through Ambedkar’s lens because newspapers is a medium that can guide people on the right path at a time when the Constitution is being ripped apart.”

Present at the programme were journalists Baban Wadke, Gajanan Nimedeo and Babanrao Taywade, among others.

Artistes of Yugandhar Creations presented songs based on Ambedkar’s life. Anil Khobragade, Anil Hirekhan and Akanksha Nagarkar were the singers. The music was composed by Prabhakar Dhakde and Bhupesh Sawai.

Title: Shaheen Bagh & Pakistan tweet: Yogi Adityanath targets CM Arvind Kejriwal at rallies
Content:
Yogi Adityanath at Karawal Nagar

NEW DELHI: UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath , who launched a whirlwind campaign for BJP candidates in Delhi on Saturday, had political temperature soaring with his remark that “Arvind Kejriwal has Pakistan links and thus the Pakistan federal minister is seeking votes for him.” In keeping with his reputation for making no-holds barred speeches, he accused the Kejriwal government of “supplying biryani to the Shaheen Bagh protesters”.Reacting to the allegation, senior AAP functionary Sanjay Singh said, “Yogi should be arrested immediately and questioned to get the information he has about Kejriwal’s Pakistan links.” Singh pointed out that 60 children had died in Gorakhpur, UP, due to lack of oxygen and the UP government appears to be standing with rapists. “I want to advise him to have a grip on his language.”AAP is planning to lodge a complaint with the Election Commission over Yogi’s remarks in which he said Kejriwal has links with Pakistan.Slamming Kejriwal on various fronts, including developmental work, Yogi indirectly accused him of funding the Shaheen Bagh protests. “Those who support terrorists in Kashmir are protesting at Shaheen Bagh,” he said at a public meeting in Rohini. He also accused the Kejriwal government of “opposing” the hanging of the Nirbhaya convicts.A dusty, congested Karawal Nagar chowk — which was converted into a fortress — was overflowing with a crowd restless to get a glimpse of Yogi and hear him. Many had climbed trees, buildings and even signboards for a better view. He was welcomed with loud cheers when he emerged on the dais set up in a corner with his picture as the backdrop.Raking up the call given by Pakistan federal minister Fawad Hussain Chaudhry on Twitter to defeat PM Narendra Modi in the Delhi assembly elections , Yogi said abolition of Article 370 in Jammu & Kashmir was a setback for Pakistan. “Had it not troubled Pakistan, the Pakistan minister would not have sought votes for Kejriwal in the Delhi elections ,” said Yogi.The UP CM addressed four back-to-back rallies in Jahangirpuri, Narela and Rohini assembly constituencies where he focused primarily on Shaheen Bagh. The protests are not against CAA but to oppose India’s emergence as a power centre in the world, he said. “Their (protesters) ancestors divided the country and they are opposed to the fact that now India is becoming Ek Bharat Shreshtha Bharat,” said Yogi.The CM said that people of Delhi need better roads, rapid rail, clean air and water and not Shaheen Bagh. “Only BJP can provide all these because all the funds of the Kejriwal government is spent in funding Shaheen Bagh like protests,” he said.Yogi reminded the crowd that AAP had failed to keep its promise of appointing a Lokpal. He blamed Kejriwal for the smog in Delhi. “He also has breathing difficulties. He goes to Bangalore for treatment. He spends 12 days in a naturopathy centre but plays with the health of the citizens of Delhi,” said Yogi.He said he had found the roads in Karawal Nagar and Mustafabad in a bad condition and slammed Kejriwal over it. He also blamed him for allegedly not releasing funds for the rapid rail project between Delhi and Meerut and not issuing an NOC for construction of an expressway from Delhi to Haridwar. He said that the UP government is working towards making the Ganga clean, but Kejriwal’s indifference made Yamuna poisonous.A group of people sitting near the dais at Narela were heard shouting, ‘Desh ke gaddaron ko, goli maro saalon ko’. Turning to them, Yogi asked them to recognise the power of ballot, not bullet. “Recognize the value of each vote in the election. Ballot not bullet is the biggest strength of democracy. I have come to make an appeal to you to use the ballot,” he said.

Title: ESZ around Mukundara tiger turf opposed
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Jaipur: Enraged with the inclusion of their villages in the eco-sensitive zone (ESZ) of the Mukundara Hills Tiger Reserve (MHTR), residents of four villages staged a protest against the forest administration alleging that they have been ‘cheated’.

After the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change issued a draft notification to declare one-kilometre eco-sensitive zone in many areas around the MHTR, villagers of Morkukala, Morkunj, Darrah and Kalikui have started protesting as this will prohibit all types of construction in their farms.

Devi Shankar, who is spearheading the protest, said, “The forest officials did not consult any villager before including their land in ESZ. If the forest department forcefully include our lands, it will be a violation of our rights.”

The protesters also threatened that if their villages are not excluded from the eco-sensitive zone of the tiger reserve, they will not allow forest officials to enter MHTR. Chief conservator of forests (CCF), wildlife, Kota, Anand Mohan, said, “According to SC guidelines, a 10-kilometre ESZ should be left around a tiger reserve, but we are restricting it to 1/10th. Also, there are certain activities which come under prohibited, regulated and permitted. Villagers can go ahead with construction, but there are vested interests which want to convert MHTR into a concrete jungle. If villagers want to reconstruct their houses, they can do so, and I don’t think ESZ will create any problem.”

On January 10, the ministry had issued a draft notification to declare a 1km eco-sensitive zone around MHTR, which is spread over 759.99sqkm covering four districts of Kota, Bundi, Chittorgarh and Jhalawar. The ministry has sought suggestions and objections within 60 days.

This is the first tiger reserve in the state for which an ESZ will be declared. The MHTR, established in 2013, encompasses areas of Mukundara Hills National Park, Dara Sanctuary, Jawahar Sagar Sanctuary and part of National Chambal Ghariyal Sanctuary (From Garadia Mahadev to Jawahar Sagar Dam) which constitutes its core area.

A senior forest official said the eco-sensitive zones will be treated as a ‘breathing space’ for wildlife. It is demarcated based on their ecological importance which reins in development activities inimical to wildlife and their habitats. While the zone will be completely compatible to livelihoods of local communities living around the tiger reserve, it will bring the order on tourism, mining activities, industries and other footloose development activities disrupting wildlife corridors outside the reserve boundary

Title: Strife on D-Street: Sensex tanks 988 points in biggest Budget Day plunge
Content: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman disappointed Dalal Street investors with her second Budget as she shifted the burden of dividend tax from corporates to recipients that will hurt promoters, didn’t give in to expectations of abolishing long term capital gains tax on equities and raised fiscal deficit targets that is expected to keep rate of interest at an elevated level. As a result, the sensex crashed 988 points__the biggest single-session points drop on a Budget day__to close at 39,736, a three-month closing low. The day’s sharp dive in the market also left investors poorer by Rs 3.5 lakh crore with BSE’s market capitalisation now at Rs 153 lakh crore.In Saturday’s session, HDFC group was hit the sharpest since market players say tough time for financial sector firms if the rate of interest remains sticky. In addition, insurance and mutual fund companies were hit by the FM’s proposal to do away with IT exemptions for individuals in favour of lower income tax rates. HDFC, ITC, ICICI Bank and HDFC Bank contributed the most to the sensex’s slide while higher closing for TCS, HUL and Infosys cushioned the fall marginally.The FM, however, changed some rules which are expected to enthuse foreign funds to invest in India. According to Rashesh Shah, Chairman & CEO, Edelweiss Group, the FM has sent out a very positive signal to foreign investors through exemptions to sovereign wealth funds to invest in infrastructure and the abolition of dividend distribution tax, “to reaffirm their faith in the India growth story.” Institutional dealers too feel that with central banks readying to pump in cash to revive a slowing global economy, FPIs are expected to continue to buy into the India story.On the other side of the spectrum, market’s expectations about strong fiscal and other measures to bring the economy back on track, were not met. “The proposed listing of LIC (the government-owned largest life insurer in India), abolition of dividend distribution tax are positives but markets were hopeful of fiscal measures to kick start the economy and the Budget fell short on this count,” said Raamdeo Agrawal, chairman, Motilal Oswal Financial Services.The day’s selling was across the board with BSE’s midcap and smallcap indices, both closing 2.2% lower. Among the sectoral indices, real estate, capital goods and industrials losing the most with IT and Teck indices closing with marginal gains. The session also recorded a net foreign fund outflow of Rs 1,200 crore while domestic funds were net buyers at just Rs 37 crore, BSE data showed.

Title: Delhi elections: Arvind Kejriwal insulted daughters by making fun of my song, says Manoj Tiwari
Content:
Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari (Left) at Ganesh Nagar

NEW DELHI: A loud cheer greeted Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari when he turned up at a public meeting at Rani Garden on Saturday. Since it was his birthday, a cake had also been ordered to celebrate the occasion.Standing amid BJP flags, Tiwari began his speech by attacking chief minister Arvind Kejriwal for mocking his song “Rinkiya ke Papa”. “AAP is making memes of the song. But they should understand that Rinkiya in the song refers to daughters. By mocking the song, AAP and Kejriwal are demeaning the role of daughters and women in society,” he asserted.Recently, Kejriwal, when asked for his views about the Delhi BJP president, had referred to Tiwari as a “good singer” who had rendered “Rinkiya ke Papa”. “I pity his (Kejriwal’s) intelligence. The girl child ratio is declining. At a time when Beti Bachao is trending in the country, he is mocking men for having daughters. Is it a curse to have a daughter?” Tiwari asked.“The Centre has allocated Rs 40 lakh in each district of all states for investing in welfare projects for the girl child. However, not a penny has been used in Delhi by the AAP government,” said Tiwari.Earlier in the day, Tiwari carried out a padyatra in South Ganesh Nagar. Even as he waved to people in the balconies, many in the crowd rushed to take a selfie with him. Tiwari said that he failed to understand how Kejriwal claimed that the last five years were well spent. “For four and a half years, Delhi government was just cursing the Modi government and lieutenant governor for not letting AAP work. How come everything has become so positive all of a sudden?” he asked.Taking a dig at the Rs 66,000 crore budget of Delhi government, Tiwari said, “Despite such a huge budget, Delhi couldn’t get new flyovers, university, Wi-Fi, quality water, roads, among other things.”

Title: 35% of wetlands across AP already destroyed: PCCF
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: N Prateep Kumar, the state principal chief conservator of forests (PCCF) said on Saturday that around 35 per cent of marshlands across Andhra Pradesh have already been destroyed. Kumar further said that the marshlands have been destroyed predominantly due to pollution.

Speaking at a state-level workshop on wetlands, Kumar said that there are 31 wetlands in the state and that the state forest department will set up district-level committees headed by collectors to chart out required measures to conserve wetlands in the region.

According to Kumar, other reasons for the destruction of wetlands in the region include construction activity and urbanisation.

Some major wetlands in Andhra Pradesh are Koleru, Koringa, Nelapattu, Pulicat and Uppalapadu. A large number of birds from across the world migrate to these areas post-monsoon for nesting and stay till March.

“We want to take each district as a unit. A report will be submitted by the committees to the forest department and we will execute those measures to ensure that these wetlands are protected,” Kumar further said addressing the gathering.

He further informed that the initiative will be launched from February 2—World Marshland Day, which came into being in 1971 during the Forest Convention.

G Khudros, professor of Sakhiyaan Institute in Coimbatore and an expert in marshland conservation attended the event as the chief guest. He spoke about various techniques used across the world to conserve marshlands.

Title: Jan Aushadhi Stores: Old wine in new bottle
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Jaipur: Announcement in the Budget speech of setting up Jan Aushadhi Stores (JAS) in all districts of the country, will not benefit the state much, as almost every district in the state already has JASs under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP).

Except Chittorgarh, all districts of the state have JAS. Jaipur has the highest 18 JAKs (Jan Aushadhi Kendras) in the state. Almost each government hospital in Jaipur has JAKs, where patients get generic medicines at affordable prices. In the state, there are 134 PMBJP.

According to a reply to a question in Lok Sabha, the Centre mentioned that the product basket of PMBJP covers more than 800 medicines and 154 surgicals and consumables covering all therapeutic groups such as anti-infectives, anti-diabetics, cardiovasculars, anti-cancers and gastro-intestinal medicines.

The Centre is planning to strengthen its network of JAS as it is targeting to provide 2,000 medicines and 300 surgical items by 2024 to patients from its JAS network. According to the health department officials, the patients can buy generic medicines at JAS situated at Sawai Man Singh Hospital and Kanwatia Hospital.

In all the 33 districts, the facility of JAS is already available except in Chittorgarh. The announcement by the finance minister of setting up JAS in each district, will help Chittorgarh to get one such shop of generic medicines.

Under the scheme, any NGO, charitable society, institution, self-help group with experience of minimum three years of successful operation in welfare activities, is eligible to open the Jan Aushadhi Store outside the hospital premises.

Title: Ajmer: Senior official joins kids for midday meal
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Additional district collector Suresh Sindhi enjoys a meal with the students of a government school in Shrinaga... Read More

AJMER: The additional district collector (city), who was on an inspection of the midday meal scheme at Government Girls’ Senior Secondary School in Shrinagar, joined the students for lunch and took feedback on the quality of the food served at the school.

Additional district collector Suresh Sindhi asked the principal and teachers of the school to sit with him on the ground during the meal and directed them to ensure that the food served is healthy and fresh.

The school staff members were surprised as senior officials usually don’t taste the midday meal given to students. “It is unusual to see a senior official sitting on the ground with children and having midday meal,” a teacher said. Generally, teachers got to the staffroom during lunch and the other staff members of the school serve food to the students, she added.

Meanwhile, Sindhi asked the school principals to maintain the quality and taste of the food served to the students by the state government and also take regular feedback from students to bring in change. Sindhi said the midday meal that he was served was good and fresh. He added that the attendance of the girl students at the school was also good.

Title: SBI field officer held for Rs 2 crore embezzlement
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: A field officer of State Bank of India ( SBI ) was held by police in Lakhimpur Kheri after an FIR was registered against him by bank authorities for embezzlement of Rs 2 crore.

The accused Sanjeev Yadav was deployed as a field officer in SBI’s Gola branch in Kheri and the issue came to light after an audit by senior officials of SBI from Lucknow. Yadav has allegedly fraudulently increased the credit limit of loan accounts of many local traders and withdrew the money without their knowledge.

Several account holders had made complaints with the branch head in Lucknow about the unwanted increase in their credit limit. Manager of Gola branch Umesh Pandey along with Yadav was suspended by the SBI audit team on Friday while the FIR was registered at Gola police station against Yadav on the complaint of officiating branch manager Gopal Datt Singh. Police and bank officials are trying to check whether Yadav was deployed at the Gola branch since January 2017 and was looking after the overdraft bank accounts which were maintained by the local businessman.

SHO Gola police station DP Tiwari said, “We have arrested field officer of SBI Sanjeev Yadav for overdraft accounts fraud on the complaint of officiating branch manager. Yadav has been sent to jail and we will seek his remand for further investigation.”

Title: Jodhpur man ‘kidnapped’, let off after giving ransom
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

JODHPUR: An electrician was allegedly abducted by some persons and was let off after extorting Rs 8 lakh ransom from him. The victim has lodged an FIR against the main accused and his accomplices.

According to SHO (Mandore) Sitaram Khoja, about a dozen persons have been alleged to be involved in the kidnapping and extortion according to the complainant Amar Singh Sankhla , who runs an electricals’ shop in Mandore area.

Khoja said that according to the complaint, Sankhla was present at his shop on the night of January 29, when one Pawan Solanki and others came to his shop and forced him into their vehicle. “After driving for a distance, they pushed him into another vehicle and thrashed him there. They kept on driving the vehicle around and also took him to an office belonging to one Rajiv Panwar,” alleged the victim.

“At the office, he was beaten up badly by the abductors and staff members of the office and demanded Rs 8 lakh as ransom. He then called a friend Kamlesh Sankhla at the office with Rs 8 lakh and handed the amount to the abductors,” said the complaint, adding that after that he was let off with a threat.

The main accused Pawan Solanki, as mentioned by the complainant, is a person of criminal antecedent and has already served a jail term in 2017. He is currently out on bail.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: RJD’s Tejashwi Yadav to campaign for two days
Content:
Tejashwi Yadav (File Photo)

NEW DELHI: Rashtriya Janata Dal ( RJD ) member Tejashwi Yadav will address two public meetings and participate in two road shows in support of Congress and his party candidates in the Delhi assembly polls Making the announcement at a press conference, RJD spokesperson Manoj Kumar Jha said that Yadav would hold a road show in Palam in southwest Delhi on Sunday, while a joint public meeting of RJD-Congress candidates would be held at west Delhi’s Vikaspuri on Monday.Congress and RJD have forged an alliance for the first time for the Delhi assembly polls. While Congress is contesting 66 seats, it has left the remaining four — Palam, Burari, Kirari and Uttam Nagar — for the Bihar party.Delhi Congress chief Subahsh Chopra said the decision to join hands with RJD was taken keeping in mind the huge chunk of Poorvanchali voters in the city who have affinity for RJD.Meanwhile, Balmiki Temple priest Chinna Maharaj, who claimed that Kejriwal had referred to him as his guru, joined Congress on Saturday. He alleged that Kejriwal did nothing for people of Panchkuian Balmiki Basti in last six years. AAP didn’t react to the allegation.

Title: Budget does little to boost rural economy, says AP farmers’ body
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The All India Kisan Sangharsh Coordination Committee ( AIKSCC ) based out of Andhra Pradesh slammed the Union Budget for ‘doing little’ to boost the rural economy .

A statement issued by the farmers ’ organisation said, “The total budget allocation for agriculture, irrigation and rural development was Rs 2.68 lakh crore in 2019-20, which has been increased nominally to Rs 2.83 lakh crore. In real terms, taking inflation into account, this amounts to zero increase.”

The Union Budget proposes increased penetration of MNCs and corporate giants in agriculture inputs supply, procurement of crops, storage, agriculture-processing, insurance and marketing of crops. However, the farmers’ association feels that it gives no relief to peasants from high input costs, low crop prices, distress sale and crop losses.

AIKSCC came down heavily on the Modi government and has said, “We are very disappointed. This is clearly a Budget that has no space for farmers of this country.”

Title: New tax slab creates confusion among salaried class
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bareilly: The new income tax regime unveiled by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in the Union Budget 2020 has perplexed the salaried class, who are now in a dilemma whether to stick with the old slab rate or opt for the new one.

According to the FM, the new tax regime is optional and would require the taxpayers to forego their claims on exemptions and deductions.

Manoj Sharma, director of national informatics centre in Bareilly, said it is good step of giving some relaxation to salaried class, but there is some lack of clarity about the new tax regime.

“I hope things will be clear once we get through the new tax regime in detail. As of now, it is not clear whether we would be able to get benefit on investment in various government schemes under 80 C and 80 D or not. There was no mention of saving related government schemes in the finance minister’s Budget speech,” he said.

Rajen Vidyarthi, a chartered accountant, said, “We now expect more clients to turn up as the new tax regime is bound to create confusion, as people will not be able to differentiate between two tax regimes wisely. In the new tax regime, taxes are reduced but now taxpayer will not be able to get benefits of various investment schemes exempted from taxes under 80 C and 80 D.”

Dr Amanjot Kaur, a teacher in Government Girls Inter College, however, welcomed the new tax rates.

“I welcome the government’s step. I will have 5% additional income, which can be spent on our kids’ education or in saving. Besides, we can use this money for tourism purposes.”

Title: Mutilated body of villager found in PTR’s core area, attack by wild animal suspected
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pilibhit: Field forest force and police have recovered the partially eaten body of a 65-year-old villager in Mala range of Pilibhit Tiger Reserve on Saturday morning. The deceased was identified as Phool Chand of Baijunagar village under Gajraula police station. He went missing after he went to his sugarcane field on Friday afternoon. His family accompanied by forest force personnel found his body around 400 meters deep into the core forest area.

Deputy director of PTR Naveen Khandelwal said forest officials are yet to confirm whether the man had intruded into the core forest area where he was mauled by some wild carnivore or his body was dumped in the jungle by some criminals who killed him and it was eaten by the wild animals.

However, deceased’s nephew, Jeevan Lal claimed that he and other villagers had seen a tigress and two cubs eating the Phool Chand’s body. Police and foresters are awaiting his autopsy report.

Makhan Lal, deceased’s son, alleged that the tigress along with its cubs had been moving about in the agricultural area, adjoining Garha forest beat for a couple of months but the forest officials had not taken any action in the matter. He claimed that his father was killed by the tigress and dragged into the jungle, where it was eaten.

Khandelwal said Phool Chand’s field was about 1km from PTR. But, the forest force could not find any pugmarks of the tigress in the area or signs of the body being dragged. He said the department on humanitarian grounds had arranged for Rs 10,000 through World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) for the bereaved family for performing the last rites. However, the family was not eligible for compensation as the killing had taken place inside the core forest area.

Asked about the murder angle, SHO of Gajraula police station, Naresh Kumar Kashyap, ruled it out, saying that the body’s condition indicated that he was killed by a wild animal.

Title: Health camps to be organized at 71 centres in Bareilly on Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bareilly: The ‘Mukhyamantri Jan Arogya Swasth Mela’ (CM wellness health fair) will be inaugurated on Sunday at 50 primary health centres (PHCs) and 21 urban primary health centres across Bareilly to conduct health checkups. Officials said these health camps will be held on every Sundays with an aim to reach out to villagers.

Officials said four doctors will be present at each centre, which will be functional from 10 am to 2 pm. Officials said all facilities of out-patient department will be available in the health camps and people will get treatment of tuberculosis, malaria, dengue, encephalitis and filaria. Besides, eye and blood tests will be conducted here and an awareness drive on a few diseases will also be conducted.

As PHCs and urban PHCs have only one doctor each, the officials have deployed three more doctors from other centres to treat patients in health camps. Health department has also sought help from AYUSH doctors, private medical colleges and private colleges for paramedical.

Chief medical officer Dr Vineet Shukla said, “Union minister of state for labour and employment Santosh Gangwar and city MLA Dr Arun Kumar will inaugurate wellness fair at urban PHC in Sanjay Nagar. Similarly, MLAs of their respective constituencies will inaugurate centres in their respective areas.”

Title: With no special mention, Union Budget a disappointment for U’khand
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Dehradun: While the measures announced to boost the agri sector and farmers in the Union Budget 2020 were hailed as a welcome move for Uttarakhand, the Himalayan state was left largely disappointed as no special announcement was made for projects in Uttarakhand. Also, there were no fund allocations announced for the Kumbh Mela acheduled to be held in Haridwar in 2021.

Providing a perspective on what the budget meant for Uttarakhand, financial analyst Rajendra Bisht told TOI, “The state will be benefitted from the reforms and changes announced in the agri sector. However, since most farmers are based in Haridwar and Udham Singh Nagar, the benefits will largely be limited to these districts.” He added that the decision to set up solar pumps for 20 lakh farmers and grid-connected pump sets for 15 lakh farmers has a great potential in Uttarakhand.

“Over Rs 2.83 lakh crore would be invested in agriculture, rural development, irrigation and allied activities. This will largely help the state government in achieving its target of doubling the income of farmers,” Bisht said.

He, however, added that more concrete steps in the field of manufacturing could have helped Uttarakhand, which is eyeing to invite more industrialists to the state. “The corridors being made to strengthen infrastructure by spending Rs 103 lakh crore will help the state but more steps are required to boost the manufacturing sector.”

Tourism professionals though were disappointed that even though Uttarakhand is a tourism state, no major project was announced in the sector although the development of North-east and the union territories of J&K and Ladakh had been included in the budget.

Title: Oh crap! Cow dung creates craters on tar road laid a week ago
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The road in Ayodhya Nagar was asphalted just a week ago

Nagpur: The quality of road works done by the Nagpur Municipal Corporation has plunged to a new low. Now, they no longer need heavy rains to develop potholes because it seems even cow dung is enough to damage them.

A road in Ayodhya Nagar under NMC Hanuman Nagar Zone is the best example. The NMC through contractor Amruta Constructions had asphalted three internal roads of length around 300 metres at Ayodhya Nagar at the cost of Rs20 lakh a week ago.

Couple of days back, cattle came on the roads and dumped at several spots. The road’s surface has scaled at spots where the cow dung was dumped. It has become a topic of discussion in the area.

After TOI pointed it out, officials of NMC Hanuman Nagar Zone including assistant commissioner Raju Bhivgade inspected the road and confirmed potholes have developed on spots wherever the cattle had left the dump.

“I am surprised to see the newly asphalted patches damaged due to cow dung. Engineers from NMC public works department (PWD) will be able to comment why this happened. Other parts of the road is in good condition,” Bhivgade said.

NMC chief engineer Ulhas Debadwar said it clearly proves that the quality of asphalting was not good. “We will inspect and initiate appropriate action,” he said.

Inferior quality of tar road are damaged due to rains or heavy traffic. There is not much water content in cow dung, still the road in Ayodhya Nagar was damaged. This indicates that the road will be damaged totally in case of rain.

TOI has many a time reported about inferior quality of works in tar as well as cement concrete roads. Even, asphalting done by NMC Hotmix Department can’t hold on for weeks though the defect liability period is of three years.

TOI had reported about damage to patches asphalted on road at Sonegaon lake within a week due to mild rain in the beginning of January. The department again asphalted the same patches couple of days ago, thus wasting public money.

RTI activist TH Naidu said the cost should be recovered from NMC engineers and contractor. “Engineers are never present when roads are asphalted by contractors. Engineers clear bills sitting in offices. I can name many roads asphalted within one year though their defect liability period was three years. Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe should appoint engineering colleges as third-party agency to inspect roads. Bills should be cleared only after satisfactory report,” he said.

Title: Nagpur: Virendra Kukreja panel wants sanitary workers to work with GPS Watches
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The committee headed by chairman of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) Health Consultative Committee Virendra... Read More

NAGPUR: The committee headed by chairman of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) Health Consultative Committee Virendra Kukreja has taken a decision to restart working of sanitary workers under GPS Watch System. It was abandoned a few months ago following strong opposition from sanitary workers.

Mayor Sandip Joshi has constituted and directed the committee to conduct study and suggest measures related to the abandoned GPS Watch System. Accordingly, the Kukreja-led committee held a meeting on Saturday and directed the NMC health department to repair the watches. The committee is likely to suggest working of sanitary workers with the GPS Watch System.

Corporator Dayashankar Tiwari, Sunil Agrawal , additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi, health officer (sanitation) Dr Pradip Dasarwar and assistant legal officer Prakash Barde were present in the meeting.

To curb the salary scam and ensure cleanliness, the NMC in association with Bengaluru-based ITI Limited, a central government undertaking, launched the GPS Watch System 22 months ago. Under the system, the attendance of workers was to be registered as per the record of GPS Watches. 8,000 workers and some officials were given watches. The NMC was supposed to pay Rs 207 per person per month for a total of Rs 16.56 lakh per month to the company.

After an inordinate delay, the NMC started to release salaries of workers as per the system in June last year. The workers strongly opposed the system and it was put on hold.

Title: Head constable booked for missing case diary in a murder case
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: An FIR has been registered against head constable Hawaldar Singh after a video CD relating to the murder of a priest went missing from the case diary kept in the record room at Bareilly Cantonment police station.

The head priest of Dhopeshwar Nath temple in Bareilly was found murdered on February 14, 2010. The investigation of the case has now been given to CBCID (Crime branch crime investigation department). However, the sleuths could not find the CD deposited in the record room of the police station in 2014. Hawaldar Singh was the file keeper at that time. He has now been booked for the missing evidence.

Giving details about the complaint, additional SP (crime) RK Bhartiya told TOI, “The case is a high profile one case and the video evidence containing the autopsy details went missing. The responsibility of every item lies with the file keeper and we have filed an FIR against him and an unidentified person under IPC section 409 (criminal breach of trust by a government servant). The missing video CD is of such an important case clearly displays negligence was displayed by the file keeper. The investigation of this complaint has been handed over to sub-inspector Yogesh Kumar Yadav .”

Title: Farm activists back move to adopt three central model laws for states
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: Farm activists have backed finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s move of encouraging states to adopt three central model laws for farmland leasing, contract farming and agriculture produce marketing.

There is a view that due to shrinking farm holdings, there is a need for the state to have laws facilitating land leasing and contract farming, so that economic viability of agriculture increases.
