Sitharaman said the government will encourage states to implement the three model laws already framed by the Centre, namely the Model Agricultural Land Leasing Act , 2016, Model Agricultural Produce and Livestock Marketing (Promotion and Facilitation) Act, 2017, and Model Agricultural Produce and Livestock Contract Farming and Services (Promotion and Facilitation) Act, 2018.

Sources in the state’s bureaucracy said a law along the lines of the Model Agricultural Produce and Livestock Marketing (Promotion and Facilitation) Act, 2017 was moved in the state legislature by the previous government. However, it was withdrawn from the legislative council following objections by certain large agriculture produce-marketing committees (APMCs) operating in the state.

Now there are plans to put up the case before the current government once again, said an official. The law calls for reforms in APMCs, which control the farm produce market.

“The state has not passed any law on leasing or contract farming in line with the Centre’s model acts, said Kishore Tiwari, chairman of Vasantrao Naik Shetkari Swavalamban Mission (VNSSM), the state government thinktank on agriculture crisis mitigation.

“The reforms are needed so that contract farming and leasing of land is facilitated. Shrinking holdings have made it difficult to reap profits out of individual farming. However, it is also discouraging that the Budget speech did not have any mention of priority sector lending or funding the states for granting bailout packages to farmers. Loan waivers by eight states prove that agriculture is no longer a profitable business,” Tiwari added.

Anil Ghanawat, the president of Shetkari Sangathana said that contract farming can help the farmers get a fixed income and assured market. “The firm taking land on contractual basis can directly sell the produce to the end user, which in turn can assure returns for the grower,” Ghanawat stated.

“Informal contract farming is already prevalent in the state. Due to shortage of holdings, the farmers lease land to increase the area under cultivation. Having a law will also secure the tenants’ rights. It should also be ensured that any bailout package announced by the government should go to the leaseholder instead of the land owner,” said Vijay Jawandhia, a veteran farm activist from Wardha.

Title: Budget gets thumbs up from Indian Industries Association
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bareilly: Members of the Indian Industries Association (IIA) applauded Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman for presetting a “budget which reflected Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s economic vision”.

Speaking to TOI, national vice-president of IIA, Suresh Sundrani, said the government’s decision to increase custom duty on imported goods would strengthen the micro small and medium enterprises (MSME).

“Moral of the Union Budget 2020 is that people who earn more should contribute more. The government has tried to put more money into the hands of the middle class which is good for the industry as well as economy. However the budget allocation of Rs 3 lakh crore for skill development is not enough, considering the size of our population. Also introducing training programmed for engineering graduate is a good concept,” Sundrani said.,” Sundrani said.

One of the renewed industrialists in Rohilkhand region and owner of a mustard oil production company, Ghanshyam Khandelwal, said, “By reducing the corporate tax for solar energy industry from 22% to 15% clearly reflects the PM’s vision of moving towards green energy from coal-based industry.”

Ashutosh Sharma, a young entrepreneur who runs a soya food unit, said the government should have thought about the social security for industrialissts, which he found missing in the budget.

“A businessman works tirelessly throughout his life, but sometimes a single mistake proves lethal to shut down the unit. If it happens at the age of 55 or 60, it becomes very difficult to overcome that situation. For the taxpayers like us there must be a provision that the government provide at least medical security to the businessman, who becomes insolvent for any reason.”

Another IIA official, RK Goel, said the increased custom duty on furniture would benefit local industry in Bareilly to a large extent.

“Bareilly is largely known for embroidery work and furniture industries. Bareilly’s cane made furniture has been in demand across the country, but for the past couple of years, Chinese low cost furniture have made a big dent on this industry. Now, with increased custom duty on imported furniture, local furniture industries will get strengthened for sure.”

Meanwhile, Ajay Shukla, president of Bhojipura industrial area who runs a packaging unit termed the Union Budget 2020 as “eyewash”.

“The FM didn’t give any relief to the MSME section, which is already on the ventilator. There is already a slump in sale. The government should have given some exemption in GST,” Shula said.

Title: Budget 2020 has nothing for us, says Moradabad’s renowned brass industry
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bareilly: The Union Budget 2020 which was presented by Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday has nothing much for us, said exporters at Moradabad’s renowned brass industry. The Union finance minister has increased custom duty on imports but they are export-based and the metal they use largely come from local markets, the exporters said.

Besides, they are disappointed with GST due to which their 18% working capital is stuck for the past six months. The brass industry demands relaxation in GST on local purchase of metal for their survival.

The annual turnover of Moradabad brass industry is around Rs 15,000 crore among which a large portion of Rs 10,000 crore comes from export. According to Moradabad Handicraft Export Association, close to 3,500 exporters are running their units in the district and 5 lakh artisans are associated with it.

Association president, Avdhesh Agrawal, said that Budget 2020 was highly disappointing for the brass handicraft exporters of Moradabad. “Until 1999, there was no tax on export. But now, we are paying 18% GST. Claiming that duty drawback is cumbersome process. We purchases raw material either from copper and brass industries or from local markets. We are ready to pay tax on metal purchased from industry, but our only demand is that there must be relaxation while buying raw material from furnaces running locally,” he said.

Another exporter, Sarfaraz Akhtar, said that the buyers didn’t pay them money in advance and GST returns come after several months. “Earlier, our export was higher in multifold than local supply but today both are almost at par, which is not good for the industry. In local market, there are few customers for quality products. We used to get a decent amount of foreign orders for quality products. Today, we have very little working capital for doing business. If the government extends some incentives to our industry, only then we would be able to survive,” he said.

Association patron Najam ul Islam told TOI, “It is not an encouraging Budget for us. Our only demand was to ease GST provisions as 18% of our working capital is stuck for several months. Besides, it would be nice if government continues 7% licence incentive on export after March 31.”

Title: Exam hall ticket protest outside Old City college
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

CHARMINAR: Many BEd students protested outside Hidayah Junior College , in Muradnagar , under Asif Nagar police station limits, on Saturday, alleging that the management didn’t issue them hall tickets for the first semester exam.

The students said that when they reached the college to appear for their first semester exam, scheduled for Saturday, officials asked them to leave because the college had not yet received the exam’s hall tickets. Instead, the students alleged, the management asked them to start preparing for their second semester exam.

Students said that though they had cleared their fees and were ready to appear for the exam, almost 66 of them were not allowed entry. “This happened due to the apathy of the college authorities. The college authorities said that they couldn’t issue us hall tickets because they were not granted permission by the university. Though they assured us that we would be allowed for the next semester exam, their apathy and carelessness have hurt out sentiments,” said Mehtab, one of the agitated students.

College authorities claimed that the late admission process had caused the problem. “We assured the students that they would be allowed to write their exam in the second semester,” said Riyazuddin , director of Hidayah Junior College.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: One-fifth of poll candidates have been booked in criminal cases
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: The self-sworn affidavits of the 672 candidates for Delhi assembly elections , which were analysed by election watchdog Association for Democratic Reforms (ADR), has shown that 243 of them are crorepatis. In 2015, there were 230 crorepatis out of 673 candidates. Women candidates have increased this year to 79 compared with 66 in the 2015 elections.Among the major political parties, Congress has the largest number of crorepatis —55 of the 66 candidates fielded — followed by 51 crorepatis among the 70 nominated by AAP. Out of BJP’s 67 candidates, 47 are crorepatis.The average assets in this year’s polls are Rs 4.3 crore, up from Rs 3.3 crore in 2015, said the ADR report. Among the major parties, the average assets for 70 AAP candidates is Rs 15.2 crore, Rs 11.6 crore for 66 Congress candidates and Rs 10.2 crore for the 67 BJP candidates.AAP has the three richest candidates. The party’s Mundka candidate Dharampal Lakra is the richest with assets worth Rs 292.1 crore followed by Pramila Tokas from RK Puram (Rs 80.8 crore) and Ram Singh Netaji from Badarpur (Rs 80 crore).The poorest candidate, Rajesh Kumar, contesting from Palam constituency, belongs to Republican Party of India (Athawale). His total assets are just Rs 3,600. He is followed by Independent candidate from Shalimar Bagh, Poonam Kaushik, who has declared assets worth Rs 6,917. Another Independent candidate, Rahul Beniwal, who will be taking on chief minister Arvind Kejriwal from New Delhi assembly constituency, has assets worth Rs 7,031.Of the 672 candidates in the fray, 210 are from national parties, 90 from state parties, 224 from registered unrecognised parties and 148 Independents. The total number of political parties contesting the elections this time is 95, up from 71 in 2015.In all, 133 candidates have declared criminal cases lodged against them. This includes those involved in serious criminal cases, including 32 candidates booked for crimes against women. One candidate has a rape case lodged against him. There are four candidates facing attempt to murder cases. There are 20 candidates who were convicted. In 25 assembly constituencies, there are three or more candidates with criminal cases against them. In 2015 assembly elections, out of 673 candidates, 114 had criminal cases lodged against them.Of the major political parties, 42 AAP candidates have been booked in criminal cases. Most cases range from defamation to unlawful assembly, misbehaviour with a public servant and causing damage to public property. The affidavits mention that most criminal cases are a result of the candidates taking part in protests.The number of BJP candidates with criminal cases is 26 and Congress 18. Many candidates have mentioned in their affidavits that the criminal cases filed against them are politically motivated.The report states that 340 (51%) of candidates are not graduates and have declared their educational qualification to be between classes V and XII. Graduates or above comprise 44% (298) candidates. There are 12 candidates who are diploma holders, six literate and 16 Illiterate.The number of candidates aged between 25 and 50 is 441 (66%). Those between 51 and 70 years is 212 (32%). There are 11 candidates aged between 71 and 80 years, while eight haven’t revealed their age.

Title: Rampur admin to send demolition notice to Azam Khan’s medical college building
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Azam Khan

RAMPUR: After taking possession of 17 bighas of land of Mohammad Ali Jauhar University , the Rampur administration would be sending demolition notice to its chancellor Samajwadi Party (SP) MP Azam Khan on Monday. They plan to raze down the medical science faculty building within a week, sources said.

The university was built by Azam, and the Rampur administration said the SP leader encroached upon the government land and illegally constructed the building.

“After taking possession of the government land which comprises 17 bighas on the university campus, we are now going to issue notice to the Jauhar Trust, run by Azam Khan, and the university authorities to remove their illegal encroachments, which includes the faculty of medical science building,” Rampur district magistrate (DM) Aunjaneya Kumar Singh said on Saturday.

The DM added that if the Jauhar Trust fails to comply with the notice, the building would be demolished and the university authorities would have to bear the expenses incurred during the demolition process.

Meanwhile, SP’s state unit president Naresh Uttam Patel said a delegation led by leader of opposition at the state assembly Ramnath Govind will be reaching Rampur to inspect the ongoing measures carried out by the administrative officials.

On Friday, a team of revenue officials led by sub-divisional magistrate, Sadar, Prem Prakash Tiwari, carried out an inspection of the site and “demarcated the disputed land”. The move comes in the wake of the revenue board order, which dismissed an appeal filed by the Jauhar University on January 20, challenging the SDM order declaring the land occupied as “illegal”.

Title: Raised limit for MSME audits welcomed, but not deemed enough
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: The Budget proposal to hike the turnover threshold for micro , small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) to conduct mandatory tax audit — from Rs 1 crore to Rs 5 crore — will benefit at least 40% of the units in the region, as per local industrialists.

A turnover of five crore is considerably high for a large number of units here, which will help ease tax compliance for the sector, they feel.

Industrialist Pravin Tapadia claimed that the raised slab for MSME tax audits will reduce the burden on businesspersons, as it will help around 40-50% of the enterprises.

“Most MSMEs have a turnover of less than Rs 5 crore, so it will help them with ease of business. But the Goods and Services Tax (GST) audit is compulsory for companies having a turnover of more than Rs 2 crore. So, the audit is conducted anyway at the slab of Rs 2 crore,” Tapadia said.

“Several companies prefer undertaking an audit when their turnover is less, as it gives them authenticity,” he added.

Vidarbha Industries Association (VIA) president Suresh Rathi, who welcomed the decision of raising the turnover threshold for audit of MSMEs, said it is applicable to units where 95% of the transactions take place through the banking channel.

“It will help the MSMEs to keep their accounting in order. As most of them usually work on cash basis, this will lead to the promotion of cashless economy too. However, we had expected the government to do a lot more for the uplift of MSMEs, as this industry creates jobs for the youth,” Rathi added.

Julfesh Shah, a member of the committee on management accounting under the Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI), New Delhi, said, “This year’s Budget has stressed more on MSMEs rather than large-scale industries. Now the non-banking financial companies (NBFCs) can also do invoice financing; earlier it was not allowed for MSMEs, so they had to go to banks for cash flow management. Due to this, they used to face shortage of funds.”

“But now that they have opened it for NBFCs, MSMEs can raise invoices for pending money and take it from NBFCs, which will regulate their cash flow and can also be subordinated by banks,” Shah added. He also welcomed the move to extend the restructuring of non-performing assets (NPAs) of MSMEs by one year, emphasizing that it would help keep several MSMEs afloat.

The abolition of Dividend Distribution Tax (DDT) was also praised by several experts, but they raised concerns regarding the tax burden on dividend recipients. “The scrapping of DDT will incentivize more foreign investors to invest in Indian industries. However, the recipients of the dividend will now have to pay the tax amount as per their tax slab,” said Shah.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Nirbhaya convicts taking legal process for a ride: Plea in Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nirbhaya’s mother breaks down after a Delhi court on Friday indefinitely postponed hanging of the four convict... Read More

NEW DELHI: Terming it a “classic case where the four Nirbhaya case convicts had taken the legal process for a ride”, the Centre and Delhi Police on Saturday moved Delhi high court seeking to fast-track the hanging of the death row inmates.

The Centre, in its plea, argued that pendency of the mercy plea of one convict in a case of multiple death row inmates can’t be used as a ground to stay hanging of those who had exhausted all available legal options. The plea submitted that the convicts could be hanged separately, if required. The mercy plea of Mukesh Singh and Vinay Sharma have been rejected by the President.

Justice Suresh Kait, after a nearly hour-long hearing, issued a notice to the four convicts to respond to the government’s plea seeking their immediate execution and setting aside of the trial court’s order staying the hanging scheduled for February 1. Acknowledging the urgency of the matter, the court fixed the next hearing on Sunday, a court holiday.

Appearing for the Centre and police, solicitor general Tushar Mehta sought setting aside of the trial court’s stay order, arguing that it was clear that the four convicts were “acting in tandem” to frustrate the sentencing.

“This case will go down in history as one of the rare ones where the accused in heinous crimes have classically abused the process of law and tried the patience of the country,” Mehta submitted, urging the court to step in so that death warrants could be executed immediately.

The senior law officer read out the rules of Delhi Jail Manual 2018, which govern execution of death penalty and maintained the trial court erred while assuming if even one prisoner’s mercy plea was filed, the hanging couldn’t take place.

“If this is how law has to be interpreted, then no sentence can be executed. Hanging has to be done one by one. Those who have exhausted their legal remedies can be executed. Else, one co-convict can ensure delay for others in the same case and make them wait, a dehumanising effect as per Supreme Court rulings,” Mehta submitted before Justice Kait.

The Centre’s plea challenging the trial court order made a similar point and argued that a joint reading of the jail provisions “makes it clear that it is only in case of pendency of the mercy petition of the prisoner/convict concerned that execution would remain stayed during the aforesaid period”.

Earlier in the day, the plea was first mentioned before Chief Justice DN Patel for an urgent hearing and it was marked to Justice Kait. The plea made parties the convicts — Singh, Sharma, Pawan Gupta and Akshay Thakur — director general (prisons) and superintendent of Tihar Jail.

The plea said the trial court had acted beyond its jurisdiction in postponing the death warrants “till further orders”, adding that the judge failed to consider that the convicts were found guilty for the gruesome and horrible offence of gang rape and murder of a woman.

It further argued that the convicts were given sufficient opportunity to avail all legal remedies, but they deliberately chose to delay the process of filing their pleas. Explaining why it approached the court, the Centre said it was the nodal agency to maintain law and order in Delhi and also the department concerned to process the mercy petitions filed by any death row convict in the national capital.

The plea said the conduct of the convicts clearly showed their intention to delay the process of execution of death sentence , which is not only an abuse of the process of law but also mockery of courts and the judicial system.

Title: Kolkata: Sops to fuel demand in affordable housing segment
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: West Bengal and the fringes of Kolkata will benefit from FM Nirmala Sitharaman’s sops to boost the affordable housing sector, feel developers in the city. Kolkata’s major realty players pointed out that this would help the housing sector in a big way.

Credai, West Bengal, president and Merlin group chairman Sushil Mohta said that most of the projects are affordable on the northern and southern fringes. “According to our estimates, 70% of the projects in and around Kolkata are in the affordable range,” he added.

Ambuja Neotia Group chairman Harsh Neotia also felt that the proposal will benefit eastern India and West Bengal more. “The inventories in this category here are substantial,” he added. President-elect of Credai National H V Patodia said that the measures for extension of timeline for the benefits will boost the demand for affordable housing in the region.

Siddha Group MD Sanjay Jain, who has number of units in this category, said “Since most of the projects in Bengal, including those in Kolkata, are under Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana, it will be a boon for real estate,” he added. Shrachi Group MD Ravi Todi said, “As demand had not picked up during the current fiscal, the sops will give people opportunity to buy more homes and avail the benefit and also more projects can be launched by developers,” he added. Mundhra Construction MD Aditya Mumdra said that following the announcement, new projects in the state will generate employment.

Title: Depositors can bank on 5-fold hike in insurance
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo

The government decision to allow insurance cover for up to Rs 5 lakh of deposits from the current Rs 1 lakh will increase investor faith in deposits in the midst of failing cooperative banks and rumours of weak banks. The flip side is that banks will have to pay a higher premium to the Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation – an arm of RBI which provides the cover.

As on March 31, 2019, around 28% of bank deposits (in value terms) and around 92% of depositors (in terms of the number of accounts) were covered by deposit insurance, which is likely to increase to around 40-50%.

“The proposal is a highly confidence-boosting measure and should support the deposit accretion of banks. However, given that the size of insured deposits is likely to increase, the deposit insurance premium paid by banks will increase the operating expenses of banks and will be negative for their profitability to the extent they are not able to pass it on to the bank customers,” said Karthik Srinivasan , SVP & Group Head, Financial Sector Ratings, ICRA Ltd.

The issue of deposit insurance came to the limelight with the PMC Bank crisis, where the public at large learnt that only Rs 1 lakh of their deposit was insured by banks. According to the DICGC’s annual report, banks are currently paying Rs 100 per Rs 1 lakh deposit which translates into a cost of 0.1% on the deposit.

According to the Mrutyunjay Mahapatra, MD & CEO of Syndicate Bank, the increase in premium will depend on the number of accounts that have such high balances. He adds that there has not been enough debate on the pricing of deposit insurance.

Private banks are comfortable with the issue of a higher premium. “While this could mean some expenditure for the banks, this would certainly give comfort to retail savers. Similarly, the proposal to amend banking laws to strengthen cooperative banks should also infuse more confidence among savers,” said R. K. Gurumurthy - Head Treasury, Lakshmi Vilas Bank.

According to Srinivasan, even if the cost is passed on to all the banks the impact would be marginal on their balance sheet. “On a return on assets (ROA) basis, the impact would be only a couple of basis points,” he said.

The stronger PSU banks feel that there should be risk-based pricing . DICGC’s deposit insurance fund has been mobilized largely from premium paid by public sector banks. But almost its entire claims are from failed cooperative banks.

Alpesh Mehta, banking analyst at Motilal Oswal said that banks are likely to pass on the cost to customers. “Banks will pass on the cost to depositors by reducing their interest rates,” he said.

But some say even Rs 5 lakh coverage is inadequate. “Even my maid had Rs 7 lakh in PMC as savings. They should be giving us 100% coverage. We are willing to pay a higher premium,” says Lavina Wadhwa (49), whose family, in aggregate, has Rs 1.3 crore stuck in PMC Bank in FDs and savings accounts.

“Look at the number of people and societies, including an RBI employees cooperative, which have lakhs of money with PMC Bank. How is Rs 5 lakh adequate?” asks Aarti Salgaonkar, a filmmaker and PMC bank depositor. A string of others like Bengaluru-based Sri Gururaghavendra Sahakara Bank , Niyamitha Cooperative Bank and Pune-based Shivajirao Bhosale Co-operative Bank have also been affected.

Title: Shaheen Bagh firing: Family, neighbours wonder how a normal guy lost his head
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

TOI spotted a board with Gurjar’s father’s name in Dallupura (inset). Gates to his house were shut.

NEW DELHI: There was a frenzy outside the Dallupura residence of Chowdhary Gaje Singh on Saturday evening. His son, Kapil Gurjar , had been arrested earlier in the day for firing three shots in the air at Shaheen Bagh , where an anti-citizenship law protest has been going on since December. Having recognised Gurjar from television news pictures, curious neighbours gathered outside the iron gates of the house in east Delhi .

Singh said he was at work when he discovered what his son had been up to on Saturday. “Kapil was at home till around noon when I left for office. It was at work that I got a phone call from a relative, asking me to check the news on television,” said Singh. “I was startled to see my son’s face on TV.”

Describing the 25-year-old as “straightforward” and “honest”, Singh said he hadn’t even seen him arguing with anyone earlier. He did note, however, that Gurjar wasn’t his normal self in recent days. “Chup chup sa raha karta tha kuch dino se, par ghar mein aisi kabhi koi baat hi nahi thi (he was unusually withdrawn these last few days, though there wasn’t anything at home that could have depressed him),” he revealed.

While the family does not have a political background, Singh has contested in municipal elections in the past as a candidate of the Bahujan Samaj Party. Residents of the locality said that the younger Gurjar had completed his schooling and enrolled for a journalism course, before dropping out. The youth handled the family’s dairy business.

A neighbour disclosed, “Kapil told us that the only problem he had with the Shaheen Bagh protest was that ambulances and vehicles were not allowed to pass through the area. Businesses are being disrupted and people are being inconvenienced and it could be that Kapil’s work too was getting impacted in this manner.”

Gurjar’s elder brother assumed he was somewhere nearby or was playing cricket in the vicinity at the time. He claimed the family did not possess a firearm. “We don’t know how Kapil ended up in Shaheen Bagh or how he got his hands on a pistol. We will find out once we talk to him,” he said.

Sachin Dedha, who is the young man’s gym partner, described Gurjar as a “nationalist”, but maintained that they seldom discussed topics like Shaheen Bagh in general. “He was like any other individual. We would talk about our daily lives and together work out at the gym. I know him well but he never confided in me about wanting to take such a drastic step,” said Dedha.

Joginder Nagar, Gurjar’s uncle, said the shooter was educated and so knew what was right and wrong. “He has a daughter who is almost two years old and a well-to-do family. Why would he take such a step? It seems like he is being set up,” said the circumspect Nagar.

A neighbour, Suryavanshi Indrajeet Gurjar, also testified to the 25-year-old’s familiarity with people in the area, with whom he was “never rude”. “He was a well-behaved man,” said Suryavanshi Gurjar. “He looked after the family dairy business and had no reason to lose his head like that. We are really surprised at his act, as surprised as everyone else.”

Title: Start-ups welcome seed fund, ESOP provisions in Budget
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nagpur: Entrepreneurs have welcomed the Union Budget presented by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday. They said the measures for start-ups will help boost India’s economic growth and promote skill development.

Deepak Menaria, founder and chief idea farmer at Lemon Ideas, said two things are really good in the Budget. “The seed fund for start-ups called ‘Early Life Funding’ will support ideation and development of entrepreneurship. At early stage, not much funding is available. They have announced it, so let us see what is the framework. Second is taxation. Making employee stock options (ESOPs) plan tax free will help start-ups to retain employees,” he said.

Menaria added that announcements on skill building will help MSMEs and start-ups so would the single window for investment clearance.

Rohan Parikh, director of The Green Acres Academy, said as a country gearing up to have the largest ‘working population’ in the age group of 15 to 65 years of age by 2030, Budget 2020 has adequately focused on building a robust structure to drive higher education and skill development. “From creating an efficient workforce of engineers, doctors, bio-medics and IT professionals to nurturing skill-based qualities for entrepreneurs, sales and marketing professionals or commercial fine arts etc, the Budget has taken into consideration the inclination of the youth and aligned it to the economic growth targets, thereby strengthening the role of education in building the $5 trillion economy,” he said.

Nilabh Kapoor, business head India, OLX People, said Union Budget 2020 is definitely a step towards boosting India’s economic growth. “The very first theme of the budget, ‘Aspirational India’, promises better livelihood for all, access to health care and greater job opportunities through education and skill development. The boost to entrepreneurship, start ups and skill development in the infrastructure sector is a welcome move that will help create jobs directly. A total of Rs3,000 crore has been allocated for skill development, which shows the government's commitment towards encouraging employment growth rate and boosting the skill sector,” he said.

Pramodh Chandrashekhar, founder CEO of Last Ripple, said the government has done credible work on start ups. But, Chandrashekhar felt, the allocation should have been 2 or 3 per cent more.

Title: ‘No need to panic as fatality rate is under 2%’
Content: Kozhikode: Medical field experts have given certain relieving facts on novel coronavirus (nCoV) which are assuring but asked the public to be pro-active. Experts urged the public to be vigil than panic-stricken after confirmation of the first coronavirus case in Kerala.According to experts, fatality rate of coronavirus is below 2%, and when compared with diseases such as leptospirosis and dengue, is less dangerous and can be restricted with effective preventive measures. However, it doesn’t take away the fact that it spreads much faster, hence health experts have urged people with a travel history to coronavirus-hit countries to take self-preventive measures of home quarantine to effectively combat the disease. They also urged vulnerable groups who are immunocompromised and suffering from chronic illness, expecting mothers, elderly and children to take special care.Dr T Jayakrishnan, department of community medicine at Kozhikode Government Medical College, said that the fatality rate of leptospirosis is 10% and dengue is around 3%. “One has to remember that coronavirus spreads faster than Nipah, hence the health department insists home quarantine of 28 days to those who have a travel history to coronavirus-hit countries. People who arrived from these countries should undergo voluntary home quarantine and avoid contact family members and vulnerable groups to avoid complications,” he said.Meanwhile, the college union of Kozhikode government medical college has already commenced public awareness programme by conducting live session on the theme ‘Corona: Precautions and Safety’ on the Facebook page of college union to disseminate health awareness message to educate public.

Title: Kisan Rail to boost West Bengal veggie market
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

KOLKATA: The ‘ Kisan Rail ’ with refrigerated coaches that will be introduced by Indian Railways, as announced by the Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday, will provide a major boost to Bengal’s vegetable and horticulture sectors.

The coaches will be used for the transportation of perishable goods.

According to senior officials of the state agricultural marketing department, 18%-25% of the vegetables, fruits and flowers is wasted during transportation to other parts of the country. “At present, we send the produce via trucks where there is no facility to regulate temperature. Sometimes it takes more than a week to transport these perishable products. Naturally, the products become dry and farmers don’t get good value. Hence, they prefer selling it at a lower price in the local markets than send it to other places,” state agricultural advisor Pradip Majumdar said.

The FM in her budget speech announced that to build a seamless national cold supply chain for perishables, including milk, meat and fish, the Indian Railways will set up the ‘Kisan Rail’ through Public-private partnership arrangement. There shall be refrigerated coaches in express and freight trains as well.

The announcement comes at a time when Bengal has been recognized as the topmost vegetable-producing state in the country for 2018-19, bettering Uttar Pradesh. The state produced 29.55 million tonnes of vegetables during 2018-19, accounting for 15.9% of the country’s total vegetable production.

Chief minister Mamata Banerjee had proposed a similar facility when she was the railway minister, but it was not successfully implemented.

Title: Metro train mooted for Rajkot
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Municipal commissioner Udit Agrawal (second from right) presenting the budget

Rajkot: It sounds bit far-fetched at present , but in the coming years travelling is set to become less troublesome for people of Rajkot. The city too is dreaming big, and in this decade could have metro train after Ahmedabad and Surat in Gujarat.

Rajkot Municipal Corporation (RMC), which presented Rs2,120 crore budget for financial year 2020-21 without imposing any new taxes or hiking rates on Saturday, proposes to appoint a consultant for metro train project. Municipal commissioner Udit Agrawal told reporters, "The civic body proposes to appoint a consultant to carry out a feasibility study on the metro project in the city." A provision of Rs1 crore has been made in the budget for the feasibility study. The size of the budget has got reduced compared to last year, but its focus remains on infrastructure projects and public transportation. The budget estimates find mentions of many schemes announced during the year and looks into the future ie 2030 when many nearby villages will be brought within the city limits. Once Hirasar airport and AIIMS become operational, it is but natural that the city limits will see further expansion toward Ahmedabad road and Jamnagar road.

RMC had last month notified merger of five surrounding villages with itself. RMC proposes to provide 24-hour water supply in ward numbers 1,8,9,10,11 and 12 for which it plans to approach Asian Development Bank (ADB) for loan. The project cost is Rs328 crore of which the portion of ADB loan will be 70 per cent. The remaining amount will be provided by the state government and the municipal corporation, which also plans to install water meters in the houses.

The civic body, which refrained from hiking tax rates in an election year, gave tax relief up to 25 per cent to self-financed schools, government buildings and banks. It proposes to form a special purpose vehicle for the administration of world-class Mahatma Museum.

RMC will be building an ebus depot for 50 ebuses at a cost of Rs10 crore as they are expected to be pushed into service later this year.

Some of the infrastructure projects proposed include two foot-on-bridges on 150-feet Ring Road, bridges on Ramapir Chowk, Nana Mauva Chowk, Umiya Chowk, Kalavad Road and Greenland Chowk. Those which are in tendering or construction stages include Dudhsagar Road Bridge, Amrapali railway underpass, Hospital Chowk flyover and Laxminagar underpass. Upon completion of all these projects, commuting will become a pleasant experience for people in the city.

Title: ‘Budget a mixed bag of ups and downs’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Dehradun: Union Budget 2020 received a mixed response from the people of the state. TOI spoke to a cross-section of people including industrialists, educators, investment advisors and young professionals to gauge their reaction. City-based industrialist and chairman of Windlass Group, Sudhir Windlass said, “On the face of it, the proposal of affordable housing looks fine but there is a lot that needs to be done to accomplish the goal of housing for all.” Realtor Abhishek Bansal added, “Government's announcement of Rs 100 lakh crore for infrastructural development will boost real estate in tier II and tier III cities. There were many measures that we would have loved the government to address but announcement of infrastructure development is a step in right direction.”

Meanwhile, educators also welcomed the increase in allocation for the education sector from Rs 93,847 crore to Rs 99,300 crore (with Rs 3,000 crore for skill development).

Ajay Saksena, principal of DAV College, Dehradun , told TOI that “the thrust on online learning was a good thing but core- education colleges were totally neglected in the budget.”

“The government says that online degree courses will be offered by top 100 institutes of the country which is a good thing but there is no mention of employment generation, so one wonders what jobs students will get after doing the courses from such renowned universities,” he added.

City-based investment advisor Sunil Mittal said that “a big put- off for the industry is the silence in the budget on the provision of long term capital gain tax (10%).”

Gaurav Mehta, a Doon-based filmmaker, said,“With no major polls in sight — except the Delhi assembly elections — the government could really have announced a major rejig even if it had come at the cost of upsetting some people. What makes promises in the budget less credible is what happened last year when the finance minister rolled back a couple of announcements post-budget.”

Title: Develop tourism in Kaleshwaram: CM
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has instructed officials to take advantage of the barrages and reservoirs constructed as part of Kaleshwaram and develop tourism spots all over the state.

He asked the officials to identify places conducive for tourism and prepare plans to develop them. The CM said this at a review meeting on tourism at Pragathi Bhavan on Saturday.

“ There is a dense forest area on either side of the Godavari river. Boating facilities can be provided. Trees can be grown on either side on the lines of Dal lake in Srinagar. Land is available with the government under the project wherein musical fountains can be developed on the lines of Brindavan Gardens in Mysuru,” KCR said. TNN

Title: Bonds in hot bother as rates stay high
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The FM’s proposal to hike fiscal deficit, to indirectly indicate keeping small savings rates at an elevated level and less incentive for life insurers to buy government securities would keep the long term government yields at an elevated level. This, in turn, would leave less option for RBI to cut rates in the short term, bond market players said. However, given the limited options that the finance minister had to manoeuvre with the Budget numbers, they feel the government has aimed at boosting “growth through acceptable level of fiscal expansion and funding the same through higher small savings collection thereby avoiding crowding out,” said Ram Kamal Samanta , VP-Investment, Star Union Dai-ichi Life Insurance.

It being a Saturday, with the bond market closed for trading, dealers will await Monday’s trading session to gauge the full impact of the Budget proposals.

Bond market players also feel that with economic recovery funded through fiscal expansion, it may exert some pressure on interest rates, which in turn is likely to be contained by accommodative policy stance by the RBI and resumption of FPI buying of Indian bonds owing to the extension of lower withholding tax facility.

Title: Rajkot: Clerk held for stealing from court treasury
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: The clerk with the principal civil court of Maliya-Miyana was arrested for allegedly embezzling Rs 2.37 lakh from the court’s treasury.

Police said the accused, identified as Yogesh Chauhan, had allegedly siphoned off the money that was deposited in the court’s treasury in the forms of fines, alimony and bail money.

“Chauhan had allegedly embezzled Rs 2.37 lakh from May 12, 2019 to January 30 this year,” said an official from Maliya-Miyana police station.

Title: Rajkot: Cop caught taking bribe
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: The assistant sub-inspector (ASI) with Rajkot B division police station was caught accepting Rs 600 bribe on Saturday.

The officials of Rajkot anti-corruption bureau (ACB) said the accused, identified as Suresh Kotwal , had demanded money from a person sent by the Rajkot ACB as a decoy to issue him a verification certificate.

The Rajkot ACB had received complaints against Kotwal that he used to take between Rs 500 and Rs 1,000 from every person who came seeking the police verification certificate.

“Acting on this information, we sent a person as a decoy to Kotwal and when Kotwal scaled down his demand from Rs 1,000 to Rs 600 and was taking the cash, he was caught,” said H P Doshi, deputy superintendent of police, Rajkot ACB.

Title: JNU students vow to shield Shaheen Bagh protesters
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

JNU students, teachers, people from Muslim community and Shaheen Bagh hold placards as they take part in a de... Read More

NEW DELHI: Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union ( JNUSU ) has announced that the students will head to Shaheen Bagh to protect and join the protesters after another person opened fire in the area on Saturday.

In their statement, JNUSU said, “There are reports of another firing incident from Shaheen Bagh. A man fired at the protesters in front of police barricades. This is the second recent incident in a disturbing trend of targeting protesters through the use of violence. A Jamia student was injured only two days ago.”

They blamed Union minister Anurag Thakur for allegedly exhorting supporters to take the law into their hands and also alleged that BJP’s Model Town candidate Kapil Mishra and UP CM Yogi Adityanath are “repeatedly making anti-Muslim remarks that are being used as fodder for intensification of a violent campaign so close to elections.”

Attacking Delhi Police for being “mute spectators”, Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union “condemned the partisan attitude of the police” and demanded urgent action to stop such attacks.

Calling the student community to assemble at Shaheen Bagh, JNUSU said in its statement that “we appeal the student community to rally in support of Shaheen Bagh against the anti-people CAA-NRC-NPR and join.”

Announcing support for protesters at Shaheen Bagh, JNU’s NSUI unit called for an effigy burning of the RSS at Sabarmati lawns of the university campus.

Title: Shaheen Bagh protests: Centre ready for structured dialogue, says Union minister
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ravi Shankar Prasad

NEW DELHI: Amid growing tension over anti-CAA protests at Shaheen Bagh , the central government said it was ready to clarify the “doubts” of protesters on changes in Citizenship Amendment Act if they came forward for a formal engagement.

“Government is ready to talk to protesters at Shaheen Bagh, but then it should be in a structured form and the Narendra Modi government is ready to communicate with them and clear all the doubts they have against CAA,” Union law and communications minister Ravi Shankar Prasad tweeted.

Sources said the tweet was a follow-up of a statement that Prasad had made in response to a question put to him in a TV debate a couple of days ago, but nobody from Shaheen Bagh had come forward. The scope of any such talk would be limited to clearing misgivings which, according to them, have been stoked to fuel the protests. “Any change in CAA is not on the table,” a source said.

Prasad told TOI, “We are a sensitive government and will like to engage with the protesters to clear their doubts provided they approach us for formal talks.”

In the TV debate, a person associated with the Shaheen Bagh agitation asked Prasad why the government had not talked to protesters yet. The minister welcomed the suggestion as a “good thing”, given that the agitators ruled out talks with the government unless changes in the citizenship law were reversed.

However, Prasad made it clear that the protesters would have to reach out to the government. “If you want a government representative to talk, then there should be a structured request from Shaheen Bagh that says all people there want to talk on the subject,” he said. He ruled out the idea of a government representative visiting the protest site. “What if someone goes there and is mistreated?” he asked.

Title: Credai bullish on realty in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Apex real estate body, Confederation of Real Estate Developers’ Associations of India (Credai), which is organising the 9th edition of the Hyderabad Property Show, is upbeat about Hyderabad’s prospects. Credai Hyderabad president, P Rama Krishna Rao, said the city’s real estate sector is witnessing all-round growth.

Credai Hyderabad general secretary V Rajasekhar Reddy, said, “We have witnessed a remarkable surge in real estate sector in Hyderabad. The growth is primarily driven by the IT/ ITeS sector, with prominent global enterprises making Hyderabad their biggest hub. The city is witnessing significant activity in the co-working segment.” The three-day property show, that wraps up on Sunday, has brought together realtors, building material manufacturers, consultants and financial institutions from across the city to exhibit the advances in the real estate sector under a single umbrella. The event is showcasing projects ranging from Rs 45 lakh to Rs 5 crore including integrated townships, apartment complexes, gated communities, green buildings with impetus on retail and commercial complexes.

Title: Shaheen Bagh protest: Women say they aren’t budging
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Shaheen Bagh Twitter handle said the protesters would not be deterred.

NEW DELHI: It was usual business at Shaheen Bagh when an armed man opened fire a few metres away from the tent, which has turned home to several thousand women for the past 49 days.

A contingent of Sikh speakers from Punjab was on the mic, calling for unity, when the sound of gunshots pierced the air around 5pm on Saturday.

The seconds after it were a blur as several women scrambled out of the tent. They walked in the direction of the shooter, unaware of the danger, but also unafraid. When they found out what had happened, their response was measured but strong. They formed a human chain at the shooting spot.

When TOI visited the site, the women were standing together, holding hands, supporting the elderly, and aiding the men in their vigil, wary of strangers in the area. Some of them also offered namaz on the road, praying for “peace and solidarity”. But Shaheen Bagh’s collective answer to the gunman who shouted “only Hindus will rule India” was the national anthem and chants of Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Isayi, apas mein hain bhai bhai.

“We know these are attempts to scare away the protesters, especially ahead of the assembly elections. But we will not budge,” said Iqra, who reached the spot just minutes after the shooting.

The young woman also questioned the police’s inability to catch the perpetrators. “The entrance to the area from Jasola Vihar Metro Station is blocked at two points. The shooter had crossed the first layer of the barricades and fired in the air a few metres away from the main stage. How has this become so normal?” she asked.

Razia, a 70-year-old woman, clutching the hand of her daughter-in-law, was an image of determination. Her frail body was bent, but she put herself in the frontline. “I have been sitting in the tent for over a month. But I came here 2 hours ago when I heard about the shooting. We are not scared of the bullets and will always be the first in the line of defence against the divisive forces,” she said.

Around 7.30pm, the official Twitter handle of the protest site also issued an appeal. “The women of #shaheenbagh call for urgent mobilisation for 2nd February 2020. We will not be deterred by threats from Right-Wing groups in our fight to protect the Constitution. Please join us (sic),” it said. The appeal also pointed to the “unverified” threats that have been posted on several social media platforms, where people claiming to be from the Hindu Sena said they would “clear” the Shaheen Bagh road on February 2.

Upasana, a resident of Bijnor who came to Delhi to join the protest on January 19, questioned the people in power, “The ministers keep calling for traitors to be shot. I’d like to ask them who’s a traitor? Those who sit peacefully in protests, or those who incite violence?” she asked.

On Sunday, the sit-in at Shaheen Bagh will enter the 50th day. The shooting did ruffle feathers, especially as it came just two days after a student of Jamia Millia Islamia was shot at a few kilometres away from the neighbourhood. But the women’s resolve remained unshakeable. As a protester articulated, the women are alert about the possibility of trouble, but are not “troubled” by it.

Title: Man murdered in Padadhari village; two booked
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A tribal man was murdered in Khakhara Bela village of Padadhari taluka in Rajkot district on Thursday night. A complaint in this connection was lodged with Padadhari police station on Friday night.

Police said the victim’s brother-in-law and the latter’s brother strangled Kailash Mavi (35) on the outskirts of Khakhara Bela village. The accused have been identified as Raju Mahida and Kaju Mahida, sad cops.

According to the police, Mavi had left home for shopping in Padadhari on January 30 and later in the evening, returned home along with his sister Atar , her husband Raju and his brother, Kaju. After having dinner, Mavi told his wife Savita that he along with Raju and Kaju was going to the farm to sleep.

“In the night, Raju and Kaju returned to Mavi’s house claiming they needed blankets, After they were given the blankets, both went away. The next morning on Friday, one Vanrajsinh Jadeja came asking for Mavi for some labour work. Savita went to the farm to look for Mavi and found him dead,” said J V Vadhiya, sub-inspector with Padadhari police station.

“We sent the body for postmortem and the report on Friday stated that Mavi had died of strangulation. As both Raju and Kaju had absconded, we booked them for the murder on the complaint of Savita,” added Vadhiya.

Title: IMFL worth Rs 11 lakh seized in Rajkot; bootlegger booked
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A total of 3 ,509 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 11 lakh were seized from the cabin of a farm on the outskirts of Ishwaria village of Padadhari taluka in Rajkot district on Friday night.

Police had received a tip-off that the accused, identified as Lakhan Dangar, had stored IMFL bottles in the cabin.

“We had received an information that Dangar used to sell liquor from his cabin. Acting on this tip-off, we raided the cabin and found 3,509 IMFL bottles. However, Dangar, who appeared to have got a whiff of the police action, had fled before the raid was carried out,” said J V Vadhia, sub-inspector with Padadhari police station.

Title: Economists stress on creation of more jobs
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: A meeting organised by the Kolhapur Chamber of Commerce and Industries saw a diverse analysis of the Union Budget 2020 . Representatives from many sectors were part of the meet.

“The real issues pertaining to the two core sectors — agriculture and industry — have been addressed in the budget. There should have been emphasis on measures to be adopted to increase jobs,” said economist Vijay Kakade.

“There is a need to spend more on projects that will generate employment while at the same time improving spending capacity. Also, taxes continue to be high for small-scale industries and co-operative industries. The co-operative sector, which comprises credit societies and the factories, have not been mentioned in the budget apart from a tax rate cut from 30% to 22%,” he said.

Anand Mane, an industrialist, said: “The government is not ready to accept that there has been an unprecedented slowdown. The proposed 16-point programme will most likely turn out to be a dream instead of a reality. The announcement made to increase farmers’ incomes to double by 2022, has not been supported by any plan. The banks are not ready to lend. The only thing industrialists can do now is to ensure that the businesses don’t suffer high losses in the coming months.”

Chandrakant Jadhav, the vice-president of the KCCI and a Congress MLA, said: “Problems have been rising in the industrial sector. A lack of concrete policies is causing losses. There was no big announcement on infrastructure, which has the potential to create jobs. We have no data that tells us how much was spent on infrastructure last year. We believe that the job crisis is going to worsen. We have sought a meeting with Union ministers, to ask for policies that could also boost the automobile sector. The official life span of vehicles should be cut down to 10 years from the existing 15 years.”

Tax consultant Mahesh Dharmadhikari said the government has given relief to the tax payers by cutting down the income tax, however, at the same time the deductions or the tax exemptions are done away with.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Shaheen Bagh protesters must rethink, prevent any harm, says AAP
Content:
Sanjay Singh

अमित शाह जी, ये आपने क्या हाल बना रखा है हमारी दिल्ली का। दिनदहाड़े गोलियां चल रहीं है। कानून व्यवस्था की खुलेआम ध… https://t.co/FC1LMQ4dyN — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) 1580560295000

NEW DELHI: AAP Rajya Sabha member Sanjay Singh on Saturday urged Shaheen Bagh protesters to “rethink” about their sit-in against CAA to “avoid anyone from taking political advantage of them”.Singh said the protesters should not let anyone harm them physically. “They should rethink about their protest. They should not allow anyone to take advantage of their protest or harm them. Polling date is drawing near.”Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal, meanwhile, on Saturday slammed Union home minister Amit Shah after a man opened fire near the Shaheen Bagh protest site and urged him to focus on the law and order situation in the capital.“Amit Shah ji, what has Delhi turned into! A shooting takes place in broad daylight. Law and order has turned into a joke. Elections will come and go, politics will also continue, but for the sake of the people of Delhi, please focus on improving law and order,” Kejriwal tweeted.Delhi Congress chief Subhash Chopra also responded saying the incident reflected the helplessness of BJP just before the elections. “BJP has lost all hope. It is trying to polarise the electorate due to which law and order has been thrown to the wind. It is doing all this for political benefits,” he added.Meanwhile, AAP wrote to the Election Commission to inform that it had learned that certain anti-social elements, in connivance with certain parties, were planning to create unrest and violence on Sunday. The party stated that a group has put out hoardings in some areas asking people to assemble near Sarita Vihar. It claimed that it feared that this might be a well-planned conspiracy to sabotage the Delhi polls. It requested the EC to direct the police commissioner and other agencies to take appropriate preemptive action.BJP leader Vijay Goel also condemned the incident. “People at Shaheen Bagh should consider that due to their protest, inconvenience is being caused to thousands of people, including children, office goers and traders. The kind of slogans being raised there is also instigating people,” he added.

Title: Existing textile units in Maharashtra hang by a thread
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Production has dropped drastically over the past few years

PUNE: The Union Budget 2020 has announced Rs 1,480 crore, over four years, for the National Technical Textile Mission to cut down imports. However, the industry rued the lack of impetus to the existing textile units that are struggling to survive.

Ichalkaranji, Bhiwandi and Malegaon are the textile hubs of Maharashtra, where cloth is produced using cotton grown in the Vidarbha and Marathwada regions. According to industry experts, there are approximately 10 lakh textile units across the state, with over 50 lakh people dependent on them.

Ichalkaranji town, which is known as the Manchester of Maharashtra, has a daily production of 1.25 crore metre of cloth through its powerloom units. The market value of this fabric is Rs 50-55 crore. The production has dropped drastically over the past few years, but even the low volume of produce is failing to find market, said Satish Koshti, the president of Ichalkaranji Powerloom Weavers Cooperative Association Limited.

Koshti told TOI that fabrics and garments manufactured in Ichalkaranji were failing to find market due to greater imports from Bangladesh. “Earlier, Kolkata was a prominent markets for us. Now, that market has been captured by the Bangladesh-based industries,” he said.

There are about 20,000 powerlooms in the lanes and bylanes of Malegaon city, which employ nearly 1 lakh people. The industry has been going through a lean phase due to the rise in power tariff, demonetization, GST, and drop in demand for the material manufactured. Koshti said the textile industry needs an immediate push for revival. “It is a dire situation for us. Ichalkaranji hosts around 1.25 lakh powerloom units at present, while around 20,000 to 25,000 units have been shut down due to the losses in the past four years,” he said.

The textile unit associations have been raising their concerns with the state and Union governments, but there has been little response. “Today’s Budget too did not paint an enthusiastic picture,” Koshti said. He said the revision of power tariffs, partial clearance of loans are some of the immediate steps that the governments should take to bail out the industry. “The floods last year also damaged a few thousand units in Ichalkaranji and weavers need to get compensation,” he said.

Prakash Awade, Independent MLA from Ichalkaranji, said the Union government had shown inclination to support technical textile, but it needs to make better provisions for the existing industry.

Title: Gray langur caged in Gandhigram
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Zoo officials cage the gray langur on Saturday

Rajkot: A stray gray langur which had entered into the residential colony of Lakhana Bungalows in Gandhigram locality near Rajkot airport was caught by the staff of Pradhyuman Zoological Park on Saturday.

“We had received a complaint from the residents of Lakhana Bungalows that a monkey had entered into their locality. When we reached the spot, we found that the monkey was a gray langur,” said an official from the zoo.

Though the simian had not harmed any human beings or caused damage to the property, it had created scare among the residents.

“We dispatched a rescue team led by the veterinary doctor of the zoo. We captured the langur after shooting it with a dart attached with tranquillizer injection. We have handed over it to the forest department which will be releasing it into the forest of Gir Wildlife Sanctuary,” added the official.

Title: Five of a family killed in accident
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kottayam: Five members of a family were killed after the car they were travelling in rammed into a truck near Kuravilangad in the wee hours of Saturday. Their funeral will be held at the SNDP crematorium in Veloor at 11am on Sunday. In the accident which occurred around 12.15am, Ulattilpadi Thambi (68), a native of Thiruvathukkal, his wife Valsala (65), daughter-in-law Prabha (40), grandson Arjun (19), and Prabha’s mother Usha Thomas (55), were killed in the accident. Prabha’s husband Praveen who is working in Kuwait reached home on Saturday evening.

The family had gone to Sree Subramanya Swami temple in Chalakkudy to attend the debut Bharatanatyam stage performance of Thambi’s grandniece. The accident happened on their return from the temple. According to MVD’s primary report, Arjun, who was driving the car, might have dozed off, leading to the accident. The speeding car crossed the middle line and went to the opposite side of the road and rammed head on into the oncoming truck. The car was totally destroyed in the crash and all five died on the spot. Local residents rushed to the spot on hearing the sound and launched rescue operations. Traffic along MC Road was disrupted for over an hour following the accident.

Praveen is working in an automobile dealership in Kuwait. Earlier, the family were living with him there. His wife Prabha and son Arjun had returned to Kottayam for the latter’s education purpose. Thambi’s daughter Indulekha, who is also abroad, will be arriving home by Sunday morning. The bodies are kept in the morgue of Government Medical College hospital. The bodies will be brought home by 8am.

Meanwhile, the MVD have come to a primary conclusion that careless driving led to the accident. Arjun, who was not used to driving at night time, might have dozed off. The car was moving at a speed exceeding 100km/hr at the time of the accident.

Title: Centre’s green norms for old units: Tamil Nadu may lose 50 per cent thermal power
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

CHENNAI: The Union government’s push for clean energy may put the state power utility, Tangedco, in trouble as it may have to decommission a clutch of its thermal units with an installed capacity of 1,850MW, which is nearly 50% of the total installed capacity of thermal power units in the state.The total installed capacity of thermal units in the state is 4,320MW.Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, in her budget speech on Saturday, said that old thermal power plants with high carbon emission levels must be decommissioned.Though the Centre is yet to define the age or emission levels that may be set for decommissioning such plants, five units in Tuticorin and four units in Mettur may have to be shut as all these units are at least 20 to 30 years old. It would be difficult to make these plants emission compliant, a senior state government official said.If the state loses these units, it may have to buy electricity from power exchanges --- which would add to the state’s financial burden.“For thermal power plants that are old and whose carbon emission levels are high, we propose that utilities running them would be advised to close them if their emission is above the pre-set norms. The land so vacated can be put to alternative use,” the finance minister said on Friday.Tangedco officials, however, denied the units were pollutants and said that with some retro-fitments, the units could continue to run for another decade or two.In 2016, Tamil Nadu decommissioned 450MW capacity units in Ennore which were the oldest thermal units in the state. “Power generation in these units commissioned between 1970 and 1975 has been stopped, and a new 660MW thermal unit is being commissioned. Work is going on,” a Tangedco official said.The Tuticorin units were commissioned between 1979 and 1991 in stages, while Mettur units were set up between 1987 and 1990.

Title: Pipe damage stalls supply of water
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Officials from the water works department of the civic administration said that the water supply to the city and the Cidco areas would be affected on account of a burst in the pipe at the New Pharola pump house on Saturday afternoon.

According to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), a 350mm pipe connected to the pumphouse supplying 100 million litre per day (100 MLD) at Pharola water purification centre tore open at 3.40pm on Saturday. The pipe that was damaged is connected to the 1,219mm main pipeline, which brings water to the city. As the welded pipe broke open, water splashed over the electric motor, panel and other electrical equipment, affecting their operations. The water supply had to be immediately disconnected.

The AMC stated in a release that the 100 MLD water scheme had to be closed for a minimum of 24 hours to repair the pipe, motor and the panel. Pumping from Jayakwadi was also stopped for the 100 MLD scheme. The civic staff immediately began the repair works. The water supply to the city will be stopped for 24 hours.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey said that the work of drying the panels and the motor pumps have started. “Until the repair is completed, there will be no supply to the city. However, Cidco areas will continue receiving water supply.”

Citizens, who were expecting water supply on Sunday, will have to wait for another day. As it is, water is supplied once in six to seven days.

The city receives water through a 100 MLD scheme laid in 1991 and a 56 MLD scheme laid in 1984. According to the water works department, the 56 MLD scheme has already become obsolete. Once the new water supply scheme is implemented, the 56 MLD scheme will be closed.

Title: Indian embassy blocks MBT chief on Twitter
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Hyderabad: Majlis Bachao Tehreek (MBT) leader and social worker Amjed Ullah Khan has written a letter to union external affairs minister, S Jaishankar about his Twitter account being blocked by the Indian embassy in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

In the letter, Khan explained that he had been highlighting the issues being faced by NRIs through his social media and had helped rescue a number of women and men stuck overseas.

In the past, Khan has highlighted the plight of Indians in distress in the Gulf. The embassy had taken notice of it to help those in distress several times. “Most of the cases pertain to the Gulf, especially to Saudi Arabia. I have been highlighting their problems through my Twitter account (@amjedmbt) and I was shocked to see that Indian Embassy in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia has blocked my Twitter account. Kindly inquire whether this act has been done intentionally to appease my political opponents or by mistake,” he said.

“Blocking anyone on official Twitter account is a violation of fundamental rights guaranteed by the constitution of India and curbs me from raising issues to solve problems,” he said. Khan also marked a copy of the letter to Dr Ausaf Sayeed, Indian ambassador to Saudi Arabia.

Title: Govt afraid of democratic protests: Chandrasekhar Azad
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chandrasekhar Azad

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Bhim Army chief Chandrasekhar Azad on Saturday said the fight against the draconian law will continue until the government withdraws the Act or till the Prime Minister and home minister resigns.

Addressing thousands of protesters who joined a march against Citizenship (Amendment) Act to Raj Bhavan organised by SDPI here on Saturday, Azad said nobody should be sent to detention camps.

According to Azad, the protest by sisters, like in Shaheen bagh , is happening in different parts of the country. “The government which is afraid of democratic protest is coming up with agendas to destroy the peaceful protest. They want the protests to be violent. We should go ahead with peaceful protest by using the privileges granted by the judiciary and Constitution. The last win will be ours,” said Azad.

Exhorting people to defend the Constitution till their last breath, Azad asked all participants to take a pledge that they would defend the Constitution. He read out the preamble of the Constitution and asked each of the participant to repeat his words before starting the speech.

The march from East Fort to Raj Bhavan which was the culmination of Kerala march organised by SDPI was inaugurated by national president M K Faizi. State president P Abdul Majeed Faizi presided over.

Chandrasekhar Azad will address a protest gathering at Kodungallur on Sunday before leaving for New Delhi.

Title: Union Budget 2020: Rs 2,487 crore kept for building country’s first RRTS project
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

A total of Rs 20,000 crore has been allocated for Mass Rapid Transit System projects, which includes all metro... Read More

NEW DELHI: In a major boost to regional connectivity in the National Capital Region , the Centre on Saturday allocated Rs 2,487 crore to the country’s first Regional Rapid Transit System ( RRTS ) in the Budget .

A total of Rs 20,000 crore has been allocated for Mass Rapid Transit System projects, which includes all metro projects across the country and the RRTS project. While Rs 2,487 has been allocated to the RRTS project, there is no separate allocation for Delhi Metro Rail Corporation, which has started work on its Phase IV project.

“Centre has provided a consolidated allocation for all metro projects and DMRC would ask for funds as per its requirement from the Union housing and urban affairs ministry, which is the nodal authority for all metro projects,” a source said.

Of the eight identified RRTS corridors to connect various NCR towns, three have been prioritised for implementation in Phase-I by the planning commission-appointed task force. “These include the Delhi-Ghaziabad-Meerut corridor, Delhi-Gurgaon-Alwar corridor and Delhi-Panipat corridor,” said a spokesperson for NCR Transport Corporation, which is mandated to implement the project.

The spokesperson added that civil construction of the 82-km Delhi-Meerut corridor is in full swing and piling and pier works are being done on the 17km priority section between Sahibabad to Duhai.

Title: Vegetarian food, beverage leave Puneites satiated
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

A man and two women, explore the delicacies; people throng the stalls at the festival at Vrindavan Lawns in Ba... Read More

PUNE: Good food, live music and a steady flow of beverages ensured Puneites had a great time at The Times of India Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest. A first-of-its-kind vegetarian food festival, Green Dot received an overwhelming response on the opening day.

The afternoon heat on Saturday failed to dampen the spirit of food lovers, who thronged Vrindavan Lawns at Baner Road to indulge in an assortment of vegetarian fare. The crowd only further swelled as the sun began to set, lending the lawn a carnival atmosphere. Live music by popular bands Malang and Fidelity kept the crowds entertained through the evening.

Food blogger Mrunmai Naikwadi said, “I am a vegetarian and I was very excited to visit Green Dot. Every cuisine has been covered here, with dishes ranging for basic vegetarian fare to some that aren’t easily available in Pune. The Bamboo Biryani and Soya Chaap were the highlight. I loved the experience and hope that more vegetarian food festivals are organized in the city. Such festivals will surely draw a lot of people as many from the city are turning vegetarian or vegan.”

Indian and international cuisines were on offer at nearly 30 stalls, including North Indian, South Indian, Indian street food, Maharashtrian, Rajasthani, Bihari, Italian, Mexican, Shawarma and much more.

The Bamboo Biryani, served by Kolhapuri Tadka, was among the showstopping dishes at the festival. Food blogger Ruchi Parekh said, “This is a new concept and I have never seen it before. The rice is filled into a hollow bamboo stick and covered using aluminium foil. The bamboo is then left to cook on charcoal. The charcoal gave the biryani a slightly smoky flavour and enhances the spices.”

Wood-fired pizzas on offer by the food truck Fire Wheels also wowed a number of patrons. “We serve only vegetarian wood-fired pizzas and are generally stationed near Blue Ridge Society at Hinjewadi. We came prepared to dish out at least 150 pizzas in three different sizes for the first day,” said Suraj Vishwasrao, owner of the food truck.

The festival also had a mixology session by Chef Gopi of Lemon Tree. A masterclass on Oriental food by Baan Tao left people spell bound. The Raw Papaya Salad prepared during the masterclass was a hit among patrons witnessing the preparations.

The Times of India Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest is powered by VTP Realty and curated by Pune Eat Outs associate sponsors are Girikand Holidays and Ranka Jewellers.

Times Green Dot Gourmet Food Fest is on at Vrindavan Lawns, Baner Road, from 11am to 10pm

Title: PMC to wait a week for traffic police NOC for infrastructure projects
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: The civic body has decided not to wait beyond seven days for a no objection certificate ( NOC ) from the traffic police for commissioning infrastructure projects on city roads.

The Pune Municipal Corporation ( PMC ), in a recent circular, instructed various departments to start the physical work of a proposed projects seven days after furnishing relevant details to the traffic police.

The civic administration said the decision was taken to avoid “unnecessary delays” while executing various infrastructure projects that required digging of roads, a PMC official said.

The corporators have been urging the administration to revise the existing guidelines related to the execution of the infrastructure projects. “Corporators cutting across party lines had during a recent general body meeting expressed concerns over the delays in execution of infrastructure projects because of non-availability the NOCs from the traffic police,” an official said.

PMC sources said it was not mandatory for the civic administration to wait for the NOCs from the traffic police to start the projects. “Until now, the administration was seeking NOCs to ensure coordination and avoid citizens’ hardships. But there have been inordinate delays in getting permission from the traffic police,” a source said.

Another PMC official said, “Heads of departments such as water supply, road development, special projects and drainage are now expected to submit details of the proposed projects, their maps, possible changes in traffic movement during such work, road digging and security plans to the zonal officers concerned of the traffic department. The departments are expected to execute the measures and start the physical work of a project after seven days from the date of submitting the plan to the traffic police.”

A senior corporator said the new arrangement was expected to streamline the civic projects and reduce people’s hardships because of factors such as road closures.

Title: Aurangabad: 3 arrested for human trafficking, rape
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The detection branch of Jinsi police have arrested three suspects, including a couple, for allegedly running an inter-state human trafficking racket that would lure gullible women on the pretext of employment with food catering services and sell them to men for marriage.

One of the suspects has been identified as Yogesh Kailash Borse, a resident of Sanjaynagar area of the city. The accused trio would be produced in a local court on Sunday.

Police said the offence was registered on Friday after a 40-year-old woman approached them saying she was sold to a man in Gujarat in 2017.

Jinsi police station’s senior inspector Vyankatesh Kendre said the suspects appear to be habitual offenders and probably would have sold several women on similar pretext.

“In this case, the suspects reached out to the woman, who is a widow, and offered her a job in catering service. They took her to Gujarat in 2017 and sold her to a man who forcefully married her.”

Worried about her teenaged daughter left behind in Aurangabad, the woman recently got her 16-year-old daughter to come to Gujarat and stay with her.

“The man, who forcefully married the widow, allegedly raped her 16-year-old daughter as well. Upon learning about it, the woman, along with her daughter, fled from Gujarat and reached Aurangabad. She later lodged a complaint with us,” Kendre said.

Based on the woman’s complaint, the suspects, including the man from Guajarat, have been booked on the charges of kidnapping for marriage, human trafficking, rape and criminal conspiracy.

In addition, the suspects have also been slapped with sections of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (POCSO).

The incident came to light only after the woman and her daughter approached the police. It was after carrying out medical test of the victims and recording their statements, the offence came to be registered around Friday midnight.

Sources said the police are collecting details about the suspects in the areas they live to get more clues about their activities.

Title: NSI signs MoU to set up sugar institute in Nigeria
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kanpur: National Sugar Institute, Kanpur and National Sugar Development Council of Nigeria signed a Memorandum Of Understanding at Abuja, Nigeria in the presence of Indian High Commissioner, Abhai Thakur.

The MoU was signed by director NSI Kanpur, professor Narendra Mohan and Dr Latif Busari, executive secretary NSDC, Nigeria.
