As per the MoU, the NSI will prepare the Detailed Project Report for setting up a sugar institute in Nigeria and in the meantime National Sugar Institute, Kanpur shall conduct faculty development programme for technical personnel from Nigeria who ultimately will conduct training programmes there.

The first batch of training for 10 Nigerian personnel is proposed from April 1, 2020. Some of the technical personnel shall also be admitted to the regular courses in sugar technology, sugar engineering, instrumentation & automation and environment science disciplines of the institute during the academic session 2020-21, said Prof Mohan. The faculty of National Sugar Institute shall also visit the sugar institute in Nigeria to deliver expert lectures and to conduct short duration training programmes, he said.

Title: Tax share of state will go up by Rs.6,000 crore
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chennai: As per the Union finance ministry’s data based on the 2020-2021 Budget , Tamil Nadu is expected to receive Rs 32,849.34 crore as part of its tax share from the Centre.

While Tamil Nadu’s share of the corporate tax for the new fiscal year will be Rs.10,104 crore -- Rs.1,193 crore more compared to last year--- it’s share of income tax will go up by Rs 1,291 crore. The income tax share of the state for the new financial year will be Rs 9,395 crore.

“As per the data, the state is expected to receive nearly Rs.6,000 crore more compared to last year. But the actual accrual may be less as there will be adjustments under CGST (Central Goods and Services Tax),” said a senior state finance department official.

"Maximum share of tax revenue for the state comes from corporate tax followed by CGST. Income tax and central excise are the other revenue sources for the states from the Centre,” said the official.

“GST revenue may increase more than what has been estimated in the budget. At present, the GST revenue collection is low, but once the economic picks up pace, we expect revenue collection to go up,” the official added.

Title: Flamingos justify wetland status for Jayakwadi
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

On the occasion of World Wetlands Day on February 2, experts have pitched for inclusion of Jayakwadi bird sanc... Read More

AURANGABAD: As the Jayakwadi bird sanctuary is yet to be considered a Ramsar site, experts have highlighted the importance of flocks of flamingos that arrive at Nathsagar during every winter season.

Nature expert Kishor Pathak said that flamingos feed on algae which only develops in wetlands, striking down the claims made by a section of forest official that Jayakwadi has deep waters and cannot be termed wetland. Flocks of flamingos and other migratory birds visit Jayakwadi bird sanctuary every year.

“The algae can grow in water bodies where sunlight penetrates to the bottom and facilitates photosynthesis. These habitats can be scientifically referred to as ideal wetlands,” he said.

On the occasion of World Wetlands Day on February 2, experts have pitched for inclusion of Jayakwadi bird sanctuary into the list of Ramsar sites.

“Jayakwadi bird sanctuary is rich not only in terms of population but also diversity of birds. Even Nandur Madhyameshwar bird sanctuary, which has received the Ramsar tag, is no match to Jayakwadi when it comes to the population of flamingos and other birds,” environmentalist Milind Giridhari said.

The Ramsar convention in 1971 defined wetlands as areas where water is the primary factor which controls the environment and the associated plant and animal life.

When contacted, a senior forest department official said Jayakwadi sanctuary was one of the shortlisted sites, when the proposal for Ramsar sites from Maharashtra was sent to the Convention on Wetlands called the Ramsar Convention.

“Parts of Jayakwadi sanctuary is a large wetland. However, the sanctuary has deep waters as we move from the banks of the reservoir towards the spillway,” he said, preferring anonymity. Forest department officials also said that Jayakwadi bird sanctuary was still in the race for Ramsar site.

Title: Accused inflicts self injury in custody
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: A man accused of stealing vehicle spare parts worth Rs 26 lakh inflicted self injury in the police custody on Friday.

The suspect, identified as Avinash Kailash Thorat (27), went to the washroom during interrogation and inflicted the injury with a glass bottle that was found, said police.

He was immediately rushed to the Government Medical College and Hospital. He was discharged after getting the first aid. Following which, an offence was registered against him with the Begumpura police station, for attempting suicide.

A police officer said that the suspect allegedly inflicted self injury to create pressure on the police and also to avoid divulging more details about the case.

The crime branch of the city police had nabbed four suspects in the case.

A mini-truck with registration number MH-20-BT-2489, loaded with about 697 boxes containing spare parts of two and three-wheeler belonging to the Bajaj Company, was stolen on January 25 from the limits of MIDC Waluj police station. The key accused used to as a driver who would transport spare parts of the company to different places.

Crime branch inspector Madhukar Sawant said that Thorat used his knowledge about the movements of vehicle from the company, to steal with the help of Dadabhau Tatyarao Khude (39) of Bakwalnagar in Nayegaon.

The stolen articles were unloaded on the premises owned by Navnath Sanjay Waghchoure (22) and Syed Khalik Syed Rashid (27), both residents of Gadhepimpalgaon, before abandoning the truck in Gangapur.

After a team led by assistant inspector Gautam Wavle nabbed the accused, they told the police where the stolen spare parts were kept. Accordingly, of the 697 boxes of spare parts, 580 were recovered from Gadhepimpalgaon.

Title: Budget push for Old Mint museum, majestic but crumbling Jadughar
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Old Mint

KOLKATA: The museum of trade and numismatics at Old Mint, which had been planned in early 90s but is yet to see the light of day, now seems to be with the realm of possibility with Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman mentioning about its allocation in her Budget speech on Saturday. Sitharaman on Saturday also mentioned about renovation of Indian Museum.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi had sowed the hopes of a complete metamorphosis of Indian Museum during his last visit to the city.

The majestic Old Mint was built in Grecian Doric style, and according to Evan Cotton , city’s most well-known chronicler, “the central portico facing the Strand was a copy of the Temple of Minerva at Athens”. Today, a tall wall of corrugated metal sheet hide the massive portico with 40 massive columns from the sight of passers-by at Posta.

The mint, located at the heart of Eastern India’s biggest trading hub, will be an ideal place for a museum because of the city’s long association with the modern currency system. The first mint of the country was built in the city inside the Old Fort William (now GPO). The Old Currency Building is where India’s first Reserve Bank operated from, said a historian.

In fact, two mints functioned there — the Silver opened in 1831 and the Copper in 1865. A PWD register recorded the value of the silver mint and bullion vault at Rs 7,35,776. It was one of the busiest mints in the world and records show that in December 1918, it produced 1,900,00 coins in one day, a world record.

Indian Museum, which underwent renovation DURING its bicentenary celebrations in 2014, has started showing signs of decay. The leaking roof and crumbling plaster paint a sorry picture. For ages, the exhibits (less than 4% of its total collection) have remained the same, though it has a massive treasure trove of Indian heritage lying as its reserve collection.

Title: Kolkata: Railway officials rue Metro silence in finance minister's speech
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Railway officials said they would have been relieved had finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman mentioned Metro p... Read More

KOLKATA: Railway officials said they would have been relieved had finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman mentioned Metro projects in Kolkata even once during her Budget speech.

“All the Metro projects in Kolkata are overdue. Neither lack of funds nor the railways is to blame for the delay, but a mention would have shown the Centre’s intent to complete them at the earliest,” a railway official said. “Bengaluru people must have felt happy when Sitharaman mentioned the Rs 18,600-crore 148km-long suburban transport project, which is important to decongest the southern city. Metro projects here are essential for faster commute. We will have to wait till Wednesday for details on the projects.”

Kolkata has five ongoing projects, two of which are nearing completion. The Metro link, which is expected to complete first is between Noapara and Dakshineswar, which will add the northern suburbs to the existing network. It will be a boon for thousands of people living in Dakshineswar, Baranagar and the Dunlop crossing, already suffering due to the closure of the Tallah Bridge. The airport link from Noapara is also nearing completion and work is in full swing for the underground yard at the Kolkata airport that promises to be the largest in the country. The airport route will be a stepping stone for the Metro’s progress towards Barasat.

“Phase-I of the East-West Metro between Sector V and Salt Lake stadium is ready and awaiting inauguration. We had expected a mention of it in the Budget speech. The cost for Phase-II between Salt Lake stadium and Howrah Maidan has also gone up due to subsidence at Bowbazar. We are waiting to see how much is allocated for the E-W Metro this year as expenses are likely to be more in 2020-21. Work for the New Garia-Airport stretch is progressing at a good pace now,” another official said.

The Joka-BBD Bag link is probably the most worrisome. Thanks to delay in land acquisition, it has not seen as much progress as it should have in the 10-odd years after its foundation was laid. The biggest hurdle for the project is non-availability of land for the Joka carshed and encroachments along the way. While 85% of the land has been acquired for the depot, work can’t start till the rest 15% are available.

Title: West Bengal: Consultants in demand after tweak in tax structure
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Saturday’s Budget left the middle-class Bengalis confused as they failed to conclude if they had gained or lost anything. Tax consultants started getting calls about this new puzzle — new slab with no deduction in personal tax or existing slab with all the deductions in tax.

Arvind Agarwal of GP Agarwal & Associate felt there was a big catch in the new tax proposal. “I personally feel the relief will be marginal but for those who are in higher slabs would get more benefit in the new regime ,” he said.

Incidentally, in the new regime, there will be no deductions for housing loan, insurance, PPF or health insurance. “Lot of people here invests in LIC. They have to take a call. There will be no leave travel allowance provision in the new regime. Considering the fact that Bengalis love to travel, this has to be taken into consideration,” he added.

According to N G Khaitan, partner of Khaitan & Company, most people with an annual income of Rs 15 lakh will opt for the new scheme. “If you see the slabs, only if one with Rs 15 lakh income can bring down his income through deductions below Rs 10 lakh will it make sense for them to remain in the old scheme,” he explained.

Leading tax consultant J S Vanzara welcomed the changes in individual tax rates. “It benefits all as many individuals may not qualify for the exemptions or deductions. So lower taxes is welcome for them,” he said. Another tax consultant, Kumarjit Das, was a bit critical about the new regime.

“High-income group will mainly benefit from the Budget announcement. The government has tried to form a Pareto efficient tax regime but in this era of stagflation, this may not be successful and may also create social insecurities,” he said.

Title: UP ATS arrests key arms supplier of Khalistan Liberation Force from Haridwar
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Haridwar/Lucknow: Uttar Pradesh Anti-Terrorism Squad (UPATS) on Saturday arrested one Ashish Singh, a key arms supplier of Khalistan Liberation Force (KLF), from Haridwar. ATS is now probing his supply channel and chains in Uttar Pradesh.

Confirming the development, Haridwar senior superintendent of police Senthil Abudai Krishna Raj S told TOI, “A wanted criminal was arrested from the Civil Line police station area in Roorkee by the UP ATS on Saturday. UP ATS has informed us about the operation and the accused was hiding in his relative’s home.”

An ATS official said that Singh has been accused in a number of cases, including attempt to murder, rioting with deadly weapons, criminal conspiracy and harbouring offender from Punjab in 2018.

Information about Singh’s movement was shared by Punjab police and passed on to UP ATS last week. An ATS official privy to the investigation said that Singh is considered to be the right hand of Gugni Grewal aka Harmeet Singh chief of KLF and a supplier of weapons to the force. Singh also has a role in the murder of RSS and Shiv Sena worker. He added that after the murder of KLF chief on January 27, 2020, in Pakistan, Punjab police traced one Sukhpreet Singh of Monga in Punjab. Later, on his identification Singh was traced.

ADG ATS DK Thakur said that Singh was named in other cases, including illegal sale of liquor. “He came in touch with KLF chief while he was in Patiala jail. Singh had also supplied 10 pistols of various bores to KLF chief. We are tracing Singh’s links and his channel of procurement of weapons,” he said, adding that a hunt is on to locate his associates in Uttar Pradesh.

Sources said that his call details have been scanned and it also revealed some numbers from Pakistan.

Title: Loan defaulter dupes fin firm, ‘sells’ impounded MUV to many
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pune: The Chandannagar police on Friday booked a man from Yerawada on the charges of duping a finance company of Rs6 lakh by not repaying the loan he had taken to buy a multi-utility vehicle (MUV) and selling the impounded car to several people across the state.

The police said the man, aged around 33, was booked following a complaint registered by Dada Shaikh (40) of Wagholi working with the finance firm as an officer.

“The man had taken the loan from the finance company’s Yerawada office in May 2011 and purchased the MUV. He paid the equated monthly instalment (EMI) for the first few months and then discontinued. After a few months, the finance company impounded the vehicle. But the man managed to take it away on the promise of repaying the loan,” an officer from the Chandannagar police said.

The officer said the man then put up a number plate bearing the registration number of the Beed RTO and also obtained a no objection certificate (NOC) from the office. “We suspect he had secured the NOC by submitting fake documents. He has since taken money from several people across the state on the pretext of selling the car, but never delivered it,” the officer said.

The officer said the complaint was lodged on Friday after the finance company traced the vehicle to Beed district, nearly after nine years.

“They are in the process of seizing the vehicle. Our investigation is also on” the officer added.

Title: Govt says anganwadi workers won’t be sacked over protest
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Haridwar: The government on Saturday went on the back foot and assured that anganwadi workers will not lose their jobs over protesting. The state informed that the job termination notices issued to them will be withdrawn and a decision regarding their demands will be taken on Tuesday (February 4).

Dehradun Cantt MLA Harbans Kapoor spoke with state minister of women and child welfare Rekha Arya on Saturday on behalf of the anganwadi workers, who have been protesting since early December for better pay and job perks.

Aanganwadi workers had planned to conduct a major rally on Saturday in Dehradun but held it off, hoping the meeting on Tuesday will yield some results.

“The entire state’s anganwadi workers were upset with the notices and we had all geared up for a mass rally. However, the government has finally given us assurance,We are hopeful that at least now our demands will be met,” said Vimla Kohli, vice-president, Aanganwari worker’s union, Uttarakhand.

Title: Seer Padmavati slaps Rs 100 crore notice on Dehradun doctors who called her ‘pregnant’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Padmavati said that these comments were made to mentally torture her and assassinate her character

HARIDWAR: Seer Padmavati has slapped Rs 100 crore notice on two Doon Hospital doctors who allegedly said that she is two-month pregnant. The statements were allegedly made when she was forcibly taken to the hospital by city police for a check-up on Thursday night.

She claimed that Dr Vijay Bhandari, who attended her, said that she was vomiting due to pregnancy and CMO Meenakshi Joshi accused her of not leading a celibate life despite being a sadhvi. Padmavati said that these comments were made to mentally torture her and assassinate her character.

“Padmavati has been fasting for nearly two months and no urine test proved her pregnancy. So, how can her pregnancy report come positive all of a sudden,” asked Swami Shivanand Saraswati, head of Matri Sadan. Padmavati’s notice gives seven days to the doctors to either plead guilty or face legal action.

Meanwhile, both the doctors claimed they made no such accusations. “Her mensuration cycle was irregular. So, a pregnancy test had to be done to rule out its possibility. But no one said anything even close to what she is claiming. The entire incident has been video-taped,” said Dehradun CMO Meenakshi Joshi.

Dr Bhandari also denied making any such statement. “I did not say anything related to her pregnancy and she was treated like any other patient,” said Bhandari.

Title: Union Budget 2020: People find new IT regime taxing, but infrastructure and health are bright spots
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Income tax rates have been lowered but the salaried class appears confused over two parallel tax slab structures . Taxpayers are apprehensive about the possible rebates in the new regime. TOI spoke to a cross-section of people in the capital to gauge their mood about the Union Budget and its key provisions.Rejimon CK from Dwarka said the Budget will put additional burden on the salaried and the middle class. “People were initially happy on hearing about the lower tax rates, but their joy didn’t last long due to the removal of exemptions. They are going back to the old slabs that have exemptions. They may be talking about no harassment tax charter, but in reality inspectors have to be dealt with,” he added.The Dwarka resident also wanted the government to declare the amount of tax being paid by people indirectly through Goods and Services Tax. “People will prefer the old system rather than taking a risk,” he said.Ratnesh Tiwari, 40, a stockbroker at Barakhamba Road, said that while the market was expecting radical reforms, the Budget did not offer many reasons to cheer about. “Besides re-jigging of tax slabs, there is nothing new in it to boost the country’s economic growth. The economy will more or less continue on the same trajectory,” he added.Faizullah Ahrar, 43, who also works in the financial sector, said that two parallel tax structures will lead to several complications. “This will do more harm than good as far as simplifying the tax structure is concerned. Removal of exemptions might even nullify the tax cuts,” he added.“The government says that people should be able to file taxes without any hassles. But the taxpayers will now have to run to chartered accountants for clarity on exemptions. No big announcement for Delhi was disappointing,” Krishna Nagar resident BS Vohra said, adding that the Budget should have also addressed the pollution concerns.Sanjay Bhargav, head of Chandni Chowk Sarv Vyapar Mandal, however, said the infrastructure push may provide the necessary impetus for the revival of economy. “If money is spent on infrastructure, the whole cycle will get rejuvenated as more cash will flow into the market,” he said.The women TOI spoke to were not too optimistic about the benefits of the allocated funds reaching them. “We as women do not feel safe in the city. The Budget is only a gimmick for the government to gather additional votes. No matter how much money is allotted for women’s security, nothing much will change on the ground,” said Manju, a banker.Her colleague, Poonam, said, “We were in office when we heard the Budget speech. There was nobody who was much satisfied with it. The taxpayers are now confused as the slabs have been mixed up. We will have to study them in depth.”However, the increased allocation for the health sector was appreciated by people. “There is a lot that needs to be done to improve the health sector. Hopefully, some changes might be made with the increased budgetary allocation,” said SK Bakshi, a working professional.

Title: Hindu group to hold fast against CAA
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kozhikode: Hindu Dharma Samrakshana Samithi will organize a day-long fasting at Mukkam on Monday to protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), which is ‘divisive’ in nature.

Kapyedath Chandran, chairman of the Samithi, said that the fasting is being organized to dispel the notion that all Hindus support CAA. “In fact, majority in the community is against the Act that divides the people of the country. Plurality is the basis of Indian culture as evident in different verses from the Vedas,” Chandran said.

He said according to Hinduism, it is a sin to show discrimination towards any religious group or persons. “It is anti-Hindu to allow citizenship on the basis of religion. We demand the government to withdraw the Act that has created anxiety and mistrust,” Chandran said.

Swami Vishwa Bhadrananda Shakthi Bodhi, Fr Jacob Puthenpurakkal, KPCC vice-presdient T Siddique, general secretary N Subramanian, IUML state vice-president C Moyinkutty, state secretary C P Cheriya Muhammed, Muslim Youth League state vice-president Najeeb Kanthapuram and others will attend the programme.

Title: Pune: No water, residents lock civic officials
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Angry over lack of water supply for nearly four days, residents of Kasarwadi locked senior officials of the civic body’s water supply department in a room for four hours on Saturday.

"There was no water supply in Kasarwadi in the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation area on Wednesday due to alternate day closure. On Thursday, water supply was shut down. Again, on Friday, there was no water due to alternate day closure. As there was no water supply on Saturday morning, the residents burst into anger and locked the officials in a room of the elevated storage reservoir,” said BJP corporator Asha Shedge, who led the residents of her ward in protest.

"I called water supply department chief Makrand Nikam, joint city engineer Ramdas Tambe, executive engineer Pravin Ladkat and other local officials to the spot. They assured that water supply would start at 10am, but in vain. So, the residents decided to lock the officials till the water supply resumes.”

Meanwhile, municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar assured her that the water supply would be restored at 4pm and requested that the officials be released. The officials were released around 2.30pm.

The water supply finally resumed around 4 pm, officials said.

Title: Army playing role to check coronavirus, says General Manoj Naravane
Content:
Chief of Army Staff Manoj Mukund Naravane was the Chief Guest for Bicentenary Commemomration Parade of Bombay ... Read More

PUNE: Chief of Army Staff General Manoj Naravane on Saturday said the Indian Army is playing its role to contain the spread of coronavirus.The Army set up a quarantine facility on Friday at Manesar near Gurugram to monitor the 300-odd Indian students who were evacuated from China after the outbreak."Coronavirus has gained global proportions and we all view it as a major threat. All nations must come together to put in all possible measures to contain this threat in the best possible way and keep it at the lowest level. The army is playing its part,” he said.General Naravane, who is also the honorary Colonel Commandant of the Bombay Engineering Group (BEG) popularly known as Bombay Sappers, was talking to reporters on the sidelines of the bicentenary celebration of the group at Khadki.He said future warfare will technical and network centric. "We will have to keep adapting to the changing nature of warfare. Engineers will have a major role in construction of bridges, barracks and roads. They will have to absorb new technologies and move with the times," he said. General Naravane said "capacity and capability building" is an ongoing process and “we will continue improving upon it”.He reviewed the bicentenary commemoration parade at the end of the four-day celebrations at the drill square at the centre.For the first time, troops of the Bombay Sappers, Sikh Light Infantry and Maratha Light Infantry regiments marched together in the commemoration parade to symbolise their affiliation with the sappers. Sukhoi aircraft from 30 Squadron based in Lohegaon gave a flypast.Rajeshwari Rane, widow of Param Vir Chakra awardee Rama Raghoba Rane, handed over his medal to General Naravaneon Saturday. It will be kept at the centre.

Title: Auto driver bludgeoned to death; two detained
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A man (23) and his minor friend were detained on Saturday night, less than 24 hours after an autorickshaw driver (27) was bludgeoned to death near the leprosy hospital in Yeolewadi late on Friday night.

A resident of the area found the body on Saturday morning and alerted the city police control room. A team from the Kondhwa police rushed to the spot and identified the deceased as Bunty alias Akshay Suresh Gaikwad of Yeolewadi.

The victim’s body was found under a tree near the cattle shed adjacent to the hospital. Gaikwad died because of multiple head injuries. The motive behind the murder is still unclear.

Investigations revealed that Gaikwad and his two friends used to sit under the tree and consume liquor. Police suspect that his friends attacked him with a stick and stone over a dispute while consuming alcohol because his blood stain was found on them.

The victim’s identity was not known initially but the residents of the area helped the police identify him as there were no injury marks on his face. The victim’s brother, Amit Gaikwad (32), has lodged an FIR.

A police team led by assistant inspector Chetan More, under senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad and inspector Mahadeo Kumbhar, have fanned teams for arresting the two friends.

Title: Life, health covers may lose lure as sops turn optional
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Sales of life and health insurance policies, which qualify for income tax breaks, are expected to take a big hit because of the new simplified income tax regime announced in the Union Budget. Tax savings, which was the biggest driver for life insurance , has lost relevance for many as the budget allows taxpayers to pay tax at a much lower rate if they forego exemptions.

“Most middle-class taxpayers will see this as -- lower tax slab, less paperwork. These will become the key motivations. Very few people take life insurance purely for protection - most view it as a savings or investment instrument. Now with that clear incentive gone, there will be a dip,” said a CGM from LIC.

Insurers feel that this a major setback because insurance penetration in India is low compared to other countries. Stocks on insurance companies fell following the budget announcement.

Every March 31st, it was common for staff members to work late into the night at LIC offices across India. Insurance agents would scurry around pressing LIC officers to take their last-minute proposals - as thousands of Indians tried to file for tax exemptions just before the deadline. But this might change this year, said sources.

IRDAI officials said they were completely taken aback by the Union Finance Minister’s budget announcement. “We were certainly not consulted on this. And it will have a negative impact on the sector,” said an IRDAI member. “But it is still early days. But, I have hope as the FM had a press conference following the budget announcement - and there she did mention the savings aspect.”

“Life insurance and health insurance will take a massive hit. Now that the tax benefit has become optional. While we will retain our older clientele, youngsters might decide to trade in financial security for more cash in hand,” said the LIC CGM.

Insurers say insurance was always a push product and now with the key incentive “tax” being removed not many might think of financial protection and fiscal prudence. “In India, the construct has always nudged future savings and risk management by encouraging conscious investment towards the same aided by tax relief. We have not seen announcements that will encourage risk management practices, ” said RM Vishakha, MD & CEO, IndiaFirst Life Insurance.

Institutions also say higher spending income should not have come at the cost of savings. “The option to individuals to opt for a lower tax slab structure with no deductions or to continue with the earlier higher slabs with deductions for home loan EMIs, investments in insurance etc seems slightly confusing. In a country like India with a young population with poor social security it is imperative to incentive young India to save for the future and own a house as well,” said Krishna Kumar Karwa , managing director, Emkay Global Financial Services .

Title: Saina Nehwal’s call to join BJP not right, says Syeda Falak
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

CHARMINAR: International karate champion Syeda Falak said that the decision taken by Saina Nehwal to join BJP was not right, especially at a time when there was an unprecedented show of resistance against the party across the country, over Citizenship (Amendment) Act.

“Saina Nehwal should have thought before joining BJP,” said Syeda, during a press conference at her residence here on Saturday. She also said that a protest meeting by women against CAA, NPR and NRC would be held in Old City on February 3. She added that the police had granted permission for the protest, provided the number of participants is not over 1,500.

Title: Maharashtra: IMD hints at rise in night temperature after February 6
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The minimum temperatures in north Madhya Maharashtra, including the city, may surge after February 6.The latest extended range forecast of India Meteorological Department (IMD) said north central Madhya Maharashtra was expected to bear the brunt of high minimum temperatures for at least a week after February 6. This winter, Madhya Maharashtra has been witnessing a trend of consecutive weeks of marginally higher than normal minimum temperatures.The extended range forecast indicated that from January 31-February 6, night temperatures were likely to remain below normal during a few days over major parts of India, including Maharashtra outside coastal and south interior Karnataka, south Andhra Pradesh and interior Tamil Nadu, where normal to above-normal night temperatures are likely to prevail on some of the days during the week. It indicated that in terms of minimum temperatures, the week from February 7 to 13 in general was likely to be warmer than the week January 31-February 6. Near-normal to 2-3 degrees below-normal minimum temperatures were likely to prevail over major parts of India at least for a few days during February 7-13, except coastal and south interior Karnataka, Rayalaseema and north Madhya Maharashtra, where above-normal minimum temperatures were likely to occur during some of the days, the forecast said.Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD, Pune said, “The extended range forecast shows a white and orange patch of higher than normal minimum temperatures in north and central Madhya Maharashtra as well as central Konkan during the upcoming week after February 6. The white to orange patch on the extended range forecast map is indicative of night temperatures that are normal to marginally higher than normal by 1-3°C in the region. The other regions in the state are showing purplish colour on the map, indicating normal to below-normal minimums there during that period.”Kashyapi said there might be a slight rise in night temperatures in Maharashtra from February 2 to 4, while there would be significant fall in night temperatures, especially over north Maharashtra, on February 5.“Thereafter, the minimums will start rising gradually. Around February 5-6, there would be a re-emergence of northerly wind flow via the northern parts of Maharashtra, especially through north Madhya Maharashtra and adjacent areas of Konkan, Marathwada and east Vidarbha, resulting in drop in minimums in these regions during those days,” he said.For full report, log on to www.timesofindia.com

Title: Bhopal: Private schools directed not to sell books, uniforms, bags in schools
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Photo used for representational purpose only

BHOPAL: Before the start of the new academic session , divisional commissioner Kalpana Shrivastava has directed all CBSE and ICSE schools to upload the list of the textbooks prescribed by them, on their school websites. Schools have also been asked to abide by the by-laws of both the boards and refrain from selling books , notebooks, uniforms and bags on the school campuses.

“If the schools do not make the book lists available on their websites and are found guilty of flouting the CBSE and ICSE by-laws that clearly state that no school should engage in selling of books, bags, uniforms etc. on their campuses or direct parents to particular shops to buy the books, affiliation and NOCs of those schools may be cancelled by the state,” said Shrivastava.

Directorate of Public Instruction (DPI) had also issued a circular in December, directing schools to upload online the book list prescribed in the curriculum. Till January 31, 12 schools of the city had not done the same. Joint director Rajeev Tomar said the department will issue show-cause notices to the schools that failed to do so. “As per the orders, the DPI can also cancel the affiliation and NOC of the schools that do not submit the list of books to DPI even after issuing a showcause notice. We will take strict action against private schools that ask the parents to buy the books from a particular shop,” added Tomar.

The order issued by Shrivastava also directs schools to only use notebooks of the standard size and not ask students to buy different size notebooks bearing the school emblems to benefit a particular shop or individual. Notebooks, uniforms, ties, belts, blazers etc. should not have monograms and symbols for publicity of the school. Students should not be compelled to purchase a particular brand or size of notebook. Schools have been told to put up a sample of the uniform a month before the new academic session so that parents of the students can get the uniform as per their convenience.

Title: Maharashtra: Fake railway recruitment racket member in net
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A man from Sangli was arrested and five others were booked on Saturday for their involvement in railway recruitment scam.

The Government Railway Police (GRP) took Vishwajit Shivajirao Mane (52) in custody at Pune station and launched a hunt with the Railway Protection Force (RPF) for the kingpin of the recruitment scam gang.

RPF inspector Ashwin Kumar said, “The prime suspect was arrested in many cheating cases earlier. He frequently changes his address. It is suspected that he is currently based in Delhi.”

Mane and the other suspects in the case promised unemployed youths jobs in different government departments, including Indian Railways. “They presented themselves as railway authorities, used computers to fill up forms, and issued OTPs and joining letters to victims after conducting medical tests,” he said.

Kumar said one Kailash Sanjay Jadhav (24) of Latur on Friday morning walked into the office of the Divisional Railway Manager (DRM), Pune, met a few officials and showed them a (bogus) joining letter issued against his name by the Indian Railways. “On close verification, the letter was found to be fake,” Kumar said.

Jadhav then filed a complaint at the GRP station, Pune. He had allegedly already paid Rs3.5 lakh to the suspects for the job of a junior clerk. “The authorities laid down a trap near the Pune railway station. When Mane came down to Pune on Saturday to collect the remaining amount of Rs50,000 from Jadhav, he was nabbed,” Kumar said.

He said Mane had met the prime suspect when he visited Delhi on a business trip about four years ago. Mane joined the racket after the prime suspect said he was associated with the Union home ministry. “Police recovered a fake ID proof from Mane mentioning that he is a member of a railway committee,” Kumar said.

Title: Ramsar status may rid Nashik sanctuary of illegal activities
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Cormorants

AURANGABAD: Nashik ’s Nandur Madhyameshwar bird sanctuary becoming the first Ramsar site in Maharashtra has given hope to nature lovers and experts who are of the view that the coveted international tag would help in scientific conservation of the wetland.

Local area development committee Chapadgaon, which supervises the bird sanctuary along with the forest department officials, said that the Ramsar tag would help in addressing sensitive issues such as keeping watch on the wetland farming and fishing inside the sanctuary. Authorities also said that the international tag would help in demarcating the boundaries of the sanctuary and ensure proper protection of birds and other creatures there.

A recent spot visit to Nandur Madhyameshwar sanctuary by TOI revealed the cultivation of sugar cane among other crops as a part of the wetland farming inside some parts of the sanctuary, posing a risk to migratory and other birds due to use of pesticides, insecticides and other chemicals.

Amol Darade, who heads the local area development committee, Chapadgaon, said curbs on wetland farming inside the sanctuary was a sensitive issue and it would get resolved amicably due to Ramsar tag for the sanctuary.

“Different contrary claims are made by the locals and the government authorities when it comes to keeping watch on the wetland farming. While authorities are duty-bound to conserve the natural habitat, locals oppose to any objection to wetland farming as it would snatch their livelihood. These long-pending disputes could see an end as the sanctuary is under the international focus,” he said.

Besides wetland farming, Nandur Madhyameshwar sanctuary also witnesses fishing activity by a section of locals throughout out the year, except occasional days when the flow of visitors is high. The birds often getting caught in the nets used by fishermen, say locals.

Situated in the shallow backwaters of Nandur Madhyameshwar dam from Niphad taluka , Nandur Madhyameshwar sanctuary officially came into existence in 1986 and believed to be homes to different variety of birds including different Ibis, ducks, cormorants, egrets, herons, stork, kites, vultures, buzzards, harriers, osprey, quails, eagles and water Hens along with other creatures.

“The exact area on which spread of the sanctuary has taken place is yet to be ascertained against established official claims. It has to be defined officially after taking out of consideration the wetland farming inside the wetland. Such attempts could not materialize in past, but could yield success shortly,” members of local area development committee said.

Range forest officer BR Dhakare said that the Ramsar tag will ensure the scientific conservation of Nandur Madhyameshwar sanctuary by involving locals. “The international tag would help in addressing some of the pressing issues. We expect more avenues of funds and resources for the scientific conservation of the sanctuary. The employment opportunities are bound to increase further in the area as the tourist footfall including that of foreigners, is bound to increase in the future,” he said.

The number of Ramsar sites in India has now increased to 37 and the surface area covered by these sites is now 1,067,939 hectares.

Title: DSCL to take feedback from Doonites
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Dehradun: After city’s civic body, Dehradun Smart City Limited (DSCL) will also take feedback from residents. During the drive, set to start from Sunday, the locals will be asked to give their feedback regarding civic issues. The feedback of Doonites would be taken into account while formulating plans for Smart City and other such projects. “Doon residents will be asked questions on healthcare facilities, road, and other smart city parameters. This is an online survey, so officials won’t be going door-to-door to take feedback,” Ashish Bhatgain, additional CEO of DSCL, told TOI.

He added that Dehradun, despite being selected for the Smart City project in the third round, has climbed up to the 19th spot from 99th. “I thank all Doonites as they have played a crucial role in this,” Bhatgain said.

Title: Duo killed, one injured in accident
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pune: Two men lost their lives and their friend suffered severe injuries after their motorcycle was knocked from the rear by a container truck near Bhakti-Shakti Chowk in Nigdi around 10.30pm on Friday. The trio were driving triple seat without helmets.

The Dehu Road police have identified the deceased as Saudagar Londhe (27) and Aishmohammed Khan (27) of More Vasti in Chikhali. Their friend Dnyaneshwar Kamble (27) is undergoing treatment at a private hospital in Nigdi.

“Londhe and Khan came under the wheels of the truck and died on spot,” an officer said.

Motorist dies in crash

Aitque Ahmed Mohammed Rafique Shaikh was killed after his motorcycle skidded and crashed into a truck in Susgaon around 9.15pm on Thursday.

An officer of the Hinjewadi police said, “Shaikh was wearing a helmet. The post-mortem report revealed that he died of internal injuries.”

Title: Uttarakhand: Leopard sighting triggers panic in Rudrapur
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

RUDRAPUR: The sighting of a leopard near residential areas of the city has triggered panic among the residents. The residents of Fauji Matkota, Chhatarpur, Bhura Rani, and collectorate premises have reportedly sighted a leopard during night time in the past couple of days.

The adult feline has also been captured by the CCTV camera installed in a house. The forest officials are combing the area and meanwhile the locals have been deterred from entering collectorate premises during night time.

Title: HC notice for neglect of Satna monuments
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh high court has issued contempt notice to the director of the state archaeology department over failure to comply with its order pertaining to protection of monuments around the ‘Ram Van Gaman Path’ site in Satna district.

“The government has failed to notify five locations around Sarbhanga ashram in Satna as protected sites even as illegal miners continue to plunder rare artefacts dating back to 10th and 11th Century BC, which are buried near an ashram in Chitrakoot, which bears Lord Ram’s footprints during his 14-year exile,” said advocate Nithyanand Mishra, who had been taking up this issue for long.

As per the provisions of the Section 3 of Madhya Pradesh Ancient Monuments, Archaeological Sites and Remains Act, 1963, notification should be issued within two months of issuance of the first notice.

The government had in 2016 decided to notify five locations around Sarbhanga ashram as a protected site by invoking powers of the 1963 Act, and the state’s culture department had said the area would be declared ‘state protected monument’ after two months from date of issue of the notice on May 26. Once notification is issued under section 3(1) of the said Act, a final notification has to be issued within next two months.

“I had filed an RTI in the archaeology department seeking information on expenditures incurred on protecting the said monuments and the reply was ‘nil’. It is for this reason that I am perusing this matter,” Mishra told TOI.

“Both Congress and BJP were talking about ‘Ram Van Gaman Path’ during elections and now I can’t see anyone around,” Mishra added.

A study by the state’s archaeology department had pressed panic buttons regarding the loot of relics in Satna district. The area is rich in bauxite, laterite and ochre. Sources said many antiques on Sanwar hill, where Sarbhanga ashram is located, have been stolen and smuggled out during mining operations in the last five years. Several idols have also been damaged due to the use of heavy mining machinery and the damaged ones were found abandoned.

The epic legacy around another hillock near Sarbhanga ashram known as ‘Siddha Pahar’, where Lord Ram vowed to eliminate demons and spent nearly 12 years of exile, has almost vanished following illegal mining. The area is spread across 100 acres of land. Sanwar and Siddha Pahar are located within a 2-kilometre radius.

On August 17, 2015, the high court had ordered the state’s archaeology department to study in detail ‘Ram Van Gaman Path’ in the three months and conserve sites of archaeological importance. According to the report, some ancient idols were damaged during mining. This study was ordered by a division bench of the high court, while hearing a petition alleging that no inquiry or study has been conducted and these sites are not declared as protected.

Title: FDI in higher education can stop brain drain with better facilities here
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The news of the introduction of foreign direct investment in higher education has kindled hope for a turnaround in the sector. A greater financial flow can boost research and development, help hire good teachers and introduce courses matching market requirements.

The government will, however, have to put in place a regulatory mechanism and mention the clearances required for the investments. “The FDI will be a shot in the arm for higher education institutes that can upgrade themselves to world-class standards. It will also aid research and development and encourage technological innovations,” said Pradeep Chopra, chairman of iLead University.

Many meritorious students leave the country for higher studies, dealing a double blow to domestic institutions as well as the economy. FDI is likely to solve the problem to a large extent. “We need a massive investment to boost infrastructure and remove financial constraints in the sector. With adequate flow of funds, universities can set up facilities to nurture talents,” said Dhrubajyoti Chattopadhyay, Amity University VC.

Other announcements by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman also invited praises. “The increase in the outlay for higher education this year sends a signal that the sector is on the priority list. It will renew focus on student entrepreneurship and internship,” said Meghdut RoyChowdhury, director, global operations, Techno India Group. Sardar Taranjit Singh, JIS Group MD said, “For innovations and better teachers, we need higher financial inflow. We can set up advanced labs, aimed at exchange programmes.”

Title: Development of the society is key, says RSS chief Bhagwat
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat

Bhopal: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS) chief Mohan Bhagwat said that India is not merely geography but a habit. Speaking at the inaugural ceremony of the three-day ‘Yuva Sankalp Shivir’ held in Guna, Bhagwat said, “The footprints of our culture are found all over the world and it is India’s responsibility to guide the world”.

Senior RSS office-bearers Ashok Sohni and Satish Pimpalkar were also present during the event. More than 1,000 youths from 16 districts across Madhya Pradesh are taking part in the event.

Bhagwat said the country does not require a politician, but a dedicated leader who can bring about change in the society. “No nation can progress without development of its society”, he said.

“Today, everyone wants to be on the forefront as a leader, which is not right. There are people who work silently for the progress of the country as a foundation stone and spend their whole life for the purpose. We don’t even know their name, but today out country is progressing because of them and their selfless efforts. We all should try to be like them for a better cause,” Bhagwat said.

“Many of us have developed a very wrong habit of getting everything without self-participation,” the RSS supremo added. Bhagwat visited Guna after a gap of 16 years, said sources.

“The concept of ‘Yuva Sankalp Shivir’ enables the RSS to directly get in touch with the young masses. The Sangh is focusing on students who have passed Class 12 and are pursuing degree courses. The idea is to give young minds the right direction and motto in life,” said a RSS worker.

Title: Pune: Internships in civic projects for engineering students
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Urban local bodies across India wiil provide internships to fresh engineers for up to one year

PUNE: Several ongoing infrastructure projects, technology upgradation and smart city projects of civic bodies will provide internship opportunities to engineering students .

The Union Budget 2020 includes a proposal to start a programme whereby urban local bodies across the country would provide internship opportunities to fresh engineers for up to one year.

Representatives of engineering colleges said that students would be able to contribute to the city’s infrastructure development through the initiative.

The All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) too had suggested a move in the same direction nearly two years ago.

Chairman of ASM Educational Group Sandeep Pachpande said, “Throughout last year, we came across a number of reports suggesting the skill inadequacy of our graduate students when it comes to performing at the workplace and the implications were quite alarming. This initiative will not only help graduates get involved in the development of the society and enrich their knowledge through hands-on experience, but it will also lead to the infusion of a technologically proficient generation into the system that will give birth to fresh ideas.”

Pachpande further said that he hoped the same privilege would also be extended to other fields of study in the near future.

Additional municipal commissioner Rubal Agarwal shared, “The engineering students will definitely be an asset for the local bodies. There are so many ongoing development projects in every local body. The students will be able to understand and take in information related to these projects. Their skills and knowledge could also be utilized by the municipal corporations, so it will be a give-and-take process.”

Local bodies take on numerous public programmes yet they often lack the proper manpower. The one-year internship could help students plan their future and their careers in a better fashion, said Agarwal.

Title: One more isolated to rule out coronavirus in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: One more China-returned traveller presenting flu-like symptoms was isolated at the civic-run Naidu hospital on Saturday to rule out novel coronavirus infection With this, the number of individuals currently under the isolation facility in Pune has gone up to six. Samples of the previous five isolated individuals have tested negative for the virus.“The newly isolated traveller is a 30-year-old man. His throat swab sample will be sent to the National Institute of Virology,” Ramchandra Hankare, chief of the health department at the Pune Municipal Corporation, said.

Title: Raw deal: Centre cuts Madhya Pradesh’s share by Rs 14,000 crore
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Madhya Pradesh’s share in Union Budget in the form of central taxes has been cut by Rs 14,000 crore

BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh ’s share in Union Budget in the form of central taxes has been cut by Rs 14,000 crore. It would directly hit the state budget to be presented in a month.

The state would get Rs 49,000 crore against Rs 63,000 crore. Officials said it is unprecedented since the amount is even lesser than what the state got last year, which was Rs 55,000 crore.

State finance minister Tarun Bhanot said Narendra Modi government did step motherly treatment with MP. It would impact the people of the state including farmers, he added.

Officials of state finance department pointed that MP’s share was cut by Rs 14,233 crore in the Budget. MP got Rs 49,517 crore as central taxes in Union Budget as against the estimated amount of Rs 63,750 crore announced for MP in the interim budget in February last year. It was cut down to Rs 61,073 crore in the budget tabled in July and further slashed down sharply.

The Rs 14,233 crore cut in the Budget is unprecedented and has happened for the first time. On an average one to two thousand crores were cut or added going by the past records. In the previous budget MP got around Rs 55,000 crore from the centre that has been brought down by Rs 6,000 crore this time, officials said, adding that the amount is final and no room for any add on.

Process to finalize the state budget is underway and finance department collected the demand of money from the departments. The allocation against the demand was not done as the finance department was waiting to get picture of the allocation the state gets from the centre clear. Based on the state’s share cut down by the centre, the finance department would also have to slash the demand of departments.

It would mean closing of a number of running government schemes, besides, taking other steps to meet the state’s demand.

Normally, there is an increase of 15 to 20% in state budget every year, but this year there would be no increase and the departments willing to start new schemes would have to first close the existing ones.

The Kamal Nath-led Congress government had in July presented its first budget for the financial year 2019-20. It was worth Rs 2,33,605 crore, an increase in appropriation by 20%. The previous year budget for 2018-19, presented by the then BJP government was of Rs 2,04,642.44 crore.

Title: Cash-strapped cantts rue allocation slash
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pune: Cantonment boards across the country now have an uphill task on the financial front following an allocation of around Rs382 crore in the 2020-21 Union Budget for the Defence Estates Organisation, a sharp drop from Rs497.15 crore in the previous fiscal.

The boards in Maharashtra — Pune, Khadki, Dehu Road, Ahmednagar, Aurangabad, Deolali and Kamptee — will be even more affected, because the cantonments are not recognized as urban local bodies under the state’s tax laws, GST or otherwise.

A senior Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) official on Saturday said it has barely Rs6 crore left to spend and its administration is worried about paying salaries from February. The other 18 boards under Southern Command, which included Secunderabad, have also been struggling with their finances. These areas have lagged behind their adjacent municipal areas in recent years in terms of development.

During a meeting of the PCB in January, Pune MP Girish Bapat had referred to the cantonment boards as “a relic from the British era” and favoured their abolition. The Indian Army had previously ordered a feasibility study for transferring the civilian areas in the cantonments to adjacent municipal bodies. The Army continues to operate and maintain the military areas.

A senior official of the PCB, one of the largest cantonments in the country, conceded that the finances were “precarious enough” for them to stop almost all development of infrastructure, “with captive revenue sources becoming limited”.

Another PCB official said the budgetary share would translate into even lesser on ground, as the Defence Estates Organisation allocation “is meant for cantonment boards, as well as defence land both inside and outside the boards’ jurisdictions, and requisition and hiring of immovable properties for defence purposes”.

“The only project going on is a multi-level parking space. But we are not able to make regular payments to the contractor. We only have money to pay the salaries for February. For all practical purposes, we are a municipal body. It is defined so in the Cantonments Act and the Central GST Act, but not in the state law. As a result, we are not getting GST funds,” the official told TOI.

When he headed the Southern Command, Army vice chief Lt Gen S K Saini had written to CM Uddhav Thackeray in January, seeking GST funds for the cantonments in the state. Despite multiple appeals over the years, the reclassification has not happened.

“I plan to file a PIL in court so that the state government gives funds to us,” PCB member Atul Gaikwad said.

Title: Maharashtra planned to link medical colleges, district hospitals in 2018
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, in her Union Budget speech, has proposed setting up medical colleges in existing state-run district hospitals under the public private partnership (PPP) model to address the shortage of doctors.The Maharashtra government had the same idea two years ago. In a gazette notification issued on January 24, 2018, the state had allowed private medical colleges to make use of state-run district hospitals for teaching purposes. The state, through this decision, had aimed to improve patient-care services at district hospitals by tackling the problem of insufficient doctors.“The government wanted to go the Gujarat way, where all district or civil hospitals are run on a PPP basis,” a senior official of the state public health department said.However, the plan — mainly aimed at districts that had state-run hospitals but no colleges — found little traction.“We didn’t get any response. Medical Council of India requirements to run a medical college, such as a requisite patient-load and qualified human resources, were the sticking points,” Tatyarao Lahane, director of the Department of Medical Education and Research (DMER), saidIn Maharashtra, a number of districts — such as Satara, Hingoli, Buldana and Amravati — have state-run district hospital facilities, but no medical college. “If a private agency had approached us, we would have considered allowing them to use our district hospital for teaching purposes. But nothing happened. The project has remained on paper,” a senior state health official said.A senior professor of a medical college said qualified manpower was the biggest hurdle that rendered the plan ineffective. “A medical officer of a district hospital can be inducted as a lecturer or an associate professor, based on experience. But what about professors? Apart from adequate experience, one has to have at least four research publications to his/her name to be eligible. Medical officers and consultants hardly fulfil this norm,” the professor said.
