Title: IISER Pune, C-DAC join quantum technology mission
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Indian Institute of Science Education and Research, Pune

PUNE: The city-based Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC) and the Indian Institute of Science Education and Research (IISER), Pune, will be involved in the National Mission on Quantum Technologies and Applications (QTA).

The mission received an outlay of Rs 8,000 crore for five years in the Union budget presented on Saturday.

Among the four verticals of this mission, IISER and C-DAC would be contributing to quantum sensor and metrology and quantum computing & simulations.

Some everyday applications of quantum technology will be autonomous vehicle navigation, weather prediction, transportation planning, pharmaceutical development, secure financial communications, and resource exploration.

On a day-to-day basis, the technology would help improve the accuracy in navigation by using atomic clock, have secure banking transactions by encrypting the data, and in healthcare sector the technology would help to map tiny magnetic fields in the brain.

Director general of C-DAC Hemant Darbari said they had sent inputs and a detailed plan along with other members on the aspects of quantum technology, algorithm, communication and cryptology. “We will be actively participating in the quantum simulation and computational part of the mission,” he added.

Darbari said the mission aims at harnessing the potential of QTA and keeps the country in league with the leaders in the sector.

On October 1, last year, a national consultative meeting was held at IISER, Pune, on Quantum Sensors & Metrology, one of the four verticals of QTA.

From IISER, Pune, T S Mahesh and Umakant Rapol were part of the detailed project report drafting committee on QTA.

“In India, many scientists have been working on quantum technology since a few years on individual level. This is the first effort being made by the government to bring them all together in an organised manner and have a targeted mission in this field,” Rapol said.

Title: Rs 5 lakh bank insurance not retrospective, won’t help PMC
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Mumbai: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, in her Budget speech, has proposed to hike bank deposit insurance cover in scheduled commercial banks to Rs 5 lakh per depositor from the current Rs 1 lakh. Henceforth, if such a bank goes bust, its account holders are entitled to receive the revised amount insured.

Even after the proposal is passed, though, this clause will not apply to past cases such as PMC Bank , considering that it will not be invoked with retrospective effect.

Moreover, the procedure is long and cumbersome, lasting years, with little or no precedent of success, say depositors who have scarcely received basic insurance amount of Rs 1 lakh due to long-drawn legal loopholes and wrangles.

PMC Bank depositor Clifford D’Souza of Andheri East said, “Hardly any people have small deposits of up to Rs 5 lakh in banks. Most have investments of Rs 10-20 lakh, even crores. So, Rs 5 lakh insurance is no relief. But most of all, we are not seeking insurance, we are asking to be able to retrieve our own hard-earned money.”

D’Souza said the route to insurance was fraught with procedural delays and red tape. “Elderly depositors will not even live to see the day. The sum is released after the bank goes under liquidation and is declared insolvent, a process that can take more than a decade. By then, inflation will have reduced the value of Rs 5 lakh by half. It is not as if depositors will simply get a cheque after the bank goes bust,” he said. “We need our money, and we need it now.”

Title: State can tap quantum tech: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kochi: The state could benefit from the proposal in the Union budget to set up a National Mission on Quantum Technologies with an outlay of Rs 8,000 crore, according to experts.

Quantum technology is an emerging field in the intersection of physics and engineering with applications in areas like quantum computing, communications and cyber security.

“There are a lot of possibilities but we need to know what the framework of the mission is. If it can be aligned with the existing thrust on creating a deep-tech startup environment, we can accelerate innovations in this sector,” said Maker Village CEO Prasad Balakrishnan Nair. It can also be used to bridge the industry-academia gap by creating institutions like the Blockchain Academy to ensure an innovation pipeline, he said.

The move to set up data centre parks in the private sector throughout the country would also be beneficial to the state’s IT sector as it is a sector that can attract huge investments.

“Through such parks, they may be proposing to set up multiple data centres at a single place. Setting up of data centres is mandatory as per new data policy,” said Infopark, Kochi CEO Sasi P M.

Currently, a greenfield datacentre, Pi-Kochi, is being set up at Infopark Phase 2 with a planned investment of Rs 400 crore.

Title: Budget lacks strategy to halt falling economy, inflation: CM Nath
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Saturday described the Union Budget as “disappointing for the country” and “jugglery of numbers”. He said the budget has not even addressed the increasing unemployment scenario and has presented several old schemes as new.

In a series of tweets on Saturday afternoon, chief minister @OfficeOfKNath said, “Today, the annual budget speech presented by the finance minister was definitely a long one, but a total jugglery of numbers, disappointing for the country and only displaying unrealistic dreams. There is nothing for the village— poor—farmers—youth—employment – protection of women.”

A second tweet by the chief minister argued, “There is no mention of how to rid unemployment and generate employment for the youth. Again, as usual, dreams have been shown of doubling the income of farmers. Several old schemes have been presented as new.”

CM Nath also tweeted, “This budget lacks a roadmap for the country’s development, progress and a strategy to halt the falling economy and inflation. A large part of the country lives in the rural areas which has been totally ignored in the budget.”

In his fourth tweet, chief minister Nath alleged, “Had all the false dreams shown by the Modi government in the previous budgets, which Modi Bhakts used to openly praise, been fulfilled then the country’s economy would not have been in this bad condition.”

Final tweet from CM on the budget said it betrays the state’s interest. “There has been a cut of Rs 11,556 crores in the state’s share of Central taxes in the revised estimates. If this amount is added to the Rs 2,677 crores slashed last year, it adds to a whopping Rs 14,233 crore. This is a betrayal of the interests of Madhya Pradesh.”

Title: Ind SAT to raise the bar, but exam may hit host of issues
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Pune: Ind-SAT for Asian and African students for awarding scholarships to study in India will bring quality students, heads of educational institutions in the city said.

The challenge will be its large scale implementation, especially in countries where internet connectivity is poor. Currently, there is no standard examination for foreign students coming to India.

Vidya Yeravdekar, principal director of Symbiosis Society said they had 75 scholarship students from the Study in India programme last year and 45 this year.

“Bandwidth will be a problem in many African countries. But the test will help students take India seriously. It will create a level playing field. At present, we rely on marks obtained by students in their country,” Yeravdekar said. There are about 3,000 students studying in the university.

Vijay Khare, director of Savitribai Phule Pune University’s International Centre that also has about 3,000 students, said they get 300 students from the Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR) on scholarship.

“ Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan do not have English in schools curricula which makes it difficult for these students to learn when they come to India. With a test like this, students will know what standards to expect,” Khare added.

At a conference last week in Pune, Vinay Sahasrabuddhe, president of ICCR, spoke about how instead of teaching English after foreign students come to India, Indian embassies and ICCR centres can double up as English coaching centres to help students reach required standards to apply for a study programme in India.

Title: MP lags in health budget expenditure
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

HEALING TOUCH

Bhopal: Look at the actual expenditure of allocated health budget over allocation, said health activists. Actual health budget spending on medical treatment and other services that have a direct impact on people needs to be increased, said activists while reacting on the Union Budget. Overall, health budgetary allocation has increased by 15% to Rs 62,659 crore.

“Madhya Pradesh and Chhattisgarh have already opposed Niti Ayog’s proposal to hand over district hospitals through PPP model to build medical colleges. The government has been unable to spend more than 60% of last year budget under PMJAY,” said Amulya Nidhi, co-convenor of NGO Swasthya Adhikar Manch. Linking handover of district hospital on PPP model with central government funding is now likely. Ensuring the allocated budget is spent on improving healthcare in MP is most important, he added.

“Health and wellness centre are already far behind their target . Of the planned 75,000 centres, only one-third have begun in last three years. Under Ayushman Bharat 2019-20, out of allocated Rs 6,556 crore, only 33% budget (Rs 2186) was utilised.

Health sector funding is expected to hit negatively with budget for national health mission (NHM) remaining static. Grants-in-aid to state governments is also static. It provides for transfer to state to support decentralized planning and flexible programming by the states including development of state and district-level Project Implementation Plans (PIPs) with a focus on outcomes particularly relating to vulnerable sections, and community based monitoring and evaluation. The activities under the NHM provides for health needs of rural population including control of vector-borne diseases, TB and leprosy.

A reduction in grant in aid to grants-in-aid to state governments in the Union Budget is expected to hit Swastha Nagrik Abhiyan (SNA), Population Research Centres, Health Surveys and Research Studies along with procurement of Contraceptives for Social Marketing and Free Distribution, Training of Doctors in NSV/Recanalisation technique among others.

Establishment of new medical colleges and increase of seats in existing government medical colleges is Rs 4,686 crore. However, budget for Upgradation/Strengthening of Nursing Services (ANM/GNM), Strengthening/Upgradation of Pharmacy School/College District Hospital - Upgradation of State Government Medical Colleges (PG Seats), Strengthening Government Medical Colleges (UG Seats) and Central Government Health Institutions Establishing New Medical Colleges (upgrading District Hospitals) and Setting up of State Institutions of Para-medical Sciences in States and Setting up of College of Para-medical Education has been reduced.

Title: Increase in funds for women, child welfare hailed
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: The women and child development department and activists have welcomed the hike in allocation of funds for women and child welfare schemes

There is a 14% increase in budget for women and child development, allotting Rs 30,000 crore to the department along with Rs 4,036.49 crore in 2020-21 for the social services sector, that includes nutrition and social security and welfare and Rs 855.23 crores for schemes of women safety.

“If the union budget has been increased, the state budget will also be increased proportionately. Like we have begun the safe city programme in six cities of MP, if we get more funds, the programme can be extended to other cities too and make the state safer for women”, said principal secretary of the department Anupam Rajan.

The safe city programme by the WCD MP aims to make cities of the state safer for women by installing lights in dark and isolated areas, starting cabs and autos driven by women along with opening crisis centres for women.

The budget for the Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana a maternity benefit programme, has been increased from Rs 2,300 crore to Rs 2,500 crore in 2020-21.

Director of city Childine Archana Sahaya added, “Safety of women is a burning issue in the country and a lot of new schemes to prevent crimes against women and children need to be made. Schemes for pregnant women and new mothers are also very important for the state for the welfare of the mother and child and ensuring proper nutrition for them.”

Another social worker Rakesh Malviya of NGO Vikas Samvad that focuses on health, nutrition and education for women and children said, “Just increasing the budget is not enough, proper implementation is necessary. It’s a good thing that the central government has increased the budget for safety of women but is also necessary to use it properly instead of just making schemes on paper.”

Title: Wesco to start disconnection drive from Feb 18
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Sambalpur: The Western Electricity Supply Company of Odisha Limited (WESCO) announced that that it would start disconnecting power supply to defaulters from February 18 in phases. Around Rs 2,117 crore arrear are pending with domestic and commercial consumers. Also, an arrear of Rs 406 crore is pending with industrial consumers.

Addressing the media, authorised officer of WESCO Tapas Pattanaik said WESCO is committed to provide quality service. “However, finance has emerged as a major constraint for the power supply company in providing quality service to its consumers. The arrears on consumers has become a burden. If the amount is not collected, then WESCO will face difficulties in operating. And hence, we are forced to disconnect power supply to consumers, who are not paying their pending arrear bill despite several notices,” he said.

According to officials of WESCO, there are 17,70,211 domestic consumers in nine districts under WESCO. Altogether 10,80,933 consumers have not paid their arrear electricity bill amounting to Rs 1,984. 45 crores. Similarly, there are 81,125 commercial consumers in nine districts under WESCO.

Around 46,093 commercial consumers have pending bills amounting to Rs 132.65 crore. Moreover, there are 920 high tension (HT) industrial consumers and of the total 148 consumers have pending electricity bills. This apart, of the total 34 extra high tension (EHT) industrial consumer, three industrial houses have pending bills. Moreover, Rs 61 crore arrear is pending with government offices.

Pattanaik said, “We have already served notices on defaulting consumers and asked them to pay arrears by February 17. We are also urging consumers to contact the sub-divisional officers (SDO) of their concerned areas if they want to pay the pending arrear phase wise or who have grievances regarding bill,” he said.

Title: Mixed reactions from biz fraternity
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: Industries body in the state gave a mixed reaction to the Union Budget 2020 stating it appeared to be well intended but lacked the punch. There was lukewarm reaction from the majority of the members of the industrialists in Bhopal.

Chairman of the Bhopal unit of the confederation of Indian industry (CII) Animesh Jain said, “there was no big-ticket announcement from the government. In terms of Madhya Pradesh, he said, initiatives taken in agriculture sector may benefit farmers to improve the economy.” he also hailed the decision to abolish the dividend distribution tax.

Vice-chairman Siddharth Chaturvedi said, “it was more a vision document than a budget document.”

Referring to the 10% GDP in the budget speech of the finance minister, Pradeep Kukreja, a chartered accountant (CA) said, “I see nothing which could spur the economy to reach this stage in this Budget.”

Talking about the new income tax slabs, another CA Navneet Garg said, “after introduction of the new IT slabs and continuation of the old tax regime, if the government thinks it has simplified the taxation for an individual, it is wrong.”

Piyush Bindal, a company secretary praised the “new direct tax dispute settlement scheme- Vivad se Vishwas “launched by the finance minister and said it would benefit the tax payers. He also said that the FM was expected to give relaxation in long-term capital gains, but it remined untouched.”

Title: No allocation of funds for Bhopal, Indore Metros
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: At a time when Bhopal and Indore rail are moving into high gear, the Union budget allocation for MRTS and Metro projects has declined to Rs 17,482 crore. The Union government’s equity in the project is crucial as Madhya Pradesh Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MPMRCL) awaits release of loan from international aid agencies.

Two budgets after Bhopal and Indore Metros were approved, the twin Metro projects are yet to find a separate allocation of funding in the Union budget. Metro projects in Jaipur and Lucknow have such an allocation. The budget in 2019-20 was Rs 17,611 crore. The twin projects are scheduled to commence operation by 2022. About Rs 400 crore was recently released by the Centre for the Bhopal project.

Other urban development projects funded through external aid for MP have witnessed increased allocation in the Union budget, which was announced on Saturday. It includes MP Skills Development Project (Rs 100 crore), MP Urban Services Improvement Project (Rs 300 crore), MP District Roads II Sector Project (Rs 600 crore), MP Irrigation Efficiency Improvement Project (Rs 500 crore), MP Rural Connectivity Project (Rs 630 crore), MP Higher Education Quality Improvement Project (Rs 700 crore), MP Multi Village Rural Water Supply Project (Rs 1740 crore) — up from Rs 1,154 crore, Development and Upgradation of Major District Roads - MP (Rs 720 crore) and MP Major District Roads II Project (Rs 240 crore).

Title: Woman loses gold chain worth Rs 1 lakh in Indiranagar
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

NASHIK: A woman was robbed of her gold chain worth Rs 1 lakh in Indiranagar area of the city on Thursday by two bike-borne suspects.

A case in this regard has been registered at Indiranagar police station. According to police, the complainant, a 50-year-old woman, had gone to meet one of her relatives when she stopped near Pathardi Road to make a phone call.

At the same time the suspects were passing from there on a two-wheeler. Looking that the woman was alone, they took a U-turn and approached her. In no time the suspect riding pillion slapped on the woman’s neck ad snatched the gold chain she was wearing.

The woman called for help and tried to stop the suspects, but failed. In her compliant, the woman has said that the criminals were in the age group of 25 to 30 years. She even claimed to see the face of the suspect who snatched the gold chain.

“The suspects were riding a black motorcycle and were wearing black jackets. The rider was wearing a helmet, but the pillion rider had not covered his face owing to which the woman saw him and can identify him,” a police officer said.

Title: Coronavirus: Phulbani man admitted in SCB with flu-like symptoms
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Cuttack: A man from Kandhamal district, who had voluntarily admitted himself to a local hospital after developing symptoms similar to those being displayed by coronavirus patients, was admitted and kept in isolation in Cuttack’s SCB Medical College and Hospital on Saturday.

Mrutunjay Muni, 26, a resident of Phulbani who had returned home from China on January 12, was admitted to the state’s premier medical college hospital at 3.20 am. He has been kept in the isolation wing and will be monitored by a nine-member team of experts.

“Muni has been kept under observation in the special ward’s isolation wing for suspected coronavirus infection,” said M R Patnaik, head of the department of pulmonary medicine, who is also the nodal officer of the treatment committee. “The patient’s vital organs have been examined. His condition is stable,” Patnaik added. “His blood and swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology in Pune,” he further said.

Besides Patnaik, the treatment committee comprises the heads of the departments of medicine, microbiology, ENT, community medicine and anaesthesiology. The 42-bed special epidemic ward set up for the treatment of coronavirus patients comprises the isolation wing, which has 11 beds, and an ICU with eight beds. The remaining 23 beds are for positive cases.

Muni, a medical student of Southwest Medical University in the Sichuan province of China, was referred to SCB from the district headquarters hospital in Phulbani, where he had got himself admitted after developing flu-like symptoms. “After returning from China, I started feeling feverish. I also had cough and cold. Given that coronavirus is spreading in China and my symptoms matched that of the deadly disease, I voluntarily went for a health check-up at the district headquarters hospital in Phulbani,” Muni had told TOI earlier.

(With inputs from Hrusikesh Mohanty)

Title: Screening of crew yet to start at Paradip port
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kendrapada: Paradip port authorities have for the moment decided not to begin screening of crew members of ships that have sailed through countries affected by novel coronavirus. At least nine ships that have passed through affected countries are anchored off the Odisha coast and their crew members have been denied permission to disembark even as the virus has claimed more than 250 lives and infected thousands in China.

“At present we have no plans to examine crew members on the ships,” said Dr Prahallad Panda, medical officer of Paradip Port Hospital, on Saturday. “But we have made arrangements for screening crew members in Paradip port and directed the captains to inform us if any crew member is suffering from fever, cough and cold and related illness. Till date we have not get any information about the presence of a sick crew member,” Dr Panda added.

Sources said that a commercial vessel normally has between 25 to 30 crew members. Rinkesh Roy, chairman of Paradip Port Trust (PPT), admitted that they have decided not to provide shore leave to crew members of ships that have recently sailed through China and other affected countries.

“This is a particularly bad time because of the coronavirus. So we have refused permission to the crew members to disembark,” Roy said.

However, cargo loading and unloading work is going on at Paradip port. Stevedore companies have been using cranes for loading and unloading cargo. At present two ships are anchored in the port while the others are moored around two to five kilometres from the coast, on the sea. Port authorities said after the two ships depart, other vessels will be given permission for berthing.

Title: Goa: Two US nationals flying from China kept at coronavirus ward
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Two US nationals have been quarantined at the Goa Medical College (GMC) and hospital as suspected cases of coronavirus , GMC dean Shivanand Bandekar said on Saturday.“A 27-year-old, foreign female suspect working in China, travelled to Bengaluru on January 20, and then arrived in Goa on January 27 along with her friend who is asymptomatic. Samples of both persons have been sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune. The suspect only has history of fever with upper respiratory tract infection,” health minister Vishwajit Rane said.Sources said when the female got fever, she approached a private hospital for treatment, and when it was brought to the notice of the doctors at the private hospital that she travelled to Goa from China, the doctors and the private hospital immediately informed the health authorities. Sources said her friend did not show fever symptoms. Later, they were shifted to GMC after taking all precautions.Two more persons were brought under observation on Friday as they had visited China. This is in addition to the six persons whose health is being monitored after they returned from China. As part of the all-India surveillance measures, the Goa airport has started screening passengers since Thursday night.The state government had also sought for scanners to be installed at the airport.

Title: Budget claim to double famers’ income an eyewash, say farmer outfits, state ministers
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Bhopal: Farmers’ organisations have ridiculed the Centre's claim of doubling their income by 2022. The state agriculture minister also termed the budget as “disappointing”.

The state government has said that the Centre’s claim of doubling the farmers’ income was “hollow” as there was no government plan to do so.

National president of Kisan Mazdoor Sangh, Shivkumar Sharma alias Kakka ji, said that the present average monthly income of farmers in India was Rs 1,566 per month. By doubling this by 2022, they want to increase it to Rs 3,132. “Even labourers in India get more money. The government representatives who want to achieve this should hang their head with shame,” said Sharma.

Instead of misleading the farmers, the government should ensure better price for their produce and timely compensation for crop damage, especially after climate change conditions.

State agriculture minister Sachin Yadav said the farmers of Madhya Pradesh were looking at budget 2020 with great hopes, but they were disappointed. Almost 70% of the population of Madhya Pradesh is linked with agriculture, but the provisions made in the budget for this community were too small.

Though the finance minister talked about doubling the farmers’ income by 2022, no concrete plan in this regard was presented in the budget. Similarly, there was no word for providing one-and-a-half times cost of the produce as compared to the cost of farming.

“Modi government has proved once again that it was not concerned over the “plight of the poor, farmer and rural folk”.

Bhartiya Kisan Sangh general secretary Anil Yadav said that the government should change its perception towards farmers’ need. “They put in hard work but get meagre returns. The government should ensure proper rates for their produce and timely payment of their dues.”

However, Union agriculture minister Narendra Singh Tomar praised Narendra Modi for “growth-oriented budget provisions for farmers.”

Title: Scrap land-pooling GO, demand civic activists
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Vijayawada: The government ’s plan to pool land from residents to an extent of 6,116 acres in 10 mandals near Visakhapatnam has drawn criticism from civic activists . While lauding the government’s plan to provide housing or house sites to poor, they said the move to evict the poor to give land to other poor people lacks merit and called for immediate scrapping of GO No 72.

“In the name of facilitating housing and house sites to the poor, land that is in the possession of and belongs to the poor is being sought to be acquired. This is unacceptable and we strongly urge the government to desist from going ahead with the public hearings to take over these lands,” said M Sarat, president of Human Rights Forum’s Visakhapatnam unit.

VS Krishna, coordination committee member of HRF in AP and Telangana, said while the process appears to be pro-poor, in reality it only undermines the poor people’s means of survival. “Among the lands sought to be acquired under the land pooling scheme are 2,552 acres of assigned land and 2,343 acres of occupied land. Those holding the land are the poor and Dalits who the government now wants to dispossess,” he said.

Civic rights activist EAS Sarma was more trenchant in his criticism. “Despite being aware of the mess the erstwhile TDP government’s land-pooling act created in Amaravati, this government still issued GO 72, which is aimed at evicting the poor from lands where they have lived on for generations. Land occupied by the poor (predominantly small, marginal farmers) is tilled by them for subsistence. How are they to survive if this land is taken over and a small extent given them in return?” Sarma asked.

“If the government really seeks to acquire land for housing and handing over house sites to the poor, it would do well to just leave the land on which the poor rely on and instead take over extents that are in plain encroachment by the rich and powerful,” he added.

Title: PM clearly said we need a tax charter: Nirmala Sitharaman
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nirmala Sitharaman (file photo)

Title: Door-to-door pension distribution begins in Vizag
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A door-to-door pension distribution drive was taken up in Visakhapatnam district on Saturday. The pension distribution service was launched by the state government recently. On Saturday, district collector V Vinay Chand and tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao took part in the distribution drive.

Moreover, the door-to-door drive also saw the participation of all MLAs in the aforementioned minister’s constituency. GVMC commissioner G Srijana also participated in the programme on its first day.

The state government recently announced that pensions would be provided door-to-door from now on and ward secretaries, village secretaries and volunteers will spearhead the service. On the first day, the district collector as well as the GVMC commissioner joined in to distribute pensions in various wards of the city.

Minister M Srinivasa Rao said, “This is being done for the first time in the history of the country and has not been done in any other state so far. The aim of the YSRC government is to ensure governance reaches homes.”

Title: EG police arrest man accused of 18 robberies
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Kakinada: The East Godavari police arrested Yallamilli Venkata Ramana, a robber alleged to have been involved in 18 cases of robbery and recovered Rs 9.3 lakh worth of gold from him on Friday . Ramana is a resident of Sivakodupalem in Razole mandal in East Godavari district.

According to the police, Ramana’s modus operandi is to lie about being a lineman from the electricity department to single women and enter their homes. Following which, he would steal their gold ornaments.

He was caught by Parvada police a few years ago when he confessed to have committed 32 property offences and was sentenced to 15 months in jail. After being released in August, 2019, he started committing robberies again. tnn

Title: 7 months go by, no action taken yet against encroachments on NH-16
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Despite several requests from the transport department and social activists to remove illegal encroachments from the clogged NH-16 stretch passing through the city, the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) is yet to initiate an eviction drive.

“It’s ridiculous. Not only us (social activists), even the transport department sent requests to GVMC two months back. But the civic authorities have just turned a deaf ear,” said social activist Tenneti Narasimham, who has fighting for this cause for several years now. In October last year, the deputy transport commissioner of Visakhapatnam, G C Raja Ratnam, had also sent a letter to the GVMC commissioner, requesting him to take necessary action to remove encroachments along the highway.

GVMC officials, on their part, claim that they are scrutinizing the claims and trying to find out whether the illegal structures are actually encroaching the highway. “It’s not easy to evict them overnight. We have to follow certain procedures. Now that we have an interim commissioner, the procedure is likely to get delayed,” a civic body official said.

If the government’s proposal to make Visakhapatnam the executive capital takes shape, the number of vehicles would increase by leaps and bounds and the NH-16 stretch could become a nightmare for motorists. “The situation is already bad. Traffic hardly moves on the stretch during peak hours. Imagine what would happen if vehicle movement in the city doubles within a few months,” added Narasimham.

It may be recalled that the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), in its report in June last year, identified 227 illegal encroachments on the 6km stretch from zoo park to Maddilapalem crossing. The report further stated that around 208 of these encroachments — which include bars, restaurants, bakeries, garment showrooms etc — were permanent in nature. “GVMC is the authority to take legal steps against these encroachments,” a NHAI official said.

Title: Meets on coronavirus control measures
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In view of the novel coronavirus alert, a meeting of the infection control committee meeting was held at King George Hospital (KGH) in Visakhapatnam on Saturday. KGH superintendent Dr G Arjuna instructed committee members and HODs to follow infection control protocol in KGH and discussed isolation beds in KGH for cases of the novel coronavirus (nCov).

He instructed the concerned staff to ensure availability of face masks, N95 masks, personal protective kits (PPE) and required drugs. Three beds were allotted in the fever ward for isolation.

Further, in another meeting on Saturday, Dr PV Sudhakar, principal of Andhra Medical College (AMC) pointed to the need of a joint effort by AMC-KGH, Government Hospital for Chest and Communicable Disease (GHCCD) and district administration in containing the outbreak of coronavirus, which WHO has declared a global pandemic.

DMHO Dr S Tirupathi Rao explained the directives issued by the state government and preparedness at the airport. He also shared Information-Education-Communication (IEC) material with all concerned and urged them to provide round-the-clock quarantine facilities for those coming from China at GHCCD.

Dr KVV Vijaya Kumar, superintendent of GHCCD has agreed to prepare a 25-bed isolation ward with wi-fi facility for quarantine. A standard operating procedure (SOP) has been designed for the benefit of all concerned for smooth handling of those suspected of having been infected. Dr B Devi Madhavi, HoD of community medicine advised the district administration to sensitise various doctors’ groups.

Title: PSU stake sale gets a new topping: LIC
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The government set a stiff target of raising Rs 2.1 lakh crore from disinvestment in state-run companies in the next fiscal while unveiling its plan to list the country’s top insurer, Life Insurance Corporation.

The FM said government would also consider corporatising at least one major port and subsequently listing it on the stock exchanges as part of the plan to realise value in PSU firms.

Government had targeted raising Rs 1.05 lakh crore from stake sale in state-run companies in 2019-20 but in the revised estimates, the target was lowered to Rs 65,000 crore as some big ticket sales failed to take off.

The Rs 2.1 lakh crore target for next year includes Rs 90,000 crore from sale of stake in state-run banks and financial institutions. The rest is expected to come from sale in state-run firms.

“Listing on stock exchanges disciplines a company and provides access to financial markets and unlocks its value. It also gives opportunity for retail investors to participate in the wealth so created. The government now proposes to sell a part of its holding in LIC by way of Initial Public Offer,” finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman said in her speech. Later, she told TOI she expected all strategic stake sale cases like BPCL, Air India and others to go through soon as most of the spadework had been done.

The FM also unveiled plans to sell balance holding of the government in IDBI Bank to private, retail and institutional investors through the stock exchange.

Title: Sarkari hiring moves online: One fee, One portal, One test
Content:
File photo

Around 2.5 crore aspirants, who take separate, multiple examinations conducted by different recruiting agencies for selection to around 1.25 lakh government jobs every year, will soon need to appear for a single online common eligibility test ( CET ), with the test scores remaining valid for three years for recruitment to any non-gazetted post.Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman said a National Recruitment Agency (NRA) was proposed to conduct a computer-based CET for recruitment to non-gazetted posts. A test centre would be set up in every district, particularly in ‘ aspirational districts ’. Separate CETs shall be conducted for graduate, Class XII-pass and matriculate-level candidates for non-technical posts, for which recruitment is currently done through Staff Selection Commission (SSC), Railway Recruitment Boards (RRBs) and Institute of Banking Personnel Selection (IBPS).This is expected to cut costs and time — for the government, recruiting agencies and candidates — in recruitment process for non-gazetted posts in government and public sector banks. And, of course, make it more convenient for aspirants.As of now, aspirants need to appear for multiple examinations conducted by various agencies at different points of time, for similar posts demanding similar eligibility criteria. “This places enormous burden on time, effort and cost of young people,” the minister pointed out.“At present, youths need to appear for separate examinations for recruitment to government jobs. We are revising this arrangement by starting an online common examination for such appointments,” Modi said.Minister of state, personnel, Jitendra Singh said CET would help candidates who are from weaker financial backgrounds as a common test will save money. They will no longer have to pay fees separately for multiple recruitment exams, and won’t have to travel to several test centres. “It will also provide a level-playing field for aspirants,” he told TOI.The CET score — valid for three years from date of declaration of the result — will be made available to the candidate and individual recruitment agencies. Each candidate will have two additional chances to improve their score, and the best of all scores will be considered.The CET merit list may be made available to states by NRA on cost-sharing basis, to undertake recruitment to state government jobs. “The CET score can also be utilised by the private sector to consider eligible candidates, other than those selected by government recruitment agencies, through an arrangement with NRA,” said a government functionary.The Budget estimates that more than 2.62 lakh jobs are likely to be created between March 2019 and March 2021 in various government organisations. The strength of government establishments was 32,62,908 as on March 1, 2019.The CET proposal was placed in the public domain in December, inviting comments from central government departments, state governments and public. “We will incorporate the suggestions and move a cabinet note soon. Hopefully, CET can be rolled out in the second half of this year,” said a government functionary.

Title: Now, Shaheen Bagh: Man fires in air, caught by cops
Content:
The suspect, Kapil Gurjar, fired three shots in the air before being overpowered by cops and volunteers at the... Read More

Looking for ‘impact’, he got weapon from friend

NEW DELHI: Just two days after a juvenile was shot at and injured a student at a Jamia University protest, three shots rang out at Shaheen Bagh on Saturday evening. A 25-year-old man opened fire with a countrymade weapon, leading to chaos in the area. Identified as Kapil Gurjar, the man had reached the protest site and managed to cross the first of three barricades put up behind the shamiana of the protesters.Gurjar approached a tea stall around 4.30pm and spoke to the owner about the protest. He then suddenly whipped out a pistol and started firing in the air. "He asked me how long would the protest continue, but before I could reply, he walked away. I didn't realise he was firing until I saw policemen running after him. He was running zigzag to avoid getting caught," said the tea-stall owner.Hearing the first gunshot, volunteers at the protest site rushed out to nab Gurjar and stop him from going any further. "He was running around with the weapon and we feared that he might again fire at the stage where the women were sitting. We alerted the policemen and ran after him," said Kafil Akhtar.Even as he was being chased, Gurjar fired two more rounds in the air to intimidate them and deter them from coming his way. He, however, ran out of luck. A police team standing behind the first barricade managed to surround Gurjar even as one of the volunteers snatched the pistol from his hand.According to eyewitnesses, he was shouting religious slogans. Later, while being bundled into a car, he came face to face with some reporters. He promptly shouted, " Hamare desh me kisi ki nai chalegi, sirf Hinduon ki chalegi (In our country, no one but Hindus will have a say)," before being taken away by the cops.Gurjar claimed that he was angry with the protesters since the closure of the Kalindi Kunj road was leading to snarls on Ring Road. He said his father owned a dairy in the area and he and his brother helped distribute milk. Lately, he has been travelling back and forth from Dallupura to Lajpat Nagar to supply milk for a relative's wedding. During this, he had to spend hours stuck in the traffic jam. He has also been reading about the hardships people are facing due to the protests and was upset about it.Gurjar told the cops that he had decided to do something that would create an impact. He had reached Shaheen Bagh after going to Sarai Kale Khan in a bus and then travelled in an auto-rickshaw.Luckily, no one was injured in the firing since Gurjar fired in the air. Also, the protest site was beyond the range of the weapon and the road was nearly empty.Gurjar was taken to the Sarita Vihar police station and his family members were informed. During interrogation, he allegedly claimed that he had got the pistol from a friend, whose identity is being verified. Police say he has been giving contradictory statements.“We have registered a case under Section 336 of IPC (endangering safety of others) and Arms Act against the man and are trying to find out how he managed to procure the weapon,” said Mandeep Singh Randhawa, Delhi Police PRO. He added that following Thursday’s shooting incident, security was being beefed up at all protest sites and multiple barricades were being installed to prevent entry of outsiders.Cops added that from now on they would start frisking people entering the protest site. Till Saturday, people were either slipping in from the sides or coming through the lanes in the area. With Shaheen Bagh becoming a poll issue, the police are not willing to take any chances.Police will question Gurjar’s family members to find out whether he had been planning the incident for some time. His mobile phone has been sent for forensic analysis. Cops are also scanning his Facebook profile to find out whether he was being influenced by someone. He will be produced in court on Sunday where cops will seek his custody for cracking the case.

Title: People enthused about Union Budget but doubts over implementation persist
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Dharwad: ‘Promising on paper, doubtful about its implementation,’ was the prevalent notion among homemakers, farmers , experts and the general public about the 2020-21 Union Budget presented by finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in the Lok Sabha on Saturday.

Most people who shared their views on the budget with STOI opined that, while the policies outlined held the promise of reviving the economy, they were as sceptical about the implementation of the ideas.

Representatives of the Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) of India’s Employees’ Union were vehement in expressing their opposition to the proposal in the budget to privatise Industrial Development Bank of India (IDBI) and LIC. On the other hand, stakeholders in the education sector were appreciative of the thrust to improve the sector, although they were disappointed with the cancellation of exemptions to institutions.

Union minister for parliamentary affairs and Dharwad MP Pralhad Joshi opined that the budget would accelerate the growth of the Indian economy. “The plans outlined in the budget are in keeping with the central government’s vision of ‘Sab Ka Saath, Sab Ka Vikas Aur Sab Ka Lakshya (Development for all, with an eye on the goals of all),” said Joshi, expressing his gratitude to Nirmala for allocating Rs 18,600 crore for the suburban rail project in Bengaluru, and reaffirming the Centre’s commitment to complete work on the Bengaluru-Chennai Expressway by 2023.

Harish Ramaswamy, a political analyst, said that, confronted with a flagging economy, the Union finance minister had acquitted herself well in rolling out policies that would ensure its revival. “This is an honest attempt at providing a cure for an ailing economy. Measures have been proposed to resuscitate the automobile sector, and reforms mooted for the banking sector are welcome. Hopes from this budget were very high, and the finance minister has ensured a good balance,” said Ramaswamy.

On the other hand, farmers’ leader Gangadhar Patilkulkarni said that peasants had been left disappointed with the budget. “There is nothing encouraging for farmers in this budget. There is no mention of a loan waiver instead of which one sees moves that may drown us in more loans,” he said.

Karnataka Vikas Grameena Bank chairman P Gopikrishna felt that there was a triangular focus to the budget’s vision: Aspirational India, economic development and a caring society. “It will have a positive impact in the industrial sector, infrastructure and holds the promise of generating employment,” said Gopikrishna.

Prof Rudragouda Biradar, who teaches in the department of economics at Karnatak University, dubbed the budget ‘growth-oriented’ and ‘people-friendly’.

Title: Karnataka: Priest, 63, asks gram panchayat to find him a bride
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Dyammanna (second from left) submits a petition asking help from the local administration to find him a bride

HUBBALLI: Having given up on society, family and friends to come to his rescue, a 63-year-old priest has approached the gram panchayat of Naregal in Hangal taluk of Haveri to find him a bride.

While villagers are sympathetic to Dyammanna Kammar’s “need for someone to understand my feelings and support me in life”, they also have a deadline: the priest has refused to perform the rituals for the upcoming village fair unless his demand is met.

Kammar says it is not for lack of trying that he remains a bachelor at this ripe age. “I studied up to SSLC and could not continue my education due to poverty. After my parents died, we three brothers and four sisters got separated. Except me, all are well-settled. I tried to find myself a suitable match but I was rejected for being poor,” he rues.

For decades now, Kammar has been performing prayers and rituals at the local Dyammava temple and lives on his own in a rented house. “Somehow, I have managed alone all these years, cooking for myself and doing odd chores for a livelihood. But now that I have turned 63, I can’t live alone. I need a partner to live the rest of my life happily and peacefully,” he says.

Somanna Barki, secretary of Naregal gram panchayat, says Kammar has been pressing his unique demand for sometime now. “He was frequenting our office, requesting us to help him marry. Finally, he has submitted a petition seeking the government’s help,” says Barki.

Kammar submitted his petition to the gram panchayat president and panchayat development officer (PDO) on Friday. “Age is no issue. If I get support from the government or others, I will start my own shop or business and get married. There are instances of people marrying after they turned 70, I am just 63”, he says.

Meanwhile, adds Barki, the village is gearing up to celebrate the Dyammavan jatre (fair) from February 14 to 22 and Kammar has refused to perform the religious rituals, “insisting that he must get married and government should help him”. Kammar earns Rs 200 to Rs 300 a day and has no assets or property to fall back on.

Barki says the priest’s ultimatum is a village concern now: “We will take up this matter for discussion in the next general body meeting of the gram panchayat. We will also meet villagers to figure out how we can help Dyammanna.”

Title: Mumbai: Bank insurance increase will not help PMC depositors
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

PMC Bank account holders protest at Bandra branch in Mumbai (ANI Photo)

MUMBAI: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman , in her Budget speech, has proposed to hike bank deposit insurance cover in scheduled commercial banks to Rs 5 lakh per depositor from the current Rs 1 lakh. Henceforth, if such a bank goes bust, its account holders are entitled to receive the revised amount insured.

Even after the proposal is passed, though, this clause will not apply to past cases such as PMC Bank , considering that it will not be invoked with retrospective effect.

Moreover, the procedure is long and cumbersome, lasting years, with little or no precedent of success, say depositors who have scarcely received basic insurance amount of Rs 1 lakh due to long-drawn legal loopholes and wrangles.

PMC Bank depositor Clifford D'Souza of Andheri East said, "Hardly any people have small deposits of up to Rs 5 lakh in banks. Most have investments of Rs 10-20 lakh, even crores. So, Rs 5 lakh insurance is no relief. But most of all, we are not seeking insurance, we are asking to be able to retrieve our own hard-earned money."

D'Souza said the route to insurance was fraught with procedural delays and red tape. "Elderly depositors will not even live to see the day. The sum is released after the bank goes under liquidation and is declared insolvent, a process that can take more than a decade. By then, inflation will have reduced the value of Rs 5 lakh by half. It is not as if depositors will simply get a cheque after the bank goes bust," he said. "We need our money, and we need it now."

Title: Mumbai: Masked man shoots at two Malad shops; no one injured
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Police guards at one of the shops targeted on Saturday afternoon

MUMBAI: Two businessmen and their employees had a lucky escape when a masked man opened fired at two shops in Malad (east) on Saturday. The firings took place within 10 minutes of each other. The police said local goon Uday Phatak, main accused in the Kurar quadruple murder case, was behind it.

In the first case, a bullet shattered glass shelves of the medical store. In the other, a bullet whizzed past the owner of an imitation jewellery shop and hit the roof.

The masked man first walked into Anand Medical & Book Center around 1.30 pm and opened fire when the owner Sunil Singh and three employees were present. "He pointed a gun, his hands trembling when he pressed the trigger."

"After firing, he threw a chit at me in which my brother's name was scribbled in Hindi. He demanded extortion money,'' said Singh.

The assailant then targeted Rokadia Traders. Akash Jain told TOI, "My brother Vikas was near the counter when the man pointed a gun. As he fired, Vikas ducked. The bullet pierced the roof."

DCP D S Swami said a team from Kurar police station is probing the case.

Title: Chennai: 'Winter' almost over; hot days, warm nights to continue
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Maximum and minimum temperatures are likely to be around 32°C and 23°C for the next 48 hours in the city (File... Read More

CHENNAI: With no major cold spells so far, winter, which has been subdued so far, is almost over. Weathermen have forecast the present trend of hot days and warm nights to continue in the coming days due to persisting easterlies.

"Sky condition likely to be partly cloudy. Maximum and minimum temperatures are likely to be around 32°C and 23°C for the next 48 hours in the city," IMD said in its forecast.

On Saturday, the city recorded a maximum temperature of 32.2°C at Nungambakkam and 31.8°C at Meenambakkam - 1.2°C and 1.5°C normal.

Experts said the southern region, including coastal cities such as Chennai, experiences above-normal temperatures due to persisting easterlies. Usually, Chennai has cooler nights with temperatures dropping below 18°C or 19°C when cold northerly winds move southwards during January and February.

But this year, easterly winds have been consistently blowing since the end of the northeast monsoon and northerly winds have been absent.

"There's no sign of northerly winds. The present above-normal temperatures will continue. Though the long range forecast for winter for the Indian region was warm, northern regions like Delhi, Punjab and Rajasthan have been experiencing extremely cold conditions while the southern region has been warm," said N Puviarasan, director, Area Cyclone Warning Centre, IMD, Chennai.

Title: 100 protesters 'swell to 2,000' as cops make a bid to wind up Mumbai Bagh
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

People arrive in significant numbers to join the protest on Saturday evening. It was the sixth day of the prot... Read More

MUMBAI: Attempts by Mumbai Police and some groups to call off a protest against CAA and NCR at Mordell Road at Mumbai Central resulted in the crowd multiplying after the women refused to leave the spot. The agitation gained popularity as ' Mumbai Bagh ' since it is similar to the month-long protest being held at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi.

On Saturday, police personnel told volunteers to vacate the area as they did not have permission to stage a protest. While people were being told to leave, a human chain was formed around the site to prevent police from evicting the protesters, who are mostly women. "Some people had left the spot, but suddenly, within 30 minutes, a huge crowd of women who did not know that the protest was being called off, reached the site and refused to leave. Seeing them, other women who were packing up or had left, returned and refused to leave," said Mohammad Rizwan Shaikh, a volunteer managing the crowd.

Shaikh said that on the first day there were 100-odd people, largely women, but on Saturday the number was around 2,000. A volunteer said they were concerned after a person had fired at a protest at Jamia Millia University and another fired at the protest at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi, so they decided to call off the protest.

The sit-in entered its sixth day on Saturday, with the entire neighbourhood coming together to help each other. They arranged chairs for the elderly, provided tea to beat the night cold and passed around food. "We were not told by anyone to sit on a protest. We came here on the first day on our own, and have been peacefully protesting against what we think is wrong. We will leave when we want to," said Faiza Ahmad, who lives near the protest site.

DCP (zone III) Abhinash Kumar said the protest began around 2pm and personnel had been deployed. The problem began in the evening. "Locals said they wanted to end the protest as they had not take permission and would continue after they got it but some others were against it. This led to verbal clashes but there was no violence," said Kumar.

Title: Mumbai: Good student not only about getting 99/100, says Aishe Ghosh
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Aishe Ghosh (ANI Photo)

By: Rudrika Iyer

MUMBAI: The term "anti-national" has been repeated so many times, that it has lost its meaning in our nation, said Aishe Ghosh , president of JNU Students' Union. Ghosh was speaking at Mumbai Collective, a gathering of city's intelligentsia, organised at Y B Chavan Centre, Nariman Point.

The two-day event will see speakers from across the spectrum, including social activists, politicians and intellectuals.

Ghosh said that when Union minister of state Anurag Thakur says "shoot bullets", it is not considered "anti-national", if somebody comes forward with a gun, that won't be called "anti national", but if the child of a Dalit comes and asks for education, his caste will be questioned and he will be called "anti-national".

She said the government was trying to de-legitimise other struggles in the country in the name of Jamia and JNU. "We can't forget the other colleges that are also fighting. It is important to recognise students' protest over fee hikes...," said Ghosh. She added that protests across the country at TISS, in Hyderabad, or in Assam or Jammu & Kashmir need to be recognised as they are part of the fight.

She said that being a good student was not only about getting 99/100 in exams, but about understanding and learning civics and democracy too, and she was proud that students today were doing that.

"The meaning of a 'student' is not only about reading a history book and learning what Hitler did. A student is one who understands things and finds similarities in our country...," she said.

Title: Kolkata port staff worry over corporatisation
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

KOLKATA: Which major port in the country will the Centre choose to corporatise in order to improve efficiency?

While Nirmala Sitharaman dropped no hints in her Budget speech, officials at Kolkata Port Trust , now renamed Syama Prasad Mookerjee Port Trust (SPMPT), are keeping their fingers crossed. For the first time in 20 years, the port has registered a net profit. More importantly, it has finally shed its pension liabilities and the profit figure will grow exponentially in the years to come.

“We can’t say which port will be chosen. Though draft is a problem at both Kolkata and Haldia, SPMPT has several advantages. It handles the largest number of ships am-ong India’s major ports. It has started utilising the nearly 50-metre draft at the Sandheads to handle cape-size vessels. This is adding to the volume of cargo and revenue. Container handling has also grown in the port and it is located at a crucial junction from where inland water trade can be controlled not only within India but also to Bangladesh,” an official said.

While being liability-free may make SPMPT attractive for corporatisation , employees are worried that this may result in downsizing. Employees fear that once any attempt is made to corporatise the port, investors will be on the lookout for a leaner entity with outsourcing of jobs. The port’s large landholding may also make it attractive to private investors, they feel.

Garden Reach Shipbuild-ers and Engineers in Kolkata has already been corporatis-ed by the defence ministry. So has Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation . At both places, there is a rush now to bag fresh orders to keep shareholders satisfied.

Title: Damage to water pipeline leaves suburbs thirsty, BMC & MMRDA play blame game
Content:
Ghatkopar residents form a serpentine queue for a few buckets of water on Saturday

MUMBAI: Lakhs of residents in parts of the suburbs faced a difficult time over a couple of days due to non-availability of drinking water after a pipeline got damaged at Jogeshwari-Vikhroli Link Road when work on the Metro was on. Even as households ran dry—with not a drop to drink, literally—the municipal authorities and the agency implementing the Metro work passed the buck to one another.Trouble started on Thursday evening after the pipeline got punctured during piling work on metro line VI, said officials. The piling rig drill got stuck into the pipeline. even as officials tried to divert flow of water into a storm water drain to avoid a soggy mess on the street as it would lead to a traffic jam.At the time of filing this report on Saturday evening, the BMC claimed it had completed repair work to the damaged pipeline and said normal supply would be restored from Sunday.A group of people from Jogeshwari spilled onto the streets, protesting against the authorities. They blocked vehicular traffic on Jogeshwari-Vikhroli Link Road briefly on Saturday afternoon.The damage to the pipeline compelled residents to arrange for tankers to supply water to their homes. The crisis affected not only households, but also commercial establishments. Parts of Bandra, Khar, Santacruz were affected only on the western side while residents of Vile Parle, Andheri, Jogeshwari in the west and east were severely hit due to shortage of water. In Goregaon, only the eastern side was affected. In the central suburbs, parts of the western side of Kurla and Ghatkopar faced severe shortage.BMC officials claimed that they had arranged water tankers from elsewhere in the city and provided free water to citizen who had called them for help. However, residents had a different story to tell.Farzana Shaikh, a resident of Daswani Society at Four Bungalows in Andheri (west), said her entire locality had been affected since Thursday. “We called BMC officials but got no help... We tried to arrange water through tankers and even offered to pay extra, but got nor esponse. For two days, we somehow managed with the supply from a ring well in our building... On the third day, we had to purchase mineral water...”However, demand for mineral water had surged due to paucity of water in the suburbs, said a resident of Andheri (east). “I had sent my employee to a couple of big shops in my locality to buy gallons of mineral water, but they had all run out of mineral water,” said the resident.Corporator from Bandra Asif Zakaria (Congress) said only a few pockets were supplied water by the BMC. “The rest struggled to get tankers. There was no Plan B in place to deal with the emergency,” he said.The region’s development agency, MMRDA, which is implementing the metro rail work, said that the BMC to blame. A senior MMRDA official monitoring the situation said that before they started piling work for the Metro VI line, they had requested the BMC to provide marking of underground utilities that snake beneath the road.“Our engineers had not been informed specifically about this 1,800mm, major utility lying 9 metres beneath the ground,” said an MMRDA official. “So, unfortunately this led to damage to the pipeline.”BMC officials said their priority was to repair the pipeline at the earliest. “We had provided all details to MMDRA,” said a BMC official. “If there are specific allegations, I will be able to comment only after examining our records.”

Title: Union Budget 2020: Push for bullet train, Tejas-like services to Mumbai
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman said on Saturday the government will actively pursue the 508km bullet train project between Mumbai and Ahmedabad, which has been facing challenges on the land acquisition front in Maharashtra. The FM also announced more Tejas-like trains, including 150 on a public- private partnership basis. Most of these trains will run on the Mumbai-Delhi and Howrah-Delhi routes as there will be capacity augmentation due to commissioning of dedicated freight corridors.

A Western Railway official said, "The Mumbai-Ahmedabad Tejas Express has been a huge hit. We can run more trains on Mumbai-Delhi and Mumbai-Jaipur routes. While Mumbai-Ahmedabad Tejas has chair cars, other private trains with over 16-hour journey will have sleeper berths." The railways have also approved a plan to improve tracks on these two routes to allow trains to run at 160kmph, which has been proposed as the speed limit for private services. To provide comfort to private players, the railways will not run regular services on the same route within 15 minutes of the scheduled operation of the private train.

Title: Kolkata: Cleaner attacks maid at Sunny Park apartment
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Rai Enclave at Sunny Park

KOLKATA: A 23-year-old domestic help survived an attack on her life after a car cleaner in a posh Sunny Park apartment slashed her neck with a knife on Saturday. The incident took place when flat owner, 80-year-old Brijendra Kumar Gupta, who along with his sons runs an international optical retail firm, was taking rest. The help, Pallavi Gupta, who has been with the Guptas for seven years, remains critical.

The incident took place around 3:35pm at Rai Enclave. There were two maids at home at that time. Gupta’s sons stay in adjacent flats. The cleaner, identified as Monojit Maiti (24), who’s a resident of Egra, rang the doorbell. One of the maids opened the door. When Maiti asked for car keys, the maid called Pallavi alias Pinki, the other domestic help. Pallavi handed him the car keys and asked why he came so late. At this, Maiti attacked her with a knife and fled with the car keys. Pallavi was rushed to a hospital. Police said they arrested Maiti from Gariahat Road-Suren Tagore Road crossing. Prima facie, police said the attack was a result of “personal grudge”.

Title: Delhi: Cops on alert before pro-CAA march today
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Delhi Police is on the alert to avert a confrontation at Shaheen Bagh. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police is on the alert to avert a confrontation at Shaheen Bagh after right-wing organisation Hindu Sena threatened to march to the site of the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protest where the Kalindi Kunj road has been blocked by protesters for around 50 days now.

Speaking to TOI, Hindu Sena president Vishnu Gupta said his group had decided some days ago to march to Shaheen Bagh. “These anti-national protesters have blocked the road and are not listening to police or the courts. People there are giving speeches against the Hindus and trying to divide this country,” he alleged.

Delhi Police has made elaborate arrangements to ensure there are no untoward incidents. Mandeep Randhawa, PRO, Delhi Police, said, “We have not given any permission to Hindu Sena. They will not be allowed to march to Shaheen Bagh. We will have police deployed there for this.”

A message circulated by Hindu Sena to ask people for support said, “The ‘jihadis’ at Shaheen Bagh need to vacate the blocked road and we must all reach there. Delhi wants freedom from traitors and these middlemen of Pakistan.” Gupta confirmed it was a message sent by his organisation. He also said that the fringe group felt it was its responsibility to tackle the protesters. “The anger among the people is rising,” he said. “Firing karne par majboor ho gaye hain (people are now forced to resort to guns).”

Gupta said he was not against the residents demonstrating against CAA, but wanted them to express their resentment in a place allowed by law, such the usual protest sites of Ramlila Maidan and Jantar Mantar. “I also don’t support any form of violence,” added Gupta.

Police will be on their toes because UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath is also slated to hold election rallies on Sunday in Okhla and Tughlakabad, both not too far from Shaheen Bagh.

Meanwhile, Updesh Rana, whose name had popped up on the Facebook wall of the youth who fired at a Jamia Millia Islamia student on Thursday, claimed neither to have met the shooter nor to be aware of the teenager’s motives. Rana who is a Meerut native, has been living in Surat in Gujarat for the past two years and was in Bihar on Saturday for an event. He is the national president of NGO Youth Brigade.

He told TOI, “I will always support anything that is in the nation’s favour. I don’t know this boy who used a gun. Many people meet me at my programmes and click pictures with me.” Rana also claimed that he didn’t appreciate anyone resorting to violence. He did, however, reveal that he has called for a rally to get the Kalindi Kunj road vacated on February 9. “If these people can protest, so can we to get the road opened,” Rana asserted.

Title: BBMP to whitetop RV Road from today
Content:

BENGALURU: The stretch from Teachers' Training College to South End Circle on RV Road will be closed for traffic for over a month with BBMP commencing whitetopping on Sunday.

Commuters travelling towards Jayanagar and JP Nagar from Lalbagh West Gate are supposed to take a left at the college, proceed towards Ashoka Pillar, take a right towards Patalamma Temple and reach South End Circle.

"We require 14 days for curing the concrete," a BBMP official said while maintaining that measures have been taken to ensure there is no delay. After he stretch is whitetopped, the agency plans to take up work on the stretch from Teachers' Training College to Lalbagh West Gate.

While BBMP claims the stret ch will have no potholes after whitetopping, many netizens took potshots at the civic agency for failing to prioritise work. "White topping on already good road, while Mahadevapura runs on mud road (sic)," a tweet read pointing out how BBMP was redoing good roads while many remain unattended for decades.

Daily users were not enthused as whitetopping will add to their misery. "Metro construction, flyover demolition and white topping all in one area... Great concern for public convenience (sic)," mocked another netizen.

"Sir, why not focus on roads that have gone bad. Why rip apart good roads and block them for months for whitetopping (sic)," a resident asked the BBMP commissioner.

Title: Fares of Bengaluru’s planned suburban rail will be based on Metro model
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

In 2016, hundreds of citizens formed a chain to press the demand for a suburban train network in the country’... Read More

BENGALURU: The fare structure of commuter trains that will run on the proposed 148-km suburban network will be similar to that of the Metro, according to the 2020-21 Union Budget unveiled on Saturday.

This essentially means there won’t be a major difference between the ticket prices of Metro and suburban rail in Bengaluru, unlike in Mumbai and Chennai where rail commute costs much less than Metro trips, according to a railway official.

“The 148-km-long Bengaluru suburban transport project, with a cost of Rs 18,600 crore, will have fares on the Metro model. The central government will provide 20% of the equity and facilitate external assistance of up to 60% of the project cost,” finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced in Parliament.

The Bengaluru suburban rail project is yet to take shape, facing repeated planning delays. The project cost, however, has already increased by Rs 1,600 crore. In 2018-19 Budget, the then finance minister Arun Jaitley, had mentioned Rs 17,000 crore as the cost of developing a 160-km suburban rail network.

The Indian Railways’ 2018-19 ‘Pink Book’, which follows the budget proposal and lists funding for projects, had mentioned an allocation of only Rs 1 crore for the year for the Bengaluru suburban rail. In 2019-20 Pink Book, the amount was Rs 10 crore. This year’s allocation will be known after the document is tabled in Parliament next week, mostly February 5.

When will the wait end?

Transport experts and Bengalureans who have been tracking the project were not impressed by the budget announcement, saying 37 years had passed, but there had been little progress on the ground.

In July 2019, RITES, a government undertaking, submitted a revised detailed project report to the railways. It included four corridors: KSR Bengaluru City Devanahalli, Byappanahalli-Chikkabanavara, Kengeri-Cantonment-Whitefield, and Heelalige-Rajanukunte. The number of suburban stations was reduced to 53 from 82 proposed earlier, and the length of the network was also revised from 161km to 148km.

In November 2019, the Railway Board cleared the project. The final cabinet note is yet to be processed by the finance ministry. Once that happens, it will be placed before the Cabinet Committee on Economic Affairs.

The network that rail planners have envisioned is likely to be the country’s first modern suburban train system. Its stations will have a different look than traditional stations, offering more facilities. There will be automated fare collection gates for cashless travel. Fiftythree air-conditioned trains, with automated sliding doors, will be deployed in the first phase. Railway sources said the minimum fare could be Rs 13 for less than 3km. In Chennai and Mumbai, a train trip for the same distance costs Rs 5 currently. “For a 15-km trip, the fare will be Rs 35 as against Rs 45 in Metro,” an official said.

Title: Union Budget 2020: Delhi gets stepmotherly treatment, says Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal during a public rally ahead of Delhi assembly elections in New Delhi on S... Read More

दिल्ली को बजट से बहुत उम्मीदें थी। लेकिन एक बार फिर दिल्ली वालों के साथ सौतेला व्यवहार हुआ। दिल्ली भाजपा के प्राथमि… https://t.co/fICDmxELAJ — Arvind Kejriwal (@ArvindKejriwal) 1580546838000

NEW DELHI: Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) on Saturday said it was disappointed with the Centre for ignoring its repeated requests and yet again allocating just Rs 325 crore as Delhi’s share in central taxes . This amount has been stagnant since FY 2001-02.AAP claimed that the Centre had showed its apathy in the Budget by reducing the overall allocation for education and giving a green signal to foreign direct investment (FDI) in schools. Delhi chief minister and AAP supremo Arvind Kejriwal said that he had expected a larger allocation for the capital, considering that assembly elections are less than a week away.Taking a dig at BJP, which released its election manifesto on Friday, Kejriwal tweeted in Hindi: “Delhi had high expectations from the Budget. But once again it has been given stepmotherly treatment by the Centre. If Delhi is not BJP’s priority, why should people vote for the party? If BJP is disappointing Delhi before the elections, will it keep promises after the elections?”Talking to reporters, deputy CM and finance minister Manish Sisodia alleged that the Budget lacked vision, was “disappointing” in the critical education sector and had “deceived” Delhiites.Disappointed with the Centre reducing the allocation for the education sector from 3.6% to 3.2%, Sisodia said, “I had expected an increase in the education budget in line with the National Education Policy, which says 6% of the GDP should be spent on this sector. The decrease clearly shows the apathy of BJP towards education.”“Allowing FDI in education is a dangerous step. BJP wants to make education a profit-making business. It also shows that BJP is only interested in giving education to a certain class of people,” Sisodia said.Sisodia said all states get a 42% share from their contribution to central taxes, but Delhi had been getting a miniscule Rs 325 crore for almost two decades. “Delhi pays about Rs 1.5 lakh crore as taxes. We had asked the Centre to enhance the share to Rs 7,000 crore to finance development projects. The Delhi budget has increased from Rs 8,739 crore in 2001-02 to Rs 60,000 crore in 2019-20. However, the share in central taxes has remained frozen at Rs 325 crore,” he added.The deputy chief minister said that despite governing the three municipal corporations, BJP didn’t earmark any funds for them. Delhi government had asked for allocation of at least Rs 1,250 crore in the 2020-21 budget estimates. “Delhi government gives 12.5% of its annual net tax collection to the local bodies, but they are not getting any financial support from the Centre,” added Sisodia.“BJP had in the 2017 municipal corporation polls declared that the local bodies would get funds directly from the Centre. What happened to their promise? Was it another jumla?” Sisodia asked.Claiming that the new income tax slabs for the salaried class were complicated, Sisodia said people won’t be able to save anything from their hard-earned money.
