Title: NRI Tax in Budget 2020: NRI definition changed to stop tax avoidance
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The Budget has tightened the screws on those seeking to escape tax by exploiting their non-resident status. While earlier it was possible to be classified as non-resident by staying out of the country for 183 days or about six months in a year, this has now been, in effect, enhanced to 245 days.

The change has been made because some taxpayers divided their time between India and overseas to avoid being categorised as tax residents in India. Once a tax resident is further classified as ordinarily resident (OR), he pays tax in India on his global income, which would include say interest income on overseas bank accounts.

As Parizad Sirwalla , partner and head, global mobility services (tax) at KPMG India points out, “Indian citizens and persons of Indian origin who were on visit to India had an extended period of 182 days of stay in India (as opposed to 60 days) before they could be regarded as a resident from an income tax perspective. This period is proposed to be reduced to 120 days now.”

As things stand, an individual is a resident in India for a particular financial year if he has been here for an overall period of 365 days or more within the four years preceding and an overall period of 60 days in that particular year. The 182-day relaxation was made available to Indian citizens and persons of Indian origin.

‘Only The Stateless Will Be Deemed Indian And Taxed’

The Budget memorandum pointed out that this relaxed duration of 182 days was misused by individuals who had significant economic activity in India (say a business), managed their period of stay, so as to remain a nonresident in perpetuity. With such individuals now being required to stay out of the country for 245 days in a year, the misuse becomes more difficult for those having business interests in India.

Gautam Nayak, tax partner at CNK & Associates cautions, “NRIs or Overseas Citizens of India, visiting relatives in India need to now be more careful and limit their stays to less than 120 days in a year, or else they may face tax on their worldwide income.”

After having determined an individual as a tax resident, there is a secondary test to determine whether the individual qualifies as a not ordinarily resident (NOR) or ordinarily resident (OR). Currently there are complex rules to determine when a person is NOR. This has been simplified to say that a person is NOR for a particular financial year if he has been a non-resident in seven out of the ten preceding years. This determination is critical as while an ‘NOR’ is only taxed on India income, an individual who is an ‘OR’ is taxable on his worldwide income.

Another change made is that an Indian citizen not ‘liable to tax’ in any other country or territory shall be deemed to be resident in India. At first glance, it appeared that India’s diaspora which works in Gulf countries (where there is no tax on individual income) would be badly hit.

However, the Finance Bill added that this would be the case if the individual is not liable to tax in any other country by reason of his domicile, or residence or any other criteria of similar nature. Nayak adds, “The SC in the case of Azadi Bachao Andolan has held that the term ‘liable to tax’ is not the same as ‘is actually taxed’. The OECD Model Tax Convention also provides that a person does not have to be actually paying tax to be “liable to tax”. If the host country chooses not to tax such income, it does not mean that they are not “liable to tax” in that country. They may still not be regarded as residents of India. However, the issue needs to be clarified to avoid litigation. This provision would therefore perhaps only impact those Indian citizens who are not residents of any country at all.”

ANI quoted the revenue secretary, Ajay Bhusan Pandey , as saying that only if an Indian citizen is not a resident of any country in the world, he will be deemed to be a resident of India and his worldwide income will be taxed. Amarpal S Chadha, partner and India mobility leader at EY-India says, “The intent behind this amendment is to tax the Indian citizens who are stateless and enjoy the privilege of not paying taxes in any country or jurisdiction, based on their tax planning. However, a formal clarification on this will be helpful to avoid litigation.”

Title: Jharkhand: Cop kills wife, 2 kids; arrested
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

RANCHI: A policeman posted as a driver with the special branch headquarters of the state police department killed his wife and two children after an alleged argument at their rented house in Chandragupta colony here on Friday night. Sadar police arrested the accused, Brajesh Tiwary, in a highly intoxicated state and admitted him to Rims.

Though police could not record Tiwary's statement as he had consumed some pills and was in a highly intoxicated state, various sources said Tiwary was involved in an argument with his wife Rinki Devi soon after coming home on Friday evening. He became violent and attacked his wife (35), daughter Khusboo (15) and son Badal (10) with a hammer and a knife, killing them on the spot, the sources said. Police said the motive and the manner in which he killed them would be known only after questioning Tiwary.

SP (city) Saurav said, "We have sent an FSL team to the house to collect evidence against the accused."

Tiwary's landlord Baldeo Sahu said the family was living at his flat for the past two years and had never heard the couple quarrelling.

Title: Heroin recovery: STF to call Akali Dal functionary; BJP demands strict action
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

AMRITSAR: The anti-drug Special Task Force (STF) is likely to summon SAD functionary Anwar Masih to join investigations after the recovery of around 194 kilogram heroin in Amritsar. The narcotics substance’s refining and processing was being done in Masih’s house. Even SAD alliance partner BJP has demanded exemplary action against all those found involved in the drug racket.

Talking to TOI on Saturday, STF inspector general (IG) Kaustubh Sharma said all the six accused were produced in a local court and taken on 10 days remand. He said a notice under section 67 of the NDPS Act would be issued to Masih to join the investigations.

“In due course, all those who are involved in the case, including owner of the house, should be called. Owner is liable under section 25 of the NDPS Act, even if he has not taken due diligence to protect his property, particularly from being used for narcotics,” the IG added.

State BJP president Ashwani Sharma demanded an unbiased investigation into the incident of smuggling and processing of heroin in Amritsar. “Whosoever is found involved in the drug racket should be taken to task and exemplary punishment be awarded to them,” Ashwani said, adding that truth should prevail at all costs.

When asked whether he would take up the issue with SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal , he replied, “I have said what I have to.”

His predecessor and Rajya Sabha member Shwait Malik said, “Recovery of such a huge amount of narcotics from the holy city is worrisome.” He said there was a possibility that many consignments could have already found their way into India undetected.

On the role of SAD leader, he said, “This is not a political issue but an issue of national interest. Strict action should be taken against anyone found involved in the drug racket. Whosoever is guilty, should be behind the bar.”

Title: Sector allocation fell from 9.61 per cent to 9.30 per cent: Farm bodies
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

The farmers have denounced the claims of the Union Budget that the farm income will be doubled by 2022

BATHINDA: . The farmers have denounced the claims of the Union Budget that the farm income will be doubled by 2022. They said the allocation for agriculture, irrigation, allied activities and rural development & panchayati raj is less than what it was for 2019-20 budget. If it is weighed against the total budget, the allocation has come down from 9.61% to 9.30%. The farmers also have expressed their discontent as the Budget has made no mention of farm debt waiver or implementation of Swaminathan committee recommendations.

Although Budget 2020 has hiked the amount allocated to the farm sector by 5.5% — from Rs 2.68 lakh crore in Budget 2019 to Rs 2.83 lakh crore now — when calculated in terms of percentage of total budget, the allocation has come down. In the previous budget, the allocation for farm sector was Rs. 2.68 lakh crore out of total budget of Rs 27.86 lakh crore which worked out as 9.61% of the total budget. Now, allocation has increased to Rs 2.83 crore but it is out of the enhanced budget of Rs 30.42 lakh crore, which means farm sector gets 9.30% of the pie.

Various farmers’ unions also claim that PM-Kisan scheme was supposed to benefit 12 crore families, but only 6.12 crore beneficiaries got Rs 6,000 in a year. “We were expecting some relief. The government is patting its back only by making small increases in MSP of kharif and rabi crops and providing only Rs 6,000 as relief to farmers which is highly insufficient. We have now lost every faith in the government,” said farm organisation BKU Sidhupur leader Baldev Singh Sandoha .

Even though Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has announced schemes for farmers, like kisan rail and Krishi udaan, in the budget, including a promise that the government will to invest widely in agricultural infrastructure, the farmers are unhappy that the government is doing nothing about farm debt waiver as well as the implementation of Swaminathan committee recommendations over fixing MSP of crops by including all costs, said activists of farm organisations.

“The farmers and farm labourers are committing suicides across the country. The government held debates over it in parliament, but when it comes to providing relief to aggrieved farmers, the governments prefers to keep mum. We were expecting some announcement on debt waiver,” said farm organisation BKU Ekta Ugrahan general secretary Sukhdev Singh Kokri .

General secretary of BKU Ekta Dakonda Jagmohan Singh echoed a similar sentiment. “Nothing has been planned to decrease the burden of debt ridden farmers and labourers who are committing suicides. The government are so scared of the farmer suicides that it is not even fully publishing the data. Nothing has been spoken about the implementation of the recommendations of Swaminathan commission as well.”

Title: Man dies, drug overdose suspected
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: A person who was allegedly hooked to drugs died under mysterious circumstances at Mai Jeena Indira colony of Jagraon on Friday. The police have started a probe into the matter after getting information about the incident on Saturday.

The deceased was identified as 30-year-old Hardeep Singh who was a lone bread earner for his family and worked in a marriage palace.

Police officials said Hardeep had been hooked to drugs for the past about five years. They said he died under mysterious circumstances on Friday morning.

Cops said a prominent resident of the area claimed that he died of drug overdose. After the incident, family conducted the last rites on Friday itself.

Inspector Jagjit Singh, SHO, City Jagraon police station, said they got the information about the death of Hardeep on Saturday and started probe into the matter.

Title: Step-fatherly treatment meted out to Punjab in Union Budget: Amarinder
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chandigarh: Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh has claimed that the proposed Union Budget was high on pomposity and low on tangibles, in which the state has been meted out step-fatherly treatment.

He said on Saturday that Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman even failed to mention the economic slowdown of 2019-20, and there was nothing in the BJP-led central government’s Budget that could pave the way for economic reforms or revive the economy.

Amarinder pointed out that the 16-point action plan for agriculture in the budget document makes no mention of any initiatives or schemes to encourage crop diversification. As buffer stocks of foodgrain were already putting a strain on states like Punjab and farmers, failure to diversify would further aggravate the problems for the country on the agriculture front, he added.

He also attacked the central government for its “failure to address the concern” of the states, including Punjab, on the delays in release of the Goods and Service Tax (GST) compensation. “Where will we get the money for the development of our state?” Amarinder said. It was really a matter of serious concern for Punjab and other states that the central government had decided to limit the GST compensation fund to collections under GST cess, he added and warned it would further add to the problems of the states.

Capt Amarinder castigated the failure of the central government’s Budget to make any outlay for the celebration of the 550th anniversary of Guru Nanak Dev and the upcoming 400th birth anniversary celebrations of Guru Teg Bahadur, or for the promotion of Sikh culture and heritage. The central government has excluded Punjab from the districts where the Centre intended to focus on for water conservation, despite the fact that Punjab was severely water-stressed, he said. The chief minister claimed that even the special tourism projects announced in the budget were meant only for BJP-ruled states.

The chief minister also raised questions on the failure of the central government to provide the much-needed push to infrastructure, and strengthen the irrigation and power sectors. He also termed the Rs 10,340 crore hike provided for modernisation of the defence forces and purchase of new weapon systems as a “pathetic joke”. “This is worse than the increment even a clerk expects at the end of the year,” he said.

Amarinder said with a meagre Rs 27,300 crore allocated for promotion of industry and commerce would not help much. Without drawing any roadmap on the way forward, and announcement of grandiose plans to make every district an export hub shows how clueless the government was, alleged the chief minister. The 10% increase in the health sector over last year’s allocation can hardly be termed sufficient for the needs of a nation of billion plus, he said.

Title: Scientists undergo training on advances in livestock
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ludhiana: The directorate of extension education, Guru Angad Dev Veterinary and Animal Sciences University, organised a one-day workshop-cum-training programme on ‘Latest Advances in Livestock, Poultry and Fisheries’ for scientists of Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs), Regional Research and Training Centres (RRTCs) as well as from the university who regularly engage in various extension activities.

The workshop was attended by 31 scientists.

Dr H K Verma, director extension education-cum-course director presided over function and interacted with the scientists and appraised the work done by all the KVKs in the welfare of livestock farming community of Punjab.

He said that livestock, poultry and fish farming is an important aspect for the farmers for the income generation as well as livelihood security and university is continuously making efforts for farmers, farm women and rural youth to skill them in different areas of dairy, piggery, goatry, poultry, fisheries and value addition so that they can start their own venture and can gain maximum return from their livestock-based enterprises.

Title: At Surajkund mela, HP will be projected to potential tourists: CM
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Shimla: During the inauguration of Surajkund International Crafts Mela, in which Himachal Pradesh was participating as a 'theme state’, chief minister Jai Ram Thakur said the biggest crafts fair of the world has provided a platform to highlight art, culture and tourism of Himachal. President Ram Nath Kovind inaugurated the mela on Saturday.

The CM said Himachal is hoping to project the state from a tourism point of view at the mela as well as provide a platform to its diverse products from handicrafts to fruits, tea and honey. He told the gathering that helicopter service has been started from Chandigarh to Shimla to facilitate tourists. Flights are being operated from Chandigarh to Shimla, Shimla to Kullu and Shimla to Dharamshala under the ‘Uddan’scheme.

Title: Another helmet-less rider loses life in accident
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ludhiana: A Punjab Roadways bus crushed a scooterist to death on bus stand flyover on Saturday. According to police, the victim, identified as Pritpal Singh of Sargodha Colony near Model Town, was not wearing a helmet. There have been several accidents in the recent past where people riding without helmets have been killed.

After incident, the bus driver escaped, leaving the bus on the spot.

ASI Chand Ahrir, in-charge at Bus Stand police post said in initial investigation, the police have identified that Pritpal was going towards Atam Nagar. The man had reached the middle of the flyover when he lost control. He fell down from his scooter, a Punjab Roadways bus coming from other side of flyover crushed him to death.

Onlookers raised the alarm after which the driver stopped the bus, but fled the scene. The accident led to traffic jam on the flyover. A little later, Pritpal was taken to the hospital, but doctors declared him brought dead.

The ASI said the family members of the victim are settled abroad. The police have contacted his relative to record a statement and further inform his family. The police will further proceed after recording the statement. The body has been kept in the mortuary.

Title: Middle class professional family feels budget a mixed bag
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ludhiana: As finance minister Nirmala Sitaraman presented the annual budget on Saturday, this family is not satisfied with the announcements in it, even as it does consider some measures as good ones. Dr Anshu Gupta is a reputed psychiatrist in the city, and his family includes his parents — father Satpaul Gupta (81), a retired professor; mother Sushma Gupta (78), a retired vice-principal of a private college; wife Dr Charu Gupta; and son Prasit (12) — all of whom have a take on the budget.

Reacting to the budget, Anshu said the most important aspect of the budget they wait for is tax rebates, but in the current budget, there is not much for those looking for saving, especially those earning more than Rs5 lakh per annum. He added that they only feel that since the economy has already touched its lowest ebb, there cannot be more bad news on the economic front, but they expected the government to announce new schemes to boost economy and create new jobs. However, he said there were some good initiatives in the budget, including a proposal to start 150 Tejas trains.

His wife Charu said the good thing about the budget was that the government had announced the setting up of more hospitals in the tier-II and III cities under the public-private-partnership (PPP) route. She added, “It is good the government also initiated a programme to set up 1.5 lakh health and wellness centres (HWCs) by 2022. These initiatives will make medicare better and affordable.”

Satpaul is also not happy with the budget, and says there is not much relief to the salaried class , which is grappling with high inflation. He added, “The government has announced it would start five new smart cities, but most of such cities announced by it in the past are yet to be developed.”

His grandson Prasit is, however, happy with the budget. “The government’s proposal to allow foreign investment in the education sector will be good for students, as big universities of the world will set up their centres in India,” said Prasit, who studies in Class VII.

Title: ‘Budget incentives would help economy take off within four months’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

This is a very positive budget and will not only help attract greater investment in India but will also help economy immensely. The abolition of DDT and reduction of corporate tax are big positive indicators and will allow greater investment to come into industry. Overall these two steps will prove to be very beneficial for the business. Overall, I feel this is very good budget as money flow /savings are being increased in the hands of very large number of people. There will be big savings for the middle class due to the substantial reduction in the income tax rates. So if the middle class gets to do savings it will give a big boost to the Fast Moving Consumer Goods (FMCG) consumption.

Increase in funding for the schemes for weaker sections will lead to increase in the consumption and will be substantially beneficial for all sectors. I believe economy will take off in about three to four months time with these initiatives and by October November we can expect big change. Regarding increased allocations for weaker sections of society, any welfare scheme of this nature result in big increase in consumption. Given this government’s track record of quick disbursal and direct transfer, its effect on our economy is going to be pretty good and will lead to increase in consumptions. I am inclined to believe the finance minister statement that GDP will rise up, though I may not agree with 10% figure but definitely the growth rate would be significantly higher than the last year. The growth rate might start inching upwards quite ramarkbly. This is largely on the basis of increase in expenditures for the weaker sections and decrease in the income tax slabs. Both the factors combined are set to play a big role. These all aspects might not sound great to large number of people right now, but the economic impact of these steps is going to be visible in the coming days.

Akshay Bector, Chairman cum managing director of Cremica Food Industries Limited.

Title: Sukhbir calls Budget pro-farmer, pro-poor
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chandigarh: SAD president Sukhbir Singh Badal on Saturday termed the Union Budget as pro-farmer and pro-poor.

He said the common man would benefit from reduction in income tax and ground had been laid for achieving a higher gross domestic product (GDP) by giving a boost to digitisation, infrastructure and industry.

Sukhbir welcomed the allocation of Rs 15 lakh crore to agricultural sector and said farmers across the country, including Punjab, would benefit from the government’s decision to go solar by subsidising 20 lakh standalone solar pumps.

Similarly, the decision to set up ‘Kisan Rail’ through public-private partnership (PPP) mode to transport perishable goods quickly as well as Krishi Udaan to transport agriculture goods to national and international destinations would give a much-needed boost to vegetable and horticulture sector in Punjab, he added. “Insurance cover given to six crore farmers under the Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojna is also a path breaking step and will shield farmers from the vagaries of nature,” said the SAD president. He lauded incentives in fish farming and balanced fertilizers.

Sukhbir also lauded the provision of Rs 85,000 crore for the welfare of scheduled castes and backward classes. “This, coupled with the government’s decision to restructure loans of more than five lakh MSMEs, would help in revival of small units,” he said.

Title: ‘Smart’ list: More cities added, but Ludhiana remains ‘unsmart’
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ludhiana: As Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced in her budget speech to develop five more ‘Smart’ cities in India, Ludhiana residents questioned the FM’s move while seeking answers on the status of 100 ‘Smart’ cities, including the industrial capital of Punjab, which had been announced earlier.

The residents claimed that Smart City projects had not taken off properly in the city and nothing ‘Smart’ has happened till date. They also claimed that no mention was made about the allocations for the projects this year.

Ludhiana was selected in the first top 20 list to be developed as Smart Cities in January 2016. But even after four years, not many projects have seen completion. Though some projects have made it to the execution stage, the pace has remained slow.

The residents claimed that when the city was selected among the first top 20 smart cities, they had hoped to see a lot of smart things in the city, but nothing has materialized on the ground.

A resident of Model Town, Sunil Sharma asked the FM what happened to earlier Smart City projects which featured Ludhiana as well. He said they do not know the status of Smart City projects and even the ongoing projects are not clear to the residents.

He said there are no boards around the site to educate people about the ongoing projects and also about its completion time. He demanded that instead of making more announcements, previous cities should be developed as smart in the first place.

Rahul Verma, another resident of Sarabha Nagar, said, “The FM should have first elaborated about the status of 100 ‘Smart’ cities, before adding new cities to the list. The Ludhiana smart city officials should also make people aware of the ongoing projects by displaying the plans at the site and giving update from time to time.”

Notably for Ludhiana, DPRs of projects worth Rs 1,000 crore have already been prepared. The officials will not include fresh projects, instead will execute announced projects now.

Title: Budget: Little cheer for industry
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Ludhiana: “Wealth creators will be respected in the country,” a remark made by Union finance minister Nirmala Seetharaman on Saturday while presenting her second Union Budget failed to find many takers among corporates as she failed to announce any relief directly related to any industrial sector.

One of the moves which was being projected as her boldest to abolish dividend distribution tax (DDT), which is currently 15% and is paid by the companies on the dividend paid to its shareholders, too failed to cheer up the industrialists as the liability has been passed on to recipients of the dividend.

Besides, the other concern being expressed by the businessmen is about the withdrawal of 70 types of tax exemption about which there is little clarity.

However, the corporates were still happy with the overall budget as they felt that slashing of income tax slabs for middle class and earmarking funds for various schemes like combating pollution are going to contribute to rise in demand of goods and services.

Onkar Singh Pahwa, chairman, Avon Cycles Limited, said “We are very happy with the budget as overall several good decisions have been taken by the Union finance minister, aiming at increasing the spending power of people which in turn will lead to increase in demand of goods and services.”

“Besides reduction in I-T slabs, commitment to boost infrastructure, agriculture, healthcare services and simplifying tax returns and easy resolution of the tax disputes are going to make positive impact on people from all walks of life,” he added.

“We had been demanding reduction in 15% dividend distribution tax (DDT) from the government. Though DDT was abolished today, but it is not going to serve the purpose as the entire load is now going to be passed on to the recipient of the DDT which means that from the present rate of 10% tax, the recipient will now end up paying 29% tax on the dividend. Moreover, the announcement to do away with 70 types of income tax exemption too can lead to rise in income tax liability, but exact implications will be ascertained only when exact details about the exemptions withdrawn emerges,” Pahwa said.

Pankaj Munjal, chairman-cum-managing director, Hero Cycles Limited, said, “The central government’s decision to allocate 4,400 crores for tackling pollution in cities with a population of over a million is a progressive move, which is in line with the commitment India had made to honour the climate change agreement in Paris.”

“Clean energy and transport must be the focal point, and the FM has already announced measures to boost the latter with the decision to provide funds to set up grid connected solar pumps and turn fallow and barren lands into power generation sites,” Munjal added.

“The government must incentivise e-vehicle manufacturers, and funnel a portion of the Rs 1.7 lakh crore earmarked for boosting transport infrastructure to make e-bike friendly roads and parking spaces to reduce congestion in the urban areas, and promote environment friendly transportation. Heavy taxation on raw materials for e-vehicles is still a cause for concern and we expect the government to reduce the GST rate so that EV manufacturers are encouraged to set up battery manufacturing units in the country,” Hero Cycle CMD said.

Komal Kumar Jain, chairman of Duke Fashions, said, “It is a normal budget. There was nothing for any sector of industry. Though we are happy that steps have been taken for farmers, under-privileged, middle class and others. I wonder how Union finance minister Nirmala Seetharaman has claimed that the country will be able to achieve 10% GDP growth. I wish that it becomes a reality soon.”

“The announcements in terms of upgrade of infrastructure like creation of more airports, boosting the railways, setting up more power plants etc should be appreciated provided all of them materialise soon,” Jain said.

Photoquotes: Mixed response

“There was nothing big in the budget. And there were no direct relief for any industrial sector this time. Though there was a mention of changes in the drawback scheme for exporters and introduction of new benefits, as of now there is no clarity about the same. I wonder how the FM chose to ignore the important sectors like textile in the budget”

Jawahar Lal Oswal | chairman-cum-managing director, nahar group of companies

“I think this was a positive and growth-oriented budget. For me, the biggest highlight was acceptance of our demand of refund of state taxes on exports. This step will make exports more competitive. Reducing the income tax slabs is also an appreciable step. I think scrapping DDT too will prove to be beneficial for large industries

Sachit Jain | vice-chairman, vardhman special steels

Title: Hit by infra blues, govt school to see changed fortunes
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Facing serious infrastructure blues in the absence of adequate funds from the government for the past several years, a Dholewal-based government primary school is likely to witness a change in its fortunes soon as a school alumnus along with a US-based NRI and others have decided to pitch in for the purpose.

The school has just six rooms for its 462 students. One of these rooms was a head teacher’s office, but was converted into a classroom to adjust students, especially in the winters. While 63 students of Class I study in one room, 73 Class II students are accommodated in another room. Third room dedicated for Class III has 68 students. The situation is worse for students studying in Class IV, V and pre-primary classes as 81, 89 and 88 students, respectively, are accommodated in three rooms.

The school has inadequate furniture too, that leaves several students to sit on the floor.

Harpreet Kaur, head teacher, GPS Dholewal, Ludhiana 1 block, said, “There is only one office and six classrooms in total. There is no staff room for teachers. We have not received any grant for the classrooms so far. We got grant just for regular repair of the school building.”

“In case we get support, we can repair the existing rooms, windows, install water filters, flooring and construct new toilets and classrooms. A better infrastructure will help us admit more students in the school,” she added.

Taraki Lal Thapar, a member of Dholewal Welfare society, and 1959-batch passout of this school, NRI Gurinderjeet Singh and representatives of some NGOs visited the school recently.

Thapar said, “We have decided to give the school a facelift.” Gurinderjeet Singh said, “We will start repair of windowpanes soon to give students some relief from the chill.”

Teachers said every class has two sections, but both sections have to be clubbed together due to lack of room. On days, when teacher of a particular section feels the need, the classes are held in the verandah. Teachers claimed that though people want to help the school by donating desks, but they back out as the school lacks adequate space for the same in the absence of classrooms.

The school has three washrooms, one each for male students, female students and staff.

Teachers have used polythene on windows to stop chilly winds and utilised the racks to put books in classes in the absence of a library.

Title: Hooda, Selja attack Centre for ‘exacting revenge’ through Budget
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chandigarh/Rohtak: While Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar and other BJP functionaries were all praise for the Union Budget, opposition leaders termed it hollow.

Leader of opposition in assembly Bhupinder Hooda said the Budget was lacklustre for agriculture and economy. “Inflation, unemployment and are at all time high. As expected there was nothing new or visible for the farmers, poor or entrepreneurs. Income tax restructuring too is confusing,” he said.

The former chief minister said, “Real picture will come out when complete budget document is decoded. Just for an example, the restructuring of income tax slabs and withdrawal of exemptions is the first thing, which will confuse a taxpayer.”

Talking to mediapersons at his house in Rohtak, Hooda said that it was an ironic situation when the Union government talks of doubling the farmers income by 2022, but does not offer anything substantial for the farming community in the Budget.

“It not only lacks roadmap for future, but also has failed to address the serious concerns like unemployment, distress on farmers and middle class battling with rising inflation,” he said. Mocking the BJP government at the Centre, Hooda added that just by installing solar pumps, the income of farmers can not be doubled, it requires implementation of recommendations of M S Swaminathan Commission.

Taking about his successor, Hooda said that Khattar was scheduled to come in Rohtak on Sunday and he owed people a report card of last 100 days’ performance of his government.

Meanwhile, Haryana Congress president Kumari Selja said that budget had disappointed people of Haryana and rest of the country. “The BJP government has discriminated against with Haryana in this budget. BJP is taking revenge as it won only 40 seats in the assembly elections in the state,” she added.

Title: Akalis flay Punjab government for plan of liquor delivery
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Former Punjab minister Daljit Singh Cheema

CHANDIGARH: The SAD on Saturday condemned the Punjab government for proposing to start home delivery of liquor in Mohali, saying that the government was running away from its promise of ‘ghar-ghar rozgar’ (employment in every house) and now offering ‘ghar-ghar sharab’ (alcohol in every house).

SAD spokesperson and former Punjab minister Daljit Singh Cheema termed the proposal as shameful and unmindful of the sentiments of people. The proposal was mooted by the state government on Friday, in its excise policy for the year 2020-21. The government wants to implement the plan as a pilot project in Mohali in the first phase.

“A probe must be ordered into this disgusting episode as it goes against the spirit of the Constitution, whose Section 47 states that the state shall work towards prohibiting intoxicants. Here, we have a state which is not only encouraging consumption, but has turned this into a state policy by getting into the business of home delivery of liquor,” said Cheema.

He added the Congress government now wanted unemployed youth to drown their sorrows by ordering liquor online which would not only increase alcoholism among youth but lead to a law and order problem. SAD leader demanded action against officials who wanted to implement this proposal which was bound to cause hurt to the sentiments of people and causing social unrest.

Title: Eminent Punjabi writer, novelist Jaswant Singh Kanwal dies
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

BATHINDA: Noted Punjabi novelist Jaswant Singh Kanwal, 100, died at his house in Dhudike village of Moga district on Saturday morning. He collapsed in the arms of his son Sarbjit, who was buttoning up his shirt after giving him a bath. He was cremated at the village cremation ground later in the afternoon.

Kanwal left studies even before completing his matriculation, but that did not stop him from becoming one of the most celebrated writers in Punjabi. Born on June 27, 1919, months after the Jallianwala Bagh massacre , he wrote fearlessly on Punjab’s social and political issues despite facing a lot of criticism due to his radical opinions on certain issues. His 100th birthday was celebrated on a big scale at Dhudike from June 26 to 30, 2019 and was attended by scores of littérateurs, writers and academicians.

“Jaswant Kanwal was the shining star of Punjabi literature. His contribution in enriching the Punjabi culture is immense. He was the hero of people, especially the rural folk, as many of his works revolved around rural life even though he wrote about many aspects of Punjab. He was worried about Punjab and Punjabiat till his last and in his demise we have lost an icon and an era has ended,” said noted poet Surjit Patar.

Sahitya Akademy awardee Baldev Sadaknama said, “Kanwal is one of the rare writers who are well-connected to roots. He had left studies at the tender age, which is considered a pre-condition to be a good writer, but he proved that writing does not necessarily come from education.”

Kanwal kept himself engaged with whatever happened in Punjab — writing about the struggles of landless farmers in the early 1940s, naxalite movement in the 1960-70s, the militancy era in Punjab. He even wrote an open letter to then Punjab chief minister Parkash Singh Badal to raise various issues confronting the state, including the depleting water table. He came close to Manpreet Singh Badal briefly, when he floated the Peoples Party of Punjab after resigning from the Badal government in 2010. However, it did not last long.

His novel, Lahu Di Lau (Dawn of the Blood), which is based on the naxalite movement in Punjab, is his most famous and controversial. He had to struggle to get this novel published as no publisher here would do it. He had to get it published from Malaysia in the 1970s and was smuggled to Punjab during the Emergency. After some years, the Rajiv Gandhi government had slapped a case against him for questioning the wisdom of the government in one of his writings.

“Jaswant Kanwal lived on his own terms, without bowing before anyone and never cared for the governments while writing the truth (in his works). We have lost doyen of literature in him,” said Punjabi writer Gurbhajan Singh Gill.

“He gave a new meaning and thought to the rural Punjabi populace, as they remained an integral part of his writings and he invented an appropriate rural diction for novel. He was most fascinated by people and layers of readership born in Punjabi are just because of his writing skills,” his grandson Sumail Singh Sidhu, a former Delhi University professor, said.

Kanwal wrote his first romantic work ‘Sach Nu Phansi’ in 1945 and went on to write over 70 books, including 35 novels. His works ‘Lahu Di Lau’, ‘Sach Nu Phansi’, ‘Raat Baki Hai’, ‘Roop Dhara’ and ‘Toshali Di Hanso’ are highly acclaimed. “He got the Sahitya Akademy Award in 1997 for ‘Toshali Di Hanso’,” said Sarbjit. In 2008, the Guru Nanak Deve University conferred him the degree of doctor of literature (Honoris Causa) for his contribution to Punjabi literature.

Kanwal is survived by son Sarabjit and daughters Amarjit Kaur, Charanjit Kaur, Kanwaljit Kaur and Rupinderjit Kaur.

2 Sahitya Akademi awardees gone in 2 days

It is a coincidence that two Sahitya Akademi awardees died in two days, almost a decade after it happened earlier. Kanwal died on Saturday, a day after writer Dalip Kaur Tiwana (84) did in Mohali after a brief illness. Ten years ago, two Sahitya Akademi Award winners — Ram Sarup Ankhi (78) and Harinder Singh Mehboob (70) — had died on February 14, 2010. Only a few days before that, Sahitya Akademi Award winner writer Santokh Singh Dhir had died on February 8, 2010.

Ankhi had won Sahitya Akademi award for his novel ‘Kothe Kharak Singh’ in 1987, Mehboob won it for his poetry book ‘Jhana Di Raat’ in 1991, while Dhir got it for his book on collection of short stories ‘Pakhi’ in 1996. Tiwana had won the Sahitya Akademi award in 1971 for her book ‘Eho Hamara Jiwana’.

Title: Municipal corporation gets 27 new sewerage cleaning machines for Rs 2.5 crore
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

LUDHIANA: In order to improve sewerage cleaning work in the city, civic officials finally got new machines on Saturday. Officials now claim sewermen need not enter manholes for manual cleaning. Even for Buddha Nullah’s regular cleaning, one poclain machine is being purchased under the Smart City Mission funds. Officials claimed the new machines were required to provide better services to the public, because in winter, sewerage cleaning becomes a tough task, and most of the time, sewerage choking creates problems for the general public.

The civic body has received 32 new sewerage cleaning machines (8 big ones and 24 small ones) at a cost of Rs2.5 crore under the Smart City Mission, because the MC does not have funds for such works. The machines will now start cleaning sewerage in various parts of the city. In the absence of machinery, the sewermen used to enter manholes even without safety kits, and several incidents had taken place in the past when sewermen lost their lives or fell unconscious while cleaning the lines.

One of the sewermen claimed there were clear directions from the Supreme Court that manual sewerage cleaning was not allowed, and in case under some circumstances they need to go inside, then it should be done carefully by taking all precautions. He said many fatal incidents happened in the past, and every time civic officials blamed shortage of funds. He hoped they would now get rid of manual cleaning. Superintending engineer of Operation and Maintenance cell Rajinder Singh said they had got the machines, and in this lot, they had received 24 small machines to clear choking in narrow lanes and within residential areas.

Meanwhile, MC had proposed to purchase two poclain machines for regular sewerage cleaning, because at present, the civic body is dependent on the drainage department for its cleaning, which takes place before every monsoon season. However, senior officials in Chandigarh have given approval for purchasing only a single machine, and after seeing the results, the officials can go ahead with second machine.

Title: Ludhiana residents offer mixed views on Budget
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

LUDHIANA: While the Budget announced on Saturday failed to live up to the expectations and demands of the micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME), reduction in income tax slabs and other announcements by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman to encourage manufacturing and automatic refund of export duties are being welcomed by city businessmen.

One of the major announcements that is being especially hailed by the business community is making stricter rules for certificate of origin in case of import of goods that, according to them, is going to tighten noose on the easy and free flows of cheap Chinese imports. The decision to bring schemes for settlement of income tax disputes is too being cheered by the businessmen.

Speaking to TOI, president of Chamber of Industrial and Commercial Undertakings (CICU) Upkar Singh Ahuja said, “If we talk of any kind of direct relief for MSME sector, there are none except for the reduction in income tax rates, but otherwise it is a well-prepared Budget and all announcements, if implemented timely, will eventually end up in boosting the growth of MSME sector. I think the most important step in this Budget that is aimed at ease of doing business is the automatic refund of export duties. Once into effect, it will make doing exports easier and cut off hectic time taken to process refund of duties. We are also hopeful that earmarking the funds for technology upgradation of automotive and pharma sector will give a big push to both sectors. However in totality, the decisions taken by the finance minister are likely to bring back the demand of goods and services back in the market.”

According to leading exporter and president of Focal Point Association Rajnish Ahuja, “This is a very good Budget. Though the finance minister could not fulfil 100% expectations of everyone, at least she has touched upon all sectors. Her statement about 10% GDP should not be taken as a mere statement. It will in fact be accomplished as earmarking of Rs 98,300 crore for the education sector and fund allocation for health sector will definitely lead to meeting this target. As far as industry is concerned, I think the biggest move made in this Budget is the efforts to put full stop on the entry of cheap Chinese goods into the Indian markets through duty-free trade routes by making guidelines regarding certificate of origin more strict and also hiking custom duty on 14 items that are mostly of Chinese origin. Besides this, the decision to bring out one-time settlement scheme for income tax disputes is remarkable as now we will be able to settle our years-old income tax cases as by just paying principal amount the case can be closed and penalties and interest waived off. I think all factors combined will have a very good impact on the growth of industry.”

General secretary of CICU Pankaj Sharma said, “The government has tried to do its best in this Budget by touching upon all sectors like manufacturing, farmimg and education. Reducing income tax slabs is a very bold step and will lead to huge savings for the businessmen falling in the eligible tax brackets. Easing norms for setting up and operations of non banking financial companies (NBFC) will lead to easy and more availability of credit for MSME sector in the market. The increase in the audit limit by five times to Rs 5 crore will act as a big booster for the MSMEs as earlier those having turnover above Rs 1 crore were subjected to audit that was not only time consuming, but also expensive.”

Title: Budget anti-farmer, pro-corporate, says farm body
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

BATHINDA: The All India Kisan Sangharsh Coordination Committee (AIKSCC) has termed the Budget presented by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman as anti-farmer and pro-corporate.

AIKSCCC, a conglomerate of over 200 farm organisations, came down heavily on the PM Narendra Modi government for its proposals and asserted the document as “highly disappointing”. “This is clearly a budget that has no space for farmers of this country. The Modi government has yet again made it clear that it is not for farmers, but for the corporate world, which matters to this government,” said AIKSCC in a press release issued after Sitharaman’s Budget speech.

AIKSCC has called for a nationwide protest on February 13 against proposals in the Budget and failure to address problems of rising farm debt, rising cost of agricultural inputs and failure to secure profitable sale of crops. “Budget proposes increased penetration of MNCs and corporate giants in supply of agriculture inputs, procurement of crops, storage, agri-processing, insurance and marketing of crops. It gives no relief to peasants from high input costs, low crop prices, distress sale, crop losses. The exploitation of farmers by companies will increase through leasing of their land, indebting them, buying their crops cheap and earning huge profits in food processing and marketing,” said AIKSCC working group members Darshan Pal and Jagmohan Singh .

Title: Eco norms: Death knell for Punjab plant
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

BATHINDA: Union finance minister approved the death knell for Guru Nanak Dev Thermal Plant in Bathinda by proposing to close down plants whose emission is above the pre set norms and use land for alternative means. Punjab government has already started process to dismantling of the plant.

“There are yet, thermal power plants that are old and their carbon emission levels are high. For such power plants, we propose that utilities running them be advised to close them, if their emission is above the pre-set norms. The land so vacated can be put to alternative use,” said Sitharaman in her budget speech.

The Punjab State Power Corporation Limited (PSPCL), which controls the power plants in public sector in the state, had invited global expression of interest for dismantling and disposing of the two units of 220 MW. However, as only one firm evinced interest, the authorities have now invited global tenders for all the four units of the thermal plant on “as is where is basis”.

The GNDTP has four units, which were built at a cost of Rs 115 crore between 1974 and 1979. Later, Rs 694 crore was spent on the renovation and modernisation of two units (2012-2014). “The plant has over 2,000 acre land, of which nearly 1,000 acre has been used for power plant and lakes. After disposing of the plant, the state government want to commercially exploit a part of the land. We strongly object to it as many jobs, directly or indirectly, will be lost and many employees will have to go to other places,” said thermal plant workers’ union president Gursewak Singh.

However, the decision has been hailed by environmentalists. “It is a wise step, to dismantle a coal-fired plant which causes lot of pollution. These plants are being phased out across the globe and we need power generation from renewable sources,” said an activist.

GNDTP chief engineer-cum-general manager Harcharan Dass Goyal confirmed that “all four units are being disposed and global expression of interest have been invited”.

Title: No new train for Ludhiana disappoints commuters
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

LUDHIANA: Railway budget announced by Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Saturday has evoked mixed the response from city residents as no new train passing through the city has been announced even as the minister promised modernization of stations and trains, including increasing safety standards to curb rail accidents

While Ludhiana residents are happy over the decision of the finance minister to ply 1,150 trains on public-private partnership (PPP) mode and redevelopment of four stations with the help of private sector that will have wi-fi, CCTV cameras on all major long-route trains to ensure safety of the passengers , some were upset with no announcement being made by the railway minister about new trains.

Rakesh Kumar, a businessman from BRS Nagar who frequently travels to Delhi, said, “The decision of not plying more trains in the northern railway route has disappointed us little, but steps towards the betterment of the passengers, including of pitching more Tejas Express and connecting the same with tourist destinations, is a promising one.”

The FM also proposed to set up large solar power capacity alongside rail tracks, on land owned by Railways. While Ludhiana residents have hailed this announcement, many are upset over the decision to upgrade only four stations in the country as model railway stations with the help of private public partnership as, according to them, there is a need to upgrade several hundred stations, including Ludhiana. “At Ludhiana railway station there is an urgent need to get advance facilities from large strength waiting rooms to well-maintained bathrooms,” local resident Ankit Kapoor said.

“Railway crossing across Ludhiana and Ferozepur division would be soon digitalised as the railway budget has cleared air over this and soon it will be implemented so that railway accidents come down to some extent,” Kapoor added.

The decision to have wi-fi at all major stations is most hailed by the youngsters as during travelling they will remain connected online and find several mode of entertainment.

“While it is compulsory for the public places to have ramps for the specially abled, Ludhiana railway station does not have any such facility mainly at the rear from where most passengers enter the station . However, such ramps would soon come up the railway stations at the earliest as the same has been announced in the Budget. This includes Ludhiana as well,” said Sanjeev Sharma , a shopkeeper in Old City area.

Many resident have also claimed that some of the key decisions taken by the finance minister in the last Budget were yet to be finalized like redeveloping 600 major stations into modern ones and installing high-tech security measure across station premises to ensure safety of women passengers.

Title: Inter-state gang behind jewellery godown robbery: Cops
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: The police have found out that an inter-state gang was behind the Ghumar Mandi robbery and are trying to trace the link of a local informer who had passed on the information on the jewellery godown to the gang.

During investigation, cops have found that not even nearby shopkeepers were aware of any such godown in the market.

On Wednesday, four armed robbers had barged into the jewelery godown in busy Ghumar Mandi market and escaped with 2kg gold jewellery after taking the owner and worker at gunpoint. Two accused were also captured in the CCTV camera and city police had also announced Rs 1 Lakh rewards to informer.

Additional deputy commissioner of police (detective) Dayama Harish Kumar said an inter-state gang is behind this robbery. During investigation, the police have identified that most of the nearby shopkeepers were not aware of the jewellery godown in the market. It is suspected that the gang must have their local informer who had passed on the information.

The official said the police teams are on the job to track down the accused.

On asking if role of owners is also suspected, the officials said that nothing such has been found so far.

The ADCP said another robbery of gold jewellery had been executed in Phagwara too and the police are getting details of that incident too.

Talking about the security of such godowns, the ADCP said, “Once the case is solved, the police will conduct a meeting with the jeweller associations to ensure they have security guards. Besides, they should also have DVRs of CCTV at some other place as accused take away the CCTV recorder before fleeing.”

Box: Two major incidents in a week, despite CCTVs no breakthrough

On January 23, wanted criminal Sukhwinder Singh Moni along with his unidentified accomplice shot dead Harjinder Jindi in busy Jawahar Nagar market. In that case too, police got CCTV recording of the accused, but failed to get any clue on them. Moni was already wanted by Ludhiana police in the Rs 23-Lakh ATM robbery case executed in November 2019. Despite that, the accused managed to visit his own locality and execute a murder.

On January 29, four armed robbers robbed jeweller Vinay Jain in busy Ghumar Mandi market in broad daylight. In this case too, the police got picture of two suspects, captured on a CCTV camera, however the cops are yet to identify them.

Title: In a first, teachers in government schools in district to get I-card
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: In a first, 9,280 teachers in government schools in the district will be seen wearing identity cards during duty hours.

The education department has released Rs Rs 2.78 lakh for printing and lamination of the cards.

The maximum teachers who will be issued the ID cards are in Ludhiana district 3,793 elementary and 5,487 secondary.

Applicable for all regular and contractual teachers of elementary, secondary and higher secondary schools, the department has directed the district education officers (DEOs) to ask all 3,793 teachers in elementary and 5,487 teachers in secondary schools in the district to get the coloured print of their ID cards from a portal of the department and get it laminated after getting the signature of the competent issuing authority (drawing and disbursing officer).

The move of making ID cards of all teachers has been initiated under the Samagra Shiksha Abhiyan and an amount of Rs 2.78 lakh has been approved for Ludhiana.

So far, the department had not provided any identity card to teachers. The new cards will have details including name of the teacher, name of the school and its code, full address of the school with block, village, district, and the designation of the teacher. The cards will also help identify if the teacher is a regular or contract one, sources said.

Title: Himachal CM hails BharatNet, agri schemes, Cong calls Budget a betrayal
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Shimla: On expected lines, BJP leaders in Himachal Pradesh hailed the Union Budget, while opposition parties flayed it.

With no specific announcement made for Himachal Pradesh in the Union Budget, the Congress has criticised the Budget presented in Lok Sabha on Saturday. Congress’s former chief minister Virbhadra Singh said the Budget had disappointed people of state who had pinned hopes from it, while CPM said that the proposals had further betrayed the people of Himachal Pradesh.

On the other hand, chief minister Jai Ram Thakur called the Budget “historic document” that revolved around three ideas of ‘aspirational India’, ‘economic development’ and ‘caring society’. He claimed the allocation for Himachal Pradesh had been raised by 33%, which would accelerate the pace of development.

Virbhadra said that budget would not help to bring the derailed economy back on track. For small hill state like Himachal Pradesh, there was no encouragement for development in the Budget. He said the Budget was not in national interest as public sector undertakings were completely ignored, while capitalists encouraged. He also called the proposal directionless.

The state committee of CPM said the Budget only attempted to address the concerns of finance and corporate capital. CPM MLA Rakesh Singha said that Union Budget was a betrayal despite Union minister of state for finance and corporate affairs Anurag Thakur belonging to state. He said some special schemes related to tourism , infrastructure development, expansion of railways, development of airports and horticulture could have easily appeared in the Budget proposals, especially when the BJP had got the highest percentage of votes from Himachal Pradesh in the last Lok Sabha election.

The CM said Union Budget was aimed to address hopes and aspirations of all the sections of the society. The proposal of 16 actionable plans to enhance the income of the farmers would especially benefit Himachal as 90% population lived in rural areas with agriculture as their main avocation, he added. The ambitious plans would not only ensure the upliftment of rural areas but also ensure socio-economic development of farmers, unemployed youth and common man, he claimed.

He said that budget was an attempt to ensure faith of masses by winning their confidence by way of all round development. He hailed the proposal for constitution of ‘Investment Clearance Cell’ at state level. He said this would give a flip to endeavour of the state to attract more investments as the state government had already signed MoUs worth Rs 1 lakh crore with various investors.

The state would also be immensely benefited by allocation of Rs 6,000 crore for BharatNet programme under which one lakh gram panchayats of the country would be linked with optical cable fibre for internet connectivity this year, he added.

The CM said budget allocation of Rs 45,000 crore for tourism sector would also prove a boon to tourism industry in the country. He said as Himachal Pradesh had already launched various schemes to develop virgin and unexplored places as major tourist destinations, the Union government’s steps would give a big boost to the state.

Title: Union Budget pro-poor and future-ready: Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Haryana CM Manohar Lal Khattar

CHANDIGARH: Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar on Saturday hailed the Union Budget as a visionary, pro-poor and future-ready budget.

Referring to the announcement of Rakhigarhi village in Hisar district to be developed as an iconic archaeological site with an on-site museum, the chief minister said that it was a matter of pride that now Rakhigarhi would be recognized internationally.

He said that this decision would not only place Rakhigarhi on the world map but also increase the revenue of the state as it would be developed as a tourist destination. Employment opportunities would also be created for the youth of the village, he added.

Khattar said special focus on farming, MSMEs and social welfare sectors would in particular help improve the lives of people of Haryana. He said that the significant budgetary allocations and announcements for promotion of good governance and ease of living, including the 16 point plan for farmers, relief to taxpayers and extension of Ayushman Bharat scheme would have great synergies with the ongoing and planned efforts of the state government in these important areas.

Congratulating Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman for presenting a pro-poor, pro-farmers and pro-common man budget, the chief minister expresses confidence that the budget would boost the country’s socio-economic development and also give a decisive upward push to the economic growth. He highlighted the importance of raising the turnover threshold for audit of MSMEs from Rs 1 crore to Rs 5 crore in this regard.

Title: Hearing on cases against CM Captain Amarinder Singh , son put off to February 15
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh

LUDHIANA: A local court on Saturday adjourned the hearing on the alleged tax evasion cases registered by the income tax department against chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh and his son Raninder Singh. The next date of hearing in the court of chief judicial magistrate (CJM) PS Kaleka is on February 15.

The income tax department had filed one case of alleged income tax evasion against chief minister Captain Amarinder Singh, whereas it had registered two other cases against his son Raninder Singh. The counsel for the income tax department, Rakesh Gupta, said they had sought adjournment of the case on Saturday, as the government has to send a senior standing counsel of CBDT (Central Board of Direct Taxes) from Delhi to argue in the case on the next date of hearing. He added that CBDT had communicated with him that their senior standing counsel would present an argument in the case.

The income tax department counsel further said there would only be an argument from the senior standing counsel, and no evidence would be produced in the case. He added that all the cases, including a case against Captain Amarinder Singh under Section 277 (false statement of verification) of the IT Act, and two cases against Raninder Singh under sections 276-C (evasion of tax) and 277 (also of the IT Act), will come up for hearing on the next date of hearing.

BACKGROUND OF CASES

* A complaint against the Captain was filed by the I-T department under Section 277 (false statement in verification) of the Income Tax Act, and several sections of IPC.

* His son Raninder Singh is booked in two cases — under one section 277 (false statement of verification) of IT Act, and another under Section 276-C (evasion of tax) of the IT Act.

* The complaint, filed by assistant director of income tax Amanpreet Kaur Walia on December 2, 2016, charges Amarinder with giving a false statement in verification, along with omission in giving information to a public servant. He has also been charged with furnishing false information, giving a false statement under oath, obstructing a public servant in discharging his functions, and giving false evidence.

* In its complaint, the I-T department has claimed Amarinder had been concealing details of the foreign assets owned by his son Raninder Singh, against whom the department has filed two complaints.

* The department had found Amarinder to be the discretionary beneficiary of foreign-based Jacaranda Trust, and also a beneficiary in other properties abroad owned by Raninder.

Title: Budget presents reforms to speed up economy, says PM
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

PM Modi (file photo)

NEW DELHI: The Budget presents a strong vision as well as action by way of new reforms to speed up the economy and lay a firm foundation for the development of modern India in the new decade, PM Narendra Modi said on Saturday.

The PM said the objective of the Budget was to strengthen every citizen economically. “Employment is mainly generated in agriculture, infrastructure , textiles and technology... there is a boost for employment generation in these areas. There is an effort to double farm incomes with 16 action points,” he added.

Modi said there was an integrated approach to agriculture with traditional practices being supported along with horticulture, fisheries and animal husbandry.

Home minister Amit Shah said the Budget offered Rs 85,000 crore for schemes and measures for Scheduled Castes and other disadvantages sections while there was Rs 57,000 crore for Scheduled Tribes . “The water mission is an important addition to housing, electricity, toilets and cooking gas programmes already rolled out by the government ,” he said.

“In this Budget, the Modi government has taken effective steps to rationalise the tax system, boost basic infrastructure, strengthen the banking system, promote investment and ease of doing business,” Shah said. There was unprecedented relief for income tax payers of every category, particularly the middle class, he said, adding that salaried taxpayers would not only see their tax reduced but would get relief from simplification of the tax system.

The PM said the duty structure had been reformed and the Ayushman Bharat programme had given a major boost to the health sector. “The connection between technology and employment has been recognised. The necessary policy support for quantum computing has been given. India is being made a bigger part of the global value chain,” he said.

Initiatives have been launched aimed at developing skill sets needed in modern India with degree courses in entrepreneurship and internships in local government, the PM said. “There is an ambitious plan to develop export potential in districts. Modern India needs modern infrastructure. The Rs 1 lakh crore for 6,500 projects will spur business and trade. Tourism needs infrastructure and it can generate employment with lesser investment,” he added.“There are basic changes in the tax structure, there is investment for employment and historic steps have been taken like in the bond markets and removal of DDT. Companies will get Rs 25,000 crore for investment. All these decisions are intended to create more jobs for youth,” the PM said.

Title: 2 trips nixed, PM plans to go to Assam again
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

File photo

After cancelling two proposed visits to Assam since mid-December, PM Narendra Modi will be reaching the state next Friday for a public rally organised in Kokrajhar in celebration of the tripartite Bodo Accord signed on January 27, minister Himanta Biswa Sarma said on Saturday.

“The PM’s arrival here on February 7 is confirmed,” Sarma said, adding that home minister Amit Shah was likely to accompany him to the rally.

The 3rd Khelo India Youth Games from January 10 was to be inaugurated by PM Modi , but the visit was cancelled a few days before the event. Earlier, he was to host his Japanese counterpart, Shinzo Abe, at a summit scheduled for December 15 and 16 in Guwahati. The summit was “postponed” in the wake of arson and vandalism on the streets during protests against the new citizenship law.

For BJP, Modi’s scheduled visit to Kokrajhar is seen as holding additional significance because of the Bodo council elections in April. “Polls will be held to fill the existing 40 seats. The expansion of the council to 60 seats will take at least another six months. We do not want to keep the poll process waiting till then,” Sarma said.

Title: Kashmir to Kanyakumari, FMs show off their verse-tality
Content:
This story is from February 2, 2020

Nirmala Sitharaman (file photo)

The use of poetry was hardly unusual. After all, all finance ministers have done so, from Manmohan Singh, P Chidambaram to Arun Jaitley.

But Nirmala Sitharaman’s choice had a political right to it. She read out a verse in Kashmiri, with a few voices from the opposition immediately shouting about the region’s lockdown. They had not heard the finance minister fully, as she translated a key sentence about the lotus blooming in the Dal lake.

Sitharaman chose Dinanath Koul’s evocative poem, Myon Vatan. Koul, who used the pen name Nadim, was a Sahitya Akademi recipient. “Our country is like Shalimar Bagh, our country is like the lotus in the Dal Lake, our country is like the warm blood of the youth, my country, your country, our country, the most adorable country in the world.”

At a time when Jammu and Kashmir has been denuded of its special status, the poem was redolent with political meaning. And the lotus simile brought smiles on the faces of the BJP leaders as the opposition fell silent. Manmohan Singh, who had a flair for Urdu poetry, cited Allama Iqbal and Muzaffar Razmi Kairanvi . P Chidambaram regularly referred to ancient Tamil poet Thiruvalluvar, as did Sitharaman incidentally. Yashwant Sinha and Arun Jaitley also freely quoted verse.

The sunny yellow silk sari complemented Sitharaman’s allusion to the bouquet of flowers that comprised the three broad themes of the Budget — Aspirational India, economic development and Caring India.

Dressed in tune with the festive spirit of Basant Panchami, Sitharaman went on for long without a sip of water, a decision that left her feeling dehydrated. With two pages to go, she said the speech be considered tabled.

The FM balanced politics and fiscal policies, while the opposition protested against Sitharaman’s claim of government’s commitment to “happiness, safety and security” of every Indian, disrupting her address with reference to MoS finance Anurag Thakur ’s controversial “goli maaro” speech.

Loud protests, led by Trinamool MP Kalyan Banerjee who is blessed with strong lung power, erupted when the FM announced the government decision to disinvest a part of its stake in Life Insurance Corporation.

Sitharaman tapped into a couple of more poets. Classical Sanskrit poet Kalidas was quoted to convey how a just and generous ruler collects drops and gives back copiously. “They collect only for people’s wellbeing” said the ancient work Raghuvamsa. She also dipped into Tamil woman saint poet Aauvaiyar to quote “BhumitiruthiUnn” — “first tend to till one's land and then eat”.

Tulsidas, Amir Khusro , Rabindranath Tagore, Bharathiyar, Ramdhari Singh Dinkar, Mirza Ghalib, Rahat Indori, Bashir Badr and Dushyant Kumar were all heard in Lok Sabha in the winter and budget sessions in 2019.

Title: rajasthan: Who is the animal?
Content: More often than not, when the discussion surrounding animal cruelty comes up it is regarding the animals being tested or experimented upon in various labs (in the name of science, research, product development etc.). A study conducted by PETA concluded that, each year more than 100 million animals are subjected to such cruelty in the United States alone. This provides a rough estimate of the worldwide use of different animals for conducting various experiments. Indian government has banned testing and experimentation that is carried out on animals in the cosmetic, and pharmaceutical world. However, that by no means reflects the cruelty that animals in the county are still being subjected to.It has become increasingly difficult not to raise concerns about the plightful state of animals. As a student, I only have so much authority when my residential community unanimously decides it to be fair to discuss the possible relocation of the animals that I have grown up with. Not only have I seen litters of puppies being poisoned season after season, but I have also faced the rationalization thrown in my face that comes along with it. I do not have many tools at my disposal when it comes to implementing a wide-scale change in morality and mindset but what I do have is the power to educate the people willing to listen and to look after helpless voices.Growing up in an ordinary north Indian setting, I have seen the rapid decline in the population of stray cats and dogs along with almost a disappearance in the population of many other animals such as lizards, snakes, monkeys and various species of birds. Whatever the cause may be—pollution, lack of food and shelter, culling by humans etc. the root of the abuses faced by these animals can very easily be traced back to us, people. If the cost of development, is the very lives of the creatures in the area, then perhaps we ought to reevaluate whether we want the type of change that deters living rather than making it easy for all.Animals are also subjected to intense cruelty in the name of sports, leisure and entertainment. Rarely does our mind think twice before getting on a camel on some family vacation to Rajasthan because of how the experience of being a tourist in that state feels incomplete without being carried atop a native animal. Never once does glorification of these joy rides seem harmful or wrong just because of how majestic we look while riding the 'ship of the desert'. From a very early age, we are exposed to situations where not only are we scared as children but also forced by elders around us to get on an elephant or a horse. No matter how wrong or frightful it might seem to our instincts, we are conditioned into believing that our place on top of the food chain allows us to tame and use those below us however we may please. Repeatedly studies have shown the pain that animals in captivity go through. They are beaten by sticks, poked by knives, saddled with blinders; have metal bolted onto their hooves just so their services can be made more comfortable for us. They are forced out of their natural habitat and into a dangerous commercial world where their very lives are commodified and soldIs it even fair to call the animals outside my house stray when they too have taken birth and lived their lives in the same locality as me? Is it also fair to alter their reproductive systems to put those around them at ease? A part of me wants to justify it by saying streets are no home for an animal but another part of me knows that if people start doing the bare minimum to feed them and look after their needs, they too will start feeling secure in their surroundings. It is our fundamental duty as citizens to have empathy for all living creatures around us, then why do we feel threatened by their very presence? Understand that as I raise some questions I do not come from a place of anger, rather from one full of sadness as I feel in some way, we as humans have failed the voiceless beings and have led to the rapid decline in their population. We ought to introduce more education regarding the injustices faced by animals in our country to truly begin a long due change in mindsets and start a transformative journey in their lives. Cruelty is not only limited to corporations and their laboratories but is also put out in the world by us when we neglect to keep the basic interests of life forms around us in our minds.
